name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: I declare open the 2017-2018 session of the European Parliament.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the report by Vicky Ford, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Directive 91/477/EEC on control of the acquisition and possession of weapons (COM(2015)0750 – C8—0358/2015 – 2015/0269(COD)) (A8—0251/2016).

name: Vicky FORD
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, there has been a common European gun law for over 25 years. It sets out the processes whereby Member States give authorisations to individuals to own, buy and sell firearms. However, certain poorly deactivated ‘salute and acoustic’ firearms were able to be bought and sold without authorisation, and some of these were re-converted and used in the tragic Paris attacks. A cache of similar firearms was discovered in the UK. The European law does need reviewing. The first set of proposed amendments from the Commission was very poorly drafted. It would have put disproportionate restrictions on many legal owners, it was not supported by an impact assessment, and the proposals had many technical failings. But, over the past 18 months, I have worked with colleagues across this Parliament and many different stakeholders, as well as law enforcement authorities, proof houses and legal experts, in order to protect the interests of legitimate owners whilst also addressing the security issues. There have been some misleading reports in the press and I would like to set the record straight here. In reality, the Parliament text that we are voting on today contains many significant improvements. Firstly, firearms will not be restricted on the basis of their cosmetic appearance: this is legally unworkable. Military reservists, museums, filmmakers and collectors will be able to continue their ownership, provided their Member State agrees. Member States will continue to organise and protect their own national security, national reserve and public defence services. This meets the needs of countries like Finland and respects the situation in Switzerland. Technical issues with deactivation standards have been reassessed and holders of genuinely deactivated firearms, such as re-enactors, will be able to continue their ownership. The controversial proposal for mandatory medical and psychological tests has been rejected and, instead, each country will have in place its own system for assessments. There are provisions to support younger owners and for those in rural areas. There are new measures for clearer marking, for better information sharing between Member States and for safe storage, but we have taken care not to put overly burdensome requirements on small traders or on historical items. There are new stricter controls on certain semi-automatic firearms when they are fitted with high-capacity magazines, and on automatic firearms that are being converted into semi-automatics. However – and this is important – individuals who legally own these today will be able to continue to do so, provided their own Member State agrees. Target shooters will also be able to own these and continue to practice and participate in their sport, again provided their own Member State agrees. There are new provisions on magazines, which go beyond what Parliament’s committee initially proposed, however the representatives from Europe’s 28 Member States insisted that they should be covered. Today, there are some additional amendments tabled by colleagues. These are not new: they have largely been considered by Parliament already and rejected by the Member States and the Council. If they are adopted, it could risk destabilising the entire agreement. This negotiation has been a long and difficult process. It is unfortunate that the original proposal came with so many failings from the Commission, but the changes that we have now agreed will close the loopholes and make an important contribution to our security, whilst also respecting the rights of legal owners. I expect Member States to use their new powers to support those legal owners and thus avoid disproportionate restrictions. I would like to thank all my colleagues for their help on this work.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. - Mr President! The Weapons Directive is an issue that stirs up the feelings of many around Europe. Law-abiding and well-behaved hunters and shooters suddenly felt identified as terrorists and realized that their respective activities could in principle be banned. I understand that. As Vicky Ford said here, the proposal was presented in the greatest haste and in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks in Paris, despite the fact that it was prepared in order to increase the security of Europe's citizens by closing gaps in the existing law that has existed for several years. A hastily made proposal to ban an entire category of weapons without investigating the consequences was the triggering factor. Criticism has been raised that we should focus on legislating on illegal weapons instead. However, as I see it, the Weapons Directive is not a measure to combat terrorism. It is about setting a minimum level for the laws of the EU countries, for who is allowed to use weapons and how legal weapons are to be handled within the Union. The tightening that we are taking a stand on today is about reducing the risk of legal weapons falling into the wrong hands or being used in the wrong way. For example, loopholes are being closed in terms of the rules for deactivation and marking of weapons, but also on the exchange of information between Member States, aptitude tests and stricter rules on the most dangerous weapons. The Weapons Directive does not at all oppose action against illegal weapons. On the contrary, in addition to the Weapons Directive, intensive work is also being done to deal with the illegal weapons on the black market. It is then more about operational measures such as cross-border police and customs cooperation, weapons amnesties and acquisition programs to counteract the availability of mainly military weapons from areas that have been in conflict, so that criminals or terrorists cannot reach them. The are major differences in the current regulations in the member states.Since some countries have very strict rules and others less strict, some have mandatory medical examinations, others none at all, it is obvious that we must create a better minimum level for everyone.I fully agree with what Vicky Ford has said before here.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we are here today for what I hope is the final vote by Parliament to approve the revised firearms directive. We have one shared objective, namely to cut off and limit the access of criminals and terrorists to guns. Our citizens rightly expect us to deliver on this to reinforce our collective security. That means cracking down on the trade in illegal weapons, but it also means strengthening controls on legally held firearms where there are gaps and vulnerabilities. Far from penalising legitimate gun owners and gun users, as some have suggested, by revising the directive we are in fact enlisting their support in the fight against those who misuse guns. We know that there are many law—abiding citizens who pursue hobbies involving firearms and who do not want those firearms to fall into the wrong hands. We completely respect that. The revision of the directive is not designed to stop people enjoying their pastimes, but, as we crack down on the illegal trade in weapons, we need to strengthen the rules around the acquisition, possession, storage and traceability of legal firearms. Clearer rules on marking and registration should improve traceability, providing reassurance for legal gun owners that their weapons cannot be used with impunity should they fall into the wrong hands. Like all of us, I would very much like to be able to say that criminal violence and terrorist attacks are a thing of the past. Sadly, that is not the case, so it is important not to be naive about the ongoing threat level or its likely consequences. Ensuring that criminals and terrorists do not find it easy to acquire powerful and dangerous firearms with the intention of harming our fellow citizens is a collective responsibility that encompasses both the legal and the illegal trade. The fact that the perpetrators of terrorist atrocities in the last two years were able to use modified acoustic and deactivated weapons that were bought legally was the driving force behind the Commission’s proposal to revise the directive.   En effet, la directive actuelle sur les armes à feu, qui date de 1991, comporte des failles de sécurité importantes. Ainsi, nous savons que certaines des armes à feu qui ont été utilisées dans les attaques à Charlie Hebdo étaient des armes acoustiques qui ont été transformées en armes létales. Or, la directive actuelle n’encadre pas les armes acoustiques. Nous savons également que des armes mal désactivées peuvent être réactivées et utilisées pour tuer. De même, certaines armes automatiques transformées en semi-automatiques, autorisées par la directive actuelle, peuvent, avec un peu d'expérience et des outils disponibles sur l’internet, être reconverties en armes automatiques. Il nous fallait agir d’urgence pour combler ces lacunes et renforcer la sécurité de nos citoyens.  The revised directive represents a compromise. It is well known that the Commission favoured doing more in some areas, but it was the subject of extensive discussion and I want here to recognise the work that has been done by Members of this Parliament and by the Member States to reach today’s result, and that result will significantly further strengthen security in a number of key areas, as we have heard. First, it will prohibit automatic firearms which have been transformed into semi-automatics. In addition, the directive will also ban semi-automatic firearms that have a high firing capacity: above 10 rounds for the long semi-automatic firearms, and above 20 rounds for the short ones. The Commission would have liked to go further, but recognises that the co-legislators did not support going further. Second, alarm and acoustic weapons will fall within the scope of the directive for the first time. These firearms will now need to be declared or authorised in order to ensure traceability. This is particularly important given, as we know, some of the recent attacks involved converted alarm and acoustic weapons. Third, museums and collectors will also fall within the scope of the directive. Following a request from Parliament and the Council, however, they will be allowed, subject to strict security conditions, to possess Category A firearms. Fourth, deactivated firearms must now be declared to national authorities and registered. This is key to prevent the illegal sale of reactivated firearms or parts of firearms. To complete this measure and ensure that the deactivation process is carried out in an effective and irreversible manner, the Commission proposed an implementing regulation to ensure common standards across the EU. This regulation, in force since April 2016, is currently being revised and strengthened to address technical issues flagged by some Member States, and indeed by Members of Parliament. Two rounds of expert meetings have resulted in agreement on draft revised technical specifications. These are now being stress-tested by national practitioners and experts, who will report back in late March. Provided the stress tests have not revealed any remaining major problems, the firearms committee will then be in a position formally to adopt the revised strengthened regulation by the end of April. Other important measures have also been included in the revised directive, such as stricter conditions for the online acquisition of firearms, clearer rules on the marking of firearms to improve traceability, and the establishment of a system to improve exchange of information between Member States. In revising the directive, we have sought to strike a balance. At the request of Council and Parliament, a derogation has been agreed, as we have heard, for sport shooters to acquire otherwise prohibited firearms under strict conditions, including proof of a legitimate and regular sport-shooting activity for which the weapon is required. Hunters should not be affected by the revised directive, as they would not usually use the type of firearms that will be prohibited. At the same time, we have continued to step up our action against trafficking in firearms, implementing the EU Action Plan of December 2015. That includes appointing national focal points to track, trace and gather intelligence on illegal firearms. I have written to Member States recently about this to ensure that we all implement what we have signed up to. It also means strengthening cooperation with the authorities across the Balkans to crack down on illegal trafficking in that region. That said, we need to keep working on this. The Europol Serious and Organised Crime Threat Assessment published last week shows that weapons trafficking remains a key crime area. Illegal firearms are increasingly available online via the Dark Net, a key facilitator for the trade in illegal firearms. So we will continue to tackle firearms trafficking as a priority under the new EU policy cycle for the years 2018 to 2021, allowing national law enforcement authorities and Europol to take coordinated action against firearms trafficking and, notably, the online trade. To conclude, I would like to thank you again for all the effort that went into achieving this balanced deal that respects legitimate users, while reinforcing our collective security. It will help further to squeeze the space in which criminals and terrorists operate and seek to do us harm. Your vote today is a key step, but the work does not end there. Once agreed, the directive will need to be implemented in Member States. The Commission stands ready to assist in this process and will closely monitor its implementation. Written Declarations of the Commission on the Proposal for a Directive amending Directive 91/477/EEC on the control and acquisition and possession of weapons 1) Written Declaration of the Commission The European Commission is satisfied that the co-legislators have reached an agreement on the revised firearm directive. These new rules will substantially reduce the likelihood of dangerous but legally held weapons falling into the hands of criminals and terrorists.  At the same time, the Commission regrets that some parts of the original proposal were not supported by the Parliament and the Council– in particular concerning semi-automatic firearms where the Commission had proposed a greater level of ambition with a complete ban of the most dangerous semi-automatic firearms, including all semi-automatic firearms of the AK47 or AR15 families. The Commission also regrets that the magazine size was not limited to 10 rounds for all semi-automatic firearms.  The Commission also stresses the importance of the proper implementation of the strict security rules relating to collectors. 2) Written Declaration of the Commission on deactivation The Commission recognises the importance of a well-functioning standard for deactivation, which contributes to improved levels of safety and gives authorities reassurance that deactivated weapons are properly and effectively deactivated. The Commission will, therefore, accelerate the work on the revision of the deactivation criteria conducted by national experts in the Committee established under Directive 477/91/EEC in order to allow the Commission  to adopt, by the end of May 2017, in accordance with the committee procedure established by directive 91/477/EEC, subject to a positive opinion by national experts, a Commission implementing  Regulation amending Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2015/2403 of 15 December 2015 establishing common guidelines on deactivation standards and techniques for ensuring that deactivated firearms are rendered irreversibly inoperable. The Commission calls on Member States to fully support the acceleration of this work.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: for the PPE Group. - Mr President! Today, we are improving security in Europe without reducing human freedom. We close dangerous loopholes. It is not enough that some of the countries have good rules, we need common minimum rules, because we have a single market and free movement. This is not an anti-terror law. For illegal weapons, we take other measures. It is about legal weapons not falling into the wrong hands, it has happened. It's not one or the other. I am committed because this affects many in Europe. I come from a family that has six generations of hunters. I understand their justified concern and outrage. Law-abiding people have felt attacked. I have met relevant organizations and am impressed by the ethics of safety that exist among hunters and shooters. I want to assure them that the Commission's proposal is dead and buried. In an open and democratic process, I have listened and acted. Through subsidiarity, we have ensured that the countries that currently have a functioning system can maintain it. We in the EPP group have guarded hunters and athletes. I want to reassure them: you will be able to continue your leisure activities as now. We have fought from the inside and surgically removed the proposed ban on distance selling. We do not punish the countryside, but take into account, for example, northern Sweden and Finland. We have also removed the requirement for mandatory medical check-ups and a time-limited license. It's time for us to have a debate based on facts. People should not worry unnecessarily. It is a test of leadership. There is no excuse that it is complicated. I urge my liberal friends not to disappoint objectivity and fish simple voices. We must not allow the directive to become a symbol of Brussels against the people. Our mission is to respond to people's concerns, not play on their emotions. You must dare to be responsible even if it is easier to be a populist. Mr President, we can not postpone the directive either because we are afraid of how it will be interpreted nationally.The EPP Group calls on the Member States to implement it correctly, without adding.I promise to follow up.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I consider the solution we have reached to be very important and positive: I say this in no uncertain terms. We worked a lot and with great effort, because the initial conditions were not the best possible. The previous directive was an old directive, which left significant regulatory gaps. Then, as has been said, the technical solutions adopted in the individual countries and also the culture of the relationship between citizens and weapons are very different and it was a question of bringing together, finding balance points between these conditions so far from each other. Finally, I would like to say, Commissioner, you have no responsibility - it wasn't there at the time - but the Commission proposal was a really bad proposal, very rough and above all it had the political error in itself of keeping the idea together. of the amendment of the directive to combat terrorism, which are two extremely different things. We have put a bit of order in what was there and it had the rough stretch that I commented earlier. We have restored certainty to unjustly worried people - I think of hunters, I think of sport shooters - who felt attacked, attacked: they always respected the law and here suddenly they felt put in the crosshairs of a measure that, in truth, did not concern them from the point of view. in view of compliance with the law. We have also created conditions for the market to be a regulated market and therefore does not lend itself either to promoting counterfeiting or, even less, to promoting the illicit purchase of dangerous weapons in other guises. The things you mentioned are all true, including the difficulties we had in the final phase regarding the trilogue. However, the prohibition of the two types of semi-automatic and particularly dangerous weapons was made with objective criteria, not for similarity as a category of the spirit, as requested by the Commission;and even the conversion of demilitarized automatic weapons has rightly been brought under control.Then we made some exceptions, including that of the Finnish defense system, for example, which didn't deserve to be involved in any way.We have introduced branding and blank firearms, if they come from conversion of real weapons, will also fall within the scope of the directive.In short, we put things right: we did it with patience, without exploitation and without demagogy and I consider this a very important landing point.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: for the ECR Group.- Mr President.The Commission apparently thinks that if a terrorist wants to commit an attack, he will first obtain a firearms pass and then legally acquire a firearm.This is, of course, naive, and according to this idea, trucks, axes, machetes should also be banned, because terrorists use their instruments to commit their terrorist attacks.Restricting legal weapons because terrorists commit attacks with illegal weapons is a mistake and serves just to make the Commission even more attractive to the people of Europe.As if that wasn't enough.As if a large part of Europe's population no longer has their teeth full of these regulations and restrictions, you are just continuing.You continue on and on until the whole thing falls apart.People don't want as many restrictions from you as you think you know better than people should live.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: for the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, we all agree on one thing - we want a secure Europe. So why are we not all applauding the material that is supposed to increase security in Europe now? Why did he find opponents across the political spectrum in the Member States? Why, contrary to all expectations, have you focused on restricting the rights of legal arms holders instead of addressing real security challenges? To limit the rights of people who have not committed and are not committing any terrorist attacks. At the same time, there is so much to improve on security. We do not have clear rules for deactivating weapons. We do not have rules for various weapon conversions, and yet it is the weapons officially listed as non-functional that killed in the Bataclan club in Paris. We lack closer cooperation between Member States, which should exchange security information more quickly and efficiently. We are not able to ensure the traceability of weapons, the control of their circulation and movement between states, and I could go on. Commissioner, you recently wrote - people who do not have bad intentions do not have to be afraid of the directive. Mistake, she's scared! I meet such people regularly. They are sports and recreational shooters, hunters, but also former and current members of the security forces. Legal owners of weapons. And they are afraid of the directive. They are even worried that they will lose their weapons. Thanks to pressure from the European Parliament, the text has been largely rectified. Unfortunately, we only got halfway. In addition, we lack logical arguments for a number of measures. And if they exist, you should have submitted them. However, the Commission apparently considered the elaboration of an impact study to be unnecessary, so even today, after more than a year, we are deciding from the table and blindly. This is an irresponsible interference with the freedom of EU citizens. I have therefore tabled a number of amendments, and I would like to call on those present to consider their position and support them. This is a sensitive issue and it is the first time we have decided on it here in plenary. Commissioner, look around myself.In the current situation, we cannot afford to adopt meaningless and illogical legislation and thus continue to undermine the confidence of our citizens in the EU.There is more to the game than you think.(The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Richard SULÍK
text: a question asked by lifting a blue card.- Mrs Charanz, you mentioned the deactivation of weapons.In this context, I would like to ask you whether you do not think that, following the adoption of the last revision of the Firearms Directive in 2007 and the CommissionCommission failure.Whether the Commission should first correct its own mistakes before limiting decent people.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: answer the question posed by raising a blue card.- Mr colleague, I absolutely agree with you.If we are missing anything here in the EU at the moment, it is clear rules for deactivation.That was one of the problems with the terrorist attacks.And we are glad that our faction, the ALDE faction, has, from the outset, made the adoption of this directive conditional on clear rules for deactivation.Yes, we fell asleep here.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, if we had a proposal on the table that will demonstrably increase security in the EU, I would be the first to raise my hand for it. However, I am convinced that this is not our case. In my opinion, the draft directive that we will be voting on tomorrow does not address anything. It focuses on restricting the rights of holders of legally acquired weapons, sport shooters and collectors of historic weapons. We can hardly imagine what a positive effect the new legislation will bring, because, despite repeated requests, we have not received any expert analysis from the Commission. Apparently, however, we will probably all agree that a terrorist will hardly ever go to buy a weapon in a stone shop. Strict bans on certain types of legally acquired and held weapons will cause a large proportion of these weapons to be transferred to the illegal sphere. Or even worse on the black market. This will make these weapons potentially available to criminals and terrorists. I am not at all sure that the proposal presented in any way reduces the risk of committing further terrorist attacks.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - So, if the aim of this draft directive was to fight terrorism effectively, I am afraid that goal was missed. Golden because this fight has focused on the wrong stakeholders, on those legal gun owners who, of course, do not pose that major risk of terrorism. We have also received a huge number of letters and e-mails reminding us of this legitimate arms holder that practically when they read such a document, it is considered that they are also part of this system, which we call terrorism. So I think, of course, the directive should focus, if we are talking on the fight against terrorism, especially on the so-called black market, on the area where these bargains take place, which then allow the arms trade to be used for terrorism and terrorist attacks. I think that it is very important to strengthen cooperation between Member States, exchange of information with the help of legal directives, and that exemplary legislation in this area is already observed in some countries, as is also the case in Slovenia.

name: Robert Jarosław IWASZKIEWICZ
text: on behalf of the EFDD group. - Mr Chairman! At the outset, I would like to express my gratitude to the shooting associations, collectors, sport shooters, hunters, museums, gun enthusiasts and over 20,000 people who e-mailed me during my work in the IMCO committee in defense of freedom, freedom from the prohibition of gun ownership. Work on this directive illustrates all the problems faced by EU legislation. From the beginning, the Commission's proposal was unrealistic and did not meet the assumed goals. Failure to assess the impact should result in an immediate rejection of the project. The final text is also unacceptable: it introduces further obstacles for law-abiding gun owners. Instead of building a positive message about weapons, we rely on negative arguments and distrust of our own citizens, who cannot decide for themselves and who are deprived of the most effective tool for self-defense. This means that the authorities are afraid of their citizens. In the preamble we find the reasons for the directive and the reference to terrorism. However, I see nothing in the rest of the text that concerns terrorists, criminals, illegal arms trafficking. Instead, I see another part of freedom taken from law-abiding citizens. Ladies and gentlemen! The reform of the European Union can only take place with the support of citizens and must be based primarily on meeting their expectations. The Czech Republic has already announced that in response to EU law, it will amend the constitution so that every law-abiding citizen has access to weapons. This is the way we should go. Free access to weapons is the only guarantee of our safety, the first and absolute anti-terrorist law. Our colleague Janusz Korwin-Mikke ends most of his speeches in Parliament with the sentence "and besides, I believe that the European Union should be destroyed". This directive is a very good step in this direction. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162 (8) Of the Regulations))

name: Vicky FORD
text: blue-card question. – You have received many emails from legal owners – from hunters, from target shooters – who are concerned because they think that they are going to lose their guns. This because you have written to tell them that Europe is going to take away their guns, but, if you read what we are voting on, you will see that every legal owner can continue to own their guns provided that their Member States agree. You, and others, are misleading the public about their rights. They will continue to have their rights, provided that their Member States agree. My question is: have you read what you are voting on?

name: Robert Jarosław IWASZKIEWICZ
text: answer to a question asked by raising a blue card.- Madam President!I have never written to anyone that the European Union will take away anybody's weapons - it will take away their freedom.And this is what this directive is about, not about specific solutions, because specific solutions can be associated at the level of - I don't know - the occupant and the occupied nation, while in the European Union there will never be consent to deprive law-abiding citizens of further freedoms.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, Commissioner, I have a question for you: by what magic, thanks to this text, will you be able to fight effectively against terrorism and the trafficking of illegal arms? As it must be remembered, this was the pretext invoked at the outset to justify the revision of this directive. It is vital to focus on the real: this is a moral requirement. Terrorists source their weapons from the black market. Illegal guns abound in Europe. It’s easier to buy an AK — 47 on the Darknet than to legally obtain permission to buy a shotgun. Today you are attacking honest citizens because you are unable to fight the Islamist scourge, because the European Union is unable to protect its citizens, because you are unable to recognize the failure of Schengen. This directive - and I will repeat it over and over again - is illegitimate because it is not proportionate to the objectives sought, useless because it does not target the trafficking of illegal weapons, unfair because it only aims to restrict the freedoms of honest citizens , and disproportionate because it lacks impact studies. You are unable to predict the economic consequences in the sector and the cost that this will represent for citizens. My “Europe of Nations and Freedoms” group tabled an amendment rejecting this text which I ask you to support during the vote. (The speaker accepts to answer a 'blue card' question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question asked under the 'blue card' procedure.'Mrs Troszczynski, you said, among other things, that it is easier to buy a machine gun from the internet than to get a hunting license.I ask you: are you aware of the changes in this report regarding the sale of weapons on the Internet?Because, from what you said, it turns out that you don't know them.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: Answer "blue card".- I especially know what it takes to get a gun possession, having registered myself with a shooting club.So I know very well what steps honest citizens must take in order to exercise their passion or obtain a weapon.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Mr President, this Commission proposal proves that it goes beyond its executive legislative powers and does not understand that its jurisdiction as a legislator stems from the needs of the people and reflects them. The proposal does not take measures to combat terrorism and illicit trade; it simply punishes and discourages law-abiding citizens. The illicit arms trade is not due to the flexibility of the previous directive. Front-loading, museum, shotguns, deactivation, exhibition and semi-automatic weapons are not treated with the logic of threat and possible participation in illegal activities. Increased bureaucracy, grouping of rules and the imposition of unimpeded restrictions lead to a mash of logic and a push to acquire weapons from third-party, illegal sources. Some technical specifications, such as cartridge capacity for semi-automatic central assault rifles, are ridiculous. I comment on this as a former officer of the Greek special forces and a user of weapons. The report must be voted against and left to the legislative jurisdiction of the Member States.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, I would like to thank everyone who worked on the dossier, especially the rapporteur Vicky Ford, but also our shadow rapporteur Anna Corazza Bildt and colleagues from the Social Democrats for an incredibly important work on a Commission proposal that was not so balanced at the beginning came from here, Commissioner King, as you have just presented. So thank you very much for that too. Indeed, it is a question of what our response to the attacks in Paris and elsewhere, which affected us all a lot, but in which legally acquired weapons hardly played a role. Nevertheless, it is the case that the freedom of one - and these are the legal gun owners here - must be weighed against the security of the other. That's why there are two sides of the same coin. We cannot play security and freedom off against each other - we have to find the right balance. That is why I said from the beginning - and many colleagues have supported this: we will not expose the law-abiding legal gun owners with this directive to new difficulties. And we kept our word. We organized a majority. It was a difficult discussion because gun rights are very different in the member states. The discussion is still not quite over in some Member States - you have heard a few crude voices here today. There is election campaigning in some member states. That, too, is an argument for many that cannot be ignored. Nevertheless, it has been possible to find a reasonable balance between the legal gun owners - above all the marksmen and the hunters - and their interests and the goal of achieving more security in Europe. I therefore hope that all colleagues will vote in favor of this proposal today.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne KAUFMANN
text: -  Mister President! Around 80 million firearms are in legal possession across the EU - reason enough to review the current rules for acquiring and possessing firearms. After all, it is about public safety, and public safety is a concern of all of us. All in all, a workable compromise was reached in the negotiations, even if I would have liked to have had more courage in some of them to take more decisive action against the massive pressure of the gun lobby, where hunters and marksmen were greatly unsettled by online campaigns with false information. In any case, in the interests of public safety, important improvements have been made. In future, all essential components of weapons will be labeled and registered. This facilitates tracing and supports the work of the security authorities. When selling weapons online, the identity of the buyer will have to be verified by an authorized body in the future, and deactivated weapons will now have to be reported. A security gap has been closed here, since deactivated weapons can be armed again afterwards, and they were previously no longer traceable. These and other new regulations serve to increase the security of citizens. I therefore also support the compromise that has been negotiated. (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- Madam colleague, I would like to ask if you know that re-commissioning a properly deactivated weapon is just as difficult a process as making a new weapon.And if you also know that there are millions of magazines among people that no one has ever registered.A container is a consumer good, and will this directive, as agreed today, also register containers?

name: Sylvia-Yvonne KAUFMANN
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Yes, I referred to the issue of deactivated weapons.I can only say to my colleague that I personally made myself very knowledgeable and also spoke to representatives of the German police, for example, and know that reactivating deactivated weapons is indeed not that easy.But it is possible.And that's why it's important to set limits here.

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: - Mr President, when the Commission presented its proposal for a new Firearms Directive, the formal grounds were security and terrorism.However, the actual subject of the presentation was the semi-automatic weapons used in sport shooting, which have not been used in terrorist attacks and whose role in crime is negligible.The most blatant excesses of the proposal were rejected in both Parliament and the Council.The compromise text is still very problematic.For example, restrictions on the size of magazines negatively affect shooting enthusiasts and entrepreneurs, but do not increase anyone’s safety.The rules on exemptions are confusing and contradictory.The proposal violates all the principles of good law.That is a disgrace to the European Union.I appeal to those who respect themselves and this institution: vote against this compromise.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, you are the Security Commissioner, so quite logically you have placed your intervention within the framework of the fight against terrorism. I would like to believe you, but I have doubts. Terrorists do not buy their weapons from gunsmiths by showing their identity card and a certificate of good character. I have here the Europol report from November 2016, which indicates that terrorists procure weapons of war on the illegal market, then on the internet, and that the deactivation of weapons and the activation of deactivated weapons were only used in one case, that of the Paris attacks. We have the wrong target, Commissioner: the priority is to fight against the illicit trade in arms and not to hamper those who legally exercise a sporting activity or collectors. Of course, the proposal has a lot of positive elements and I would like to follow them, but I come up against a fundamental problem which, personally, I cannot pass: that of the sale of weapons to individuals on the internet. I do not understand why the sale of certain drugs is prohibited on the internet without a medical prescription. We would be stricter on drugs than on weapons. I do not accept this situation and it is reluctantly that I will vote against this proposal.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: - Mr President, it is difficult in just one minute to counteract the work that has been carried out for months by one of the most powerful lobbies in the world: the lobby of the arms industry. All of us who have worked on this report believe that we have been able to notice their pressure, and that we have not dealt with the big business of selling arms to criminal dictatorships or to countries in conflict. We are basically talking about the sale of arms to individuals in Europe, but that is not a minor issue either. There are 25 million gun owners in the European Union. Many studies and common sense tell us that more guns and more lax legislation, more deaths from firearms. More controls and stricter regulation are needed, and don't use hunting or collector's weapons or shooting sports as an excuse not to. Ladies and gentlemen deputies, do not pretend to turn what is actually a business into a right. (She agreed to answer a question asked under the "blue card" procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Vicky FORD
text: blue-card question. – In your speech you have just said that there is going to be an impact on hunters, sport shooters and collectors, but, under the text we are voting on, hunters will be able to continue hunting and collectors will be able to continue collecting. There needs to be strong protection for security. So my question is: have you read what we are voting on today?

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: 'blue card response.- Madam, I think you have not understood my intervention at all.What I have said is that there are MEPs in this House who are using arms collectors, athletes or hunters as an excuse.They are using them as an excuse, because they don't really want there to be more controls, they don't want there to be stricter regulation.I simply say that they are being used because I understand that this report, that this legislation, is going to allow these groups to continue using weapons.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: - Mr President!The proposal for a new weapons directive has been presented by the EU as a way of fighting terrorists and organized crime.However, only legal gun owners are affected.The Commission has therefore used an incorrect basis to launch this legislation, and this is contrary to all democratic principles in the Western world.In other words: there is a huge democratic deficit in the process that the EU is pursuing.In addition, the Commission has not allowed any impact assessment, which is clear as this act creates great legal uncertainty.Vote for the Weapons Directive and instead raise your voice for the EU to secure external borders and implement measures that are directly aimed at terrorists and not legal gun owners, one of our most law-abiding groups of citizens.Do it again and do it right.(The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question) under Rule 162 (8).

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: question (“blue card”).- Kristina Winberg has not been involved in any way in the negotiations.She has done nothing to improve the directive.If the Commission's proposal was so bad, why did you not get involved in the process?What we are voting on today is not the Commission's proposal, but an agreement between the Council and Parliament that has completely changed the Commission's proposal.In what way does it affect legal gun owners?In what way is it not democratic when we are elected parliamentarians who have negotiated with 28 elected governments that are the same governments that sit in the capitals?In what way would the directive to be introduced through national parliaments be undemocratic?It is a directive.Read your papers and stick to the facts!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Ms Corazza Bildt, I do apologise but we have a limit on the blue-card questions and I have to stick to it. (Ms Winberg, you have half a minute for the answer).

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: answer ("blue card").- Maria, I belong to the popular parties that listen to the people.I've been to gun owners, shooting clubs, hunters, gun collectors - and I do not know everything.I have read it as much as I can.Even if you say I have done nothing, we have written amendments and tried to do everything not to get this idiotic proposal to go through.You know yourself that it is such a small percentage where you see that legal weapons are used in murder and crime.It's like fishing in deep water or looking for a needle in a haystack.You are completely wrong!

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: -  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! I cannot help but get the impression that essential parts of the European Union live here in a completely parallel universe. You want to create more security in Europe: yes, good. But you ignore the fact that there are a large number of jihadists, terrorists and criminals who have come to our continent and that there are 800,000 illegal weapons in Bosnia alone - a statement by the border protection agency Frontex. But instead of doing anything here, you are molesting righteous citizens. You abuse sport shooters, traditional shooters, people who have a defense interest. This is completely the wrong way. Remember back: whether it was Charlie Hebdo, whether it was the attack in Brussels, whether it was Nice, whether it was the Bataclan Theater - nowhere a problem with legal gun possession. They are righteous people. You focus your security efforts on the abuse of righteous citizens and completely ignore that there are many criminals here. They have to be the focus here. I would rather seek a liberalization of the gun law where people who have a defense interest can exercise this accordingly. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr. Vilimsky!I have listened carefully to what you said.You have pointed out that the most important thing to look into is illegal weapons.Now it is the case that the EPP Group respects the competences of the European Union and that is why it does not want to impede the Member States - I think you are from Austria - in the places where they are responsible - that is why my question to you: Are you familiar with this division of responsibilities, and do you agree with me that responsibility for the fight against illegal weapons in this case would lie with the Republic of Austria?

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.-  Thanks for your question.In general, I am of the opinion that the European Union is not needed here to regulate this.The European Union would be necessary to ensure peace, freedom and prosperity on our continent, but not to abuse the citizens here with one bureaucratic harassment after the next.Austria in particular has absolutely no problem with legal gun possession.And now we are faced with having to implement a multitude of bureaucratic regulations, ignoring that the threat comes from a completely different corner, namely from open borders, from jihadists, from terrorists, from threats to righteous people.This is where we must start, and this is where all efforts must be focused, but not with the bureaucratic chicane that is likely and unfortunately decided here today.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, allow me to make a few remarks as a member of the IMCO Committee on this Arms Directive. Firstly, the Commission's proposal, Commissioner, was extremely poor. You are talking here about the Commission's ambition, but that proposal, Commissioner, has caused us to vote on a failed compromise today. The original proposal bullied sports shooters, hunters, but also museum owners and administrators, collectors, etc. He certainly did not address terrorists. Here in Parliament, the rapporteur, the shadow rapporteurs have done their utmost with the proposal, they have really significantly improved it, and I would like to thank them. But I must say that the compromise is still unacceptable to me. The compromise further restricts legal weapons holders. Yes, there is a possible exception, states will be able to say that current gun owners will not be affected, but potential future owners who would like to buy semi-automatic weapons will not be able to do so. That is, we are interfering in the legal possession of weapons. It is not true that future legal possession of weapons is excluded from this, and that is simply unacceptable to me. There is a compromise here that may not harm current holders, it is better than the original draft directive, but it is a compromise that I can hardly explain to my citizens, I can hardly say why people will not be able to buy semi-automatic weapons in the future. So it would be better to withdraw the directive and draft another proposal.

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: -Mr President, I amwithmulti-speaker, I believethatwe are gaininga balanced,good-Weapons Directive,whichactuallyincreases safety.It is important that Europe is different from the United States, where the relatively free availability of weapons has led to very serious crimes and where, for example, school shootings say that they could be prevented if teachers also had weapons.Europe is different!It is therefore a good thing that the European Union's decision-making process, in which the Commission, the Council and Parliament must reach a consensus, thus produced a balanced solution.In Finland, the most worrying issues were our defense, which involves a large reserve.We also got a very good solution for this, so friends of the national defense, hunters and gun collectors can live in peace.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: - Mr President, some time ago, Mr Juncker presented five plans for the future of the EU. One of them was that the EU would do less and do better. I would like it, but here in that case, unfortunately, the EU is doing more and doing worse. If the European Parliament is frustrated that people do not take it too seriously and that there is a low turnout in the European elections, then let us repeal one hundred directives or give half of the European budget by 2020 to protect external borders from illegal migrants and terrorists, because by the way nothing will be valid in the fight against terrorism, terrorists will laugh at it, because, of course, they will always have a black market, and the only thing this directive can do to sway is destabilizing effective national legislation on possession of weapons, such as in my country, and it will become an instrument of bureaucratic buzzing of decent people, decent holders of weapons. By no means will I be involved in this and will not support this directive.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, rapporteur! We all agree: terrorism is something that is now causing problems for Europe, frightening European citizens, and we must do something about it together. But what was proposed here by the Commission, and what is now the result of the trialogue, is not suitable for this. It has already been said here: The wrong target group has been brought into focus. It was also said that this is not about more cooperation between Member States, which we need to fight terrorism. In contrast, it is the case that legal gun owners are harassed. The rapporteur said that the hunters are not affected, and the Commissioner said the same - true. It was also said that target shooters can continue to practice their sport if the Member States agree. The EPP spoke of the free internal market. I ask myself: If we want a free internal market, why don't we make minimum standards for legal gun owners - including for sport shooters? Why do we leave this to the Member States and thus have a ban through the back door? That is not proportionate, so please absolutely agree to ALDE, which says that we want to put our amendments to the vote before we come to another vote. That would do it justice.

name: Petr MACH
text: - Mr President, you want to fight terrorism by restricting the right to bear arms for normal, innocent citizens.This is absurd, you should have done something else, you should have protected the borders and not allowed millions of illegal migrants.I know that none of those terrorists used a legally held weapon, whether it was a submachine gun, whether it was a truck, it was an ax or a knife.I wonder why you're doing this, and I see the answer.You are obsessed with regulation, so today we will regulate the possession of weapons, we will regulate cages for rabbits, next time it will be the regulation of the Internet, and I feel that the citizens have had enough, at least in my country.In the Czech Republic, not only a majority of Members here in the European Parliament oppose this directive on arms possession, the government is opposed and the cup of our patience has simply overflowed.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: - Mister President! The rapporteur would also like to use this method to combat terrorism, and she has rightly received opposition from her own group. The nonsense of this project becomes clearest, however, in the so-called Lex Helvetica: Because the Swiss belong to the Schengen area, they are also included in the Weapons Directive. Thanks to a Lex Helvetica, veteran Swiss can keep their assault rifles. The EU made this exception to prevent Switzerland from holding a referendum on Schengen membership. This exemption appears from the text like a parrot from a winter oak. The Swiss assault rifle is a symbol of the equality of state and civil violence. The state delegates part of its monopoly on the use of force to the citizen because he trusts him and because he knows that he cannot always be everywhere to protect all citizens. Today's Europe is as far away as possible from such considerations. It is right to severely punish illegal possession of guns. If someone acquires a weapon illegally, he is up to no good, then he may want to engage in criminal activity. But why should an innocent citizen who is psychologically inconspicuous and can demonstrate training in weapons expertise not own a weapon? The CDU considers a further tightening to be a middle way, the SPD would like to have even more - nonsense, ladies and gentlemen, to reject that. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Nuno MELO
text: - Mr President, I would like to start by saying that the Commission linked this legislation to terrorism - and that was nonsense. The Commission genuinely believed that by complicating the lives of hunters, snipers and collectors, it would solve some problem of terrorism. I'm sorry to say, but it won't work. Hunters, snipers and collectors are not there to close their gun barrels to rob banks or place bombs on the streets. Hunters, collectors and snipers value their weapons. Terrorists, for their part, do not buy weapons in the highly regulated market, subject to registration, which, in the end, allows their identification because of that. Terrorists even use, see, knives, axes, motor vehicles and trucks, as happened in recent attacks. That is not why the Commission is going to make drivers' lives miserable. Once here, what I want to say is this: fortunately we had the European Parliament here working on codecision - I myself made many amendments myself and I thank Ana Maria Corazza Bildt for the effort. Today, we have a text that is completely different from what the Commission originally intended, but the purpose makes us fear for whatever the legislative effectiveness of those who can make a difference there is. Emotively, they wanted to link the regulatory market, hunters, snipers and collectors to the fight against terrorism. That was the impetus in presenting the legislation here. Please fight the black market and illicit arms trafficking, and then maybe you can do something ... (the President interrupts the speaker) ... in the fight against terrorism.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Colleagues, for those of you who were not present, I have already stated that I will not accept any more blue cards for reason of time.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: -  Mister President! I have to honestly say that I find it increasingly unbearable when I hear how the right-wing side of this House, these populists, keep working with half-truths and falsehoods in order to unsettle the citizens. That is simply irresponsible! Or have you ever seen a hunter stalking with a Kalashnikov or an assault rifle? Not me. But have we ever seen a gunman who used a semi-automatic automatic fire gun to kill people? The Yes. These are the questions we need to answer. We have to make sure that security for citizens is increased. We have to make sure that the weapons are traceable so that the police can also see where those illegal weapons that are on the market come from. We must ensure that we really have a rule of law for the citizens again, which can also give them security. That is the purpose of this law.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, in the Western world, the trend of maximum restrictions on the acquisition and possession of weapons has long taken off.The state disarms loyal citizens who legally possess weapons and thus makes them an easy target for criminals and terrorists who buy their weapons on the black market and knowingly break the law.Weapons don't kill, they kill a man.The role of the state is to ensure that these weapons end up in the hands of only those people who are in no way a threat to the environment and to regularly monitor whether they are still physically and mentally ready to use weapons responsibly.It is absurd that in this time of growing terrorist threat, we are disarming our own citizens.The police and the army cannot be ubiquitous and that is why I do not think it would be bad if there were those among the citizens who are armed, trained in the use of weapons and ready to help in extreme situations, both themselves and others.

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: - Mr President, this debate brings about an old dichotomy: freedom versus security. And it is true that it can be understood that the Commission had cyclical concerns, but it is no less true that it has incurred in excesses, in excess of regulation and in an inclination in favor of security, depriving of liberty. Therefore, it has been criticized and rightly so, but, fortunately, the dialogue between the sectors concerned and in this House and with the Council has corrected this excess, producing a proposal that is very worthy of being appreciated. The text that we are going to vote on, ladies and gentlemen, is the result of a more measured analysis than that originally presented by the Commission. It is a text that has been enriched after having attended the demands of sectors of society that had a lot to say on this matter. The agreement that has now been reached addresses the key issues in the sector, helps to restore the correct balance between the right to legally dispose of a firearm and the safety of citizens. As a result, we have a report that aims to weigh and evaluate what measures can be truly useful in tackling crime. It includes some new features that will allow us to face the risks that threaten public safety. The rules on the market for firearms are strengthened, establishing, among other things, a new obligation to also mark all essential components to avoid rebuilding weapons that are already inoperative. In addition, it has added a new provision to establish a common system for the systematic exchange of information between Member States, a fundamental point for the proper functioning of the system and security. This proposal is a very complete document that seeks consensus, previously complicated. You couldn't kill flies with cannon shots, but dialogue, understanding, rationality and balance have produced a rule worth voting for, and I will.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, we have an important report today, much discussed and which has created a lot of controversy. But we also know why. Here, some of our colleagues did not want, or did not want to explain to citizens what we want through this report. I have also proposed amendments to increase the safety of internet sales, labeling, stricter rules for gun owners and harmonization of holders' health control. Not all the amendments were taken, but I want to congratulate the rapporteurs on reaching a much better compromise than the Commission proposal. The report does not want to create obstacles for collectors, hunters, museums, the report wanted to increase the security of citizens. The traceability of firearms and components has been better established through this report and, therefore, I believe that it contributes to the accountability of those who trade in weapons, but also of the owners of weapons. So, I support this report.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: - Mister President! The proponents of the draft we are voting on today often say that the hunters, the shooters and the gun collectors could be satisfied with what is being presented as a compromise today. The question to be asked is: Are you satisfied? I have spoken to a great many in this field and they are not satisfied. So we can't just say here: you should be satisfied - you are not. And they are justifiably not satisfied because the regulation that is now planned is simply not proportional. We can't say: Because we want to fight terrorism, we're covering millions of law-abiding people with new regulations. We do not have a lack of laws in the EU, we have a lack of the implementation of laws, a lack of the fact that we, the institutions, do not obey the law either - we have to work on it. A secure Europe does not come about by introducing new laws, but by making sure that the existing ones are applied. I will reject this draft.

name: Karl-Heinz FLORENZ
text: -  Mister President! This report from the Commission caught us at a very unfortunate moment, after the Paris attacks. And then the impression arose that the hunters and sport shooters are the problem cases in Europe. Commissioner, they are not! The weapons that are in the hands of hunters and marksmen are in the very best of hands, and they will remain so. That has not changed, dear colleague from the right. I would like to reiterate that it is indeed the illegal weapons that are the problem, and I would like to add that it is not always just the terrorist, but a whole host of real criminals who use these weapons. I very much regret that the Commission has not raised this any more and that it has not followed up. You could have done a lot in the course of the debate - and we also had a very active debate on this in my intergroup. You didn't do that. If I had written a class test like this during my school days, Commissioner, with the aim of combating illegal weapons, then I would have had to write this paper all over again.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank Parliament's rapporteur, Vicky Ford, and the shadow rapporteur, Anna Maria Corazza Bildt, for having a very balanced presentation. We know that the starting point was bad, because the Commission presented the proposal for an arms directive as incomplete and incomplete. Quite understandably, responsible gun enthusiasts, hunters, sport shooters and gun collectors lamented that their legitimate hobbies were linked to terrorism. Now, as a result of this parliamentary process, those shortcomings have been rectified by the proposal, I myself have made a number of amendments, and legitimate hobbies can continue. The most important thing for us Finns is that the activities and training of reservists can continue as before. It is important for Finland's national defense, because reservists are an important part of Finland's national defense. Significant changes have also been made with the introduction of national flexibilities in areas such as arms licenses, medical certificates and inspections. On the other hand, security is significantly enhanced by the fact that station markings are now being harmonized, as is registration and also the exchange of information between authorities. This proposal and the outcome of the negotiations are worth supporting.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! We have to make it very clear that legal gun owners must neither be criminalized nor have they been criminalized in the debate in this House. We want to protect the legal gun owners and we must take action against the illegal gun owners and the abuse. The submission of the Commission proposal for the revision of the weapons directive, which took place more than a year ago, and the further processing in the European Parliament took place very seriously. We have all received an abundance of letters and emails from hunters, sport and traditional shooters, collectors and museums who have followed the revision very carefully. And we addressed these concerns. We improve cooperation between national authorities and the marking and traceability of firearms. We are addressing the issue of converted alarm pistols and reactivated firearms. At the same time we keep the balance. The proposal is balanced, the proposal is good and the proposal respects the principle of subsidiarity - therefore the members of my delegation are in favor.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, I think the European Parliament has made a big change to the Commission's original proposal, which was unacceptable, and I would like to thank both rapporteurs.We all agree that common standards for possession, deactivation and arms trafficking should be set at EU level in order to prevent the illicit arms trade.We should be able to exchange information across Europe.However, I am very sorry that the directive, the compromise we are now putting to the vote, still contains unacceptable proposals on details such as the holding of containers, which are details that Member States should be able to adjust.On the contrary, it does not introduce the obligation for compulsory medical examinations, which are essential for holders of weapons.I will be voting in favor of the amendments and, if they are not adopted, I will not be able to support this compromise.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, introducing limits on the acquisition of weapons and, at the same time, protecting those who legitimately possess them is not a simple solution but it is important for strengthening security. The amendment to the directive that we will vote on tomorrow aims to fill gaps in existing legislation and raise the level of security for European citizens, focusing on measures to prevent the sale of legal firearms on the black market and prevent massacres, suicides, homicides and firearm accidents. The directive is without prejudice to the application of national provisions relating to the carrying of firearms or relating to the regulation of hunting and sport shooting. Certainly more could have been done. In fact, I believe that it would have been better if the Commission had previously presented an impact assessment to allow this Parliament to have a better impact and if it had also focused attention on the problem of illegal weapons, organized crime and terrorist activity. they are related, representing other far more serious types of weapons-related problems.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, first of all I would like to point out that the directive is not going to help tackle terrorism, because terrorists have weapons that are illegally procured. The directive effectively punishes those who are legally armed and at the same time usurps the sovereign rights of the Member States, which are solely responsible for matters of national security and public order. The Member States, respecting their national traditions, respecting the rights of the peoples of Europe, may determine the conditions for the lawful possession of firearms in the light of the need for public order and peaceful social coexistence. At the same time, the principle of proportionality must be applied, without prejudice to the rights of hunters, members of shooting clubs, collectors and museums, as well as the legal holders of weapons. The rights of peoples to collective self-defense, especially in border areas, should also not be restricted in order to contribute to their country's national defense.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, in this debate, I have heard some arguments that are quite similar, if not the same, to those used in the United States of America by the arms industry to combat the prohibitionist measures of possession and use of weapons. I would like to say that the security of citizens does not come from the possession or use of firearms, it comes from correct public security policies. Citizens' security depends on the police, it depends on government policy measures, and not on citizens being armed. The weapon, held by citizens, undermines collective security. The only weapon that should be allowed to the human being is the word, it is the argument, it is the ideas. The possession and use of firearms, Mr Commissioner, Mr President, are remnants of barbarism, they are situations that should not be allowed in a civilized society. Hunting and the use of weapons, even in hunting, come from a culture of death and not from a culture of defending life, especially civilized life in modern societies.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: - Mr President, I am not a hunter or a sports shooter, I do not collect weapons.I am one of those who play Napoleonic soldiers like a tambor.Can you imagine that in the reconstruction of the Battle of Waterloo, instead of historical ancestors, people with wooden sticks would run and call boom, boom?What will the 100,000 spectators say?You don't mean that.We will not gain greater security with the proposed directive, and owners of illegal weapons, terrorists and criminals are already laughing at the authors of this directive today.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: - Mr President, you are preparing to vote on an absurd report that has nothing to do with reality, it will in no way tackle the problem of terrorism, it will only serve the illegals and criminals, it will create serious problems for millions of legal gun owners around the world. Europe. In relation to terrorism and crime, you should know that no legal weapons are used in terrorist attacks. Assault rifles, such as Kalashnikovs, used in attacks in Paris are already illegal throughout Europe. This, of course, did not stop the terrorists from procuring them. In no country in the world have criminal acts decreased since the arms embargo. On the contrary, in many they increased. I therefore call on the European Parliament to vote at the same time as the arms embargo and the knife ban. As much logic as there is in one report would exist in the other, and whatever effect the ban on weapons will have in the fight against terrorism, the ban on knives will also have.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you all for today’s debate. The first Vice-President is actually already aware, here, but I will make sure that I report on it fully to Commissioners Bieńkowska and Avramopoulos and other colleagues who have worked on this dossier over the months. This is a difficult area and I am the first to recognise that. I understand the concerns that some of you have voiced on the importance of guaranteeing the rights of legal firearm owners such as sport shooters, hunters and collectors. Personally, I think that is what the revised Directive before you today does. Anyone needing to hold a firearm for a demonstrated legal use, such as sport shooting or for exhibiting in a museum, will still be able to do so, as a number of speakers, not least the rapporteur and other Members of Parliament who worked directly on the text, have made clear. What we are doing with this revised text is making sure that the most dangerous firearms do not fall into the wrong hands. A number of you have asked about the assessment the Commission made. Right at the start of this work, we conducted a number of studies. These were done in consultation with Member State authorities and stakeholders all across Europe, including hunting, collecting and sport shooter federations. Those studies actually pointed to some of the security loopholes in the existing Directive which, unfortunately, were confirmed in reality and which are being addressed in this text. A report based on those studies was presented to this House and the Council earlier on in this process. A number of you also asked about tackling deactivation. We agree, and that is why we are doing work to reinforce the regulation on deactivation. It is going to be revised and strengthened by national experts to address the very technical issues that had been flagged by people in this House. A number of us have spoken about the Europol study that has just come out, which addresses this area. It underlines that firearms traffickers are highly adept at exploiting legal loopholes and differences in the regulatory regimes between Member States. They do that to divert firearms from legal suppliers. The reactivation of deactivated weapons and the conversion of blank firing weapons are among the main sources of illegal firearms trafficking in the EU. That is why we need to clarify the rules. But increasing the clarity of the rules around the possession and acquisition of illegal firearms is not sufficient. Again, I am the first to recognise that. We need a comprehensive approach, including taking forward the fight against illicit firearms trafficking, as a number of you have underlined. Indeed, the Europol report that we have been referring to points to the proliferation and availability of illegal firearms in Member States and that that increases the risk of their use by criminals and terrorist groups. That is why the Commission is working closely with Member States on the implementation of the Action Plan against the trafficking of illegal weapons and explosives, and we count on your support in reinforcing that fight against illegal firearms trafficking. A number of you have underlined the importance of implementation. Again, once this revised Directive is agreed, it will need to be implemented in the Member States, and we will work with you to ensure that this is done effectively and in the spirit of the text. To conclude, I would just like to say that I hope that the revised Firearms Directive can now be adopted. We, and many of you, have done intensive work to achieve a good and balanced text that will enhance the security of our citizens, which is our shared objective.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Thank you, Commissioner. For the sake of clarity as regards the impact assessment, was there an impact assessment that was assessed by the Impact Assessment Board, or just a number of studies?

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, as I described, there are a number of studies and they were summed up in a report.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: And that was assessed by the Impact Assessment Board?

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – It was not assessed by the Impact Assessment Board.

name: Vicky FORD
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, let us remember that there was a fundamental flaw in European law. Semi-automatic firearms with a pin through the barrel were able to be bought and sold without permission. The pins were taken out of the barrel and the guns were used to kill people in Paris. Over 30 of the same guns were found in the United Kingdom. The law needed to be changed. Some people have suggested that this law will take away freedoms for legal owners: this is not true. Hunters, collectors, museums, re-enactors, reservists and target shooters will be able to carry on with their sports and hobbies, both now and in the future, provided their Member States agree. That is thanks to the work of this Parliament. We live at a time of fake news. Stop telling people half truths about what this report does. This report addresses fundamental issues to protect our security, especially about those poorly deactivated firearms. It makes it easier for countries across Europe to work together against terrorism but it also respects the rights of legal owners to get on with their hobbies, their pastimes and their sports – and I would like to thank all those legal owners who have helped us with this work. Thank you, colleagues. I hope the report is passed and thank you for your support.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Tuesday, 14 March 2017. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – Ensuring the security of our citizens whilst also respecting their fundamental freedoms is the balance that we need to reach. This balanced approach must be adopted at all levels to ensure Europe does not become an Orwellian security state. This is why our efforts as policy-makers must be targeted towards ensuring that those citizens who obey the law are not targeted unnecessarily. The Commission’s firearms was putting into jeopardy the rights of licensed arms collectors, museums, hunters and sport shooters who are often scrutinised to the highest standards within our individual Member States. This is why I welcome the text as negotiated in trilogues as it removes the association between such persons and terrorism whilst safeguarding European citizens from semi-automatic and automatic rifles, which fire 20 rounds or more and are not stereotypically used for traditional activities. At the same time it ensures that activities that are ingrained within the culture and heritage of many of our Member States, such as traditional hunting activities and sport shooting, are safeguarded. The EU has a large task ahead to safeguard citizen’s fundamental right to security, and this should be done in line with our citizens’ fundamental rights.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: in writing.- Thank you to everyone involved in working out a compromise which, while not perfect, is still much better than the Commission's original proposal.The work of my colleagues from ECR, including Vicky Ford, contributed to this, which I supported from the very beginning, incl.making corrections.I appreciate the great involvement of civil society representatives in the work on the shape of the directive.Thank you for your help and advice.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing. - Following the terrorist attacks in Paris in January 2015, interior ministers demonstrated their countries' determination to reduce the supply of illegal firearms across Europe, strengthen mutual cooperation against crime threats, improve the exchange of intelligence and ensure full use of Europol, Eurojust and Interpol resources. Exactly two years ago, the Heads of State and Government called on all relevant authorities to step up cooperation in the fight against the illicit trade in firearms. The proposal to amend the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on control of the acquisition and possession of weapons seeks to strike a balance between the right to arms ownership and the inherent requirement of control of ownership based on the need for prudence and security. Violence against firearms in the EU is not an exceptional phenomenon. Modified and reactivated firearms pose a particular threat, so the requirement for stricter control of ownership and handling of weapons is justified and necessary. In the event of an unauthorized attack, the origin and ownership of the weapon must be traceable.
