If the owner or holder of the weapon handles it in accordance with the law and therefore legitimately, he does not have to worry about stricter control.

name: Emil RADEV
text: In written form. - The agreement reached between the European Parliament, the Council and the European Commission on the Weapons Directive will only affect law-abiding people who already have weapons permits, but will in no way lead to an effective fight against illicit arms trafficking and terrorism, what was supposed to be the purpose of the proposed legislative amendment. I believe that the text will lead to the confiscation of a number of legally owned weapons by thousands of hunters and collectors who have not violated the law so far, but whose weapons will not meet the new requirements for the number of bullets in a cartridge. The criteria for which weapons to be allowed and which to be banned are impractical and unfounded. It is unacceptable that there is no initial assessment of the impact of the legislative proposal, given how many people it will affect. Legal ambiguity will be created through the possibilities for different interpretations of the legislation in the Member States. I also believe that the procedures for issuing weapons permits will also be complicated. However, the agreed text will not meet the challenges and threats to European security, will not prevent future terrorist attacks and will not even facilitate the arms trade in the single market. On the contrary, it will do more harm to legal owners. That's why I can't support him!

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. - Tightening of controls on authorizations for the possession of firearms, but also on controls of blank or poorly neutralized weapons such as those used during the terrorist attack in Paris, improvement of traceability, increase and supervision of mutual exchange of information on weapons: these are the objectives achieved by our revised legislative text, the result of negotiations lasting almost a year and which will be voted on this midday in plenary session. A text for a safer Europe, combining both greater security for citizens and the interests of legitimate arms holders. Our text sets up a legislative base common to all the Member States and guarantees the consistency that is essential and eagerly awaited by the most rigorous European countries in this area, such as Belgium, Germany and France. States remain free to be even stricter on their territory than proposed by European law. The new rules voted on reconcile the need for greater security to which citizens are entitled and the interests of legitimate weapon holders such as hunters, athletes, collectors, reservists or extras

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - The safety of citizens comes first. The current legislation on firearms dates back to 1991, so the need for renewal is fully justified. We need decisive, well-founded and, above all, well-thought-out solutions that will really provide more security and better protection. I believe that the said directive, given that the text is, however, significantly better than the original, still leaves quite open questions. The biggest allegation is that it discriminates against the owners of legally acquired weapons. Of course, I agree with the tightening of controls and the adoption of additional rules that will reduce security risk, but I am afraid that the consequences of this directive will be borne by the wrong target group. Hunters, sport shooters and collectors are not the ones who threaten our safety, nor are they the ones who would recycle weapons. Terrorists are the ones who should be the target, and the fact is that they do not use legally acquired weapons in their actions. I regret that no proposal has been adopted, which I myself supported, which would have made the content of the directive clearer and more unambiguous.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing. - In my opinion, this new directive on firearms is full of mistakes and looks quite funny not only to experts but also to the whole of public society. This is mainly due to the fact that it contains many errors and ambiguities. At the same time, these are very fundamental aspects of possession of weapons! These are not sufficiently discussed and often lack both a legal reason and logic itself. One example for all are magazines - the proposed reduction of the magazine size from thirty to ten rounds is nonsense and has no logical justification. After all, the magazine has never been, is not and will not be the main part of the weapon. This proposal therefore requires a number of changes in its current form, which we have proposed with several colleagues. And if we want this legislation to be meaningful, we must adopt it. It is naive to think that restricting the possession of legal weapons will prevent terrorists from committing their actions. If we really want to prevent terrorists from their actions, we must first and foremost fight illegal weapons. But they will not be affected much by the forthcoming directive.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the joint debate on: - the report by Simona Bonafé, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2000/53 / EC on end-of-life vehicles, Directive 2006/66 / EC on batteries and accumulators and waste batteries and accumulators and Directive 2012/19 / EU on waste electrical and electronic equipment (COM (2015) 0593 - C8-0383 / 2015 - 2015/0272 (COD)) (A8-0013 / 2017), - the report by Simona Bonafé, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 1999/31 - EC report on waste landfills (COM (2015) 0594 - C8-0384 / 2015 - 2015/0274 (COD)) (A8-0031 / 2017), - the report by Simona Bonafé, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and food safety, refe on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2008/98 / EC on waste (COM (2015) 0595 - C8-0382 / 2015 - 2015/0275 (COD)) (A8-0034 / 2017) and - Simona Bonafé, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 94/62 / EC on packaging and packaging waste (COM (2015) 0596 - C8-0385 / 2015 - 2015/0276 (COD)) (A8-0029 / 2017).

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: rapporteur. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all allow me to thank all the shadow rapporteurs for the hard work of these months and above all for the climate of collaboration which has enabled us to proceed quickly with the approval of more than one hundred compromises on about two thousand amendments, with a large majority in the ENVI committee, of a delicate and important dossier. Indeed, the package we are about to discuss and vote on today is only formally the amendment of four directives on waste. But I think that it would be absolutely reductive to relegate it to the sphere of environmental policy or to the sphere of waste policy. I think that what we have before us today is, to all intents and purposes, a package that poses a very profound challenge to us, which is the challenge of setting up a new sustainable industrial model, that is, of ensuring that environmental sustainability can be considered. one of the levers of the competitiveness of our economic system. Because we must acknowledge that the current linear development model is showing all its limits: it is an ineffective development model, it is an expensive development model, it is a development model that is no longer producing well-being for our citizens and which is exploiting the planet's resources excessively. So, today we have the opportunity to get out of this crisis and move towards the transition to a circular economy which, mind you, does not only mean recovering raw material from waste but also engaging a virtuous circle such as to create value in everything. the life cycle of a product. This, in a nutshell, means greater sustainable growth, it means jobs, it means, as I said before, relaunching competitiveness, it also means focusing on innovation and new technologies and therefore opening up our economic system to new opportunities. Of course, to do this we must have clear legislation, which favors investments and ambitious policies. There are many things I would like to say about this package but I will limit myself to the most essential ones. I must say that we started from a good proposal from the Commission, a proposal that we have however improved above all in two main lines: on the one hand, prevention in the generation of waste and, on the other, the development of an efficient market for raw materials. . In the meantime, why start with prevention measures? Not only because prevention in the generation of waste is the first level of the waste hierarchy, but because, in our view, prevention in waste generation is a clear indicator of how far we are moving towards a circular economy. Let me explain: producing less waste means having set in motion all those innovations of production processes, products, business models that tell us to what extent we are moving towards a circular economy system. Among the prevention measures I would certainly like to mention the clearer definition of end of waste or by-products, certainly the minimum requirements of extended producer responsibility, certainly specific measures along the entire useful life of the product, such as reuse and planned obsolescence. , but also, President, let me mention two ambitious but very important targets: one is the 50% reduction of food waste, which is not only an environmental policy measure but is also an ethical issue, and the other is the reduction 50% of the marine litter, which, I recall, are two objectives of the United Nations SDGs, which, however, were not foreseen in the European legislation and we have filled this vulnerability. As regards the development of the secondary raw materials market, I want to recall the targets, which we have entered, of recycling and reducing landfill, ambitious targets but, I must say, also very pragmatic, in line with the previous proposal of the Commission but also in line with the conclusions of the Commission's 2014 impact assessment itself.Clearly, the premise for having an efficient quality secondary raw material market is quality separate collection, which we have also extended to the obligation to collect organic and textile waste.We are talking about 7% of total waste and it is clear that we must close the loop by also taking industrial and commercial waste into consideration.We must not hide the fact that we are facing a challenge that requires a profound change of paradigm and the involvement of all the players, not only institutional but also businesses and consumers.But I am convinced that Parliament will be able to rise to this challenge starting with the proposal we are going to vote on today.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start where Simona Bonafè also started, by thanking everybody involved in this, especially the rapporteur here in your Chamber and also, on my side, Commissioner Vella, Vice-President Katainen, and those involved in the excellent work done by our services. Some of the people concerned are sitting behind me, as are their Parliament counterparts. Their work was also of very high quality. I came to this House in December 2015 to present our ambitious programme for the circular economy, and Karmenu Vella was here in January of this year to update you on developments. I have always insisted that waste is just one part of the circle that we must tackle to achieve circular systems, but it is definitely a crucial one. We will never close the loop if we just keep throwing away or burning finite resources. The individual resources in our waste are just too valuable to burn or to bury in a hole in the ground. That is why waste reduction and modern waste management are essential parts of the material loops in a circular economy. State—of—the—art waste management is key to the success of the circular economy in Europe. Waste ceases to be a problem and becomes an opportunity when it is properly managed. Scrap contains precious materials and retrieving them creates profits and jobs, and reduces our dependency on raw material imports – a very different story from the complaints we regularly receive about hazardous, unsightly, and often illegal landfills. We are moving in the right direction. Recycling rates in the EU have been increasing. Land filling is decreasing. But Europe still loses around 600 million tons of waste materials per year, which could otherwise be recycled or reused. We can do something about this. EU waste policy and legislation have been key drivers for resource efficiency, growth and job creation. A swift adoption of the waste legislative proposals will further boost the markets for secondary raw materials and support a viable recycling sector and, what is more, the draft legislation we are discussing today has the potential to change for the better the whole life cycle of products in the wider economy. I would like, once again, to thank Simona Bonafè for her excellent work, and all the colleagues involved for their commitment and ambition and the good results that have been produced. The impressive number of amendments and the intensive discussions in Parliament have demonstrated the importance of the issue. It is equally important to agree the package so that it starts making a real difference on the ground. All the stakeholders are waiting for this and, with this package, they are all on board, which is something we also need to cherish. In December, along with the Council, we adopted together a joint declaration on the EU’s legislative priorities for 2017. The waste proposals are part of this selective list. So let us do all we can to come to a viable agreement during the first reading. There will of course – and Simona indicated this – be much focus on the target levels. I take note of the ambitious levels to which Parliament is committed. At the same time, I believe our proposals strike a good balance by setting targets that are challenging but feasible for the Member States to achieve. I am also glad to see Parliament taking into account the fact that some countries may need additional time to achieve the targets. While it is important that Member States make continuous efforts, the mechanism for granting time extensions should be simple and should ensure legal, policy and investment certainty for all involved. The levels of the targets should be seen together with the rules for calculating them: this will determine the true level of ambition. It is encouraging that both legislators have as an objective achieving the greatest possible level of comparability and a level playing field among the Member States. I share the view that the calculation rules need to be both robust and practical. This is the only way to avoid the problems of the existing legislation, which offers no methodological clarity at all. Of course, the best waste is no waste. So the priority that this House gives to waste prevention has my wholehearted support and I underscore the remarks just made by rapporteur Bonafè. I have taken note of the suggestions for a waste reduction target and for new targets for reuse, food waste and marine litter. They deserve careful consideration. This means comprehensive impact assessment, sound data and agreed methodologies. We have learned our lessons from the current waste legislation, which does not offer methodological clarity at all. We need to avoid this in the future. The waste package is also about improving the means to achieve higher recycling rates on the ground, while promoting a broader circular economy transition. More use of economic instruments can provide the right incentives to move up the waste hierarchy. At European level, more efficient and transparent extended producer responsibility rules are key to encouraging better design and production techniques to enable more efficient recycling. In this context, Parliament’s proposals to clarify and strengthen provisions resulting in better performance of waste management systems on the ground are most welcome. Last but not least, I note the very wide range of initiatives that Parliament would like to see in the waste area in the near future. We are looking forward to discussing these with you and the Council, but let me say the following at this stage: I believe that we should set clear priorities in this work, examine where we have sufficiently developed methodologies available, and agree realistic deadlines. In order to ensure tangible results on the ground we need to focus our efforts. Much has been achieved. I very clearly recall the antagonistic position that we – the Commission and Parliament – had at the beginning of this process of re-evaluating our waste proposals, and I am therefore very happy that we are in such a cooperative, forward—looking mood today. I will do everything in my power to make sure that we stay as close as possible to Parliament’s position in this.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. - Mr President, our economy is facing a number of new challenges. How we respond to them will affect our long-term competitiveness, quality of life and quality of the environment. If we want to ensure people's prosperity in the future and create new and better-paid jobs, we will have to go through a series of changes, if not revolutions. Digital revolution, technology revolution and transform our energy into low carbon. We also need a radical change in the area of ​​waste management and in the way we manage and use materials and raw materials. A key part of this revolution will be a change of perspective on waste, which must become a resource. We need to create the best conditions for the efficient use of resources, for the development of the market for secondary raw materials, for innovations in the field of materials management and their reuse. That is why we need a new legislative framework that is ambitious enough to stimulate much-needed change. That is why I support raising the targets as discussed in the committees. It's not just economic factors that we have to take into account, it's food waste or the flooding of the sea with waste.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – Mr President, I remember the submission of the proposal more than a year ago. I was one of the very few MEPs who was positive about the proposal, because it was inclusive, and we could already sense at that time that if we handled it well it could lead to a real transformation of our industry, creating a completely new sector. If we look at the proposals, and I am looking at them as the rapporteur on two of the proposals, in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE), and in case one as a shadow, I must say that this is a good result. I also appreciated the interaction with the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI), which has taken on board a number of the points made by the ITRE committee, including the annex on incentives, the one-stop shop, and the questions of illegal shipments etc. Now is not the time to spell out all the positive provisions – it is the time to invite the House to fully support and back something that has enormous industrial, environmental and social implications. I think that we have got it right. Let’s go for it.

name: João FERREIRA
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Industry, External Trade, Research and Energy. - Mr President, Commissioner, with regard to the targets for recycling packaging and packaging waste, taking into account the wide disparity in the starting points of the Member States vis-à-vis these targets, now revised upwards - which determines the the need for also different efforts to achieve the established goals, without jeopardizing the objectives -, some temporal flexibility in its implementation is justified, which safeguards the diversity of situations. It was a concern of the opinion approved by the Industry Committee. On the other hand, the existence of new objectives, revised upwards, should justify the existence of new means to achieve these objectives and this is an aspect that has been neglected until now. The regimes of extension of the producer responsibility appear to be adequate, either for the prevention of the formation of packaging waste, or also for the creation of systems that guarantee the recovery and / or the collection of used packaging and packaging waste from the consumer or the waste stream, along with reuse or recovery - I finish - including the recycling of packaging and packaging waste collected, according to the waste management hierarchy.

name: Karl-Heinz FLORENZ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, dear Vice-President Timmermans! It's nice that we have made progress now - a good year after your introduction. I think it has become clear to all of us that this circular economy act - if you allow me to do so in my mother tongue - is a groundbreaking instrument. We have to tell people that it's no longer about burying anything, but about reusing things, for the benefit of our children and grandchildren, because in ten or twenty years they may no longer be raw materials have to build certain things. That is why I think we are at a point here, at a turning point - Mrs Bonafè, you explained that wonderfully that we have to wake up. It is not always about the last percentage recycling rate, but about the awareness of this society that we can better recycle and recycle our raw materials. 60% of our fuels and raw materials are burned by us. It's a shame, we can't let it go on like this. And the prices are skyrocketing. Neodymium cost $ 25,000 seven years ago, today neodymium costs $ 700,000. This is a material for cell phones, but also for wind turbines. So we are rich parents and our children may be poor children. That's why we have to put the handbrake on. I am pleased that in Mrs Bonafè we have an excellent rapporteur. The cooperation with her - I am happy that I can say the same for my office, Ms. Philipp, who worked very actively all night: Thank you very much for that, that was very neat. We have clear definitions today. We used to have six terms. What is recycling anyway? It now turns into a corridor, and then we have a term, then we no longer need to talk about percentages. The high one today Having percentages may not be that good after the new corrections and measurement methods.So that's where movement comes in.I am happy about it, because it is a movement for the benefit of our next generation.Commissioner, I would not have trusted you, à la bonne heure, to hold out like that, and Mrs Bonafè, I always knew with you that you would hold out.We will accompany you, Commissioner.We'll take you by the hand, and in the end you'll have a good piece of paper.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – First and foremost, I would like to start by saying thank you not only to Simona Bonafè, our S&D rapporteur, but also to all the shadow rapporteurs, who managed to help make the circular economy package achievable for our consumers, our SMEs, our big businesses and governments alike. The way forward is to integrate resource efficiency in the way we do business. What we are speaking about today is not only the environment or the economy – we are also managing to bridge the gap and bring both of them together. We need to arrive at a point where the waste of one business becomes the resource of another; where the output of one industry becomes the input of another. The resources we have out there are all we have; they are finite. This is the reason why we cannot continue building an economy that uses things up and creates waste. We need an economy that uses and reuses things. This is our chance to inspire young people, who see new openings where others see challenges. This is their opportunity to be creative and innovative, and to help rebuild an entire system that actually works. The transformation required will not come about through legislation alone. We need smart regulation, together with market-based instruments, innovation and incentives. Investors need a clear and positive signal and regulatory certainty, because this in turn will help create jobs. It has been said today that success will be measured by how well these policies are implemented in our Member States, because ultimately it is only through smart implementation that we can ensure that the decisions we make today will have a positive impact on what is left for tomorrow.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - First of all, I would like to express my sincere thanks to the rapporteur, Mrs Bonafè, for her resolute and constructive approach, and to the shadow rapporteurs for the excellent cooperation. The EU is heavily dependent on third countries for the import of raw materials. Many of these raw materials are in danger of being exhausted in the relatively short term. Yet we handle it very carelessly. Every European citizen produces about five tons of waste every year - the weight of an adult African elephant. We only recycle a third of that. Our mountain of waste is growing, while precious raw materials all too often disappear underground. We must break through that dynamic and commit resolutely to a circular economy, in which we recover valuable raw materials. This is not only good for the environment, it is also necessary to keep our economy competitive. Recycling more and turning landfill into an ending story is essential, but better recycling alone is not enough. If we really want to switch to a circular economy, we must also focus effectively on less waste, more reuse and closing cycles through innovative business models. Everyone should participate, including the producers. In addition, one unique measurement method for calculating the recycling figures must ensure that we no longer compare apples with pears and that everyone takes their responsibility. Flanders, the nation I represent, is a pioneer in the field of materials management and the circular economy. The trajectory we have taken over the past twenty years strengthens my belief that much is possible if there is the political will. We can learn a lot from each other. I am thinking, for example, of our best practices, such as the concept of “thrift shops” to encourage reuse and innovative ways to valorise biological waste. Trash is cash: this pun came from you, Mr. Timmermans. Very what stakeholders and companies have already understood well.The ball is now in our camp to design a good legislative framework that provides the right stimuli and sets the bar high enough.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: for the ALDE Group. - Mr President! In recent months, I have had the great pleasure of beginning my speeches at home in Finland with a brief statement: "I will talk rubbish". I will also talk rubbish here in this House today. This expedition into the world of waste has been very interesting in many ways. Among other things, it has been an expedition into reality, and I have had the opportunity to visit various facilities, both at home in Finland and in other parts of Europe. The interesting thing in this context is that reality has proven to have taken several steps forward. Today, we are far more advanced in terms of reusing our waste than we were perhaps just a year ago. I have visited a small factory that manufactures waste containers. It is probably Europe's foremost factory. Through the technological solution, it achieves a sorting of the waste that leads to a purity in the consequences of 98 percent. Thus, by following the examples we already see, we can achieve an incredibly much cleaner waste stream. So a lot is happening out there, and we should not fall behind. The second part of our expedition has, of course, been mainly about Simona Bonafè's work to help us along this difficult path. I think we have been satisfied - we heard from all the other shadow rapporteurs how satisfied they have been with her way of working. However, it is not only she who has been good in this context, but also our assistants and our political advisers have been excellent. I do not always and in all matters agree with my colleague Demesmaeker. There are some issues where we actually have quite different opinions. But to emphasize the good work we have done here, I will say that together with Demesmaeker we go to a Flemish city to see how it is done there. We intend to continue this journey into a better reality.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to start my speech, also along the same lines as Mr Torvalds, recognizing the work and willingness of the rapporteur, Simona Bonafè. Now, we need to send a clear signal to the Council. I think the Commission could have been more ambitious in December 2015, but I commend the words now spoken by Mr Timmermans. Here it is about the model of society that we want to have and that we will pass on to our daughters and sons; it is about reconciling sustainable development with the environment and, of course, fighting climate change. We need to promote a systemic, comprehensive change that implies the design of a new paradigm. Commission and Council should foster the collaborative spirit, based on development and innovation, that is part of this legislative package. And the global vision should be combined with the local one. This implies taking into account the vital role played by the administrations closest to the citizenry. And this must be done precisely together with social and citizen movements. If we do so, we will not need to explain to society what we are doing, because it will have taken part and led the process. Thanks again to the rapporteur and I encourage the Commissioner to do, as she said, everything possible so that the ambition and the spirit of what the European Parliament has proposed is not lost in the trilogues.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Club. - Mr President, honorable Members, Honorable Vice-President of the Commission Timmermans, I would first like to thank my colleague Bonafè and all the other shadow rapporteurs for their excellent cooperation, for the cooperation of our teams, who have contributed to us discussing and voting on more ambitious goals. set by the European Parliament. Why vote today for these more ambitious waste recycling targets, why go for a lower waste disposal rate. I will try to explain this with the example of a cartoon. Wall-e is an Oscar winner in which he shows how one small robot, the only one of its kind, collects waste, packs it and stacks it in pyramids. Will the achievements of our civilization be pyramids of waste, and we know what the achievements of Egyptian civilization were. And look at the miracles, that little robot recognizes the circular economy because the things it recognizes that it can fix, that they have some other value, it takes to its shelter, repairs it there, and enjoys those remnants of our civilizational heritage. And the question actually arises as to where the people are in that film. Humans fled into space because they used the entire space of the planet earth to dump waste to build these pyramids. The question is how will we then escape into space. Donald Trump seems to have a solution to this problem. A few days ago, he announced that he was reviving the space program and that he intended to send people to the moon. But, by the way, we must not forget that in addition to this recycling, in addition to disposal, we throw away too much food, we dump our waste in the sea and oceans, we forget that we have biodegradable waste from which we can produce energy and compost, we forget that this ambitious circular proposal economy, these goals, actually represents the creation of our local jobs and in all those Member States that are protesting, it actually represents the creation of local jobs. That is why I urge you not to listen messages that come to reduce these ambitions than to vote for higher recycling targets because a bigger delay, a bigger reduction in recycling targets will lead to that ... (The President took the floor from the speaker ...)

name: Julia REID
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, although I sympathise with the ideology behind the aims of creating a circular economy, I believe that we should be circumspect, bearing in mind what is happening globally. We are told that an EU circular economy is an efficient economic model that ensures that the environment receives adequate protection, at the same time as promoting reindustrialisation and competitiveness in Europe. However, I am yet to be convinced. As always, such ambitious EU policies need to be backed by a clear legislative framework. However, such legislation will not be binding on our competitors in China, India or the United States. In conclusion, we, in UKIP, believe that such legislation should be made by national governments so that they can put forward policies that are best for their country and their people.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, Madam Rapporteur, ladies and gentlemen, the Group on Europe of Nations and Freedoms has attached a minority opinion to the report on waste. This text lists our major concerns on the essential changes made to the directive. We have criticized tax incentives, which are the prerogatives of the Member States. We deplored a lack of flexibility, given the diversity of the situation in the European Union. We have noted that the definite consequence would be the increase in public spending and the deepening of the internal market, to the benefit of a few rare transnational entities, without any guarantee of efficiency. But I would especially like to mention EPR, that is to say the extended responsibility of the producer. Come to think of it, this REP considers that, in the entire manufacturing cycle of a product, the tailoring stage of the actual production is the real problem. Intermediaries and raw material suppliers are therefore exempted from their responsibility in creating future waste to be recycled, and the burden falls on the producers, that is to say it weighs on the added value at the heart of the 'economy. The uncontrollable costs also lie in manufacturing. No doubt such a debatable subject will be the subject of heated discussions in the Council.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: - Mr President, changes to the worst of the anti-popular direction of the 2008 directive and the corresponding waste are being promoted on the basis of the European Union's strategy for the so-called circular economy. In Greece, our people are paying heavy consequences for the environment, their health and their pockets from the incorporation of the guidelines of the above directive. I am referring to the untimely construction and operation of adequate landfills, as a result of which the impasses are perpetuated - for example in the Attica Tribe landfill - in the uncontrolled landfills, in the big problems in the Peloponnese and Zakynthos or in other areas. The excessive, unattainable goals for our country for 2020 are utilized by the capital for the design of very expensive facilities that are delivered to the business groups. In the context of the circular economy, cement industry groups such as Lafarge in Volos start and are essentially licensed as waste incineration plants. The aim of the binding provisions of the European Union under the pretext of greater recycling is to increase the profits for the monopolies of the industry and to supply other industries with cheap - - alternatively called! - - raw materials and fuels to the detriment of the environment and the health of popular strata. The only solution in the interest of the people is to claim by their struggle, in conflict with the monopolies and their power, a single public state body, without any involvement of individuals at all levels, complete exemption of the people from reciprocal fees and raids , policies to reduce waste generation in recycling by source sorting and composting.

name: Peter LIESE
text: - Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen! I would like to thank everyone who has contributed to the fact that we have this good result on the table today: of course, the rapporteur, Mrs Bonafè, but also our shadow rapporteur Karl-Heinz Florenz, who brought things together very well and into that Has contributed overall result. We have to consider where we were two years ago: the proposal had been withdrawn and, I think it would not have been necessary. If we had worked on the original proposal further, we could have come to this conclusion. But I am pleased that the Commission is able to learn, and I am delighted at what Vice-President Frans Timmermans said that he would like to support the result that Parliament is about to vote on and that we should be as close as possible whenever possible it is possible. We do something for the environment; I would just like to emphasize two points: When waste is dumped, methane is generated - methane is a worse greenhouse gas than CO2. And in my country, the largest single contribution to climate protection in recent years has come from the fact that we have less landfill. So that's at least as important as other things in climate protection. And we urgently need to address the problem of plastic and other substances littering the oceans. We make a contribution to both. But it's also about our children's raw materials, as Karl-Heinz Florenz always says, and it's about jobs, it's about jobs that we can safeguard and create through a sensible circular economy. Finally, I would like to point out a point where I believe we are improving the Commission proposal and making it less bureaucratic. It's about the transport of small amounts of hazardous waste, for example: If a painter takes paint from the construction site, then it shouldn't be treated like a large waste company.If the Commission could take a closer look at this and support it, I would be very grateful!

name: Jo LEINEN
text: -  Mister President! Vice-President Timmermans, you promised that the new circular economy package would be better than the old one. Colleague Liese pointed this out. I believe that with what Parliament decides today, that will indeed be the case. We have more ambitious goals, we have better mechanisms and proposals to reduce the mountain of waste and to recycle as much of the raw materials as possible. Now we are still waiting for the second pillar that has yet to come, namely the action plan with the ecodesign proposals. Because it has to start with the product policy and not just with the disposal of the products that are in circulation. We are excited to see what you are presenting to us in the action plan before the next European elections. There is no question: we want to move away from the throwaway society towards a circular economy. There are many good suggestions. I thank Mrs Bonafè and all the rapporteurs who have contributed.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: – Mr President, negotiating multiple legislative proposals at the same time, particularly when they have been withdrawn and rewritten, is no easy task. I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Ms Bonafè, and her team of shadows, on their work. Of course, we support the circular economy principles, but my delegation will be voting in favour of this report. We do not think it is a perfect compromise and we should take care to ensure that we do not, unwittingly, take steps backwards by imposing overly ambitious mandatory targets. I have concerns on two areas. Firstly, on the levels of the waste targets, I will be supporting a return to the Commission targets. Secondly, on extended producer responsibility (EPR), I have tabled an amendment to delete Article 8a. EPR has an important role to play in improving environmental delivery, but the proposal to include minimum operating conditions is too prescriptive. We should encourage the adoption of more, and better, schemes but allow flexibility in their design across Member States. With the establishment of targets in the ‘producer pays’ principle affirmed, I believe that it is not necessary to apply such a rigid approach in setting requirements for Member States’ EPR schemes.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: - Also on my behalf, many thanks to the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for the excellent work they have done. I heard this morning that many, including the European Commission, have emphasized the importance of the economic benefits of that circular economy. And rightly so: it was McKinsey who declared eighteen months ago that the circular economy should become the future political, economic project, the project we have been looking for for so long. But if we are so convinced of those economic benefits, then we shouldn't do half the work. Then we also have to go for that circular economy with full conviction. The fantastic properties of a circle only apply if it is complete, and not with a semicircle. That is why we have rightly increased the recycling targets. On this point too, I expect full support from the European Commission, as Parliament's goals are the preferred option in the impact assessment. So I sincerely hope that the Commission will also fully support us in the negotiations with the Council.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: - Mr President, also allow me to thank the rapporteur and all the shadow rapporteurs who have done an incredible job on this package, and I think they have succeeded in creating a far more ambitious version of the package than proposed by the Commission, which is certainly a positive and good basis for the next negotiation. I must say that I am satisfied with him. I feel that the goals we have set are something extra that can bring a lot of positive things to citizens. There are certainly fine targets for bio-waste and a progressive approach to microplastics, as well as eco-design and the use of waste as a raw material, which is the right way to ensure a real circular economy. Personally, I support the pursuit of recycling and landfill targets, but I cannot agree with a total ban on the energy recovery of waste, because I do not consider landfilling to be better and more environmentally friendly than converting waste into energy where it makes sense. Let me wish you very much, all the colleagues who took part in it, and above all that the ambitions are maintained and that you succeed in enforcing them in the trialogue as well.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: – Mr President, let me remind you that in previous resolutions, Parliament has called for more ambitious targets. The Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) also recently called for raising the ambition of the current proposal by introducing a binding target to have 70% of municipal waste recycled by 2030 in addition to limiting the amount of municipal waste that can go to landfill to 5%. The ENVI Committee also called for a minimum of 5% of total municipal waste to be prepared for reuse, a binding target of 80% of packaging to be recycled, and a 10% target of packaging waste to be reused by 2030. I believe that the European Parliament has to send a strong message to the Commission and the Council and stick to this high ambition level, in line with the previous Commission proposal for the package, as this is the only way to trigger action in the Member States. Dear Mr Timmermans, this is not exaggeration, this is simply the level of braveness of the previous Barroso Commission. We need strong incentives to reduce waste generation, food waste and marine litter as well. It is crucial that investment choices are taken so that they facilitate moving up the waste hierarchy. There is also a pressing need to phase out harmful subsidies, as well as a need for better systemic eco-design measures to counteract planned obsolescence and to substitute for hazardous substances. Last, but not least, the Commission has to do everything it can to ensure the implementation of the existing provisions. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question.- President!I really insist on asking my question, because I see that most of the speeches here still remain at the percentage level.But I would rather like to ask the honorable Member whether you could live with or support radical ideas such as, say, a liter of e.g.ban plastic bottles everywhere - given that it rises exponentially and that doesn’t stand out from the percentages.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Blue card answer.- Thanks for asking!For my part, I think that in the long run, the system must definitely move towards recyclable packaging.What the possible speed of this is and what Parliament, the Council and the Commission can agree on - this limits and determines the level of ambition from which we can move forward.For my part, I have argued in the debate on the package, and I am still arguing that we should take action as quickly and as ambitiously as possible.In the end, we have to get there to completely remove disposable, one-way packaging from the system.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we support this legislative package as approved in the Environment Committee because, in any case, it improves the current situation, since it introduces more ambitious targets on recycling, more ambitious targets on preparing for reuse and also greater limitations on incineration. , as well as landfilling. We would have liked, however, to see more courageous and concrete actions, such as a total ban on waste incineration. More courageous and concrete actions, such as the elimination of any possible subsidy to fossil fuels, because this would have been the only real way to make a transition towards a truly circular economy. If we don't do these simple things, we are talking about nothing. That is why we have tabled amendments to the text on precisely these two issues and we have tabled them even though we know very well that most of this House will not vote on them, because the incineration and oil industry lobbies are still too strong in this House.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: - Today we are talking about the circular economy and how we can reuse products and materials.I think that's all fine, just go ahead with your hobbies.The delicate thing is that the EU itself has been end of life for years, but is not eligible for recycling, simply because the parts are no longer usable.The multi-billion dollar Turkey deal can never be used anywhere again and Draghi's money press is even spinning so fast that Mugabe doesn't want to take it over.No, Mr President, the only circular EU element that works is the job machine.And that is your luck, because after this year's elections in the Netherlands, in Germany, you name it, you will badly need that job machine.(The speaker addressed a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: "blue card" question.- I am a little annoyed at my colleague from the Netherlands, who does say something and shout here but does not participate in all those debates - look at the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs - in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety.If you say something here, you should do something there too, but I just never see you there.I think that is very serious.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: "blue card" answer.- Mrs Schreijer-Pierik, it is good to hear that you miss me.I often miss you too, but then I miss you in the Netherlands.What really matters is talking to the taxpayer in the Netherlands who has to finance all this.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - President!The four pieces of legislation now under discussion are not simply a review of waste legislation, but in fact introduce a complex way of thinking.He sees waste as a resource, a secondary raw material within the circular economy.Reuse and recycling will become a key concept - these goals can be agreed upon.However, there are critical parts to the submissions.The fact that by 2030 it wants to reduce the disposal of municipal waste in municipal landfills to only 10 and 5%, respectively - is simply an unrealistic expectation.By means of delegated and implementing acts, the European Commission effectively deprives the Member States of their decision-making power, as the French National Assembly and the Austrian Parliament have made clear in their opinions.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Bonafè, and the shadow rapporteurs, especially Mr Florenz, for the great work that this package has involved. In my opinion, the whole circular economy package is ambitious and coherent in nature. However, I think we have to go deeper into eco-design and waste prevention, since, as much as we improve management, if the reduced level continues to increase, we will not solve the problem. It is important to respect the waste hierarchy at all times to avoid shortcuts that may favor some options over others. When it comes to setting new targets, it seems essential to me that there are clear concepts and definitions. This is how we will ensure that all data and methodologies are comparable and comparable. The Waste Directive has to draw a clear distinction between municipal waste, on the one hand, and commercial and industrial performance, on the other. That is why I want to ask for support for Amendment 251, which includes the quantity criterion in the definition of municipal waste. Eliminating this word in the definition may mean opening the door, including industrial commercial waste in municipal waste. This makes it difficult to manage this waste, which must be the true objective of this regulation. Finally, we cannot forget that all the measures we take will be of little use if we fail to make consumers aware of the importance of the circular economy.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: - Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, if we do not support this legislative package, Europe will continue to throw, burn and bury billions of euros a year. As rapporteur for the food waste report, I particularly welcome the adoption of a hierarchy and definition of food waste. During the vote, we can take another step to reduce the embarrassing amounts of food thrown away. We can establish a basis for binding Union-wide reduction quotas. Of course, when the conditions for that are met in the form of reliable statistics. Public opinion supports this, the citizens want it and it is the right time for the Union to show that it can solve this great economic, environmental and moral problem. Circular economics is perhaps a pretentious name for something that seems simple as a matter of common sense. Waste is not garbage but a resource on which our countries and citizens can earn with an additional bonus of nature conservation. In conclusion, I would like to thank my colleague Bonafa for his excellent effort and work.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! The idea of ​​a circular economy is a very good idea, it has many advantages, not only environmental and economic, but also social. Unfortunately, as is often the case, the European institutions manage to spoil the best ideas by setting unrealistic goals. They are good, of course, but only for some countries. Germany, Belgium and Sweden are very close to achieving them. However, my home country, Poland, still has a long way to go in this area, and unfortunately it is not covered by any flexibility clause. For example, when it comes to municipal waste, in 2012 Poland processed 20%, Germany - 64%, Austria - 59%, and an overall target of 65% is set, so Poland would have to increase processing by 225% of currently processed waste to 2030. This is an absolutely unrealistic goal. Polish society cannot afford to reach these goals in this time distance. Therefore, I cannot support this package.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: - Mr President, each European state has a talent, has its particular talents. Germany has the most satisfied workers, Estonia produces the least waste and my country, Belgium, is the European champion when it comes to recycling its packaging - over 80%, compared to around 64% of European average. This shows whether this package on the circular economy interests us and whether the objectives set for 2030 by the European Parliament in the “Packaging and packaging waste” directive, ie 80% for wood and 90% for aluminum and for glass, are obviously achievable. Now, as our rapporteur said, this legislative package must be seen as a starting point. Be careful not to make a false start. I come to what I wanted to bring up this morning, the issue of food waste: 80 million tonnes wasted each year, 400 euros of food thrown away per household. Beyond the ethical problem which is unbearable, an economic loss, an ecological loss. In conclusion, it is therefore essential to vote on Amendments 145 and 236 - keep these two numbers - to halve this waste by 2030.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: - Mr President, in order to protect the environment and ensure the quality of life, we must end uncontrolled waste generation and focus on sustainable consumption. It is not possible to consume everything, because in the context of the circular economy, waste will be recycled. We welcome individual proposals that are promoted. We agree that binding targets should be set, the responsibilities of large producers should be broadened, prevention measures for the efficient use of resources should be strengthened, recycling should be promoted and, finally, the development of the necessary infrastructure for the management of waste. Of course, special support should be given to states that have been hit hardest by neoliberal policies of harsh austerity and are facing more problems in achieving their goals. But there are other important goals that are unfortunately missing. We must promote the rehabilitation of landfills. And to ensure the involvement of local communities, environmental and trade unions as well as other social actors in the legislative process.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: – Mr President, firstly, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her great work in getting to this deal and, indeed, I would also like to thank the Commission. We have come a long way in the discussions and I think we are now on the same page concerning the importance of the circular economy. What we are doing here is making sure that waste can be used in the circular economy, but we know that we also need to look at how to create a demand for reused and recycled material and at making sure that the design is ready so that we can create a circular economy. This is a very good, and very important, step, but we are not there yet. We are asking for, and expecting, additional steps from the Commission, as also announced in the Action Plan. For those who are always referring to impact assessments and saying that it is important, the higher targets will deliver EUR 6 billion in benefits to society: 34 000 more jobs and 99 million tonnes of CO2 reduction. People, planet, profits, thanks to the higher targets. Read the impact assessment.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, annoying, hindering, expensive: this is the portrait that is recorded outside these buildings by the people, by the citizens towards the European Union. And why do they often attribute such a portrait to this Europe? Because within the provisions they do not find the application of the logic of reason, that is, the logic that should include, within these provisions, the fact that the interests of the people, of those who elected us, of those who, above all, we they pay. And in this provision, on which I am questioned and measured, there is nothing that serves the interests of citizens, families, businesses and, above all, the real world. What would the real world expect from this provision? The simplification of procedures and above all the reduction of costs. Instead, we are witnessing, as in Italy, a tax on waste which, in less than three years, has increased, at least in some cases for artisans, traders and families, by 400%. A measure of this type absolutely had to provide for a reduction in the costs of the waste tax. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: blue-card question. – Mr. Ciocca, I read the report, and it is a weighty report. Did you find anything in that report that did not increase taxes, that did not increase the cost of regulation, and that did not increase the number of European bodies across Europe? Did you not find that, in fact, there was more waste and more regulation? Can you confirm that? That is what I read. Is that what you read as well?

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: answer to a "blue card" question.- What I can confirm is that the labyrinths of this material are increasing and, consequently, the costs for artisans, traders and families will increase: this is the theme.A measure of this type, over 230 pages, had to have an ambitious theme, a vital theme, of survival for families and businesses: the reduction of the costs of the waste tax.Unfortunately, there is no trace of such an ambitious project, which would justify the existence of this Europe.

name: Elisabeth KÖSTINGER
text: –Mr President, Commissioner! I think it is very important, with this vote today, to also express that we are finally moving from a throwaway society to a resource community and that we are trying, above all, to deal with the great differences that exist in individual definitions, in the treatment and storage of Raw materials partly predominate in the individual member states, really try to standardize and thus actually create a very innovative and also new system in Europe. Because what is currently being burned in a neighboring country, we could very well use as a raw material in another in the future, or in other words: Today's garbage may at some point be tomorrow's fuel. Today, with the higher recycling rates and lower landfilling, we want to create the circle towards a real eco-social market economy. In my opinion, we are also starting today with the idea - and above all with the vision - of finally moving towards a zero-waste society. And I think that should be the next big goal for us. Waste has never presented so many opportunities as it does now, and I think we really have to take advantage of them and also give value back to waste. We have to move away from plastic and cheap single-use solutions, and towards using the full potential of products. The time has really come to create awareness in society as well. If we do not manage to take the people with us on this journey, we are unfortunately doomed to failure.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! The present package and what Parliament has also improved and expanded on here is a great opportunity for our future. We say that we have to put a stop to climate change, we say that we have to be careful with our resources. It is therefore absolutely essential that we create these conditions. We need to bring products to market that are reusable and recyclable. We have to create an awareness that products can be used in many ways and that not everything that is waste should end up in the landfill. Six member states, including Austria, more or less introduced a landfill ban in 2014, and it works. That means if we create this awareness together that waste can in reality also be a raw material, if we create the awareness that with products that are easy to dismantle, we have products that are designed from the outset in such a way that they can be recycled, then we have taken a valuable step here. The present drafts are a good way to get there.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: - (FI) Mr President, the circular economy is a great opportunity for us in Europe, but it would also be able to respond to global environmental challenges even fairly quickly, if we pay more attention to the accessibility of the material cycle. This requires investment on the product and research side, among other things, but even more change in our world of values, both at the individual level and in society as a whole. With a view to the forthcoming work on amending the Renewable Energy Directive, I would also like to point out that, although we in Parliament deal with issues separately for good reason, in practical life they are interlinked. Thus, it is good to understand that, for example, more efficient utilization of materials through different cycles always also requires energy. A sustainable circular economy cannot therefore be achieved without renewable, clean energy. It is not just about Europe's success in global competition, but even more importantly: saving our planet.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: - Mr Chairman! We want economic growth, but we also want a clean environment. We also want to ensure the future of future generations through sustainable development. A circular economy is such a concept. The directives we are voting on today introduce very ambitious targets, including recycling, and will significantly affect the shape of waste management in Europe and in individual Member States, presenting on the one hand a challenge for local governments and, on the other hand, an opportunity for economic development, also in these areas which have so far lacked significant economic impulses. An economy that is resource efficient and environmentally friendly is not only recycling, but also low waste generation. I thank the rapporteur for placing the emphasis on this prevention, which is the highest level in the waste management hierarchy. However, I regret that the promotion of the economies of countries that produce the least waste per capita has not been introduced. I think it could also significantly cause increased interest. And the last thing, Mr. Chairman. I would like to highlight the introduction of my proposal to process organic waste not only into compost, but also in the gasification process, in an anaerobic process with biogas recovery. I believe this is a good idea, as is saving food and producing less waste.

name: Clare MOODY
text: – Mr President, I must also thank the rapporteur, Simona Bonafè, for her hard work on this deeply significant file. In my work as a shadow rapporteur on the packaging and packaging waste directive, I had two objectives: a binding target on marine waste and a minimum level of recycled plastic in new packaging. I am glad that these ambitions have played a role in the development of this report.  The package recognises the scale of action that is needed to meet the joint challenges of achieving our climate change commitments, conserving our resources, and also beginning to address the disastrous levels of plastics in our environment, particularly in our rivers, seas and oceans. I look forward to voting for this package, but even more to the work that must follow to deliver real change in our society.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Mr President, in a circular economy we would need to produce the same welfare with a tenth of the resources. This regulation is a crucial part of that. We are getting there, but we are still on the way. Firstly, the targets should be more ambitious. The second important point is that there should first be a requirement for a separate collection and then for the sorting of communal waste before incineration, because at the moment incineration is actually part of the problem, rather than part of the solution. Thirdly, regarding methodology, we should have input and output to final recycling in the longer run. To really get where we want to be, the methodologies must be harmonised all over Europe. There are two specific issues: food waste must include the whole food production chain to really achieve prevention. Secondly, regarding marine litter, there should not only be aspirational targets, but also the banning of producers of microplastics.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: - Mr. president. Commissioner, I welcome the package being discussed here today on the circular economy. A package that will be positive for the environment, for the climate, for health and for the economy. I especially welcome the increase in objectives that the rapporteur has worked on, necessary to reverse the pattern of consumption and production that we need, as well as its positive effects on job creation. And it is that in the European Union we have advanced in the last decades in the management of waste, but, to this day, this is still very unequal between countries and municipal waste, in more than a third of the cases, continues to be dumped and less than half are recycled. In short, an ambitious and positive package to change consumption patterns. Now I would also ask the Commission that, to be effective, this package addresses the challenges of financial instruments, technical skills, consumer behaviors and business models of governance, so that - as I say - it is carried out and achieved. these goals.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner. The economy of the Soviet Union was very inefficient. The industry was absolutely polluting - couldn't breathe, black smoke - but in one area, ironically, she was effective. Exactly in terms of consumers, because there were no goods for consumers to buy. There was no waste, it was just paper and glass. Today - including, say, the countries of the former Soviet Union - we have a very wide range of consumers. We have cell phones, we have water in plastic bottles, we have plastic that protects food that she stays on for a long time, and so on. Only all this creates mountains of waste that did not exist before. In addition, we need to import all these raw materials that create these mountains from elsewhere. So, of course, it is right to move towards making more sensible use of our waste, so that we can reuse as much as we can. We do not want to go back to a time when consumers had no choice, but we still have to think about this giant mountain of imported waste, which we need to get rid of.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the crisis we are experiencing can only be overcome by promoting a new development model.We need to grow but in a different way, smarter, more respectful of the environment and people.About 90 million tons of food are wasted every year in the European Union: 170 kilos each.Food waste is a scandal.With the circular economy, we set ourselves the goal of reducing it by 50% by 2030. How?With a clear definition, which there was not, of food waste, which serves the Commission to develop a common methodology to measure its quantity;through education against waste and prevention of waste along the entire production chain;by encouraging a clearer regulatory framework with tax cuts;with the gift of food to the poor.Enough with "do it yourself" and "disposable".A serious policy against food waste can create new and good jobs.

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: - We will soon vote on the revision of European waste legislation, a historic moment. Actually, we should no longer be talking about waste legislation, but about recycling legislation. This is not about waste that we have to get rid of, but about valuable raw materials that we must value. Unfortunately, not all countries are making the same rapid progress in establishing this circular economy. The Netherlands is at the forefront. And that's a shame. It is of vital economic importance for this continent that we make speed and show sufficient ambition. We must phase out the landfill of reusable and recoverable waste. That is the fundamental condition for the real transition to turn Europe into a circular economy. In doing so, we must clearly strengthen cooperation with producers and waste processors. Together we can close the cycle to a true circular economy. And finally: let's get rid of the bureaucratic obstacles to reuse, let's get rid of the lack of ambition and let's get rid of the concept of waste and talk about the utilization of valuable raw materials. We must not leave the Netherlands out in the cold and [...] be able to develop further.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: - Mr President, in any viable scenario for the future of the European Union, the circular economy must occupy one of the central pages. The circular economy is an example of the kind of measures that we need to take so that citizens can feel the favorable impact of our work on their lives. I welcome the excellent work done by the rapporteur, Simona Bonafè, and by the entire team that has worked on this legislative package. With the shadow rapporteurs, I proposed to promote transition and energy efficiency, to phase out landfill until it is completely removed, to ban the disposal in landfills of waste that are the object of separate collection, to create a framework program for scheduling objectives that encourage and further facilitate selective collection, sorting and recycling, monitor the transfer of waste within the European Union and to third countries, that there is an impact study on the opportunity of setting a target for the total amount of waste that can be landfilled, calculated per kilo, per person and per year. The circular economy must be, Mr Commissioner, more than a good narrative. It has to be a concrete and positive reality and we are now in a position to do so.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to congratulate Mrs Bonafè, as well as the shadow rapporteurs, for the great work done on these four reports. The circular economy is not simply the modification of four directives related to ecology, but a powerful tool in the fight against climate change and a change in the economic and production model, for which European industry must be prepared, and we know that it has already begun to adapt. In Catalonia itself, the Bufalvent industrial estate in Manresa is establishing cooperative business practices in waste management that are turning it into a fully circular industrial estate. Like this one, we could find many other similar examples around the Union, which give us hope that the path we are starting today - and for which we will necessarily need the firm commitment of the Council - will be a success that will help reindustrialization of Europe, help to create new jobs and consolidate a much more sustainable economic growth, with low emissions and adapted to the commitments reached at the COP.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: - Vehicles are a source of vehicle components that can continue to work and scrap. Millions of used cars sail from Western Europe to Central and Eastern Europe and other Member States, where they end their lives. Who will bear the social and environmental costs of their dismantling and further development? It is therefore urgent to create an EU market for secondary raw materials. These raw materials should be classified and standardized. Waste electrical equipment could be subject to similar procedures. It is difficult to collect and disassemble. The regulations burdening the producer with this task do not pass the test. Accumulators and batteries are too cheap and their collection is not adequately stimulated. Lead prices driven by Chinese competition are also not encouraging this. Electronic scrap has not been transformed into efficient ecological and energy-saving technologies, and energy efficiency is, in my opinion, the driving force behind the circular economy.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: - Mr President, Mr Vice-President, I am delighted that we can finally have this discussion on the challenges of the circular economy. This Parliament wanted it, the meeting is there, and I thank Mrs Bonafè for all the work she was able to do. Basically, when we look at the future of the European economy, the question of the circular economy is a very central question. But it cannot be just circular, it must also be united. For this, the place of companies in the social and solidarity economy must be at the heart of the strategy we are implementing. This is what Mrs Bonafè's report does and I thank her for it. The fact remains that, when we talk about municipal waste for which we set targets, I believe that it is a completely winning strategy, but for it to really be so, we must ensure that, in these municipal waste, which today constitutes a large part of household congestion - namely waste electrical and electronic equipment - is included in these quotas which could be reused or reused. From this point of view, in many situations, there are logistics platforms for producers, which means that this waste is perhaps not automatically considered as household waste. It is a point of vigilance to which I draw your attention.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: - Mr President, I come from a country that has a long way to go in terms of waste management. With the reports we are discussing today, we are changing not just the goals for recycling, landfilling, but the philosophy with which we operate. From the linear model "production-consumption-disposal" we are transferred to a new model of sustainable development with the least possible waste. The goal is to close the cycle, with priority on reuse and recycling. With the right incentives, the circular economy model can contribute to the creation of new jobs. Especially in Greece it is an opportunity to modernize the way we manage garbage, improving the environment and creating growth conditions. Finally, I would like to thank Mrs Bonafè very much for the very good work she has done and for accepting my proposal to introduce mandatory oil collection and recycling targets.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: - Let me start, like many before me, by thanking our rapporteur, Mrs Bonafè, for her incredible hard work. Not only did she bring the whole file to a fantastic success together with the shadow rapporteurs, [...] we will see later in the vote, but also on behalf of our group, together with the other groups, took the lead to put this high at the top of the political agenda. You yourself referred to it, Commissioner, in your introduction. In the beginning it was somewhat difficult for the Commission and Parliament to find each other in this story. We have now done so: we have an ambitious package in front of us and that is crucial for our group, because in our opinion it is about so much more than a waste package, about so much more than an environmental file. This is essentially about our economy: how to change our economy, how to make it truly sustainable and, as the Commission assessment also points out, how we create jobs, often local ones too. This is actually the summary of what is important in this file, and this means that it is the beginning of a number of more steps to come. After all, it cannot only be about waste, it must of course also be about the design of our products and how our economy converts this into a truly circular experience. For example, it is also about a sharing economy: how can we move from owning products to sharing our products or renting our products? There is a much more sustainable way to look at it. In any case, I wish ourselves a fantastic vote, within the overall objectives of the European Union.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: - (FI) Mr President, six hundred million tonnes of raw materials are dumped in landfills in Europe every year, which could be recovered and reused. This is an issue that is both economically and environmentally important when we deal with this circular economy package. This will also have an impact on European competitiveness. Europe is highly dependent on imported raw materials, with up to 40% of raw materials being imported from outside Europe, and up to 90% for certain critical raw materials. These are very important for the electronics industry. This circular economy package can significantly boost innovation and increase resource-wise activity. Certainly there are still many details that will need to be negotiated in the future. It is essential that we have a coherent knowledge base of what the various countries are at now, so that we can set sufficiently ambitious yet realistic targets. Today's circular economy package is a major step towards a more environmentally and economically sustainable Europe.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the transition from a linear economy to a circular model is a necessity rather than a choice for modern society. Today the Earth takes a year and a half to regenerate the resources we extract and use in a year. The revision of the directives we are discussing today is only a first step to push the company to reinvent its lifestyle and, therefore, to conceive a new production system in which products are designed to last and can be repaired, reused, recycled, regenerated and in which the harmful synthetic or fossil-based components are replaced by biological alternatives. It is essential to pursue an industrial transition towards an economic system that takes the environment first and foremost. A 30% resource productivity improvement by 2030 would translate, for example, into a 1% increase in GDP, create more than two million new jobs and place us on a virtuous, more efficient path under the resource profile and most beneficial for the related ecological, economic and social benefits.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the transition to a more circular economy offers great opportunities for Europe and its citizens. European society consumes renewables 50% faster than it can replace them, while the European Union imports six times more raw materials and natural resources than it exports. That is why a circular economy must be created with the rule of reuse and recycling. This transition is particularly important from an economic point of view, as there will be significant benefits and enhanced competitiveness. Thanks to it, environmental benefits and significant energy savings are achieved. Local jobs are created. The total benefits will reach 1.8 trillion euros. It will create 2 million jobs and increase the European Union's competitiveness in the world market. Finally, in order to achieve the 2030 targets, emphasis must be placed on innovation, research, science and the circular economy model.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Mr. President, our reality is still far from all our desires. I give strong support to the logic of the circular economy, to try to prevent food waste, to resolve, as far as possible, all the pollution we have in our seas, our oceans, the Baltic Sea, the Adriatic Sea, the Mediterranean Sea and everywhere else where we have such pollution. But what I want to emphasize on this occasion is the following: Croatia is a country that, unfortunately, has a very low rate of waste recycling. However, there is one county in Croatia, the County of Istria, at the head of which I had the honor of being 12 years old, which, by building a regional waste management center, has largely resolved waste management.
