But now, because the European Union once funded that regional waste management center with a € 30 million grant, we have some changes in government policy when it comes to waste management. We do not want those who were the best to be penalized.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: - Mr President, I think the most important thing we have to say is that we produce things that we do not use. There has been a lot of debate in Parliament recently on the issue of chargers. The iPhone 4 has a different charger than the iPhone six. Millions of miles or miles of electric wire go for recycling, if it goes for recycling! I am of the opinion that glass bottles should not be damaged in order for glass to be recycled. They must be washed to be returned; I dare not tell you that the same must be true of plastics. But what a nice conversation about the circular economy! The company Monsanto, dear colleagues, produces seeds that can not germinate afterwards. What a beautiful world! There is no recycling of seeds! If this is not a crime against humanity, I do not know what else can be described as such.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, today we are discussing the circular economy package, which goes beyond reducing the focus on waste management and recycling, marking a time for redesigning processes, products and new business models. The linear model paradigm no longer answers the contemporary challenges of resource availability, environmental and social problems arising from the globalization of markets, the conservation of natural capital, the reduction of emissions and the fight against climate change. The landfill replacement directive will make it possible to clarify the waste hierarchy that determines an order of priority, from prevention, through preparation, to reuse, recycling and energy recovery to final disposal. Landfill, although it is the worst option according to the waste hierarchy, remains the most widely used waste disposal method in the European Union. We have to change the way we collect and manage our waste. Transforming waste into a resource is crucial to increase resource efficiency and close the loop in a circular economy. This landfill directive responds precisely to this ambition.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, I would like to emphasize the complexity of the reports and the work of the rapporteurs. Waste management and recycling, but also the avoidance of excessive waste production are important objectives. I believe that we should take this into account when setting targets for different waste groups and the capacity for investment in research, investment in education and investment in technology. I think it would be very important to develop inspection and control tools to ensure that Member States prevent the declassification of hazardous waste through mixing activities. However, I cannot claim from the report the exemption from the registration of companies transporting non-hazardous waste in quantities of less than 20 tonnes, respectively two tonnes per year of hazardous waste, because there is a risk of illegal shipments of waste. Another thing I cannot support is the proposed targets and that is why I will opt for the Commission's option.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Members very much for this inspiring debate. Our waste package is part of our circular economy package and the circular economy package is part of a much broader societal change leading to a sustainable society. Part of that is a sustainable economy, sustainable social systems and a sustainable environment.  Sometimes in our work it is nice to do things, but here it is necessary to do things. I maintain that the longer we wait with the waste package and the less ambitious we are with the waste package, the higher the cost will be. We need to make this transition anyway, so we had better do it quickly. It is my true belief – and I have been around for a couple of decades – that, if Europe takes the lead – even if it makes ambitious choices – the rest of the world will follow. We saw it with the norms we had in the internal market and we will see it with the norms we have on waste. I am absolutely sure about this.  Those countries that are worried because they are lagging behind should actually be comforted by the fact that, if you are lagging behind, the changes that you make will have an even greater impact than the changes made by countries which are leading. By the way, EFSI funds are available for investment in this, so, if you make the investment, the gains will be huge and you will make the transition to a sustainable economy more quickly than others. We are simplifying things because we are reducing four methodologies into one methodology, which creates clarity for everyone involved.  Finally, let me say this: in the approach that we have chosen, we have been inclusive from the start. This is the first time that I can see that everybody who is a stakeholder in this is on board. Sadly, in this peculiar world of ours, it takes three to tango, as we know. Now, after you have voted, Parliament and the Commission will have to confront the Council and make sure that we get Member States and the Council on board for an ambitious plan, but again I think that the Commission’s proposals are the best basis for this. I applaud Parliament for being more ambitious. The more ambition we can get through with the Council, the better it works. We will try to do this together with you in the next couple of months.  (Applause)

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: rapporteur. - In the minute I have available, I want to thank all the colleagues who have spoken and who have emphasized the many issues in this package and also the problems that are still open. I am aware of the difference in the waste management system of the Member States and I want to say loud and clear that no state should be left behind. From this point of view, I am pleased that Vice President Timmermans recalled the importance of the EFSI. But to those who say that we are going to increase the costs in the bill for citizens, President, then I want to answer that those who profess to be sovereign should know that we do not decide the tariffs here but the Member States decide them, indeed the municipalities decide them. And I would also like to remind you that it is precisely by increasing recycling that we make quality secondary raw materials available on the market, which produce profits and which truly allow citizens to lower their bills. Finally, I welcome the words of Vice-President Timmermans, whom I see as an outstretched hand for the next steps and I am convinced that we could do a good job at the trialogue.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Tuesday, 14 March 2017. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: in writing. - This revision is an opportunity to put in place a policy aimed at limiting the withdrawal of natural resources while optimizing recycling. But we must remain pragmatic and realistic about the direction we want to give to European policies. Going too far, too fast, without analyzing what is achievable will only reinforce Euroscepticism and undermine what we are trying to build. We need to come up with high but achievable goals and a workable calculation method. What we will vote on today is going in the right direction since we are putting in place a real logic in this area with a harmonization of definitions, a stimulation of waste prevention, reuse and the secondary raw materials market. We also evoke an important line of reflection on the consideration of industrial and commercial waste. I would like to come back to the fight against food waste. The foundations for the establishment of a real policy to fight against waste are laid in this package and I welcome it: a proposal for a European definition, the taking into account of a specific hierarchy and the call for establishment of a common methodology.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: in writing.- The aim of the European Union, resulting from the implementation of the circular economy, is to reduce the amount of waste as well as to improve the efficiency and quality of recycling.To meet these intentions, both efficient waste management and a more rigorous approach to production processes that avoid toxic substances that hinder reuse and recycling of these products are necessary.Therefore, the principles of the circular economy should treat all stages leading to obtaining a finished product and its use equally, in a way that minimizes their impact on the environment.Let us remember that only a fully functional circular economy can contribute to guaranteeing the European Union a lasting competitive advantage and protecting enterprises from resource scarcity.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: In written form. - Increasing resource efficiency and creating an economy that is closer to the circular economy will benefit the environment and reduce our dependence on imports of raw materials through their reuse. In addition, the circular economy model has the potential to create new jobs and generate sustainable growth by improving the competitiveness of European companies in the field of clean technologies and innovation. It is high time to look at this waste as a resource. I believe that in our efforts to move to a circular economy, we must set ambitious but realistic goals that take into account the existing waste management infrastructure, as well as the differences in the level of development and use of technology between Member States. Countries for which the achievement of the set goals is not realistic within the set deadlines should be given additional time for their realization. Additional investments will be needed to achieve the new goals. That is why the European Commission must support circular economy projects in the Member States through the EU's structural and investment funds.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: written. - Each of us produces waste, and so waste issues come close to everyone. The report talks about a wide range of bio-waste, but I would now like to draw attention to one form of bio-waste, food waste. The adopted waste directive now includes a target to reduce food waste. A distribution obligation is one way to reduce waste and direct food to those who need it. The principle is that shops or city or state facilities should not dispose of edible food if aid organizations come to apply for it for distribution for relief purposes. Shops, schools or other institutions do not have to arrange the distribution or transport of food themselves, only not to destroy edible food if the aid organization is willing and able to distribute it to those who need it. In France, for example, a law has already been passed that supermarkets are not allowed to throw away or destroy food. The matter is also being discussed in the Finnish Parliament, signed by more than a hundred members of parliament. It is unfortunate that my concrete amendment did not reach the final directive, but it is an available model for countries that must now reduce food waste in accordance with the directive. I see the obligation to distribute as an important part of reducing food waste and bio-waste, as well as a way to increase the value of food and help people.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written. - In the case of the opinion for which I have been responsible in the ITRE Committee, that of waste dumping, we value the introduction of hierarchy in waste management to avoid incineration and dumping as much as possible. However, it is worrying that the management of this process falls massively on the private sector and that incineration continues to be promoted as an alternative to landfills (even with advantages for the entry of energy to the grid) when in some regions its environmental impact may be higher. I also want to highlight that we have introduced very important proposals, such as the progressive closure of landfills, public consultation in municipalities and other affected stakeholders, recovery of closed landfills, auditing of existing landfills and greater control of landfills. waste. In Spain (with four sentences pending enforcement on illegal landfills) landfills continue to be used, unfortunately, on a massive scale. Impact evaluations are avoided via the expansion of capacity, their use levels are not controlled, etc. causing environmental emergencies and against public health that we hope the new directive will help to combat.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: signed up. - The circular economy package must ensure coherence between the 4 dossiers, so that a transition to a waste recycling economy and a long-term consolidation of this transition can be ensured. It must be borne in mind that the protection of the environment and human health is directly proportional to improving waste management at European level and the recovery of primary resources, on the one hand, and increasing energy efficiency and reducing the Union's dependence on raw materials, on the other. other side. The European Union can reduce the import of raw materials if it has a sustainable circular economy strategy supported by a clear legislative framework capable of transmitting viable signals to investors. Therefore, European legislation must include clear definitions for waste and recycling and mandatory targets. The objectives proposed by the European Commission must first and foremost be realistic and achievable for all Member States. If this is not taken into account, the EU will face the risk of fragmentation of the internal market, which will mean uneven development in this area, which must be avoided.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- The aim of the circular economy is to avoid waste and to keep materials in circulation for as long as possible.This approach promotes the EU economy and competition and helps to protect the environment.This creates more jobs and profitable re-use prevents the use of excessive new resources.The EU must therefore set new targets and update directives covering both waste and landfill.New limits are set for the disposal of municipal and packaging waste, which is mandatory for all Member States, some of which have time derogations.Estonia is also covered by the exception for municipal waste.It is important to know that, although the Commission is developing common goals that all countries must achieve, the way to achieve them is for each country to do.It is therefore important to raise awareness at national level as well.In the future, we could come to the conclusion that waste is not a problem but a resource.

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: written. - The Member States set themselves the objective of identifying measures that the European Commission should implement in relation to the so-called "circular economy". The ultimate aim of the new European circular economy package is to promote the transition from a linear economy, in which the maxim of "use and throw away" prevails, to a circular economy in which waste is reduced to a minimum and considered as useful resources . In short, it is about ensuring that products can be reused after reaching the end of their useful life. In this way, in addition to creating value, we will be able to influence climate change and the environment and we will promote global competitiveness, sustainable economic growth and job creation. The generation of waste is a heterogeneous reality that makes it difficult to reuse it as a quality raw material, because there is no adequate separation and classification from the source. It is also well known that each Member State separates unevenly, even between regions of the same State; Therefore, we hope that the new regulations guarantee the quality of the waste generated and with it the quality of the raw materials so that they are truly reusable.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: written.- I support Mrs Bonafè's important and well-written report on the development of the circular economy.I would like to underline that the circular economy cannot function without the participation of the general public.We need more involvement of citizens, politicians, civil servants, universities and research institutes, as well as representatives of various companies.The circular economy is not just about recycling, processing, conversion and reuse, but about the utilization of the entire value chain.The words "public", "awareness", "citizen" or "consumer" are mentioned too infrequently and too seldom presented in an active role.There is a clear opportunity to involve all EU citizens more as a community in climate change.This is something that touches us all.Citizens must not be left as mere audiences, but must be involved as active players.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. – Today we vote on an important set of proposals to increase recycling and reduce waste in Europe. Every day we throw away valuable raw materials and increase our environmental footprint, depleting our planet’s finite resources. Such actions undermine our own policies on resource efficiency and simply defy common sense. While under-nutrition remains a severe problem in many parts of the world, we still throw away up to one third of our food. And it’s not just a question of wasting the food. There are huge environmental and health impacts of using water, energy, fertilizers, pesticides, and packaging to produce and transport food which is ultimately thrown away. I am pleased that the Environment Committee supported my proposals for a definition of food waste. This is a basic requirement for monitoring and reducing such waste, but it is still lacking at European level.

name: Bart STAES
text: written. - We want the Member States to take preventive measures and reduce food waste by 30% by 2025 and by 50% by 2030. The total food loss and by-products in Flanders amounts to approximately 2 million tonnes annually. We need to be more careful with our natural resources, soil, water use and stop transporting food over many kilometers. I am delighted that we are making these targets binding. Food waste encompasses the entire production process. This also includes food waste. Most importantly, this definition enables policymakers to detect obvious causes, measure quantities, compare results and determine a common strategy throughout the chain. The circular economy legislative package integrates four laws on waste. It is good that there is a plea for an almost complete phasing out of waste dumping. By 2030, only 5% of our household waste will be allowed to end up in landfills. This is ambitious, also because it is combined with a higher target for recycling waste (70%). This will prevent Member States from incinerating all waste. The Parliament now has the mandate to negotiate the final legal texts with the Council (Member States) and the Commission.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. - Due to the European Union's dependence on raw material imports, the key challenge is to retain as many resources within the Union as possible and to increase efforts in the transition to a circular economy. It offers great opportunities and potential for local economies, and would benefit all participants involved. This would result in significant savings for all consumers and reduce total annual greenhouse gas emissions. Greenhouse gas emissions could be reduced by between two and four percent a year. The circular economy should be an integral part of climate policy. An important measure is the use of production residues as by-products in order to bring real non-waste resources into the production cycle. A clear regulatory framework needs to be defined at EU level. In order to achieve the credibility and comparability of Member States' results, the definition of municipal waste needs to be aligned with that established by Eurostat and the OECD for statistical reasons. The definition must, in combination with a harmonized uniform method of calculation for all Member States, be based on final recycling data and supported by an effective reporting system to prevent landfilled waste disposed of or incinerated as listed as recycled waste. Reuse and recycling are key to creating new policies to improve sustainability, making waste a resource a resource.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: In written form. - Ladies and gentlemen, improving waste management has an unconditionally positive impact on the protection of the environment and the health of European citizens. Today, in the era of the circular economy, we must clearly realize that the recycling and reuse of more and more waste should become a mandatory and conscious element of our way of life and part of our economic culture. I therefore welcome the four pieces of Commission legislation in this area that deserve to be supported. At the same time, and in the spirit of the European directives in this area, I consider it absolutely necessary to take into account the economic effectiveness of the proposed measures in order to achieve a less and bearable social burden in the pursuit of recycling targets. The very ambitious goals set by Parliament must also be accompanied by flexibility measures in the Member States in order to achieve a socially affordable price in implementing this policy. There is hardly anyone who can deny the need to recycle and reuse waste in a resource-poor Europe for which it is vital to reduce its dependence on imports of such resources. That is why I fully support a sensible approach and consistency in the implementation of the new measures.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Before moving on to the communication, I give the floor to Mr Dartmouth.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: – Mr President, I have a point of order. I rise under Rule 11(3). Last year the Conference of Presidents appointed Mr Guy Verhofstadt as the European Parliament’s Brexit negotiator, but Mr Verhofstadt has in addition four outside jobs. That’s four. Three of these jobs pay up to EUR 5 000 per month and one of them pays more than EUR 10 000 per month. As we all know, Mr Verhofstadt is of course a man of integrity, a man of honour and a man of probity. But how, therefore, can a man of Mr Verhofstadt’s integrity in good conscience carry out and fulfil all his responsibilities in his four outside jobs and be the European Parliament’s Brexit negotiator? I would ask that this appointment be reconsidered.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: – Mr President, as the British Parliament passed the Brexit bill yesterday evening and Article 50 will be triggered by the end of the month, you should urge the Brexiteers in this House to give up leadership positions before the April part—session. Is it not absurd that Mr Farage, who wants to destroy the EU, gets almost 260 daily allowances a year without doing any work in the committees in this House? If he were to stand by his convictions, he would refuse the privileges of those who want to remain in the EU.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you for your suggestion.This is not the session to discuss Brexit.There will be long and important discussions on this topic.I would say move on to today's jobs.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Mr President, I would like to ask Vice-President Timmermans if the absence of the responsible Commissioner on the Internal Market, Bieńkowska, or the Vice-President responsible, Katainen, this morning to present the revision of the firearms directive was justified, or if it was a deliberate decision to have the Home Affairs Commissioner to present an internal market legislation. This Parliament spent one year to tell the Commission that it is not an anti-terror law. It is because we have freedom of movement that we need to have minimum common rules in the internal market. Why do you not listen to us and make it so difficult to put the facts on the ground on what this directive is about?

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, a tragedy occurred two days ago in Ethiopia with more than 60 people, mostly women and children, losing their lives in a landslide at a rubbish dump. This happened in a country which is a major recipient of funds from the EU. As well as expressing our solidarity with the people of Ethiopia, we should ask the Commission to enquire into the level of misgovernance and oppression that the EU is funding in Ethiopia today, where people are losing their lives at the mercy of a dictatorship which is totally anti-democratic.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I have decided to impose a sanction on Mr Korwin-Mikke for the remarks he made on women during the plenary sitting of 1 March 2017 in the course of the debate on the gender pay gap, chaired by a woman, Vice-President Gebhardt. (Applause) I consider that these remarks constituted a violation of the principle laid down in Rule 11 of our Internal Rules of Procedure. Therefore, in accordance with Rule 166 of the Rules of Procedure, and having taken note of the written observation that Mr Korwin-Mikke has submitted, I have decided to impose the following penalties. The first: a forfeiture of his entitlement to the daily allowances for a period of 30 days. Additionally, without prejudice to the right to vote in plenary, the temporary suspension from participation in all the activities of Parliament for a period of 10 days starting from today. Furthermore, Mr Korwin-Mikke is prohibited from representing Parliament on any interparliamentary delegations, interparliamentary conferences or any interinstitutional forums for a period of one year starting from today. (Applause) The decision has been communicated to the Member concerned.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is voting time.(For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, pursuant to Article 59, paragraph 3 and paragraph 4 of the internal regulations, and with the aim that the provisional agreement reached ... ("sorry, shut up ... fuck it", addressing without a microphone to another MEP) ... with the aim that the provisional agreement reached with the Council takes into account the will of European citizens to eliminate a very dangerous substance such as mercury from dental fillings ... (The President interrupted the speaker: "Can you speak slower for the interpreters, please? If you can speak slower, for the translation?") ("Fuck you", the deputy turning to another deputy without a microphone, "... asshole ...") ... take into account the willingness of European citizens to remove a very dangerous substance such as mercury from dental fillings, I ask the name of the EFDD Group that our amendments to the draft legislative act be put to the vote before the provisional agreement.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: - Mister President!We have just discussed that improper behavior cannot be tolerated, and I refuse that the colleague, just because he feels disturbed, turns around charmingly and shouts vaffanculo!This is behavior that I will not put up with, and I ask you to check it out and to punish it accordingly!

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: We will hear the recording and then of course the procedure will start.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, in application of Rule 59, paragraph 3, of our Rules of Procedure I would like to request on behalf of the ALDE Group to vote on the amendments before the vote on the provisional agreement. The plenary has never had the opportunity to take a position on this important text, as it was negotiated directly by the Committee. Therefore I ask all my colleagues to vote in favour of this request, which will simply allow all Members to express their opinion.

name: Vicky FORD
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, as I understand it, this is a request to vote on the amendments before we vote on the substantive vote, and I am aware of the amendments that have been tabled by colleagues for today’s votes. The issues they raise are not new. These amendments are the same as those that have been debated in committee, discussed with the Council and ultimately rejected by the Member States, and there is no reason to believe that the Member States have changed their minds. If we adopt these amendments, we will destabilise the entire agreement. It will overturn the first reading position that this Parliament has fought for, and the hard work that we have done to secure practical solutions to allow sport shooters, hunters, collectors, reservists and other legal owners to continue with their sports. If these amendments go through, it will move into a second reading, where, under the process of this Parliament, Parliament has far less say, and the voice of legal owners will therefore not be heard. If you vote through those amendments, we lose all the hard work that has been done and the success that Parliament has had in improving the text. The Commission’s original proposal was not acceptable, but that is not what we are voting on today. If you pass these amendments, you destabilise the whole negotiation and the benefits that we have brought in place for the legal owners. (Applause)

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: rapporteur.- (IT) Mr President, in accordance with Rule 59 (4) of the Rules of Procedure, I propose to refer the matter to the committee responsible for the opening of interinstitutional negotiations.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: rapporteur.- (IT) Mr President, on this issue too, in accordance with Rule 59 (4) of the Rules of Procedure, I propose that the matter be referred back to the committee responsible for initiating interinstitutional negotiations.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: rapporteur.- (IT) Mr President, again in accordance with Rule 59 (4) of the Rules of Procedure, I also propose for this report that the matter be referred back to the competent committee and that the interinstitutional negotiations begin.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: rapporteur.- (IT) Mr President, for the last time, again in accordance with Rule 59 (4) of the Rules of Procedure, I propose that the matter be referred back to the committee responsible for initiating the interinstitutional negotiations.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Equine husbandry is an important source of livelihood for a number of industries in Europe, such as agriculture, local tourism and ecotourism and, last but not least, equestrian sports and racing. In Member States like mine, Bulgaria, horses are part of the way of life and traditions of the local population. I therefore welcome the inclusion in the report of my proposal for more financial support for the conservation and protection of local breeds in view of the danger of their extinction. Bulgarian breeds such as the Karakachan, East Bulgarian, Danube and Pleven horses fall into this category and I believe that, like other indigenous breeds, they should be protected and their breeding should be further financially stimulated. I also welcome the inclusion of my proposal for more educational and community initiatives aimed at a wider segment of users and professionals. This would help to raise awareness of the problems and opportunities in the development of the sector. I call on the European Commission to take concrete initiatives and measures as soon as possible in relation to the proposals in this report.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: - (IT) Mr President, I voted in favor of this report because the equidae sector is a great resource in rural areas. For example, horses are a fundamental part of farms but their use is also growing in other sectors, different from the traditional ones of agriculture and sport. Horses are increasingly used in tourism and in the training sector, for example, they are animals with extraordinary qualities for rehabilitation for the disabled, for the education of children, for the training of children with difficulties. The presence of horses in increasingly disparate contexts, however, exposes them to risks for their health and well-being. For this, I believe, an ever greater institutional commitment is necessary for their protection and control. In my region, Sicily, there are some important realities that work for the increase in horse racing but, at the same time, there are very serious cases of exploitation such as the phenomenon of clandestine races run by the mafia. Each state and each region has its own traditions that it is right to respect: but it is equally right to make horse owners more responsible.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: - Mr Chairman! I voted in favor of this report, which deals with the responsible approach to the ownership and care of equidae, as I believe that it will help to standardize the treatment of animals in different Member States and thus solve the problem - or at least to some extent improve - the treatment of these animals . The equine sector in the Union has great economic potential, creating jobs and contributing to many sectors: sports, research, medicine and food production. For this reason, in recent years the high demand for equidae has led to uncontrolled reproduction of lower quality animals. Many Member States have seen a significant increase in the abandonment of equidae, and hence more abuse and suffering of equidae. The report includes a package of measures to improve and combat the welfare of equidae. The recommendations include the issuing of comprehensive guidelines for the care of horses and donkeys and the development of new guidelines for food products made from these animals. I believe that these recommendations are extremely important, and that the report is an important step in improving the situation of equidae in the European Union.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, this report contains many, many important aspects but paragraphs 49 and 50 – where we talk about the differences in health requirements for horsemeat produced in Europe and for horsemeat imported into Europe from third countries – are particularly pertinent. This is an issue that has been raised by many colleagues, not just in my Member State of Ireland, and it is a problem that the Commission is aware of, although thus far it has either decided not to do anything or is unable to do anything. The vote for this report today repeats our message to the Commission that consumers do not want different standards for horsemeat produced within the EU and horsemeat that is imported. I was surprised to learn that over 75% of horsemeat is imported into Europe – so we rely heavily on imports – and that, as a result of our strict standards in Europe, half of our horses are excluded from the food chain, even though they could usefully be included. And given that we are going to vote on food waste, maybe this is an issue that needs to be looked at.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: - (IT) Mr President, I voted in favor of this report because it is absolutely necessary to limit the use of a harmful substance such as mercury as much as possible. For years we have poisoned ourselves and poisoned our citizens with the uncontrolled use - unconscious I would say - of one of the worst pollutants in the world. The result on the use for medical purposes is appreciable but much still needs to be done, because a lot of mercury is still in the soil and in the waters. The European Union must intervene to save those territories, such as the so-called triangle of death in Sicily, where the petrochemical industries have destroyed the environment and dramatically compromised the health of citizens. It is essential that, in the first place, contaminated sites are identified and treated in respect of the environment, so as to put an end to the pollution of nature and exposed populations who often already suffer the economic consequences deriving from the closure of industries which, with the blackmail for a monthly salary, they have been poisoning them for decades.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - So mercury is one of the most dangerous substances and poses a global risk to both human and animal health.It is actually found everywhere, it is found in waters, it is found in fish, in seafood, it is also found in nature and it really is one particular cause for concern about environmental pollution.I think that this report, which we are talking about, is indeed a good basis for respecting the commitments made within the United Nations, and above all those key points from this report regarding dental amalgams and waste and the use of exports, export restrictions andand, of course, warnings that are important in order to protect ourselves from the harmful effects of this substance.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mister President! I voted against the report on the acquisition and possession of weapons today because almost all the claims and reasons why we need this report are false. The fact that just five days after the terrible attack on the Bataclan Club in Paris the Commission presented a draft to tighten up the Weapons Directive is, for me, an indication that this idea had obviously been with the Commission for a long time and that it was only taken out of the drawer. when the timing was right. In other words, clear legislation on the occasion, actionism, where one consciously wanted to meet hunters, shooters and gatherers. I now come to the essential point of my criticism. On the face of it, the Commission claims that this regulation is intended to combat terrorism. This claim is flimsy. It is clear to every reasonable citizen that terrorists - criminals - buy their weapons on the black market in the Darknet and not from an arms dealer around the corner or officially on the Internet. In truth, this directive mocks the legal gun owners - the hunters, the shooters and the gatherers -. With this guideline, the legal gun owners are placed under general suspicion. However, this directive actually represents willful maltreatment of the citizens. It would be much more important if we were to tighten up actual smuggling and border controls, or if we even think about it and ask where these weapons come from. You can import tons of Kalashnikovs from the former Yugoslavia if you want if you are on the illegal side. That is, it also brings additional costs, additional bureaucracy for our citizens, the harassment that this directive presents for law-abiding gun owners. We should not be surprised that there will certainly be states that either do not implement this directive or implement it hesitantly. We We should not be surprised either that the citizens are moving further and further away from this centralized EU policy.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: - Mr President!The proposal for a weapons directive that is on the table is hasty.There will be no problems with illegal shootings and terrorism, but it will only make life more difficult for hunters and snipers.Does anyone think that those who plan to carry out illegal shootings want to end up in the police's weapons checks and submit to all the checks that a person who legally owns weapons must go through?Of course not!Therefore, this Directive misses its target.Instead, it affects hunters and snipers.The directive also contains unclear terms and many national exceptions.According to the proposal, Switzerland will be completely exempt from these rules, while Sweden will have them.Is it reasonable?You try to limit the magazine capacity without defining magazines.I'm sorry but you have to reject this directive - it's just common sense.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: - Mr President! We have voted through a good balance between security and freedom, which does not change the situation for snipers and hunters. I am surprised that so many inaccuracies are being spread through the media and in Parliament. What is the source? Have you read the text? From the Liberals to the Sweden Democrats, I have not heard in what way it affects hunters, in what way it affects snipers, in what way it does not increase security. You criticize without telling why. It is easy to pick up the finger and feel where the wind is blowing and just be against. The debate must be based on facts. Nine mislead the people with inaccuracies. It is you who create dissatisfaction, it is pure populism, it is irresponsible. Many of those who criticize, such as Jasenko Selimović, do so in the eleventh hour. Have you not seen it before in negotiations? What have you done to improve the directive? Why do not you say that it has fundamentally changed the original proposal in a democratic way? Why do not you tell us that our legal gun owners can continue their leisure activities and keep their guns? There will be no mandatory medical check-up, no ban on distance selling or time-limited licenses. It's not an anti-terror law. It's about controlling legal weapons. There are dangerous loopholes that really need to be fixed immediately, such as acoustic weapons used by Charlie Hebdo.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, I voted against this Commission proposal. There were some areas that I was able to support, but they were nowhere near enough to protect the interests of the United Kingdom organisations with which I met over the preceding months leading to today’s vote. The key objectives to thwart terrorism and the transfer of illegal weapons for terrorist purposes will never be delivered by this particular proposal. They will not be delivered because of the fundamental pillar of the single market: the freedom of movement, people, services and goods. All the time that fundamental pillar is in place, nothing is going to change the access and transfer of weapons – whether they are there for lawful or unlawful purposes – within the European Union Member States. That means that the single market, because of its issues that I have explained, is outdated, dangerous and out of touch, given the sort of proposals that this Chamber has considered today.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, I voted against the adoption of this directive because I fear the uncertainty in its application and, therefore, the fundamental concern of legal holders.Above all, I consider it a mistake that it was not possible to vote on the specific amendments that we tabled and which we still wanted to correct this directive.I consider it unacceptable to criminalize the possession of magazines over 20 or 10 rounds.With its vote, the European Parliament de facto rejected our proposals en bloc and approved a compromise, for which I did not vote, but I must also acknowledge that this is a solution that is significantly better than originally presented by the European Commission.I don't think there's any reason for any hysteria, because the current holders will be able to keep the weapons.What I am afraid of is rather uncertainty in application and unnecessarily compromising the original proposal to combat terrorism.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: - Mr President, this directive, drawn up - in an emergency, it is true - after the Paris attacks, completely misses its stated objective because everyone knows full well that terrorists and criminals - as has been said by many other speakers - obviously do not buy their guns legally. The only ones penalized will therefore be the hundreds of thousands of sports shooters, collectors and hunters who will be listed and overwritten, while in many of our countries, they are already controlled and are sometimes even subject to multiple constraints which border on persecution. Some are happy that the compromise is better than the initial Commission text. Indeed, we avoided a generalized theft and the final destruction of historic weapons, but we came very close. Fundamentally, this text remains ideological in the first place. It is about making people believe that the European Union is fighting terrorism, when its policies favor it. I say "ideological" because its principle stems from an obvious detestation of gun owners, even when it comes to honest citizens.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Mr President, I voted against this weapons directive because it is full of mistakes and smiling not only to experts but also to the general public.If we want to fight terrorism, we have to fight terrorism, but we do not have to link the directive to the fight against terrorism, a directive that actually restricts the legal possession of weapons.I simply lack logic here at all about this directive, and I think when we look back at our decision today, which did not allow us to vote on the amendments, we will consider it very, very wrong.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: – Mr President, I welcome today’s vote on improving EU gun control. I was privileged to chair the trilogue negotiations, and I want to thank the rapporteur and shadows for all their hard work. We will see improved conditions for authorisation requirements and safe storage. We will see a revised categorisation aimed at increasing public security. We will see that activities of collectors will be covered by this directive, closing the existing legal loophole, and we will see easier rules of traceability. Thanks to the key role played by the S&D Group, the revised directive on the acquisition and possession of firearms in the EU will ensure that public security will be strengthened via better exchange of information among authorities. We will see more stringent rules on deactivation and use of the most dangerous semi-automatic firearms, and better monitoring systems for checking the medical conditions of users. At the same time, the rights of legal owners and users will be preserved. I thank all who have been involved in this, and I look forward to the speedy application of this directive.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, I voted against this proposal and I want to say, although, of course, there has been some improvement on the Commission's originally very disastrous proposal, that I do not think that these improvements are enough to support the proposal. I therefore voted against this report, saying that I would first of all like to condemn the procedure that was followed in plenary here, when our amendments, which were tabled and applied according to the procedural rules, were not actually voted on. I do not understand why my proposals, for example, were not voted on when I applied them properly, and I am not a member of the relevant committee. So I think that really should have been discussed today. Above all, in the report that I have presented, I want to condemn the way in which it affects legal arms holders. If they do not commit any terrorist attacks, their impact on crime is very minimal, then I do not understand such dramatic effects on their legal status. In my opinion, it is first and foremost necessary to tackle terrorism, and I do not think that was the solution.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Mr Chairman!Sir Julian King has made it clear that the European Commission wants even greater gun control than is foreseen in the current report, and these proposals are a typical example of anti-policy pursued by the current European Union authorities.The answer to terrorism is to be even greater control of our own citizens, and anti-Western hate centers only need to be careful, because they are not dangerous until they are radicalized.The Council's decision to effectively combat the organized smuggling of illegal migrants - soon two years from them - has only been replaced by essentially humanitarian operations, and the states defending Europe's border are under attack for defending Europe's borders.There is no consent to increase the powers of this authority, and even less to greater control of our citizens.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – Mr President, I voted against the amendments on principle. What is the fundamental difference between a free man and a slave? The difference is that a slave is not allowed to possess weapons. He is not allowed to bear weapons. Terrorism is a pretext. You are afraid of your own people. You are afraid of the revolt of the slaves. I am not afraid of my people. I am afraid of you. You are the enemy of the people, not the people themselves. So I voted against and, moreover, I think that the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, I supported the legislative package on waste management, which aims to reduce emissions in the long term, increase waste efficiency, emphasize producer responsibility, reduce administration and create new jobs. Of course, it is also essential that these objectives take into account the real possibilities of individual Member States in order to be achievable at all. That is why, in the vote, I supported the relaxation of the binding targets for the recycling of packaging and municipal waste, which are even stricter in the proposed report than originally proposed by the Commission. Some municipalities are already facing problems in meeting the set goals. I have therefore supported the amendments, which seek to clarify some problematic concepts, such as municipal waste. I consider it important that the proposed rules, which aim to achieve a more environmentally friendly impact, take into account the possibilities of the Member States. Although these proposals were not adopted, I ultimately voted in favor of the draft report.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, first of all I would like to say that I profess the principle of frugality, which means that everyone in our lives should behave in a way that is resource-friendly, undoubtedly resource-friendly and, of course, what we produce, what we we are left with, that is, waste management. On the other hand, I believe that the approved reports do not correspond to what was presented by the European Commission, which has already set relatively ambitious goals and has based these goals on some research, a kind of study that has been presented. On the other hand, the ENVI Committee has approved even stricter limits, which, I do not know to what extent, are even more ambitious; in any case, no assessments have been made that such stricter limits will be realistic. And in that case, I think we should each apply the precautionary principle and give it to the Commission, which has perhaps put forward substantiated considerations. It seems to me that we will still have to address this issue, because the states will be against it. And I am convinced that our goal is to protect, above all, a quality environment, and not just for political proclamations.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, my mother used to say ‘Waste not, want not’, and I think many of us in this House will know that phrase. It makes a great deal of sense and that is why I supported all of these reports on waste management. However, we are going to have to do some work in Member States to convince the public to deal with their household waste in a way that separates what can be recycled from other waste streams. I was disappointed to learn that several – I think 160 – containers of green-bin waste from Ireland were stopped because they were found to be contaminated. So we need an education and awareness programme for citizens about the importance of separating waste in a way which allows us to reuse it, putting it back into the entire production cycle. Lastly, I would say that rural Europe, including rural Ireland, tends to be used as an illegal dumping ground for waste from villages, towns and cities, and this needs to stop. We are destroying our countryside.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: - Mr President, dear colleagues, we believe that the so-called linear economy, as industrialized societies have known it since the end of the 18th century - extracting, manufacturing, consuming, throwing away - is going through its last moments, its last moments. At the start of the 21st century, this model is no longer viable, due to its climate impact and the scarcity of resources. Only the transition to a circular economy will allow us to meet these challenges. As quickly as possible, we must establish a new economic paradigm based on the 3 Rs: reduce the consumption of resources, reuse and recycle. Such a change of economic paradigm obviously requires ambitious policies, based on a solid legislative framework. This is why I fully support the ambitious objectives of the “circular economy” legislative package that we adopted today, this noon, and which is under the leadership of our colleague Simona Bonafè.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I too would like to compliment Simona and also Karl-Heinz Florenz and others for working on these reports. The bottom line here is that we have too much waste and we must do everything we can to reduce it. And these measures which we have passed here today, and which I was pleased to vote in favour of, will hopefully mean that Member States will do everything they can to move to a circular economy. These reports are strong and balanced positions for the European Parliament and they will help us to move towards a more resource-efficient and sustainable economy. It is a big challenge, but one that must be met. For instance in 2010 EU waste production was 2 520 million tonnes, of which only 36% was recycled. The remainder was put into landfills and incinerators. Up to 600 million tonnes of this could have been recycled and the resources returned to productive use, but instead was wasted completely. This is just a synopsis of what is happening. We have got to eliminate municipal waste and general waste and move to a circular economy.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Mr. President, we lose 600 million tons of waste a year, and we can turn it into jobs, into money.The circular economy is a good tool for solving the problem of waste.The goals are high, I agree, however, if we do not set high goals, we will not meet them.Specifically, when it comes to Croatia, it is very difficult that by 2030 we will meet the target of only 10% of waste.But in the long run, we must strive to dispose of waste only when we have no alternative.The European Union depends on raw materials and we constantly import raw materials.We must turn waste into a resource and conserve resources in the European Union.So I stand for those who say that waste has ceased to be our problem and has become our chance, but of course, provided we manage it properly, and that is what we must all insist on and my message is: waste is a chance, keep resources,conserve resources in the Union.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Mr President, the European economy has slowed down, being resource-dependent, and energy cooperation with the Russian Federation has disappointed us, because Russia is not a reliable partner and, in fact, many of us have known this for decades. days. We need to use as much as possible and waste as little as possible. As we heard earlier, this is what we learn from childhood. I voted for this report. It is part of the circular economy package which virtually eliminates waste and increases competitiveness. As such, new jobs are being created. We need products that are reused and we need to eliminate waste and long-term losses, not just short-term ones. For example, the Commission aims to reduce urban waste by up to 70%; I hope she succeeds and I hope we help her, each of us, at home, where we talk to people, where we talk to the authorities and where we can change things.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: - Mr President, the measures for the circular economy that we have adopted today give a clear message to the citizens of our countries, that the linear economy is disappearing and the circular economy is coming. Yes, we can actually have the same level of prosperity using only 10% of the resources. But we can not ignore the difference in know-how between Member States. For example, the circular economy is a daily occurrence in Finland but an almost unknown term in Greece, and it is necessary to have direct access to know-how and good practices. Indeed, 49% of bread ends up in the rubbish, valuable materials are buried in landfills and only 1/3 of the rubbish is recycled in the European Union. What do we do about it? We need investments in the lagging Member States, with a clear orientation towards the circular economy, which will yield profits and, above all, jobs. For example, the European market lacks recyclable packaging materials. We especially need the citizens with us, to support the circular economy with responsibility and sensitivity, with the absolute feeling that the planet does not belong to us.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: - Mr Chairman! A circular economy is worth supporting. And Poland is, of course, in favor of achieving the best possible results in this area. However, account should also be taken of what level Member States are currently at when it comes to waste recovery. Why is it so important? Because everyone should have the same, equal requirements, in accordance with the principle of EU solidarity. Meanwhile, it turns out that they are equal and more equal in the European Union. This document fails to recognize that Member States have different levels of waste treatment. And this is what I would like to tell you that the target you voted for - 70% of municipal waste processed - is very easy to achieve for Germany, which, according to 2016 data, was recovering municipal waste at the level of 64%, and for Austria, which reached 59%. Unfortunately, this goal is very difficult to achieve for Poland, which is at the level of 20%. There should be equal opportunities for all in the European Union. This time you are also breaking this rule.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank very much the rapporteur of this report, Ernest Urtasun, for the work he has done, including listening, with the other groups and which leads us to this important final result. We continue to reiterate that gender equality is among the guidelines of the fundamental treaties of the Union but still, unfortunately, these guidelines are largely disregarded and we continue, even in this House, to hear interventions that discredit the presence of women. From this point of view, I thank President Tajani for the measures taken against the Member concerned today. Europe is not a space of self-determination, it is not a space of equality: with EIGE, with which we have been collaborating for some time, we have data that tell us how far we are still from a real gender equality. So, I believe it is important that this Parliament takes a stand to ensure that gender equality is guaranteed as soon as possible; I think it is also important to listen, to listen to a global movement like "Non una di less", to listen to the women who went on strike on 8 March and proposed a truly feminist Europe free from violence against women.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: - I voted against the document due to the lack of interesting proposals for solutions in the field of equality between women and men. If the European Union aspires to be a world leader when it comes to women's rights, then we should legally help women as part of the implementation, as I mentioned in my speech. Similarly, instead of lamenting the low pensions, it would be good to introduce solutions that would equalize pensions for men and women. Completely unacceptable is Art. 47 of a document that interferes with the doctor's appointment to save health and life by wanting to limit relying on the conscience clause, according to which the doctor may refrain from performing health services inconsistent with his conscience. In addition, I would like to remind you of the opinion of a well-known cardiologist, Dr. Fenigsen, according to which even mere mental acceptance of killing inhibits the development of medicine, apart from reversing the system of values ​​inscribed not only in the medical profession, but also in everyone protecting life.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Mr Chairman! We are discussing a report that forms part of a very important agenda for equality in the European Union. Equality between men and women, as well as equality between people, is one of the most important values ​​and civilizational achievements of the European Union, but it is treated differently in individual countries. Also, depending on whether it is private or public life, depending on the industry or sector, we have different achievements in terms of equality between women and men. Certainly, in areas such as science or business the situation is better, but in the labor market the average wage of women is still lower than that of men, which cannot be tolerated. However, what is the most important and the most difficult is the equality in the treatment of a woman's health and the right to self-decision about one's fate. This is being violated practically everywhere, and we should continue to work in the European Union to remove this stereotype and this state of affairs.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Mr President, I could not support this report, even though I wanted to.The report was very well done and there were a number of points with which I completely identify.The fact that there are scissors between women's and men's wages, the fact that there are scissors between women's and men's pensions in many EU countries, is something that is absolutely crucial that we need to address.On the other hand, this report was full of such filling sentences and nonsense that it concerns subsidiarity.It is the right to abortion, which is simply changing in each state and each state has a different one.That is why I could not support this report as a whole, and I would like to call on the European Parliament to really stick to its competences and not to propose things that it, as the European Parliament, can never change.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - So, these are issues that both the Commission and the European Union as a whole have been dealing with for a number of years, and we are, of course, still far from being able to talk about gender equality.Even the statistics and the so-called equality index actually show the stagnation and decline of this equality, which can be seen everywhere.It is seen both in the wage system, it is actually seen in the concrete representation of women in key positions in both the economy and politics.Even the recent crises, both economic and migrant, have shown that these are very very vulnerable groups of people, to whom we must of course also give, I will say, reports and also through the legal basis of the possibility of full inclusion and equality in all areas of our lives.This, of course, starts in the educational process and later in the acquisition of job positions.I think it is Parliament's duty to pay special attention to this in all the policy segments it deals with.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: - Dear Mr. Chairman, The report on equality between women and men has little to do with the actual idea of ​​equality. It promotes abortion as one of the reproductive rights, interferes with education by implementing the gender perspective at every level, violates the natural identity of the family, promoting parenthood of LGBT people, and indicates the obligation to combat stereotypes, and understands the role of women as wife and mother as stereotypical roles . I would like to say very clearly that I am in favor of supporting women. Let us make sure that women have opportunities for professional development and at the same time they can play the role of mothers and wives, if they wish. To ensure this, it is not necessary to change the concept of gender and promote sick ideologies. The facts speak for themselves. According to the PwC report "Women at work index 2017", Poland is in the forefront of countries with the lowest pay gap - only seven percent. In addition, this report indicates that if we maintain the current trend, these wage gaps will be closed as early as 2021, which is the fastest among all OECD countries. In my homeland, in Poland, we are committed to traditional Christian values ​​and, as you can see, even though we still have a lot to do, it is not ideological, gender-oriented stubbornness, but understanding and adequate support of women that drives positive changes in the situation of women.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I recall once again, in arguing my vote in favor of this report, how important the day of 8 March was: the global political strike, the strike from productive work, the strike from reproductive work, whichbrought women across Europe to the streets, from Madrid to Rome.I remember the strike precisely because I believe it is connected to the themes of this report, a very important report, which tests the maturity of the European institutions when it comes to gender equality and access to goods and services.Access to goods and services is not neutral: sexual and reproductive health is a right that is still too often not guaranteed in the European Union itself.So, I believe that this report represents a step forward but there are still many to be taken, if it is true that in this European Union the gender pay gap is still a scourge far from being eradicated.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: - Although it is undeniably necessary to implement the principle of equal treatment of men and women in access to goods and services, with the provision of these goods and services, and although I fully share the rapporteur's view on insufficient protection of women during pregnancy and maternity, in some cases I would recommend caution due to the different gender sensitivities and feelings. This does not mean that separate tourist carriages for women and men should be introduced as a prevention of harassment, because the problems of violence, such as harassment, should be prevented by stimulating personal development, and not separating women from men. Violence against women is due to many reasons, including the recommendations of the Istanbul Convention and Freedom without any restrictions, which is tantamount to approving actions against life and family, and I cannot agree to that.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: - I voted against the report because - at least for the time being - the natural roles of women and men cannot be reversed, and even in same-sex relationships there is a difference in roles. Therefore, instead of sending women to work against their will in favor of men's leave, I would prefer other solutions, so that the funds of billions of euros promoting equality are not wasted on introducing an ideology against women's life and health, which in fact objectifies women, but allocate these funds to help women raising children or caring for the elderly. The FEMM commission should be, first and foremost, a women's rights commission, who are repeatedly deprived of their natural rights within the framework of specifically understood equality. For example, through reports of this type, which additionally accuse Poland of false facts, which can be classified as violence against my country, as stigmatization is also a form of psychological violence.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, let me explain why I did not support the report on EU funds for equality between women and men. Of course, I consider it important for the European Parliament to monitor the use of European funds, including those designed to promote equality between women and men. But it turns out that the funds seem to be missing their goals, because in the long run the goal of equal pay as well as equal pensions, which are constantly very different, and women who take care of children and families all their lives, then have undignified pensions. I think we should rather teach our society that investing in children is an investment for the good of society as a whole and that the time spent raising children should not be seen as a disability that reduces income. Rather, the European Parliament should focus on encouraging Member States to value mothers and parents, for Member States to seek to promote their parental role and to reconcile the conditions for reconciling parental and professional life.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - The report, which is very important, is very important to us, because it concerns, among other things, technologies that are already present, and will certainly be the foundation of development in the future, and not only economic, economic, but also civilization development. The civilization of the future is a civilization of new technologies, which is why we place so much emphasis in Europe, in the European Union, and in individual Member States on building a digital society. But you have to be aware that generating a huge amount of data is also a danger, especially a danger for an individual. Of course, also for states, for institutions of a certain type, etc. So already in the European Union we must prepare such standards, such procedures, which will protect this security. Today, in my opinion, there are no such certain norms and procedures and there is a threat to fundamental rights, especially those referred to in Art. 7, actually exists. We have an urgent need to guarantee the right to privacy of the citizens of the European Union.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Mr President, we live in the midst of a data revolution. I recently visited CERN, where their data centre processes the equivalent of 210 000 DVDs’ worth of data every single day. Tidal waves of information are generated as we log on to websites, buy train tickets or make a cash withdrawal. With big data come big opportunities. Properly used, this data has the power to transform the smarter, more personalised public services, to better inform decisions, increase efficiency and unlock new ground-breaking research. Of course, people have legitimate privacy concerns, and we have seen what happens when people feel they have not consented to the changes they see around them. This is why I welcome this report and the safeguards that it recommends. With big data come big challenges and big responsibilities for legislators.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Mr President, for the last time today.I voted in favor of this proposal as it represents an important step towards greater protection of fundamental human rights when using large amounts of data.On the one hand, these data have a huge potential for economic development and can be used, for example, in health care, transport or in the fight against crime.At the same time, however, we must realize that this is often sensitive personal data.I am thinking, for example, of location information.Therefore, a legal framework needs to be put in place in the future to effectively prevent the misuse of this data and to ensure transparent procedures for its analysis.It is also necessary to prevent both desired and unwanted distortion of the database.The outputs of data analyzes can serve as a basis for political decisions at all levels of public administration.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Mr President, they say that Britain is a nation of animal lovers and I think that the 20 000 plus emails that have bounded into my inbox over the last couple of weeks – all about rabbits – pay testament to that. My constituents are angry that 99% of Europe’s farmed rabbits are kept squashed into tiny wire cages. The rabbits cannot run or hop or hide as they naturally do in the wild. The EU has rightly banned similar cages for hens. Now let us seize the opportunity to improve animal welfare again. It is time to end the cage age.

name: Paul BRANNEN
text: – Mr President, I am pleased to say that all of the British Labour MEPs voted today in favour of minimum standards for farmed rabbits across the European Union. I myself received over 20 000 emails calling for support for minimum legislation in relation to farmed rabbits. I also received a large number of pictures of rabbits, drawn by children from across the European Union, in calls for support for action in this area. I would like to congratulate Compassion in World Farming on a very successful campaign. There are over 300 million farmed rabbits in the European Union, which means there are more farmed rabbits than there are men in the European Union, and those farmed rabbits are living in cages no bigger than two sheets of A4 paper. It simply is not acceptable. We no longer have battery hens: the time has come to end farmed rabbits.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Mr President, I have also received thousands of emails from constituents who have joined Compassion in World Farming in calling for legal protection for farmed rabbits across the EU. A recent report by researchers from Bristol University found that current legislation does not adequately address the welfare needs of rabbits. Unlike other farm animals, there are no minimum standards specific to them, yet rabbits are the second most farmed animal in the EU. Every year over 340 million rabbits are farmed, many of them confined in cramped and foul conditions to be slaughtered for meat. These inhumane conditions also facilitate the spread of disease, leading farmers to use alarming amounts of antibiotics. As we know, antibiotic resistance is one of the most serious public health risks facing our world today. We must move towards lower-intensity and more compassionate farming methods to safeguard the well—being of rabbits and other farmed animals and to improve the health of our population.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - So, as my colleague said, this is the average area available to a farmed rabbit, less than two A4 sheets.As many as 99 percent of the entire rabbit population lives in such unacceptable conditions.More than 340 million of them go to slaughter every year, and their life until slaughter is a sad and cruel life in overcrowded and dilapidated cages, where they have been proven to be exposed to very, very poor conditions.I therefore welcome the minimum standards for the protection of farmed rabbits, which mean that battery farming and wire cages should be phased out and that free-range or ground-based rabbit farming should be introduced with grass as the main source of nutrition.I also welcome the fact that the report calls for respect for the findings of the European Food Safety Authority and the World Organization for Animal Health, so of course I supported the report in this part, which is a necessary step towards a more humane situation and let rabbits live.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: - I hereby close the explanation of vote.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item on the agenda is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the U.S.global gag rule (2017/2599 (RSP)).

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, honourable Members, I am here on behalf of my dear colleague, Commission Vice-President/High Representative Federica Mogherini. As you know, President Donald Trump has reinstated the Mexico City Policy with a presidential memorandum issued on 23 January. This policy requires foreign non-governmental organisations to certify that they will not ‘perform or actively promote abortion as a method of family planning,’ as a condition for receiving US global health assistance. This also includes NGOs receiving funds from outside the US. The policy, when in effect, applies to foreign NGOs as a condition for receiving US family planning support, either directly or indirectly. So the Commission is concerned about the possible implications for our objective of achieving universal coverage in health and reproductive health services, particularly in developing countries. Eventually, this decision might also impact on our Sustainable Development Goals, targets to reduce maternal mortality, and to empower women to take more informed decisions about their health. In the poorest countries of the world, this can put the lives of young women and girls at risk. And we do not want the progress that we have made over the past decade on women’s rights to be lost. Let me be clear: European Union policies are driven by our own priorities and values, not by what others do or stop doing. As far as humanitarian aid is concerned, what I can say, as the Commissioner for Humanitarian Aid, is that our approach is based on needs. Our humanitarian partners which consider that abortion would be appropriate are not prevented from doing so. We have never issued instructions to the contrary. A decision on abortion will depend on various factors: the woman’s wishes after she has received all relevant information, definitely her condition, and the legal framework of the country, of course, which could influence the security of both the woman and humanitarian workers. In this context, decisions on how to treat women and girls are always better left to doctors. It is not something for lawyers to prescribe. Let me add that we are also continuing our work to prevent sexual and gender-based violence. Focusing on the treatment of violence can only ever be a second-best. Prevention is also the reason why we have strengthened the place of gender in our humanitarian aid. Over the past decade, the Commission has allocated around EUR 200 million annually from the humanitarian budget to healthcare, including sexual and reproductive health. In parallel, my dear colleague, Commissioner Neven Mimica, issued a press statement on 1 February 2017 underlining that the Commission will continue to play a leading role in ensuring women’s access to health and family planning services around the world. He also attended the ‘She Decides’ event on 2 March 2017 and reiterated our commitment. Several governments and private philanthropists have pledged nearly USD 200 million for family planning services. We are also assessing the potential impact of a loss of funding for the UN Population Fund (UNFPA). The funding gap could be large. Together with Member States and civil society in particular we are analysing the US contribution to the fund in order to determine the best approach to take. We remain strongly committed to supporting global health initiatives such as UNFPA, into which we are putting EUR 20 million for 2016 and 2017; and also the Global Fund, to which we have pledged EUR 475 million for 2017 to 2019. Or GAVI, the Vaccine Alliance, to which we have pledged EUR 200 million for 2016 to 2020; and the partnership programme with the World Health Organisation and Luxembourg, worth EUR 28 million, for 2016 to 2018. The informal foreign affairs and development ministerial meeting on Thursday will enable this matter to be addressed. We will have an impact only if we respond together, with a common European position.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, thank you so much, Commissioner, for everything you are doing. I strongly condemn the newly instated global gag rule. We had an alarm call from Africa, through Asia to Latin America, on the serious consequences for the health of hundreds of thousands of women and girls globally. Today my thoughts really go to all these women and girls who are at risk of losing a very important health programme. This also applies to the Zika virus, AIDS prevention, on prenatal and postnatal basic assistance for babies and young women, victims of rape, and victims of female genital mutilation. The risk is that women’s mortality is going to increase and that there will be more illegal and unsafe abortion. Last week we were marking the International Day of Women.
