We met fantastic women from Tunisia, Morocco, Kosovo, all over the world. We were told terrible stories of a woman that was found with a piece of a television antenna in her uterus because she wanted to interrupt her pregnancy. Another one had drunk pesticide and died. This is not to mention the victims of Isis and Daesh slavery, and the girls that come back, having been released from Boko Haram, and who are refused into their communities and cannot in the new circumstances get assistance for their basic health and reproductive rights and for their children. What we are talking about is not whether you are for abortion or against abortion. We are talking about humanitarian law: health, safety, child protection and women’s rights are human rights. No woman or girl should have to risk her life to have a baby. That is what we are talking about. There is a chorus of concern that is coming from NGOs, Save the Children and the United Nations. Europe has to step in. This is our opportunity to show leadership. Trump’s sexism is as bad as the problem that we have with security in Europe and with free trade with the new administration. I am glad that the ‘She Decides’ campaign has been so successful. I am glad that today we have voted to devote European funds to compensate for this setback. I hope that more pledges will come, and the test is going to be next week at the United Nations Conference on the status of women. I call on Member States to do their part and to raise their voice. Let us continue to support the Women’s March in the USA and Europe, and women’s health in the world.

name: Linda McAVAN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, this is an extremely important debate, and I am glad we are having it in the week when we are debating women’s issues after International Women’s Day and just a few days after the conference in Brussels on ‘She Decides’. This is a debate we should not really be having, because a woman’s access to family planning should not be a political football to be given and withdrawn depending on who is in government. In particular, it does not seem right to me that it is a decision that has been taken by people who will not be affected by it. People here will not be affected by this decision, and certainly the men who surrounded President Trump when he signed it into law will not be affected by this decision. It is the poor women in the world, and the poorest countries in the world, who will pay the price – the women we heard from at the ‘She Decides’ conference on 2 March. So if we are serious – as the Commissioner said – about the SDGs and gender equality, we cannot afford the cuts that have been talked about. An estimated 225 million women globally lack access to modern contraception. Every day, 830 women die from preventable causes linked to pregnancy and childbirth. That is over 30 an hour. It is one since I started speaking to you. As we have just heard from Mrs Corazza Bildt, no family planning means other problems, such as HIV and other issues. Let us make no mistake about it: cutting this funding does not mean fewer abortions. All the evidence from the last period when the gag was in place shows that the number of unwanted pregnancies and abortions increased when the global gag came in. Mrs Corazza Bildt has just told us about the consequences and what happens to women when that happens. So this policy is not a success story, and that is why she said that we must step in. But we must also step up now. So what can we do here in the EU to counter this policy? Well, we voted today. We voted for the report by Claire Moody this morning with a very big majority, calling for EU funds to counter the cuts caused by the global gag. We can support the ‘She Decides’ initiative, and I pay tribute here to Lilianne Ploumen and the Swedish, Danish and Belgian Ministers who organised that conference and brought over 50 countries together to raise funding. We can also look at our own wider funding and prioritise SRHR spending in our own plans. We have got a review of the DCI coming up and of the EDF in the mid—term. Let us look at what we are doing already. Commissioner, you indicated that the Commission was willing to do this and will be talking about it in the Council on Thursday with Ministers. I hope you will come back soon and tell us that the funding is being made available and that we will back the ‘She Decides’ initiative. Looking around this room, many of us here – mainly women here, but men as well – have made choices about our own fertility and if and when to have children. It is not a first world right, it is a right for every woman, wherever she lives. Commissioner, I know that you will be supportive on this, but we need the support of the whole Commission and Ministers to make sure that women are not let down after this gag comes into place. (Applause)

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, yes, women must have good quality health care – especially when it concerns the unique contribution to our society of having babies. So my opinion is, why would anyone – especially those calling themselves feminists – complain that a global abortion industry is losing some of its funding? Why are EU Member States wanting to step up and fund a practice that harms women and babies? That is genocidal, economically disastrous and anti-democratic, anti-feminist and anti-woman. And if someone has a different opinion, if President Trump decided on a different approach, it would have to be respected. There are reasons. And also there are reasons which come from reverence: reverence to life, reverence to dignity of life, reverence to the right to be born and to live, and reverence to those who cannot speak for themselves – for those who are unborn yet and cannot speak for themselves. So I strongly disagree with the Commission’s intent to spend millions to export this barbarism to developing nations. Abortion has no healthcare benefits. There are none. And it cannot be called health care. Abortion is not a health initiative, as Commissioner Stylianides has named it, because it cannot be called a basic health care. All of those valuable resources should be immediately redirected to provide real and maternal care to women so that we can benefit from the next generation and not mourn them. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: blue-card question. – Mr Škripek, can I ask you whether you have ever spoken to a woman who got pregnant, even though she did not want to? Maybe the man she had sex with did not want to use a contraceptive or it broke or she might have been raped. That even happens within families. It happens with brothers, husbands, etc. Have you ever spoken to anyone who said no, she did not want to have that child? Just another question: have you ever imagined what would happen if you were able to get pregnant and you did not want to become pregnant? Maybe, in such dire circumstances as we have in many countries in this world, would you then not decide that you did not want that and you wanted to have safe access to abortion, given that otherwise both you and the child could die?

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: blue-card answer. – I do not know if I will manage two questions in 15 seconds; probably you need to answer in 30 seconds. Of course I did speak to a lady who was in a difficult situation. What I condemned on this industry is that it is a mixed thing; all, all, all, all reasons into one. Let us help children to be aborted, let us fund it. But the other side does not speak about the very different approach which admires life. This is what I am missing on this pro-life and pro-choice debate. A lady does not kill her own body, cannot decide about her own body, because it is not her body. If she kills her body, she dies. After abortion a baby dies, not a lady.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I am not sure what to say to Mr Škripek, because I do not have the illusion that we are going to change his mind. But maybe I would rather address the citizens of the European Union, who should understand that the agenda of the so-called populist parties is not just about nationalism, anti-EU or national sovereignty; it is also very much about sexism and misogyny. It is against women’s rights. So keep that in mind when you go to the ballot box, and know what you vote for – like the Trump administration, who reinstated and expanded the gag rule, and the Helms amendment, which was still in the background. It is very necessary that the European Union gives a strong response, and I very much welcome the very positive attitude of the European Commission. You have our support, because the European Union must not only accept standards imposed by third countries; we must lead in the world, we must set the standards. We are the strongest actor in the world, and we have to make sure that we impose the standards and do not accept. That is why I very much welcome the ‘She Decides’ initiative. It sends a very strong signal to the Trump administration and women around the world. We need to go further. First of all, I would like to ask the European Commission about the 2015 letter about women who are pregnant as a result of rape in conflict, and you consider that that is covered by international humanitarian law. But now we need to make sure that these guidelines are actually transmitted through the practitioners in the field so that people know that they have the backing. Women should know what their rights and their options are, so I would call on the Commission to do this proactively. Secondly, we need to fill the funding gap that was left by President Trump, but not only in response to him reinstating the gag rule. But it has to be structural. If we want to lead, it has to be structural. Finally, we are going to table amendments to the budget this year in order to strengthen the funding. I also expect those EU Member States who have pledged funds to the ‘She Decides’ initiative in the budget procedure to give support to amendments, increasing the budget for sexual and reproductive health and rights – and not only in situations of conflict. Because, dear colleague Škripek, I firmly believe that women should decide on their own bodies. Always.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Commissioner!There are questions and suggestions, so please kindly take this into account in the time provided for you.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: for the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President! Every Republican presidential administration in the United States has introduced this gag rule, but this one is worse than most others. It goes even further. It restricts virtually all support for women's sexual and reproductive health. Good sexual and reproductive health is a matter of life and death for women around this globe. However, it is also a question of being able to live a whole or being able to live a half life, to have control over one's body and sexuality or not to have it. This gossip rule implies such deep contempt for women, for our health and for our well-being. But just like our colleagues from the US who work for Pro-choice said: We will not be silent, we will not be gagged. Just as different Member States stand up for women's rights, the EU must now do the same. I welcome the She Decides initiative. That is part of the answer, but it is not enough. It is too quiet from the Commission, and it is too quiet from the Council. My question is what the EU will do, not only at the political level but also in terms of funding. The European Parliament has acted. We have voted in both the previous and this part-sessions. We want to see more funding, increased funding for women's sexual and reproductive health and rights. Now, however, we want to see the Council and the Commission also act. We need clear recommendations to our partner organizations on how to ensure that they will be able to continue to perform important and vital abortion care. We need to increase the development assistance budget for women's health and sexual and reproductive health and rights. I would like to say this, namely that one's commitment and sincerity are put to the test when it is discouraged. If the EU is serious about women's rights, it is now time to step forward and take concrete action. We must therefore condemn the EU's gag rule, we must take the fight in international forums, and we must shoot for more money! I look forward to those decisions, both in the Council and in the Commission.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, we call it the Global Gag Rule, but what are we actually talking about? We are talking about the lives and the well-being of millions of women worldwide. We are talking about girls getting support after being victimized by female genital mutilation. We are talking about maternity care for pregnant women. And, Mr Škripek, I think it shameful that you are insulting family planning organisations here by calling them an abortion industry, whereas sometimes they risk their lives and their well-being to help women who are at risk of serious health damage.  I find that unbelievable and we should not accept it as parliamentarians in this Chamber: these organisations are doing great work. We are talking about access to contraception here. We are talking about providing sex education, but we are also talking about giving women power over family planning and hence their freedom to decide about their own lives and be an equal part of society. We are talking about progress within societies. We are talking, indeed, about the Sustainable Development Goals, and, sadly, we are talking about an old white man in the White House who, in one of his first actions in power, has threatened all of these things. Approximately USD 600 million could be lost. We cannot let this happen. So, Commissioner, I urge you to increase the EU funding, to counteract and fill this decency gap, and also to take a very clear message to our colleagues in the US: we, as the European Union, will fight for the freedom and self-determination of women and girls all over the world.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The fact is that Mr Škripek volunteered by raising a blue card, but I would like to ask that this should not be a discussion or a debate between the Members and Mr Branislav, and that we, however, acknowledge that everyone has already benefited from the blue card procedure once.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Mister President! Today we are talking about funding abortion organizations. The US decided to stop funding abortion and now the EU wants to jump into that loophole. Abortion is not a European Union competence. We can't finance something for which we are not responsible - where are we going? In addition, abortion is still a criminal offense in Germany! It is only not punishable in exceptional cases. The only good thing about this debate is that we are finally coming true and you stop talking about reproductive health, humanity and child protection. It's about abortion! It's about the ending of the life of unborn children - I think you can say that objectively, even you won't deny it. The EU is not responsible for this. Abortion is a criminal offense. Let us stop trying to finance these things for which we are not responsible and which are criminal offenses, but instead concern ourselves with protecting life instead of ending it! (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: question "blue card".- I wanted to ask the Honorable Member if he considers the right of women to self-determination something that the European Union should concern itself with, if he considers the right to self-determination something that the United Nations has enshrined as a fundamental right, a fundamental human right anda right of women.I beg you to consider that continuing to deny the fact that women can choose over their bodies, yes, it has nothing to do with the European Union.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- So the Global Gag Rule - it is precisely and precisely about abortion.It's not about everything else, it's about abortion, about ending life.And if you talk all the time about whether women have a right over their bodies: Yes, but maybe also before conception.This claiming a right over one's own body begins before conception, and in 98% of the cases it is not rape that leads to an unwanted life.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I wanted to contact Mrs. in 't Veld.Mrs MP!You wanted to ask a question, but I have a request: one question by raising a blue card to one speaker.So if any of the speakers make your question relevant, then please ask the next speaker, okay?I am asking for forgiveness, but we have to organize ourselves somehow.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, all the pretexts seem to be good in this hemicycle to attack the new American president whom you are devoting to complaining, just as you do not stop hurling anathemas against the Russian president, on the grounds that he has a family policy in his country that does not suit you. I understand your frustration at seeing your model of society rejected and I welcome it. The United States will no longer seek to impose on the rest of the world, through NGOs, such as international family planning, political standards inherited from the Cultural Revolution of May 1968. And that is good news. The American desire to upset traditional family structures and its aggressive promotion of urbi et orbi abortion were indeed not acceptable. But the European Union clearly does not have that wisdom. Mr. Trump's reinstatement of the "Mexico City policy" - adopted by Republican presidents since Reagan and banning funding for pro-abortion NGOs - is a sign that our old world is falling apart, and it scares you. So much so, moreover, that the French socialist government felt obliged to pass a law aimed at banning websites which simply presented solutions other than abortion. Moreover, at that time I did not hear the usual advocates of tolerance being indignant at this obvious attack on freedom of expression. In contrast, to lecture Mr. Trump to justice, the left, its cohort of ideologized associations, and the weak right are all set in motion. But it is the strictest right of the United States to choose its own criteria for funding NGOs. The European authorities, together with the media and politicized associations, do not have to use this affair to harm the American president, democratically elected, I remind you. They are the same who without ceaselessly invoke international law to force states to submit to libertarian dogma which, here, superbly ignores both the sovereignty of states and international commitments.At a time when nearly 50 million abortions are performed each year around the world, reducing the use of abortion should really become a public health objective, as stipulated in the international commitments made at the conference ofCairo in 1994. (The speaker agreed to answer a “blue card” question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: "blue card" question.- Colleague, I think you have very much mixed up two things in this debate by comparing Trump to Putin.Let's stick with the debate here in the hemisphere.The point today is that we as Europe let the President of America know that women's rights apply to all of us and that we must respect women's rights around the world.So if you act against abortion in this way - even though we all have known your position for a long time - it actually means that you are against the right of all women to self-determination.Do you know, madam, every minute somewhere in the world a woman dies from an unsafe performance of an abortion?This must stop Europe.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: answer "blue card". - Madam MP, it will not have escaped your notice that I am a woman and I am a French member elected to the European Parliament. What I see is that in my country, for 20 years, there have been 200,000 abortions per year and that, despite all the information campaigns, these abortions are not decreasing. I am also telling you that there have been a lot of information campaigns and that, contrary to what you say - and this is an untruth -, we are not against the right to abortion, nor against the right to information. I'm just saying that we are for the right to inform women of other options available to them. Moreover, since you talk a lot about international law, I remind you that, precisely, an obligation contracted by France and most of the States of the European Union under international law, in relation to this Cairo convention, was to support precisely children before and after birth, and to take appropriate measures for women, precisely to try not to have an abortion. This is what I said, nothing more, nothing less.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Mr President, I would just like to mention that, according to Parliament’s rules, I was named by Mrs in ‘t Veld and Mrs Reintke by name and I had the right to react.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: If you want to react, please make your personal statement within 3 minutes after the end of the debate.Consent?

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, this US policy is nothing new, it has existed since 1984 and is fully in line with international conventions - the program of action adopted at the International Conference on Population and Development held in Cairo and the Beijing Declaration and Platform for action. The key in these documents is that abortion is not a method of family planning and money is denied exclusively to organizations that promote abortion as a method of family planning. The funds have not disappeared or been reduced, as it is wrongly stated, they are still there and will be received by organizations dealing with the health of women and children. Abortion that saves the mother's life is not subject to this policy. Also, abortion in cases of rape or incest is not covered by this prohibition, nor is post-abortion care. There is no financial gap to be filled when it comes to funding family planning services. The financial gap was created only in relation to abortion as a method of family planning, which is prohibited by law in most developing countries. Therefore, if NGOs abide by the law in those countries and do not carry out illegal abortions, they should not be harmed by this policy. I am absolutely opposed to the idea that the EU is financially supporting organizations that promote abortion as a method of family planning in third countries. Money from the European Union should be allocated to organizations that care about the health of women and children, not to those that openly promote abortion as a method of family planning.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: - Mister President! It is a shame that the new US administration under Trump no longer wants to fund family planning projects in developing countries. The new US administration is accepting that the already 18 million unsafe and illegal abortions and maternal mortality will increase in developing countries. It also means that safe abortion services will no longer be available in the event of rape. The fact that Frau von Storch from the AfD does not care is frightening and shows what kind of a brainchild she is. I therefore urge the US government to reverse its decision as soon as possible. I also welcome the initiative of the Dutch government to want to close the resulting financial gap with other countries - including US foundations. Over 20 countries have already agreed to do so. Unfortunately, Germany has not yet taken a position on this. I call on the European Commission to increase funding in this area in the short term. Likewise, the funds made available for the EU budget 2018 must be expanded in the area of ​​sexual and reproductive health. The world has a joint responsibility here, just as we jointly adopted the development goals. The right to good health also counts for women - it's a human right!

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Mr Chairman!President Donald Trump's suspension of financing abortion practices around the world is a great example of the unwavering youth of the American republic, while the attack on the United States taking place here is another convulsion in a sick Europe.The official title of this debate defined the blockage of the death industry as a "global gag."This is what you called America's commitment to the civilization of life at a time when French socialist authorities introduced drastic censorship involving prison terms to gag appeals to defend the lives of the unborn.Europe is being destroyed today by populism, yes, your populism, the populism of power, the populism that repeats to the societies of Europe "there is no moral law except your wishes."It is time to face it if Europe is to continue living.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: - Mr President, let's take a concrete example to illustrate the drama created by the rule of the global gag order: to save the life of a pregnant woman in a conflict zone, the doctor responsible for her treatment sees no other solution than termination of pregnancy, in agreement with his patient. Does he have to explain the provisions of US law to this woman or will he treat her? By performing the abortion in question, the doctor saves a life, but he exposes the NGO for which he works, at the risk of seeing it deprived, henceforth, of any public aid from the United States. We are addressing this theme today to signal to this doctor that we support him, that we find it astounding that his choice is called into question by the rule of the global gag order. If he saves a life, he weakens his NGO. If he wants his NGO to continue to function, he lets the pregnant woman die. Anyone who has the slightest idea of ​​the tragedies that these women are going through renounces the blackmail that the humanitarian sector is subjected to as a result of the application of this law. Let the doctor act, in agreement with his patient. This is what the European Union is doing and we encourage it to persevere in this direction. A few moments ago, I heard a strong plea from Mrs Storch for the respect of life. I wonder where her legendary humanism was when she said that it would be appropriate, from time to time, to shoot asylum seekers when crossing the border.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: - Mr. president. Of course, the new United States government has declared war on feminism. And it has done so by cutting funding to NGOs that work to ensure information and help women who want to terminate their pregnancy safely. It is unacceptable and therefore we need to respond with Union and State funds to the humanitarian challenge posed by the United States. Commissioner, remember that this Parliament last month passed recommendations to forcefully denounce this global gag law at next week's meeting of the United Nations on the legal and social status of women. They must, because women's rights and freedoms are not a bargaining chip that depends on the political color of a government or who wins the elections. Inside or outside the European Union. They must be conquered and permanent rights. It is a right that each one can freely exercise control of her body. Nobody forces anybody.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Mr President, President Trump’s global gag rule goes much beyond and much further than his predecessor’s, another Republican President, Mr Bush. We do not quite yet know how far it goes but we can estimate that the work of non-US-based NGOs in all areas of global health assistance, including family planning, will be jeopardised. And this will directly threaten the lives of hundreds of millions of women and girls in the world. We know also that the Bush rule, during its eight years, added 36 million unwanted pregnancies to the world, and it added 15 million abortions. Is this what you want? This is certainly not what I want. I want to get rid of these kinds of hypocritical interventions which are calling for a total ban or even criminalisation of abortion in the name of some obscure ideology in defence of life. What we need is to look at what really works, and what really works we can see, for instance, in Nepal. In Nepal, abortion was legalised in 2002, and we have seen that immediately, maternal deaths started to go down in numbers. We can also say that a good-quality sexuality education with a permissive abortion legislation is the best way to bring the numbers of abortions down. If that is what you want, then change your thinking. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Marek JUREK
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- According to the MP, countries that protect life from birth are obscurant countries.I would like to ask if you think that Alcide de Gasperi or Robert Schuman were such obscurants?Was obscurantism prevailing in Europe when these leaders concluded the Treaties of Rome, the anniversary of which we will soon be celebrating?

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: blue-card answer. – Schuman certainly was a great European politician. I am not disputing that. But I am sure that in order to get what you want, you have to look at figures. You should not just say ‘ban abortion’ or ‘stop supporting abortion services’. And, as I said, what we are seeing now is that this is also about stopping family planning. We can all be very proud that the European Union fought against this rule during the Bush era, and I am convinced that the European Union will have a sensible and courageous approach on the question even now.

name: Raymond FINCH
text: – Mr President, while I believe it is an obvious right that women’s health issues should be a concern for us all globally, I also believe it is the right of every nation to spend its taxpayers’ money in the way it sees fit. The fact of the matter is this is a decision for the government and people of the United States of America, and to call it war on feminism as someone did, is hyperbole and just demeans their argument. We must look back in history and acknowledge that this legislation is a political football, even in the United States. Its origins go back as far as the Reagan administration. It has been brought in and rescinded by previous administrations as the republican and democratic fortunes have waxed and waned. The powerful religious factions who support this in the United States have a precise analogue here in Europe, where the Catholic Church strongly opposed Parliament’s own Sandbæk report. Issues of this kind are heavily emotive and each person must reach into their own moral core to decide how to speak and vote. In the end, I believe it is not for the European Parliament to tell the US Government what to do. You would not be pleased if the positions were reversed, so I would urge you to consider these points. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: blue-card question. – Just to clarify one misunderstanding, we are not actually debating the US budget here. We are debating the EU budget. We may deplore what the United States has decided, but we cannot change it. But if you say that every state – or entity in this case, when we are talking about the EU budget – has the right to set its own priorities and decide on its own budget, I count on you being on my side when we table amendments to raise the budget for the issues we are discussing today.

name: Raymond FINCH
text: blue-card answer. – The fact is that it is entirely up to the EU how it spends its budget. As you are doubtlessly aware, I am not in favour of the EU having a budget, but I would be greatly in favour of individual nations – and I do not believe this is a nation – doing so, if that answers your question.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: - Mr. President, it is my turn to worry deeply about this Global Gag Rule, this rule of the world gag that President Trump has just brought up to date in the most severe and sinister way possible, much more severely than all of its predecessors. With the entry into force of this global gag rule, international organizations and international associations dealing with family planning, which develop actions in the area of ​​sexual and reproductive health, may be deprived of all funding from States. United of America. The warning signals were immediately launched by a whole series of organizations, by large associations in Africa, Asia, Latin America, by the United Nations Population Fund, by the large association Save the Children: there are hundreds thousands of women, young girls, young girls who run the risk of being deprived of access to health care or family planning, who could again be forced to face the hell of clandestine abortions that are - as we know - terribly dangerous for the life and health of women and young girls. More generally, with these budget cuts, a whole series of preventive actions against, for example, the AIDS virus or the Zika virus, which could be threatened. So it is about facing up to our responsibilities. It is up to the European Union and its Member States to continue to develop humanitarian actions, as well as a development policy that takes into account the need to promote actions in favor of reproductive and sexual health throughout the world. .

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the face of the shameful attack by the Trump administration, a strong commitment by the European Union to protect the sexual and reproductive rights of women is indispensable. The policies of the US administration not only affect the Union's cardinal principles on gender equality but will have disastrous repercussions on NGOs and programs that spread contraception, prevent the transmission of disease, protect the right to abortion and promote planning family and mother and child health also in developing countries. The global gag rule creates a funding gap of around $ 600 million. The "She decides" initiative for global fund raising launched by the Dutch minister to counterbalance the effects of the global gag rule deserves all the support of our institutions. Indignation is not enough! I appeal in particular to the Member States: they must translate the condemnation of this provision into a significant increase in funding and that they are new resources, not displaced by other priorities. Women have to decide on their own body, as many shouted on March 8 at the women's march, "My body, my choice!".

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! With the stroke of a pen, the President of the United States has put the 2030 Sustainable Development Agenda in jeopardy, and women around the world will suffer the dire consequences of this pointless action. Because this is not about potential savings, but about the fact that the female body and the rights of women are once again used as a political battlefield. But such political games can have life-threatening consequences. Unsafe abortions are one of the top five reasons for maternal mortality worldwide. Therefore, dear colleagues: It is high time to get up. It is now up to us, the European Union, to take action and lead a global, progressive alliance around the world. We cannot just watch such a destructive way of doing politics become the norm. The EU and its partners need to step up their efforts to protect sexual and reproductive health. This includes both an increase in development aid in these areas and a stronger advocacy of this important issue in diplomatic relations.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, fortunately hundreds of thousands of women have already taken part in this debate, who took to the streets on 8 March for the Feminist strike, for the World March of Women, tearing that horrible photograph with which the President Trump, surrounded by men, wanted to decide - and wants to decide - on women's bodies. I am genuinely furious to have heard in this Chamber today the words of Members who want to deny me, a woman, us women, the right to decide on our bodies. I think we must be clear that this $ 10 million cut will have a negative effect on the lives of some 460 000 girls, mostly the weakest and poorest girls. I think we can't afford it. I also want to remind you that 14 countries in the European Union have not yet signed the Istanbul Convention. We must distance ourselves from President Trump's policy but we also have a long way to go.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! You probably all remember when Trump signed the Global Gag Rule, surrounded by lots of old, older - maybe a few younger - white men. This means that roughly $ 600 million a year will no longer be available in the future. And it's not just about abortions - let me tell you this for once: It's about contraceptives, it's about education, it's about HIV / AIDS prevention. This gag rule threatens the lives of girls and women, girls and women who have already been born. And you know: unwanted pregnancies or improper abortions by angel makers, that is the second most common cause of death for girls and young women between the ages of 15 and 19. And you, who argue against it, want to reinforce that. We - and I would also like to thank the Commission - here in the European Parliament, too, the majority supports the “She decides” program, this new initiative, led by the Dutch Development Minister plus Belgium, Denmark and Sweden, that things will continue here. In just a few weeks, more than 180 million euros were donated for it. That has to go on. I am disappointed that my own home country, the government of Austria, is not willing to pay with it. I believe that it would be up to every EU Member State to help ensure that more can actually be done here. Because the principle of feminists from the 1970s still applies today: My body is mine and I make my own decisions.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, documentation and analysis of the impact of the global gag rule has shown that the policy restricts a basic right to speech and the right to make informed health decisions, as well as harming the health and lives of poor women by making it more difficult to access family planning services. It has also been found that the policy does not reduce abortion. I strongly believe we cannot make any compromise on gender equality. It is the world’s poorest women and girls who will bear the brunt of any funding cuts. The EU has to ensure the effective implementation of its international aid programmes, in view of the restrictions imposed by partner donors. In the light of the current developments, the European Union’s role in defending the rights of women and girls through its international aid becomes even more important.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! This goes out to President Donald Trump and all of you who take the right to rule over women's bodies. No one should deprive a woman of the right to terminate a pregnancy if she so wishes. Making it more difficult for women to have an abortion only leads to more illegal abortions that are performed with great risks to women's lives and with great costs to society. It's really about life and death. I am ready to take up the fight for women's rights, sexual and reproductive rights and the freedom to choose. Two million girls give birth before the age of fifteen. Those girls do not need less support, they need more. This is exactly what President Trump and several other opponents of abortion do not want to give women the right to - the right to their own bodies. Which governments in Europe stand up and say: “Now that should be enough. She always decides ”? The Swedish government together with about 50 countries gathered in March at the She Decides conference in Brussels. The conference raised € 180 million from a number of countries around the world for sexual and reproductive rights. Opposition is growing to the global gag rule. Together we are strong.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: - Madam president. An estimated 225 million women in developing countries would like to prevent or delay pregnancy, but do not have access to contraceptive methods and available health services. More than 800 women and girls die globally from preventable causes related to pregnancy and childbirth every day, including unsafe abortions. Let's not get confused. We are not now facing a debate on abortion yes or abortion no. What the gag law of the Trump Administration does is block the funding of all those organizations that are working in the field of health, saving women's lives and facilitating access to family planning methods - prevention of unwanted pregnancies -. I therefore believe that this Parliament's sensitivity needs to be shifted towards a measure that is endangering the lives of millions of women. The Commissioner has conveyed to us the commitment that exists on the part of the European Commission regarding funds earmarked for this matter. But we ask for more. We want there to be a commitment to also compensate for the lack of funds caused by this gag law. We welcome the 'She Decides' initiative of the Dutch Government to compensate for this lack of funds. And, furthermore, this morning, in a report approved by the majority in the European Parliament, we have asked for a greater contribution from the European institutions in this matter. We are talking about the lives of millions of women who cannot access these family planning services if it is not thanks to the work that these non-governmental organizations do, which I think they deserve today, here, a great thank you for the work they are doing. developing.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: - As you know, at its February plenary session, the European Parliament adopted its recommendations to the Council on the European Union's priorities for the 61st session of the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women, in which it strongly condemns the so-called universal silence rule.a direct step backwards in the field of women’s and girls ’rights.In addition, this rule could in practice mean that many related health and disease prevention programs in third countries, such as maternal and child health, the fight against Zika virus or the fight against AIDS, will suffer financially.And we certainly do not have the right to allow that, so I really believe that, in this situation, the European Union simply needs to step up its support for third countries in the field of family planning through humanitarian aid and development aid.

name: Maria ARENA
text: - Madam President, on January 23, the Trump administration makes the decision to stop funding NGOs, solely because these NGOs fund services that serve women's rights and the right to sex education and reproductive. This decision will deprive millions of women around the world of access to contraception. It will increase the use of clandestine abortion, which is risky - as we know - for women. It will increase the number of deaths, which are maternal deaths, but also increase the number of gynecological diseases, such as fistulas, or raise the issue of prevention with regard to AIDS. We can therefore only take a position at European level, that is to say no, we are not criticizing the American question, we are saying "what role do we have to play on the international scene in matters of law and rights? women?". I think it’s our duty to be able to make up for what Americans don’t do today. Today, "She Decides" has managed to raise funds in the amount of 180 million. I think that we have to supplement the means which were obtained by "She decides".

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: - Madam President, the global gag rule was one of Trump's first decrees. He not only decided to reintroduce these draconian regulations, but also to broaden their scope. This rule now affects not only family planning organizations, but also all NGOs which, as part of a comprehensive health approach, offer or refer to sexual and reproductive health services. We are therefore well beyond a simple sign of American public subsidies. NGOs must make a commitment not to talk about or offer abortion, even on their own. This rule will deprive of funds any organization that refuses to comply with it and self-censor, hence the notion of gag order. Result: 600 million euros over the next four years are threatened, according to the Netherlands, which has launched a campaign and collection fund. We support this campaign and this fundraising, and we are pushing for the European Union and the Member States which have remained silent to also provide these funds. It is freedom of choice that is gagged, millions of women's lives are threatened, so Commissioner, what initiative do you intend to take to provide a collective and united response?

name: Paul TANG
text: - Donald Trump screams all kinds of things in and against the media.But the details about his global gag rule are quietly coming out and they are startling.Hospitals that perform abortions are no longer eligible for funding.In this way, Trump wants to cut 600 million euros and that directly affects the health and freedom of choice of the most vulnerable women in the world.However, the rights of these women should not depend on who is in the White House.That is why I would like to compliment Lilianne Ploumen, who launched She Decides immediately after Trump's announcement, and to all countries, persons and organizations that have already pledged more than 200 million euros.She Decides deserves every possible support to reverse Trump's decree and prevent tragedies.I hope that the Commission and the still missing Member States will now also make a direct, substantial contribution.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, the European Union is known as the largest donor for humanitarian and development aid, and healthcare is, of course, part of these programs.I am in favor of the EU funding medical aid against epidemics and, above all, the medical care that is often lacking in these African countries.I do not agree with EU funding for abortion beyond life-saving interventions.If the EU is to fund anything, it must be healthcare that protects, saves and does not destroy people's lives.The EU should fund education, awareness-raising and basic health and prevention care.Abortion, dear ladies, is not prevention.I do not agree with the funding of these programs.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, Donald Trump is certainly proving the substance of his misogyny to the world because stifling global funds for women’s reproductive health was one of his first acts as President. The fact of shutting us up, keeping women and girls subordinate, and starving women’s health programmes in the poorest countries of the vital money they need to save lives, is in itself an act of violence. Therefore I applaud the European governments which have come together and pledged to replace US aid money that is being pulled away worldwide. Let us all commit here to replace every dollar withdrawn with money from Europe. I hope that the Commission and all the EU governments will step up to the mark. However, my own UK Government has not yet committed to the initiative. I think that Theresa May’s holding hands with President Trump, hoping for a trade deal at any cost, shows that she has lost international credibility on issues such as this. It is only through solidarity and cooperation that we can turn back this misogynist tide. Let us show this un—President Trump that this is about our bodies, our choice, our rights.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, I think there is an effortless conclusion to be drawn from the debate that the gap in funding now due to US policy should be filled by the European Union, it should be filled by the Member States, it should be filled by the Europe itself to look for ways to find the necessary resources, because it is a given that European help is needed in the Third World, there is a need for public information in these areas, there is a need for education on health, very specific interventions are needed. So, instead of spending a lot of time criticizing US policy, we should rather look for ways in which Europe can really fill this gap, and I think that is where we all need to go.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: - President Trump had barely been president for a week when he extensively introduced the global gag rule. Surrounded by - I may say that, colleagues - old gray men. Now that is not that unique: his Republican predecessors have shown him that. But with this, coupled with his sexist statements, I think he hits all of us, all the women here in the hemisphere, really hard. We all know that America is a global player. That is why we as Europe must act harder. As Europe, we must say: it cannot be that we touch upon acquired women's rights. Because that's what it's all about here: he is scaling back funding, but also makes sexist statements. So I support the colleagues who have argued in favor of supporting She Decides, I support the Belgian minister Alexander De Croo. We were there, I was at that symposium. What you felt there was phenomenal. I would like to feel that here in the European Parliament. Therefore, Commissioner, my questions: what are we going to do to counteract the effects? Are we going to provide additional funding for She Decides? What are we going to do to act against sexism?

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: - Madam President, this is a decision that mainly affects poor women. That's what we have to resist. We owe it to the European Parliament to support these women. Mr. Trump's Gag Rule offends all women worldwide, and we do not agree with this reduction in resources but at the same time look for ways to make up for them, otherwise we speak without results. The reduction of resources leads to abortions outside organized medical centers, with often unpleasant results. A clear message must go to Mr. Trump.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Madam President, the serious problem of abortion, which has come to the fore with the recent decision by the United States Government not to fund abortion advocacy NGOs, is an issue that cannot be resolved through political or economic decisions. There is no doubt that a woman has the right to decide whether to terminate her pregnancy or not. But there is no doubt that abortion is a crime, a murder of an innocent and defenseless creature. So do you realize what a terrible psychological dilemma a woman finds herself in when she is called to terminate her pregnancy or not? Can one imagine what consequences - not so much physical as mainly psychological - any decision will have on this woman? So if we want to tackle the problem, support the family, we need to educate our girls properly and inform young women around the world so that, if they ever need to find themselves in this dilemma I mentioned earlier, take it seriously.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, thank you for this timely discussion – very constructive and very productive. Also thank you for your suggestions and questions. I will try to meet your concerns and your worries. First of all, you may be assured that the European Commission will remain alert on this issue. We have to remain alert on this issue. But also let me reiterate once again: our action is not dependent on others. And I would like to be clear: our policies are driven by our own priorities and by our own values, not by what others do or stop doing. At the same time, if we see a funding gap in development and humanitarian aid, we look into stepping up our assistance to health and gender-based violence projects, should that be needed. And of course, I count also on your – the European Parliament’s – support to reinforce the budgets. My final point, last but not least. Some colleagues referred to the need to inform our partner organisations on the ground. As far as I am concerned we have over 200 humanitarian partners on the ground, in the humanitarian and development field, registered in the EU. And they know better what to do on the ground to help women in need. I have witnessed their knowledge and their action in my missions on the ground around the world. On the other hand, our partners work with local implementing organisations. If there is an information gap there, I stand ready to discuss with our partners how best to address this without compromising humanitarian access and the overall safety of the people in need and of the humanitarian workers. This is my promise regarding the formation of our humanitarian partners and, of course, regarding the possible funding gap.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Before I close the debate, Mr Škripek has asked to make a personal statement under Rule 164, which we will now invite him to do. But I would just say that, as you will be aware, you may not speak on the substantive matter but obviously address observations or rebut remarks that were made about you in person. So I now give you the floor under Rule 164.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Madam President, I did not answer the question I was given because I objected to the fact that I was named by Mrs in 't Veld and Mrs Reintke. I was named because of the content of the debate, so I feel that I have the right to answer. Please explain your objection to me speaking about the content of this debate. Mrs in 't Veld did not attack me. She asked me a real question about this debate, as did Mrs Reintke. So I do not feel attacked, but challenged by the question and they named me by name.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Mr Škripek, as you know, I was not in the Chair during that exchange. Rather than addressing this now (because the debate is almost formally finished), I propose that you address the issue that was raised in the Minutes of the sitting. If I had been in the Chair I could perhaps be more specific, but because this was left to the end of the sitting, and under Rule 164 there are very particular issues that can be addressed rather than the substance of the debate, with your permission, if you would be happy to address this in the Minutes of the sitting, we could accommodate that.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – So what I want to say should be in the Minutes?

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: If it was a question that was raised in the format of normal questions – blue cards – then it should have been addressed at the time of the debate. I was not in the Chair so I cannot make that judgment now, but I would ask you to talk to the services and we will address your concerns in some other manner rather than at this point. Thank you for your understanding. The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - 225 million women in developing countries would like to prevent or delay pregnancy, but do not have access to contraceptives and health services. More than 800 women and girls die every day worldwide from preventable causes related to pregnancy and childbirth, including unsafe abortions. We are not facing a debate about abortion yes or abortion no. What the "gag law" of the Trump Administration does is block the funding of all those organizations that are working in the field of health, saving the lives of women and children and facilitating access to family planning methods to prevent non-pregnancies. desired. It is very important that this Parliament denounces a measure that is putting the lives of millions of women at risk. We welcome the Dutch Government's 'SheDecides' initiative to compensate for the lack of funds. We have approved a report that calls for a greater contribution from the European institutions in this matter. We are talking about the lives of millions of women who can only access health services thanks to the work of NGOs, who deserve our thanks and help.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: written. - 225 million women in developing countries would like to prevent or delay pregnancy, but do not have access to contraceptives and health services. More than 800 women and girls die every day worldwide from preventable causes related to pregnancy and childbirth, including unsafe abortions. We are not facing a debate about abortion yes or abortion no. It is very important that this Parliament denounces a measure that is putting the lives of millions of women at risk. We have approved a report that calls for a greater contribution from the European institutions in this matter. We are talking about the lives of millions of women who can only access health services thanks to the work of NGOs, who deserve our thanks and help.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: written. - 225 million women in developing countries would like to prevent or delay pregnancy, but do not have access to contraceptives and health services. More than 800 women and girls die every day worldwide from preventable causes related to pregnancy and childbirth, including unsafe abortions. We are not facing a debate about abortion yes or abortion no. What the "gag law" of the Trump Administration does is block the funding of all those organizations that are working in the field of health, saving the lives of women and children and facilitating access to family planning methods to prevent non-pregnancies. desired. It is very important that this Parliament denounces a measure that is putting the lives of millions of women at risk. We welcome the Dutch Government's 'SheDecides' initiative to compensate for the lack of funds. We have approved a report that calls for a greater contribution from the European institutions in this matter. We are talking about the lives of millions of women who can only access health services thanks to the work of NGOs, who deserve our thanks and help.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on EU priorities for the UN Human Rights Council sessions in 2017 (2017/2598(RSP)).

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, just a few days ago the European Council adopted conclusions on the European Union’s priorities in the United Nations human rights fora in the current year, 2017. The promotion and protection of human rights is central in our external action. It is consistent with our values, but also with our interest to foster resilience for societies in our region and beyond. I would like to thank the European Parliament for its continuing support in this area. The international community asks governments to respect human rights as universal, indivisible, independent and interrelated values. All fundamental freedoms should be universal. I am therefore proud to say that the European Union is in the lead on many key debates in the Human Rights Council in the General Assembly. Looking at the ongoing session of the Human Rights Council, we will run the regular EU resolution on freedom of religion or belief. This is a complex resolution aimed at promoting a universal approach to religion or belief. We also continue to work with the Organisation for Islamic Cooperation to ensure a good relationship with their resolution on defamation of religion. We will also run, with our partners in the Latin American and Caribbean Group, a resolution on the rights of the child. Our focus shall be on the implementation of Agenda 2030 and the objective of leaving no child behind. Let me now refer to the specific situation in some countries. The conflict in Syria remains the most serious humanitarian crisis facing the world. The European Council has stated several times that the situation in Syria should be referred to the International Criminal Court, calling on the UN Security Council to take action. With regard to the situation in Ukraine, we are accompanying the government’s reform agenda. At the same time, we continue to focus on the reports by the Office of the High Commission for the Human Rights Monitoring Mission, as well as the grave situation in the illegally-annexed Crimea peninsula. Now on the Democratic Republic of North Korea. We will co-present with Japan a strong resolution calling for accountability and extending the mandate of the Special Rapporteur. The resolution will also reflect developments such as the UN Security Council meeting in December, the well-supported UNGA resolution and the new report from the group of experts on accountability. On Myanmar, the goal of our resolution remains stopping the ongoing violations of human rights in several regions of the country, in particular against persons belonging to the Rohingya population in Rakhine State. In light of the high rate of application of the death penalty in Iran, and with an eye to improving the human rights situation in the country, we will support the extension of the mandate of the Special Representative. Allow me one final word on migration. We all know how delicate this issue is and how exposed to abuses these men, women and children can be on their long and dangerous journeys. For this reason, we are working with the UN High Commissioner for Refugees and with the International Organisation for Migration to improve the living conditions of migrants and refugees all along the routes. No other power is as engaged as we are in the protection of the rights of migrants. Thank you for your attention, and I look forward to our discussion.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - The human rights situation in the world, which we are talking about in this Chamber for the first time, is alarming. Especially in open areas, but also in areas of frozen armed conflicts, including in our close, eastern and Mediterranean neighborhood. This was also confirmed by the European Parliament's annual report on human rights in the world, which we adopted last December. Regimes of various kinds are exacerbating repression and I express serious concern over the deteriorating situation of civil society in many places, including the media, as a result of adopting solutions that are also stigmatizing, for example, saying that they are allegedly external or foreign agents. Many human rights activists, including journalists, bloggers, representatives of NGOs, are imprisoned or subjected to various kinds of repression. This also applies to human rights defenders who have been awarded the Sakharov Prize by the European Parliament. Particularly noteworthy is the fact that in the resolution we emphasize the difficult situation in terms of freedom of religion and belief. Also not for the first time: the Middle East, North Africa, some Asian countries too. In this work, we support the European Union's special envoy for the freedom of religion and belief, Jan Figel. We also support the standing rapporteur of the UN Human Rights Council on Freedom of Religion and Belief, Ahmed Shaheed. Christians are the most persecuted religious group in the world today. There are particularly dramatic situations in the Middle East and Africa. We must make every effort to end this exodus of Christians, but also of followers of other religions. The world must learn from these atrocities, and the need for justice and reconciliation cannot be replaced by the logic of revenge. In the resolution, we support the activities of the International Criminal Court. We call here again - thank you for this declaration, Commissioner - regarding the efforts in the United Nations to punish those crimes that are genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes. The issue of people with disabilities will also be discussed during the ongoing session of the Human Rights Council. This is an important topic that must be dealt with more extensively by Parliament. We joined this topic, which is a priority of the Subcommittee on Human Rights of the European Parliament. The delegation will be in Geneva on March 21, among others, which is the Day of Down syndrome. There will also be young people who suffer from it. The session of the Human Rights Council is also a time of bilateral contacts, including with special envoys and rapporteurs who deal with problem areas or countries. We are also continuing our support for the abolition of the death penalty. We also want Ukraine and the situation in this neighboring country to be regulated, to improve the humanitarian situation in Donbass, so that one and a half million internally displaced people can obtain the status of people who can live with dignity.

name: Soraya POST
text: for the S&D group. - Madam President! Dear colleagues! Next week, we will be sending a delegation from the European Parliament to Geneva to present our common position on the state of human rights in the world. I would like to start with the most important thing: the EU must now, more than ever before, defend, promote and strengthen with a clear voice what is the origin and framework of EU peace and peaceful co-operation between countries. We have a super tool in our hands, the realization of human rights. Let's seriously start using this now. The EU must also work closer to the UN, especially with regard to the UN's various human rights mechanisms. This is a much more important collaboration than issues of internal market or common currency. Understand me correctly: Questions about economics are central, but we must remember that they are only tools, not an end in themselves. The goal must be a policy that gives every human being security and freedom every day. When we look out over the world today, we see increased tensions, belligerence, occupation and outright war. Patriarchal logic and rhetoric say that we must fight hard, that we must protect borders and defend ourselves, increase defenses, establish military alliances, prepare for war. We hear these arguments swirling around our legs in an attempt to make us fall over. What we see from history, however, is that this patriarchal logic of agitation does not create increased security and safety, on the contrary. It leads us to war and destruction and dehumanization. It leads to a situation where we can in some inhuman way justify seeing children die and women raped to defend a hill. Involving women in the building of societies that have suffered a conflict is a cornerstone in seeking reconciliation to move forward as a human being. Here it is incredibly important that we do not allow perpetrators to move on in life without punishment. Providing redress for victims is central to the peace process. Even in peacetime, women's rights become strong questioned.Our sexual and reproductive rights face loud opposition.Like violence, this resistance strikes directly at the core of our freedom - the freedom to rule over our own bodies.Here we must take a clear stand on the right to be a human subject.We see the same alarming development with regard to the death penalty.Several countries have broken their deadlines in executions, and some are also discussing reintroducing the death penalty.Here, the EU and the UN must be clear with their zero acceptance of state executions.Everyone has the right to life.In short, we are seeing a growing global opposition to human rights.Its defenders face more and more threats and are exposed to both prosecution and slander.The way forward requires courage and a clear stance on human rights.That is the courage the EU must now show.

name: Bas BELDER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - One question has actually occupied me for years: is there still a future for Christians in the Middle East? This is a revealing, depressing hot topic in panel discussions today. Consider, for example, the exchange of views at the Munich Security Conference less than a month ago. When I speak to insiders in the region about the future of Christians in Syria and Iraq, I hear bleak scenarios: hardly any future. At the same time a nightmare for Christians in the Arab neighboring countries, eagerly looking for escape routes if things should go wrong in their own country. I am thinking of Jordan, for example. That leads me to the honest, urgent question to the European Union: which priority - because today it is about priorities - do the fundamental rights and human rights of Eastern Christians enjoy within our international position? With the follow-up question: if that is really the case, what concrete strategy does the EU use to stop the exodus of Christians in the Middle East? By the way, at the aforementioned conference in Munich, a prominent German politician spoke without detours about “Christocide” in the Middle East. Her and my pressing question to ourselves, to the EU: are we passively watching this humanitarian catastrophe? I end with a ray of hope. At the beginning of this month, Yezidis, Turkmen, Shabak and Christians in Iraq united in a new initiative, al-Rafidein: the land of two rivers, Euphrates and Tigris. It is a plea for an autonomous peaceful region for these minorities in Iraq. A combination of European soft power and American hard power in support of this initiative towards Baghdad could mean the protection of basic human rights. And also, for these minorities, a future in their own country.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, 2016 was marked by negligence and deteriorating human rights situations across the world. As the reality on the ground is very sad, I have hopes that this resolution will allow us to be more focused and speak with one voice. On behalf of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Group (ALDE), I should hereby like to highlight the following elements of importance. Firstly, protection of all human rights defenders in all forms of their expression – online and offline. Secondly, fighting back oppressive laws and systematic practices contributing to the shrinking space for civil society, which includes rights to free and impartial media. Thirdly, international humanitarian law: we cannot allow any more hospitals to be bombed, and must ensure that humanitarian aid reaches those in need in war-stricken areas as well.  In addition, ALDE calls to stop impunity for all States, to comply with ICC and make perpetrators accountable. We are all concerned by the resurgence of death penalties in many countries, especially in the Gulf, and call for a moratorium on the death penalty. More specifically, I should stress the appalling situation of Raif Badawi, the Sakharov Prize winner. He remains in prison and his health condition is unknown, and his relatives are not allowed to meet him. Lastly, we urge the European Council next year to adopt a more geographically balanced country priorities list. ALDE Group especially felt the need that some countries of Latin America, such as Cuba or Venezuela, should have been included.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, once again, I do not like the way we work on this subject. Through this debate, we theoretically give a mandate to our delegation to attend the meeting of the Human Rights Council (HRC) next week. We are unable to prepare a resolution that takes into account the agenda of the sessions of this HRC. Perhaps we will have a resolution, but one modeled on the Council's position which, too, has hardly taken into account the priorities of the agenda of the HRC. I noted a surprising paragraph on the importance for the European Union of international refugee law and, more broadly, of the human rights of migrants. It is noted that the determination of the European Union to guarantee the right to asylum remains unshakeable, of which act. The Council recalls the importance of the interdependence of human rights, but nothing on the main subjects of the CHR in this area: terrorists and human rights, human rights and the environment, democracy and the rule of law and human rights. The development of a binding international legal instrument for companies is also an essential instrument, in particular to respond to the climate emergency. But we know today that the Member States are all against it. There is nothing on the Durban Declaration and the fight against racism and nothing on Palestine. On all these subjects, however, it would be important for the European Union to have a clear position, which reflects a truly universal commitment and not its only priorities. This is the universalism of human rights.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! First of all, I would like to thank the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights for what he has done recently and what he has achieved. I think that deserves all respect. Nevertheless, I would simply like to criticize the fact that countries like Saudi Arabia, China and Egypt sit on the Human Rights Council, which violate human rights themselves in blatant ways. I believe that no objective assessment can be made here. I am particularly interested in two countries: One is Western Sahara, which is in danger of being forgotten by the rest of the world. I remind you of the judgment of the ECJ: it banned the EU's trade agreement from extending to Western Sahara. The Commission had great difficulty accepting this judgment at all. Now is really the time to do that with all the consequences. These people need our help! Let me remind you that the part where you can do business in Western Sahara is occupied by Morocco and that the people who were born there who were residents of that country have no access to these sources, even if they do Somehow they only express the slightest criticism, they disappear into torture prisons, where it happens that I cannot describe it here. The second thing I wanted to address - very briefly - is the situation in Palestine. You heard it: a few days ago it was announced again that old Arab settlements would be flattened and houses destroyed in order to make new Israeli settlements possible. I believe that the EU cannot remain silent here either. I ask you, Commissioner, to stand up for respect for human rights - that is our trademark in the EU.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, again this year, as always, this discussion is back: among my two personal priorities, I certainly mention the case of Burundi and what is happening following the third term of office of President Nkurunziza, which has also violated the constitution: mass rape, torture, imprisonment of thousands of people and daily violations of the freedom of the press and of thought. I cannot fail to mention also the case of Western Sahara and the ruling of the Court of Justice which would certainly push us to do more, not only in words but also in deeds. However, I would like to underline an aspect that is the formal one, of the method, if we want, because even today a system for monitoring fundamental rights at a global level is very far from being what it should be: it is never possible that we continue to elect members of the Human Rights Council among champion countries of human rights violations, such as Egypt, China and Saudi Arabia? Is it possible that European countries do not coordinate from this point of view? How is it possible to have in this Council a country like Saudi Arabia, which systematically violates rights, suppresses any desire for freedom - even religious - and tramples on women's rights? In our resolution we talk about "priority actions": I would like to ask my colleagues in this House if anyone still remembers Raif Badawi, who won the Sakharov Prize last year?

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this report confirms the subjugation of the European Union to the Onusian ideology of human rights: a universalist ideology, which wants to impose itself everywhere in the world, without prior consideration of traditions, history, the rights of peoples. Here we talk about human rights but never about the rights of peoples: for example, as mentioned by my colleague Belder, the rights of religious freedom of Eastern Christians. What does the UN do? What do all these agencies do that spend two thirds of their budget not already on assisting and helping refugees, etc. but to pay the salaries and luxury of five-star officials? It is no coincidence that a great American columnist defined this large bandwagon a "humanitarian jet". And then let's see to whom the assistance is provided: it is, in reality, a mass of dictatorships, satraps and corrupt and spendthrift dictators, whom we see arriving in Europe in large cars with great luxury, in large hotels and we finance all of this! What is the UN doing to put an end to the most serious tragedy we have before our eyes, that of the transport of human flesh in the Mediterranean: its presence in Libya is ghostly; yet, there would be a lot to do there. Why does the UN ask for the intervention of the International Criminal Court against Isis, against the massacres, even on a cultural level, against the tragedies that the Islamic State creates: because it is afraid or because it is in awe of the countries that finance it? Well, it seems clear to me that the concern of the leaders of the United Nations is rather that of having the vote, the support and the contributions of all the nations that support it and this of the money seems to me to be an issue that conditions a lot and unmasks the hypocrisy of this body that always talks to us about human rights, but then, as happened in Rwanda, turns its head away and does not intervene. The situation in Libya and the trafficking that they happen continuously and uninterruptedly document my claims.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, the European Union, as an important player in the international political arena, must work with the UN on the protection of human rights in all parts of the world, of course setting some priorities. These priorities must start with the protection of citizens' rights in the Member States, extend to the acceding countries and then extend to other countries of the world. A basic right of the individual is the right to housing. This right is largely violated, especially in the European South and even more so in Greece, which is damaged by the implementation of the Memoranda. Because Greek citizens do not have the ability to repay their mortgages, banks take them and assign them to foreign companies. These companies buy them at a low price, remove the houses from the Greeks and give them to international NGOs, which intend to settle illegal immigrants in them. I also point out that the European Union must pay attention to its cooperation with international NGOs, especially those dealing with human rights, because they are engaged in illegal activities. It has been proven that they are profiting by collaborating with traffickers of illegal immigrants from Turkey to Greece.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: - Madam President, our debate precedes the visit of a mission from the European Parliament in Geneva to the United Nations Human Rights Council. In this context, I want to emphasize three points.
