First, I believe that more action should be taken at the international level to draw attention to the growing difficulties that civil society organizations and human rights defenders are facing in several third countries. From Russia to Venezuela, including some countries in our neighborhood, or even candidate countries for enlargement, human rights defenders are increasingly threatened and prevented from doing their work. I particularly want to draw attention to the plight of journalists who are quite often put under pressure. To counteract this tendency, we need - I believe - to sound a red flag every time the laws are manipulated by politicians to silence civil society or - as I said - journalists. Secondly, I stress the importance of reflecting at the international level, on the best way to bring justice to the victims of Daesh and therefore to judge the crimes that this organization is committing. As the resolution makes clear, the European Union can play a key role in this process - I recall that in the DROI sub-committee we are currently preparing a report which will address this issue. Thirdly, I support the priorities mentioned, in terms of countries, in the Council conclusions as well as in the resolution we are going to vote on tomorrow. Whether it is Ukraine, Abkhazia and South Ossetia, Belarus or Iran, the human rights situation in these countries must remain on the agenda. international. On the question of the occupied Palestinian territories, I regret the fact that a separate agenda item - number 7 - is devoted to discussing only Israel. This does not happen with any other state and it is all the more regrettable that Israel is a democracy.If we want to defend human rights effectively, we need a more balanced approach, which will strengthen the credibility of the institution.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation facing human rights today describes a picture full of uncertainty and ambiguity. If we look closely, we can say that the euphoria for human rights still exists, but it takes on the most nuanced tones of hope in many places on the planet, where rights are invoked because they do not exist. It becomes disappointment if they are deformed by rampant relativism or by a senseless and guilty political realism and it turns into a critique of human rights when they do not give what they promise, because they are hindered in their implementation and denied or betrayed by unjust laws. In short, human rights have filled the world but the world is now finding itself increasingly poor in rights. We would like to start from here, from this new awareness, from this new approach, looking at the annual meeting of the DROI delegation at the UN Human Rights Council during the spring session The Council document identifies some priorities, both thematic and territorial, towards which we should direct the greatest efforts to improve the situation in terms of respect for human rights. I am thinking of the protection of freedom of religion and worship, I am thinking above all of the protection of human rights defenders who play a fundamental role in the social contexts in which they operate and where they are often victims of intimidation, persecution, threats and imprisonment. I am thinking of the protection of children's rights and gender equality in the framework of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development implementation program and, finally, of the condemnation of terrorism and of the acts of violence and crimes against humanity carried out by terrorist organizations. As regards the issue of migrants and refugees, in compliance with the provisions of international law and the provisions of the New York declaration of September 2016, it is necessary to strongly reaffirm the commitment to guarantee refugees the right of asylum.The complexity of the field of action described therefore requires strong and united action and I wonder if the time has come for the European Union to be able to speak with one voice, so as to be able to assume an important role at theUnited Nations and carry out the most urgent requests, indicate solutions and assume roles of responsibility in the international context on the issue of human rights.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: - Madam President, as the Council conclusions point out, the European Union remains vigilant in the face of ongoing human rights abuses worldwide and will continue to work with all stakeholders to ensure that the relevant United Nations bodies are dealt with on a case-by-case basis. Commissioner, you have made extremely clear the cases of many countries that blatantly violate human rights and individual freedoms and discriminate harshly not only against their own citizens but also against anyone else or illegally occupying territories of other UN member states, acts of genocide and ethnic cleansing threatening world peace, and many of these countries have both the right to vote and the right to make decisions. However, you did not mention the case of Turkey, which violates all the human rights of the Turkish people, while it has committed genocide for ethnic cleansing in the occupied Republic of Cyprus, and against the people of Kurdistan. So along with all the other measures that the European Union must take to defend human rights, we would agree with Commissioner Hahn's position on the cessation of pre-accession assistance to Turkey.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Madam President, 46 000 immigrants were fleeing to the US between October 2015 and July 2016, an increase on an annual basis and nearly double the two years before. Nearly 900 arbitrarily detained people per month. Yes, I am talking about Cuba. Cuba, which is not among the priorities that the Council agreed on and not a priority that we have set up. The political groups went along with the Council’s priorities. But the situation has not improved in Cuba; on the contrary. You will remember that we awarded Mr Fariñas the Sakharov Prize. This person, last year, went on hunger strike with a number of activists. Why? Because the situation has massively deteriorated in the country concerned. There are people that are being detained – some are detained for days or longer, and there is no contact for families. This situation has not improved, and I think that we should be aware of it and next year, regardless of the fact that we are in contractual relations with Cuba, put Cuba again as one of the priorities, as a country which is enormously breaching human rights.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: - Madam President, the double standard in human rights is the worst that can happen to human rights. And listening to the commissioner's priorities, it is very clear. The double standard and the use as a political weapon. You spoke to us about children's rights, you said verbatim: "do not leave any child stranded." And then we go to the UN Human Rights Council wearing on the lapel the agreement with Turkey, an agreement on refugees criticized by UNHCR, by the UN Human Rights Rapporteur, who seriously say that it is not compatible with European legislation or with international humanitarian law. Are you sure there are no children left stranded in Turkey? That is a lie, Commissioner. He talks about freedom of belief: we support him, but we have had radical groups as interlocutors who did not respect that. And in Syria, it speaks of a humanitarian crisis. Look, I was in Aleppo on Friday and the Red Crescent and Christian leaders - the Maronite Catholic Archbishop - told us that humanitarian aid from the European Union had reached the eastern place where the terrorists were, but not now, when the area has been released. We have to look at ourselves, fulfill human rights within our borders, not use them as throwing weapons. Then we can give recommendations. I assure you, lessons, none.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, good afternoon, Commissioner. Also this year we find ourselves debating on the priorities of the European Union for the annual session at the Human Rights Council at the United Nations, a Council chaired by Saudi Arabia, in which China and other states that certainly are not human rights champions are voting. . Among the many noteworthy issues mentioned in the resolution, I would like to reiterate above all the urgent urgency to intervene in favor of human rights defenders, who are struggling to defend the environment and people from the speculations of governments and multinationals, continuing to suffer numerous and serious attacks in various parts of the world. It is essential that the European Union, the United Nations and all international actors show concrete and constant closeness to this category of heroes of our day, who often carry out their work which should be done instead by the institutions that abandon them. What are we doing, for example, to support them and to support those who are fighting against land grabbing? What are we doing to put a stop to the excessive power of multinationals that devastate the environment, the territory and the very life of entire local populations? Eight months ago, we approved a report, of which I was the rapporteur, which provided for corporate responsibility for serious violations of human rights in third countries. We are waiting for a beginning, something from the Commission that has not yet arrived. From the point of view of the nations, we decided not to support this resolution because it was an opportunity to come out strong and decisive against human rights violations committed by anyone, while in reality it turned into an opportunity to point the finger at someone. .

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: - Madam President, the European Union has rightly expressed concern to the United Nations Human Rights Council about the restrictions on freedom of expression in several countries around the world, particularly in Turkey . But it should also question its own practices. More and more MEPs are being prosecuted for crimes of opinion. However, almost every time, the European Parliament lifts their immunity. As a result, their freedom of expression is no longer guaranteed and some states have understood this. We have seen France suing Marine Le Pen for anti-Daesh tweets and Qatar attacking Florian Philippot for anti-Qatar comments. Today, the European Parliament even pilloried a Polish MEP in order to punish him for the opinion he expressed in the hemicycle. More seriously still, the Union now wants to organize the repression of hate speech. Let's not be fooled, this will be one more way of trying to silence her opponents, which she calls populists. The Union is playing a double game: it wants to protect freedom of expression but it violates it when it suits it. The Union does not deserve to be saved.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - Madam President, how will the European Union act consistently in the UN Human Rights Council, in an era when civilizational progress achieved over decades in international human rights law is being threatened by some of its main promoters, as it turns out the election of President Trump, in the United States, or as a result of the European Union's own action, which enters into an immoral deal with Turkey on refugees, and which leaves unpunished Member States, such as Hungary, that attack, detain and expel refugees and co-operate with the free press and human rights defenders' organizations? In spite of everything, I want to highlight here the courageous performance of High Commissioner Al Hussein, in denouncing serious human rights violations around the world, including in authoritarian and repressive regimes that are protected by the United States and the European Union itself. I give as an example the massacres of Irreecha, in Ethiopia, in 2016, and the massacre of Mount Sumi, in Angola, in 2015, on which the UN High Commissioner asked for independent investigations. The European Union has an interest and an obligation to defend the functioning, integrity and independence of the High Commissioner for Human Rights and to enhance the work of the UN Human Rights Council. This is all the more crucial when President Trump threatens to cut 50% of the United States' contribution to the UN, targeting various agencies and undermining the multilateral system, which, despite all the shortcomings and shortcomings, has prevented humanity from rushing forward in a collective catastrophe.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Madam President, the European Union remains a reliable ally of the United Nations in eliminating human rights abuses.Last year was marked by bloodshed due to extremist groups.I would like to quote Amal Clooney, a human rights lawyer, who says "Isis is a bureaucracy of evil" and to condemn once again the terrorist acts and the killing of people.If we want to help those who are really fleeing death, torture and abuse without endangering the lives and rights of other citizens, we should go and take refugees right from the camps where they are,for example from Iran, and to do medical, criminal and security checks.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: - Madam President, the priorities of the European Union for the 34th session of the United Nations on human rights are an excellent basis for discussion. We know, of course, the obstacles which still stand in the way of respect for human rights in the world, the references to ancestral traditions, the right of peoples to self-determination. In short, any pretext is good enough to leave many countries in total disrespect of basic rights. However, the Universal Convention on Human Rights is, of course, universal and not limited to a continent, even the European continent. We support you in your desire to concentrate on certain priorities, Commissioner, including the rights of the child. When will we finally be able to ban child marriage? Yes, the European Union document mentions early and forced marriage among human rights abuses. As we are all in favor of a coherent policy in the matter of the European Union's external relations, it seems appropriate to me to make this point a priority during the negotiations on the post-Cotonou and to see to what extent we can make it an essential condition for continued cooperation.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, the least that citizens can demand of us is that we be consistent. Only five months ago we voted in favor of the report on corporate responsibility for human rights violations. On that day, we all took a position in favor of the adoption of binding instruments that force companies to the great "madness" of respecting human rights. Being consistent means that what we voted then we repeat today, to set the Union's priorities at the United Nations Human Rights Council. It is a great incoherence that this institution vigorously promotes the "free bar" of multinationals through arbitration tribunals while stopping any attempt to hold accountable those who violate human rights for pure benefit, promoting the most heartless impunity. The case of Berta Cáceres is only one of many. That is why I trust that you will join us in demanding that the Commission, in line with what this Parliament has asked so many times and also with the principles of the Union, we support the binding treaty on business and human rights within the United Nations. , so that women human rights defenders can find justice and reparation.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, first of all thank you for your commitment to what constitutes the cornerstone of our values ​​as a European Union, namely human rights. It is precisely because human rights are a long-term struggle that we, as the Union, must continue to work firmly in order to defend and promote them. I have always asked myself the following question: what is our strength, what is the added value of our action? And this is where it gets tricky. It is the balance between action, there now, in an emergency, and at the same time, long-term commitment, investment in the future. Acting simultaneously on these two levels makes our actions sometimes delicate, but our responsibility is greater and we must have the courage to do it on the "there, now", by firmly denouncing the harassments, violent attacks and assassinations of human rights defenders. We must denounce them, including when they take place in partner countries, and it is precisely because these countries are partners that we must remind them that partnership implies rights but also obligations. I am thinking here of some African states, but colleagues have also - rightly - cited other countries. Today, the emergency is what is happening in South Sudan, Somalia, Nigeria and Yemen. The voice of the European Union must be the conscience of all of us who find it unacceptable to remain without trying to do more for the crises unfolding there. Human lives depend on it. In the long term, I completely reverse the perspective. Do you not think today that it is necessary to put more emphasis on the countries which have taken measures to prevent human rights violations and which offer remedies when such violations are committed? ? We must also encourage them and not focus only on the problems.Finally, our support is necessary for the full and effective implementation of the Horizon 2030 program to achieve development goals, especially for equality between men and women.Investing in women's rights and empowerment is one of the most promising levers for combating poverty and for making a major contribution to sustainable development for all of us.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: - Madam President! In times of Trump and Putin, it is very important for Europe to strengthen the multilateral political framework, especially when it comes to human rights. The UN Human Rights Council is therefore indispensable to us, and in the past it has proven to be a very effective and useful instrument. But it is also important to build on this continuity and to defend the rights enshrined in the human rights declaration. But above all, we must meet the current challenges. In the area of ​​migration in particular, it is necessary to press for human rights. Flight and migration are very often the result of systematic violations of human rights. With a view to tackling the root causes of displacement, it would be important to mention Northern Iraq in this context. Here in this house we have just honored two Yazidi women with the Sakharov Prize, and now fighting is starting again in this region. I believe that it is precisely against this background that it would also be important to create a multilateral framework that would prevent something like this in the future.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, Mr Stylianidis, I have not heard you say anything about Turkey, about the violation of the fundamental rights of the Turkish people, about the oppression of the Kurdish people, about the censorship imposed by Ern the fact that thousands of dissidents are now in prison; a Turkey that has committed ethnic cleansing in Cyprus, which now illegally occupies 37% of Cypriot territory; a Turkey that does not allow Cypriot citizens to enjoy their property in the occupied territories; a Turkey which also does not allow Dodecanese Greek citizens to enjoy their rights related to dozens of islands that belong to them and which are under Turkish rule, what we call "Dodecanese properties". These are the overriding important human rights violations.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: - Madam president. Commissioner, thank you for your work. We live in a world in which securities are for sale. However, there is something that should never be and that is respect for human dignity. We are the hope for all people who live in countries where their rights are violated, and it is in their name that the European Union is and must continue to be an example of defense and promotion of human rights at the international level. I will cite some issues that are being debated in the Council, such as the one that defends the empowerment of women. The Security Council approved - on the proposal of Spain and unanimously - the Resolution renewing the women, peace and security agenda and reinforcing the protection of women and girls in armed conflicts and their role in these conflicts . Another high-priority issue on the international agenda is the situation of millions of migrants and refugees fleeing hunger, misery, oppression and who suffer abuse by the mafias that traffic in human beings. We need to face it globally and in the long term. Terrorism is considered one of the gravest international threats at the United Nations. We must also give a firm response to those who want to end our model of open, plural and tolerant life. Let us always bear in mind the victims of terrorism, because they gave their lives for our freedom. This Resolution denounces the persecution of all religious minorities, especially that of millions of Christians in the Middle East and Africa by jihadist groups, to which we cannot remain indifferent. I conclude with the mention that the United Nations High Commissioner has made about Venezuela, denouncing the human rights violations - such as the arbitrary arrests of opposition leaders - and with his immediate request, to which this House joins and to which I I join, of his release.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are witnessing a dangerous phenomenon of growing populism and extremism, which has the effect of exacerbating racism, xenophobia, anti-Semitism, Islamophobia and other forms of intolerance. Without a firm commitment from international bodies to respect for fundamental human rights, dignity and the value of the human person, we risk reaching a world dominated by confrontation, chaos and war. The disastrous humanitarian and human rights situation in conflict zones requires the full attention of international human rights bodies. The European Union will have to continue its efforts to ensure full and unrestricted access of humanitarian organizations to conflict areas and to hold accountable all those who violate international humanitarian law. The European Union has a duty to continue to promote children's rights, namely access to water, health care, hygiene and education, especially in conflict areas and refugee camps, to fight for the elimination of child labor and so on ( recruitment of child soldiers) and the fight against torture, trafficking and sexual exploitation. Colleagues, internal and external coherence on human rights is essential for the credibility of the European Union's human rights policy in its external relations with third countries.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Madam President, the Union's human rights policy has always been an important part of the overall political and economic activities of this Community at global level. The Union must show the rest of the world that it has reached the level of civilization at which human life is sacred and that it cannot allow so many people to suffer daily from curable diseases, famine and war. Accordingly, we should be more committed to the lives of unborn children and help them be born in a safe environment. We will not be able to achieve this solely through aid programs, which often do not produce the expected results, but above all by encouraging economic activity in less developed countries and promoting free trade. We must not remain blind to the fact that European companies are also using the institutional weaknesses of these countries to make additional profits and thus contribute to the chaos in which human life is worth too little. Only by raising ourselves from the moral mire will we be able to help the less developed to rise from the economic mire.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: - Madam President, the Commissioner has very rightly and aptly outlined the issue of human rights for all humanity, and at the same time I must point out and congratulate the Commissioner and the European Commission on their sensitivity to these issues. Besides, the humanitarian action of the Commissioner is well known, as well as his unlimited sensitivity for human rights issues. We are pleased that the European Commission continues to be the watchdog for the safeguarding and protection of human rights. I am not going to repeat what the Commissioner and my colleagues have said so very important and aptly. But what I have to say is that in the Middle East, which has historically been the cradle of Christianity, there is a barbaric elimination, annihilation and leveling of every Christian element and Christians are persecuted as well as their religious leadership. Historical Christian monuments were destroyed, which were the symbol and lighthouse of Christianity. This barbaric activity must be stopped and stopped, and I call on the European Commission to be able to intervene at the appropriate time to restore, re-create and restore Christianity in its cradle in the Middle East. As far as Turkey is concerned, I must say that yes, Turkey continues to violate human rights not only within its own country but also in my own country, Cyprus. Unfortunately, for 43 years now, Turkey has been violating every rule of law, every human right, depriving my refugees of the right to return, depriving their imprisoned compatriots of their rights and freedoms, depriving them of the right to use their property, and unfortunately lately showing an unacceptable provocative attitude and behavior regarding the solution of the Cyprus problem. I believe that the European Union can really put pressure on and convince Turkey that it cannot is a candidate country and at the same time violates human rights in a member country.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: Madam President, UN human rights organizations are now called upon to deal with setbacks in this field, all over the world. In addition to the situations correctly identified as priorities in the resolution presented by my political group, I want to use this intervention to refer specifically to the situation in Latin America. The issue of human rights in several countries in Latin America is very worrying. This region has too high rates of human rights violations. Take, for example, the real epidemic of violence linked to criminal organizations and corrupt security forces, which today affects Central American countries like El Salvador, Honduras, Guatemala and Mexico. In addition to the thousands of deaths to be mourned and the climate of widespread impunity, this violence is causing hundreds of thousands of internally displaced persons, in what is already a genuine migratory crisis. I cannot fail to mention Venezuela, where there are currently hundreds of political prisoners in unworthy situations. Pay attention to the alarming number of femicides, forced disappearances, trafficking in human beings, the disproportionate use of force by the police forces, the security and health conditions of prisons, from which horrendous reports come from various sources. Latin American countries. Many of the situations of human rights violations in this region are related to a particular historical and cultural context. This is the case of indigenous peoples, whose rights to their ancestral territories continue to be disrespected, in parallel with the criminalization of environmental activism and the persecution of those who defend the rights of these minorities. It is true that some progress has been made, but in most Latin American countries reforms that are capable of protecting human rights consistently take time. The time has come for the UN to pay more attention to the situation human rights in this important region of the globe.

name: Godelieve QUISTHOUDT-ROWOHL
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! We very often discuss human rights here. We are adopting resolutions in this Parliament. But not only in this Parliament, in very many institutions - in official and unofficial institutions - there are discussions, resolutions are being drawn up and there are warnings that something should be improved. Is something getting better in our world? I'm not so sure about that. And that's why I first of all make a strong appeal that we start acting wherever possible. This is the first. We have to be ready to actually fight for our views and fight to enforce them. The second is that we must act together. We need much better coordination between all institutions, between official and non-official, between global institutions like the UN and the very local institutions that deal with human rights. And I think we have to think from time to time about what the fundamental rights are that are violated every day. Violence against women is used every day all over the world. We keep silent too often. We talk about when this happens in a hotspot, but it doesn't happen there alone. Freedom of expression is violated on a daily basis. And I believe that it is very important for us in the West, in the European Union: We should have the courage to denounce that freedom of belief, freedom of religion and religious practice are basic human rights.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: - We are in a time when we face enormous challenges related to the protection of human rights. This makes it all the more important that we take action and set priorities for the United Nations Human Rights Council. The situation of human rights around the world must be closely monitored, and we must not wait in a period of conflict and crisis, but must stand up for human rights. The protection and respect of human rights is the foundation for the existence of the European Union, and that is why we must also work within the UN. I support close cooperation between the European Union and the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, which includes both financial support and human resources. Children's rights deserve more attention. Children are the most vulnerable part of society and more exposed to exploitation and violence than others. We must therefore ensure that the Convention on the Rights of the Child is not only the most widely ratified human rights instrument to date, but also the most implemented.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the 2016/2017 report by Amnesty International, which analyzed the human rights situation in 159 countries, an increasingly divided and dangerous world is highlighted, mainly due to politicians wielding deleterious and dehumanizing rhetoric of "us against them". This populist rhetoric has taken on a dangerous force in world affairs. But even in Europe in recent years we have registered a dangerous decline. Emblematic is the case of Hungary, a member state, whose parliament has passed a law which provides that all asylum seekers, including minors, are detained for long periods in containers surrounded by high barbed wire fences. Europe must be able to reaffirm its commitment to combat racism, racial discrimination, xenophobia, intolerance and any violation of human rights. The founding principles of an open and pluralist society, in which cultural diversity is promoted in every part of the world, but above all in Europe, must be respected and guaranteed.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: - I would actually like to make two more points during this interesting debate.The first point is the situation in Eastern Congo.Since 2014, more than a thousand people have been brutally slaughtered there, women have been brutally raped, children have been used as child soldiers.And actually we note that no one is held accountable.We are not going to see who the perpetrators are.We are not going to punish the perpetrators.That is why I would insist on an independent investigation.We must punish those perpetrators, ensure that those acts of violence in eastern Congo are stopped and the victims and their families have a face and a name.We owe that to them.A second point I would like to make is the impending destruction and displacement of the Palestinian Bedouin community in Khan al-Ahmar.A school has been set up there with EU funds that is now in danger of being destroyed.We must also address this.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: - Madam President, I think we need to stop looking for hell in places other than Earth. The city of Raka yesterday in Kompani is hell for its inhabitants. Orphaned and barefoot babies cry for our attention and we do - we say, Commissioner - what we can. However, we are at a time when, according to the great philosopher Nikos Kazantzakis, we must do what we cannot: to transcend ourselves. In Ethiopia and other parts of Africa, people are dying of hunger in 2017. It is a shame for the whole world, but more so for us, who are supposed to represent the civilized part of humanity. And a word for Turkey: I think it was necessary and I do not know if the policy pursued by the European Union today towards this country is the most beneficial. Is there a human right that has not been violated?

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - Whereas the recognition of the innate human dignity of all members of human society and their equal and inalienable rights constitutes the foundation of freedom, justice and peace in the world, because the denial and trampling of human rights in which all people would have freedom of speech and belief, in which they would not live in fear and deprivation, recognized as the highest endeavor of mankind, because it is essential that human rights be protected by the rule of law so that man is not forced to resort to extreme force a revolt against tyranny and violence, a Universal Declaration of Human Rights was adopted within the framework of the United Nations General Assembly. So we also have the European Convention on Human Rights. It is right to talk about human rights violations all over the world, but it is also right to talk about human rights violations here in Europe, between Member States, and it is also right to read sometimes what the Council of Europe has to say about this. it’s here across the water and so let’s listen to their views as well.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, when it comes to human rights one cannot fail to consider that, in such a complex historical moment, fundamental freedoms, respect for human rights and the rule of law are also at risk in developed countries, with possible consequences in terms of violation of rights and dangerous fundamentalisms. At the next session of the United Nations Human Rights Council, the European Union has the opportunity to insist on some priorities in terms of human rights: first of all respect for the rights of children, to verify to what extent the Member States of the 'UN are implementing the sustainable development agenda to halve the number of children living in poverty by 2030. The European Union must take the lead in defining a legally binding international framework for businesses, aimed at eliminating malnutrition, violence, child labor and promoting access to education for all children. Development cannot and must not be associated only with economic variables but, on the contrary, is inextricably linked to respect for human rights.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, in your speech you said that human rights must be promoted and protected. Well, that is what I ask the Commission: to include the question of Western Sahara on the agenda of the United Nations Human Rights Council, beginning with the restoration of MINURSO, with a full mandate to observe and protect rights. humans. I have just arrived from Rabat, where I have been an observer of the trial of the Gdeim Izik prisoners. I have seen the fundamental rights of Sahrawi political prisoners being violated. Reports obtained under torture are used as evidence and it is not allowed to investigate the facts following the Istanbul Protocol. There is a conviction against Morocco issued by the United Nations Committee Against Torture. How can you ignore this fact in your report? Intimidation inside and outside the trial, including the arrest of a Saharawi journalist at the gates of the court. If it is firm in its defense of human rights, the European Union must act to free the Sahrawi political prisoners and to hold the self-determination referendum immediately.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, the first paragraph of this resolution reaffirms the EU’s continued support for the UN Human Rights Council. Unfortunately, that in itself is the crucial point here. With the wave of nativism and nationalism we are seeing, now is our time to defend and strengthen our commitment to international law and cooperation. Many so—called democracies are trampling over human rights: India in occupied Kashmir; Israel in occupied Palestine, for example. Authoritarian leaders across the world – be they Putin, Erdoğan, Trump or others – are being emboldened to violate human rights and cause pain and suffering to marginalised and minority communities. It is up to us, to all true democrats, to mobilise and defend our universal values. Too often, the Human Rights Council is used by governments for their own interests. We need to strengthen our investment in human rights institutions like the Council and work to strengthen them from both the inside and the outside. We need to invest more in human rights NGOs and civil society and invest in education for true democratic values to raise a new generation of human rights defenders.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, this has been a very useful exchange, and I thank the honourable Members for their interventions. From this debate I conclude that we all share a common vision of human rights as a flagship of our external policy. As you recalled, this is not an easy moment for human rights worldwide. Among other things, the challenges to freedom of expression, the shrinking space of civil society and the threats against human rights defenders continue to preoccupy us. Last week I was in Mosul and saw on the ground all these atrocities carried out by Isis. I have witnessed the victims of these atrocities and I met many victims from the Yazidi community. I do of course share your concerns and warnings about all these things. We are increasingly aware that cooperation by human rights defenders with UN agencies can expose them to reprisals. This is exactly what we want to address with our ‘protect defenders’ mechanism. We also look forward to supporting the recently-appointed UN Assistant Secretary—General for Human Rights to deal further with this issue. For the European Union, the protection of human rights is always a work in progress, and this is also true inside the European Union. We are still far from perfect and we have a duty to uphold the highest standards here at home if we want to be credible. But let us also be very clear: there can be no relativism on human rights. We should not curb our ambition to see credible institutions addressing human rights violations, to pursue the rule of law, and to protect media freedom and a strong and independent civil society worldwide. This is an area where more positive results can be achieved, provided the EU speaks with one voice. I am grateful for Parliament’s support to push for EU unity in this policy field.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Motions for resolutions to be tabled in accordance with Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure will be announced at a later date.The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Thursday March 16, 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing.- Cooperation between the European Union and the United Nations on the protection of human rights is essential.Both organizations need to focus all their efforts and prioritize gender equality issues around the world.The European Union must actively support United Nations initiatives to mainstream gender equality in all programs, continue to support measures to empower women and girls and work to eliminate violence against and discrimination against women and girls, including gender-based violence.The European Union must support interregional initiatives for the protection and implementation of women's rights and seek to implement both the Beijing Platform for Action and the Program of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The next item is the debate on the recommendation for second reading of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning official controls and other official activities serving to ensure compliance with food and feed legislation, rules relating to animal health and welfare, health of plants and plant protection products, amending Regulations of the European Parliament and of the Council (EC) No 999/2001, (EC) No 396/2005, (EC) No 1069/2009, (EC) No 1107/2009, (EU ) No 1151/2012, (EU) No 652/2014, (EU) 2016/429 and (EU) 2016/2031, Council Regulations (EC) No 1/2005 and (EC) No 1099/2009 as well that Council Directives 98/58 / EC, 1999/74 / EC, 2007/43 / EC, 2008/119 / EC and 2008/120 / EC, and repealing the regulations of the European Parliament n and of the Council (EC) n ° 854/2004 and (EC) n ° 882/2004, Council Directives 89/608 / EEC, 89/662 / EEC, 90/425 / EEC, 91/496 / EEC, 96/23 / CE, 96/93 / CE and 97/78 / CE, as well as Council Decision 92/438 / EEC (regulation on official controls) (10755/1/2016 - C8-0015 / 17 - 2013 / 0140 (COD)) (Rapporteur: Karin Kadenbach) (A8-0022 / 2017).

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! It will be a little safer again for Europeans! This time it's not about road traffic, this time it's about what ends up on the plates of Europeans. We have had very good official controls in the past, which affected the controls along the food chain. But during the revision of the 882 from 2003 it was found that in this area in particular a great number of parallel controls took place, which did not always meet the requirement of being effective. Furthermore, we have found that over time, of course, other demands are placed on controls and control mechanisms. And I am very happy that we are in the very long, very intensive and very cooperative negotiations - first here in the House, between the individual political groups, then in a trialogue with colleagues from the Member States, in the Council and, of course, with the Commission - have found a solution which, I believe, meets all the demands that we can make of modern, efficient, strict and effective controls along the entire food production chain. We want, as the saying goes, from farm to fork, in reality from the producer, from the farm, from the fattening farm to the plate. But here not only meat and foods that come from the meat of animals, but also plants. The title already said: Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on official controls and other official activities to ensure the application of food and feed law and the rules on animal health and welfare, plant health and plant protection products. So we see that this is a very comprehensive framework that really encompasses all of these control areas Future will cover. We have made it here - and that is a very big demand - that the Member States provide the appropriate funding for all these controls. And here we know that there is not too much money involved in the member budgets, and so I believe the risk-based approach we have taken is the right answer to that. Unannounced, risk-related checks with a minimum frequency of checks guarantee that we use our resources in a targeted manner and ensure health and safety. Food in Europe must be safe, safe and healthy. But we also want to protect Europeans from something else: namely from fraud and deliberate misleading. When I think of the horse meat scandal, which was perhaps one of the factors that triggered the question: In general, there was no health risk for Europeans, but it was clearly fraud and misleading. With the new regulation we also have mechanisms in hand to combat this fraud. For the first time, we have legally established the possibility for whistleblowers to disclose their knowledge of grievances without having to fear for their own position or their own economic independence. We now have a system of even more independence, quality and accountability for the law enforcement agencies. We have a new system of transparency in which the publication of the activities of the official control bodies must be guaranteed, and we can - and this is also essential for me - act much faster than before in times of crisis. What for many of us - and today's discussion on rabbit husbandry in Europe has shown it - is an essential point, which is also recorded here, is the question of animal welfare: we cannot and should not be indifferent to it, like animals in Europe be treated.Even if the slaughterhouse is the destination of their transport, conditions should also prevail there that do justice to animal welfare and animal husbandry.We have suggested that there be reference centers where all this knowledge can be exchanged and to identify the authenticity and integrity of the food chain for animal welfare as well.This project is also future-proof, which means that we have the opportunity to react to new developments in production, to new market conditions and, of course, to new consumer patterns.I'm actually quite proud of what we've brought together here.My thanks go once again to all those involved.It was a tough one at times, but I think the end product that we have created here - a very pleasant collaboration.Europe is a little safer again.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I am very pleased to appear before the plenary here today to successfully conclude our work on the regulation on official controls. This is a very important piece of legislation. It is, as you know, the result of the joint and dedicated efforts of the Parliament, the Council and the Commission. The outcome is, I believe, a credit to all three institutions. Indeed, they all recognise the importance to provide Member States’ authorities with effective and efficient enforcement tools to ensure the coherent application of European law. Consumers and businesses should feel reassured that the control system across the EU is fit for purpose and safeguards the safety and quality of the entire agri-food chain. In particular, the new regulation will, first, introduce a more comprehensive approach to official controls along the entire agri-food chain by extending its scope to cover plant health and animal by-products. Second, it requires Member States to regularly perform controls to identify fraudulent practices and enable the establishment of new European Union reference standards for the authenticity and integrity of the agri-food chain. Third, re-enforce rules on financial penalties for fraudulent or deceptive practices by requiring that those penalties reflect the economic advantage either of the operators or a percentage of the operators’ turnover. Fourth, introduce new provisions for the protection of whistle-blowers reporting on possible cases of non-compliance. Fifth, strengthening the mechanism of administrative assistance and cooperation among Member States in case of cross-border non-compliance. Six, create a common framework of carrying out border controls on animals and goods entering the EU. And finally, seventh, increase the transparency of official control activities carried out by national authorities. The regulation is a major step forward to provide national enforcers with the powers and tools to effectively deliver on their control tasks. I therefore look forward with both hope and expectation to a broad agreement and endorsement of this file. Our work will, of course, continue with the development of delegated acts and implementing acts and through the practical implementation of the new rules, once adopted.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam president. Commissioner. First of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Kadenbach, for this work and also thank all the shadow rapporteurs, the Council and the Commission for the spirit of collaboration that we have had during the negotiation to reach this agreement. If you will allow me, I would also like to have a special memory for our old colleague, Mr Schnellhardt, who was responsible for this report in my political group during the first reading. He strongly defended the role of official veterinarians, which is one of the topics that has generated the most debate. The Regulation will continue to maintain the fundamental role of veterinarians, while allowing, at the same time, some flexibility, by being able to delegate some tasks. It will always, of course, allow the particularities of the Member States to be taken into account for the sake of subsidiarity and, furthermore, these delegations will be highly regulated, clearly specifying what tasks can be delegated and whether the veterinarian has the power to supervise or not, and clarifying who has the final responsibility. Another issue of great relevance, and for which Parliament has fought to achieve this, is that controls are carried out, as a general rule, without warning and based on risk. This will allow control bodies to manage resources according to those sectors that most need to be controlled. As I have already said on several occasions, in the European Union we have the best legislation on food safety, traceability, animal health and animal welfare, and compliance must be controlled. We don't need more legislation. What is needed are more controls and an effective sanctions regime to deter those who break the law. I think we should congratulate ourselves on the fact that fraud is coming into the scope of the Regulation. All risks will be taken into account and not only health risks. Recent scandals in the food chain made it clear that sanctions were not enough. From now on, anyone who commits fraud will be sanctioned, not only based on the economic benefit obtained but also based on the volume of business of the company or subject who commits the fraud. The Regulation that we are going to adopt also clarifies the measures to be applied in relation to imported products, which must also be controlled, and which must be subject to the same rules as European products. Cases such as Xylella fastidiosa, which continues to dramatically affect our olive trees, or the black spot of citrus are examples of the importance of controls on imported products. Also a controversial issue has been financing. Given the complexity of the subject, we have tried to strike a balance, because we need food safety at the same time that we have to ensure that certain controls are carried out. And, for this, they have to be financed. The agreement has maintained the status quo of the Regulation in force, that is, mandatory rates for the meat sector and imports, which will allow the Member States to have sufficient funds to control all sectors at risk. I want to add that above all this there will be great transparency regarding the financing and the way in which the financing has been made.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: on behalf of the S & D group. - Madam President, Commissioner, first of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on the successful completion of the negotiations. We are talking about very important new rules that will improve food safety and help combat health-threatening practices. The food supply chain is often long and complex. That is why harmonized rules are needed to guarantee the same level of safety for everyone and to simplify this process for all involved. Consumers, food producers, traders and industry authorities will all benefit from simplified standards, applied consistently throughout the chain. The new types of controls will be based on risk assessment, thus helping to focus the authorities' attention where it is really needed. Inspections will be unannounced, making it difficult for any attempt by operators to conceal non-compliant practices from the authorities. Tougher penalties will help deter those companies tempted to resort to food fraud. In addition to ensuring better consumer protection, the new legislation will also help support those companies that comply with the law. For example, organic food producers or producers of food with a protected geographical indication, who have often faced unfair competition, will benefit. Food safety, food quality, fair competition and consumer confidence are key elements of this new legislation.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I have been working on this file since 2013. It has been an extremely difficult and technical file, and I would really like to congratulate Ms Kadenbach for getting us to this point, and indeed to my fellow shadows for their cooperative spirit throughout our discussions. The official controls proposal was part of the review of the plant and animal health package announced by the Commission in 2013 with the intention to simplify and modernise existing rules, while strengthening the enforcement of health and safety standards across the agrifood chain. This became particularly urgent in the aftermath of the horsemeat scandal. Negotiations on this regulation have spanned two parliaments and 10 trilogues. I was very happy we were able to reach an agreement with the Member States under the Dutch Presidency in June last year. The agrifood industry is worth approximately EUR 750 billion a year and employs over 48 million people, making it the second largest economic sector in the EU. It is absolutely critical that we have a dynamic and streamlined legal framework to deal with this. A more uniform enforcement of controls across a number of sectors and increased transparency, as well as taking a more risk-based and thus less burdensome approach to controls, is a very positive outcome. This should help to detect fraud more effectively by concentrating resources on areas where they are most needed. If someone is intent on committing a criminal offence, it will not be easy to legislate to stop them, and indeed such intentional action should be met with dissuasive and proportionate financial penalties. By giving Member States’ competent authorities strengthened instruments at their disposal, we can help tackle compliance in line with the level of risk, thereby avoiding unnecessary controls and administrative burdens for SMEs in particular. Before I finish, I must just mention the issue of mandatory fees, which became a very difficult point in our discussions and negotiations. Again, I want to congratulate Ms Kadenbach for her handling of this. I am sure that Member States will now step up and make sure that they have the budgets available to put this into place.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur, shadow rapporteurs, Commission and Council for their good cooperation. We did not, of course, agree about everything all the time, but I think we have found a good compromise.  The proposed new rules on efficient hygiene control seek to deliver improved controls and enforcement along the agri—food chain. Our efforts have addressed three main objectives. First, better safety control along the agri—food chain, which I think we will get through the effective controls system based on risk. Second, more effective rules against fraudulent practices. European citizens want us to secure high safety standards, and these new rules are – or will be – delivering on that point. Third, the new efficient controls will also ensure a high level of human, animal and plant health along the agri-food chain.  This legislation will update and harmonise our framework to better adapt to the more than globalised market and increasingly complex agri—food chain, which today requires flexibility while maintaining high safety standards. We can be content and satisfied with the deal agreed. The final text is balanced, creates transparency and safeguards the independence of operatives and authorities, as well as the efficiency and consistency of the rules. I can without hesitation recommend that my colleagues in the group adopt this regulation.

name: Stefan ECK
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President! Today is a big day for animal welfare in this House, with an overwhelming majority in the vote on my rabbit report. The EPP had to accept a rebuff to its counter-draft, which was aimed at maintaining the cruel battery cages. The report on official controls is also very important for strengthening and monitoring animal welfare standards. The report gives the right impetus to ensure a higher level of traceability for our food by helping to strengthen existing rules and ensuring that new rules are adopted, at least in theory. Unfortunately, the present text is not yet an ambitious guideline for ensuring food safety, but this was not the fault of the rapporteur; it was up to the Council. However, a positive development can be seen that has been learned from past food scandals. For example, the report provides for unannounced controls in all sectors, better enforcement procedures in the event of fraud and clear rules for greater transparency, including with regard to the results of the controls. However, the trialogue negotiations have also shown that we are dealing with a large gap between the good intentions of the legislators and the actual implementation in the Member States, for example in border controls, in the transport of food or the control of animal welfare standards in slaughterhouses. Nonetheless, I support this report as a first step in the right direction and would like to express my thanks to the rapporteur Karin Kadenbach and her team for their valuable work.

name: Bart STAES
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - The aim of this legislation is to ensure uniform control of the food chain throughout the European Union. I think we can be rightly proud of the work we have done. We have therefore spent hours in the negotiations, mainly with the Council and even with three Presidencies. We ensure harmonization of the work of the different food safety control services. We are extending controls from food, animal, feed, animal welfare and animal health controls to plant health, residues and pesticides. We also focus on fraud. We learned from the horse meat scandal that this is necessary. I personally welcome the fact that the specific controls on organic farming have been removed from this regulation and will be covered by the specific regulation on organic farming. There are separate certification organizations for organic farming, which not only monitor the end product, but also the quality of the product and the entire production process. The independence of the inspection services is better regulated. Unannounced checks are essential. There will be more transparency with an annual obligation to publish checks and results. There will be stricter fines. Of course, the specific clause on whistleblowers is also of great importance. Personally, I would have preferred the responsibility of veterinarians in the slaughterhouses to be a bit stronger, but that was not feasible. I recommend my group to indeed approve this report.

name: Julia REID
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, this report calls for further EU harmonisation in order to achieve uniform application of rules for the agri-food chain in the EU. This includes more controls on the use of products, processes, materials, feed additives or substances that may have an impact on food safety and animal welfare. In addition, the report asks for further financial support from Member States in order to perform official controls on the aforementioned products. We in UKIP want to guarantee a high level of human, animal and plant health and we support the aim of informing consumers whilst guaranteeing fair commercial practices in the trade of agri-food products. However, we do not believe that the best way to achieve this objective would be through further EU legislative harmonisation. We oppose the financial impact of this project and believe that national parliaments are perfectly capable of making the best decisions with regard to all those processes, products and activities which relate to food, its production and handling and the rules which ensure that it is safe and fit for human consumption.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Mr President, firstly, I would like to give my thanks to the rapporteur for this lengthy piece of work, and I am happy to welcome a more balanced text. Mr President, I can welcome any report which aims to simplify and streamline European regulation, but especially a report around these important issues. However, I do feel that the Commission should do more to tackle the challenges facing farmers, and in particular the mandatory labelling changes for free—range egg producers affected by outbreaks of avian influenza. These producers have, through no fault of their own, been placed at a financial disadvantage given the need to house birds in high-risk areas. These farmers are worried that such labelling moves may affect the importance of free—range status, devaluing not only their product in the long term, but also their business. The Commission must do more to protect this important industry in exceptional times. I would also like to raise the concerns of arable farmers in my constituency, who are horrified at the potential outright ban of the active substance glyphosate. Such a ban would increase costs for growers and limit the efficiency of their businesses in what are already difficult times. And I would call upon the Parliament, and in particular the Commission, to act on sound science and not scare tactics.

name: Peter LIESE
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I would like to add my thanks to Karin Kadenbach and to everyone who took part, especially Pilar Ayuso, who did that in our group. But she herself pointed out that Mr Schnellhardt did important preparatory work in the last Parliament. Thanks to everyone who has contributed to our having this result today. We have to act when we look at the scandals - from horsemeat to many other food scandals, where the European internal market has been abused to deceive consumers and in some cases there have been health risks. For me, three points are important that I would like to emphasize in particular. First, we need dissuasive penalties. In the horse meat case, there have been cases where the economic gain for the company from the fraud outweighed the penalty. We'll put an end to that. It is clearly stated that the punishments must be dissuasive. We need unannounced controls because, firstly, we will discover black sheep as a result, and secondly, everyone must know: if in doubt, I can be unannouncedly checked. Then the fraud will not even take place because you know you can get caught and will then be severely punished. And then, like some other colleagues, I would like to turn to the subject of fees. The weakness of the original Commission proposal was that it would have forced the Member States to introduce compulsory fees even for small food business operators such as restaurant owners, bakers and butchers, even if they were not guilty of anything. That created a lot of trouble and luckily we negotiated that out. But now my urgent appeal to the Member States is: if you introduce fees, do not blame the European Union! This is just Brussels bashing thing here really is not appropriate.If the Member States want that, they have to turn their heads for it themselves.I am grateful that we made that clear.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the context of sustainable development in order to ensure the protection and promotion of food security and the nutritional well-being of Europe's citizens, it is necessary to regulate the risks to human, animal and plant integrity through regulation on harmonized rules. identity, health and quality of plant reproductive material, animal by-products, production regulation, veterinary and phytosanitary legislation, but also rules on the provision of information to consumers and the guarantee of good commercial practices in trade in products in the chain agri-food. Obviously, the correct and efficient application of EU legislation governing the agri-food chain can be seen through official controls, carried out in Member States and third countries, and the solid but simplified, transparent and sustainable legislative framework for their organization contributes to modernization, integration and the efficient functioning of the European Union's reliable and coherent control system, giving competent authorities access to up-to-date technical data, research results, new techniques and expertise, as well as the most effective tools for carrying out official and other controls. official activities.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: – Mr President, I would also like to take the opportunity to pay tribute to the rapporteur for an excellent job. The revision of the official controls was part of the legislative package and the Commission launched the response to the horsemeat scandal back in 2013. What was brought home to me clearest at that time was the sheer length of the food chain that was exposed from that particular time. In reality, however, the response was far from rapid: four years, two parliaments, ten trialogues later, agreements were finally reached in June 2016. Nevertheless, I am glad agreement has been reached on the proposal, and I hope it succeeds in reducing incidences of fraudulent and deceptive practices along the food chain. It is also less burdensome retaining the use of slaughterhouse staff under the supervision of a veterinarian or auxiliary for meat inspections, and it retains flexibility in Member States in terms of the fees charged in relation to controls such as in the slaughterhouses and dairy products at border control posts. Crucially, the proposal also allows suitably qualified persons, and not just official veterinarians, to perform certain controls. I also welcome the fact that there are more stringent penalties to deter international and intentional fraud and the additional possibility of using a percentage of the operators’ turnover as well as penalties based on the economic advantage sought. I welcome the much waited-for agreement on this file, and that we can now have a more uniform enforcement of controls across a number of sectors, taking a more risk-based and thus less burdensome approach. I would also like to say that I hope this will lead to restored consumer confidence and that trust will return.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: - First of all, I would like to thank Mrs Kadenbach very much for her good work on this file. In the trade in plants, food and animal by-products, the logistical process for import and transit in the EU is of great importance in connection with the required freshness and quality of these products. In order to offer entrepreneurs and authorities - such as customs - handles for this and not to put pressure on the free movement of goods, it is important to focus on simplifying and reducing the regulatory burden regarding controls. I therefore support the text that is now available, which focuses on a risk-based approach to the checks to be carried out while at the same time guaranteeing the safety of products. This is relevant for the large numbers of trade flows that are processed via ports such as Rotterdam and Schiphol. Redundant administrative actions, however small, can cumulatively slow down the import and transit of products considerably due to the large volume of trade flows. I will therefore continue to critically monitor the further implementation and implementation of this legislation to see whether the objectives of this legislation are also being achieved, so that in the future we are not still saddled with unnecessary rules that go beyond the purpose of this legislation.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: - Animal welfare receives a lot of attention in this report, but unfortunately some abuses are not addressed. I will give one example. The presence of a veterinarian is not mandatory when slaughtering rabbits and poultry. And that while it is precisely with these animals that a lot goes wrong during the stunning and slaughter. I find that incomprehensible. The food sector is moving from scandal to scandal and this report should restore consumer confidence. But if countries can decide for themselves what they will or will not check, that will not happen. Do you really think consumers are reassured to learn that in some countries there is not enough money to train inspectors? Do you really think that consumers are reassured when they hear that products that are banned here in Europe are nevertheless entering our market, such as battery cages or hormone meat? I do not think so. We need to close the gap between the good intentions of this Parliament and the reluctance of the Commission and Council to come up with regulations. Otherwise we will not be able to prevent food scandals and animals will be exploited for a long time to come. I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: - I am pleased that the European Parliament, representing the voice of the 500 million citizens and consumers of the European Union, is making public what citizens are most concerned about: the safety, quality and standards of the food they consume.In the context of both trade agreements involving third countries and the agreement to reduce climate change, citizens' expectations have increased even more.Naturally, consumers expect safe, quality food at an affordable price, grown naturally without interfering with genetic modification.On the other hand, the successive crises in the agricultural sector have shown that if we do not provide our farmers with a decent standard of living, we may quickly lose it all.I would therefore like to point out that, while ensuring the highest standards of quality, safety and other standards, those who care about us must not be forgotten either, i.y.farmers.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: - (FI) Mr President, our global food system is currently in a very serious crisis in terms of food safety, health, traceability and sustainability. In order for us to build a better system out of it, we first need a framework law that is able to control our food chain and the products there, from source, production, animal feed, animal production to trade and to the consumer. Many of the big food scandals we have had have very clearly shown the shortcomings of the control system. I dare say that this legislation, which has now been agreed, is the first good, comprehensive control legislation that monitors and produces the necessary information for the whole food production chain. This will also be very important in the future, because animal feeds play a key role in terms of risk factors, diseases, excessive use of antibiotics and chemical accumulations and migrations, as we have seen in previous mad cow disease scandals and so on. We now have powerful tools at our disposal to monitor potential risks. Now we need other good legislation to limit the routine use of antibiotics in animal feed, to limit chemicals that pose a risk to humans, and to limit, for example, the use of pesticides and their accumulation in food chains. For my part, I would like to thank the Commission as well as the rapporteur and the whole negotiating team for a good result.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, European citizens have long demanded reliable, transparent and rigorous controls of the food supply chain. With this regulation, the Union finally equips itself with an integrated, modern and effective control system in the sectors of food products and feed safety standards, veterinary and phytosanitary requirements, organic production and protected geographical indications. For the first time, the global framework will also apply to controls aimed at verifying compliance with Community plant health rules and will provide for a fully integrated system of border controls. The main innovations introduced include the risk-based approach to controls, coverage of the entire food chain, flexibility of controls and a strengthening in the fight against fraudulent and deceptive practices. The added value of a uniform set of rules at European level will offer national verification authorities a context based also on the verification activities carried out in another Member State and on the reproducibility and technical-scientific validity of the results of the controls. Congratulations to the rapporteur.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, under Union law there is a set of rules to ensure that food and feed are safe and healthy and that activities that could have an impact on the safety of the food chain or the protection of consumers' interests in relation to food are performed according to specific requirements. We have raised the issue of consumer food safety many times in opposition to the introduction of genetically modified products into the European market by some with CETA or TTIP. I have also personally expressed my support for the clear and distinct labeling of all products, so that the consumer can know what he finds on his plate. On the one hand, ostensibly for food safety reasons, the consumption of traditional foods that have nourished our societies for centuries cannot be restricted, and on the other hand, no protection can be obtained for the consumption of controversial products of biochemical innovation. Strict restrictions on the quality standards of food products on the market must finally be put in place.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Mr. President, it is good, we finally have the announcement of good legislation that should really protect the health of people, animals and plants. However, let us not run away from the truth and from the fact that we are still witnessing big scandals when it comes to the health of our citizens and the nutrition of our citizens, when it comes to animal welfare or plant welfare and everything that happens in the field and everything comes to the shops and takes what comes to our table. I am in favor of getting this kind of global legislation because we desperately need it, but I am still for something, I am not only for the logic of punishment and control, but I am also for positive logic. Let us support, but seriously and responsibly and to the end, financially support those areas that want the health of their citizens, their guests, animal welfare, plant welfare. Areas, regions, cities that want it. We have such opportunities, we can create a synergy of financial resources. Let’s do this as a good example of good practice. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question) (Rule 162 (8)).

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: the question he asked by raising the blue card.- Colleague Jakovčić, Croatia has recently abstained twice in the Standing Committee, in the Standing Committee of the Commission, which discusses the impact of herbicides and pesticides on human health and GMOs.So, the first time she abstained from voting on glyphosate, the second time she abstained as far as GMOs are concerned, although the official policy of the Croatian government is that there are no GMOs in Croatia.I would like to know what your position is with regard to the regulation that you said is needed both at the global level and at the level of the European Union, and how does this reflect on Croatia?

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: the answer to the question posed by raising the blue card.- Thank you for your question, Your Honor.I will be very clear.With this vote, Croatia has shown, that is, the government has shown that it does not adhere to what is the official policy in Croatia.Because we are not for GMOs.I will personally say, as an active and true farmer, that I really think glyphosate can do more harm than good.We’re going to get rid of some weeds, but we’re sure to bring a lot of non-health into plants that are around what it means to use glyphosate.And I would like to say the following in the end: if you remember, I was the Istrian prefect and we were the first to declare the Istrian county a GMO free region in Croatia.That tells you everything I think about GMOs.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: - Commissioner, three brief notes in this debate: First, we ask that in developing this legislation adopt specific rules so that the homemade product and small-scale processing have their own legislation that allows for its continuity and sale in local markets andshort sales channels.Second, the strengthening of controls must prevent pests such as the solanivorous weave, known in Galician as the Guatemalan potato couza, from continuing to enter the territory of the European Union and spread to our countries.Thirdly, we are calling for legislation to tackle the source of the biggest food scandals.I refer to the logic of the industrial production mode.And I want to remember here that meat meal was legal and caused one of the biggest scandals known in the European Union.Today's checks will not prevent the transgenic or pesticide scandals of tomorrow.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, there are about 28 words in the full title of this proposal and the length is probably appropriate because agri-food chains have become longer and more complex, and as a result the EU is more and more exposed to new risks. Therefore we need improvements in the controls along the food chain, and I was pleased to see the Commission coming forward with proposals in this regard. I welcome the hard work that has been done in the trilogues and I think the agreement provides for a simpler and more effective control system for food and food safety rules, veterinary and phytosanitary requirements, organic production and protected geographical indication rules. This agreement is important to ensure comprehensive scope and it encompasses the whole agri-food chain, which is vital for the safety of the food consumed by all EU citizens. I am pleased that we have a provision for penalties against fraud and I welcome its inclusion. The horsemeat scandal of 2013 is something that must be avoided in future, with better controls and traceability provisions as well as punishments for infringers. The bigger the punishment, the greater the deterrent. We know only too well the potential damage that can be caused for the entire agri-food industry of a Member State in the even of unwanted ingredients ending up in the final product as a result of lax controls, with the ensuing controversy upon their discovery. It is important to stop this early, and I believe that the current agreement will help to do so. It is also important that there is provision included to ensure that food business operators can have a quick follow-up inspection if they are found to be non-compliant. This is crucial, as companies must be able to act quickly, rectify the situation and get back to trading or production.
