A common-sense approach will help eliminate mistakes and hopefully ensure they are not repeated. Ultimately, this is all about protecting our citizens and ensuring that consumers have confidence in the food they are buying and consuming, and that is the job we are trying to do.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Mr. President, congratulations to the rapporteur on a job well done because this is a really complex package of regulations that ensures the quality of food from producers to consumers. The agri-food sector is the second largest sector in the European Union. It employs 40 million people who annually produce 750 billion euros of new value. The European Union has the highest food safety standards in the world, but recent scandals involving, for example, horsemeat in Europe and infected chicken and eggs in Croatia show serious weaknesses in the current legislative framework. European Union legislation is fragmented into 70 different regulations. In addition to the difficult control of disease transmission, too much room is left for fraud in stores because customers are threatened by cheap imported products of dubious quality and nutritional value. The paradox is that we thoroughly test domestic products while products imported from the rest of the European Union have a unique health certificate, often without coverage. In the single market, the sale of unhealthy products between Member States is absolutely unacceptable. The costs of control, no matter how high, must not be an excuse to endanger the health and lives of consumers.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: - Mr President, the main objective of the European Union must be to increase the efficiency of the official control system at Member State level, so that there are high standards of safety and quality throughout the food chain that give confidence to the European consumer. At the same time, there is a need to modernize and simplify the instruments, aimed at enabling the implementation of legislation and guaranteeing a real protection of animal and plant health and welfare, but also of plants. The administrative burdens of small and very small enterprises need to be reduced so that the administrative burden is not transferred to a higher cost of the products being marketed. I also appreciate the need to strengthen official control over marketing standards for agricultural products in order to prevent fraudulent and misleading practices, but - and I also emphasize - the application of appropriate financial sanctions to discourage them. It is extremely important to strengthen alert mechanisms and the exchange of information between national authorities so that, through swift measures, any risk to food chain safety can be counteracted. At present, there are significant concerns in Eastern European countries about double the quality standards of the products being marketed compared to Western European countries. In other words, we have the same product, the same brand, the same packaging, but a different and inferior quality of the product, an aspect that I appreciate as inadmissible. In this context, it is rightly said that sometimes cheese is also made from milk, sausages may also contain meat, and wine is occasionally produced from grapes. Moreover, beyond all that is required by the mandatory labeling of products, effective mechanisms must be found to explicitly prohibit the use of the name of cheeses or sausages. if these products do not contain a significant proportion of raw material of animal origin.Otherwise, instead of saying "Good appetite!"when we sit down at the table, we may say, "Good luck!" because we don't know what we have on our plate.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - President! For my part, I would also like to offer my warmest congratulations to Mrs Kadenbach, because she has really presented this Parliament and, at the same time, European consumers with a great report. At the same time, I agree that, by extending controls to the EU level, we can, on the one hand, serve the smooth running of the internal market and, on the other, protect consumers, in order to maintain confidence in EU products from the point of view of our trade agreements. We therefore call on the Commission to monitor Member States' implementation vigorously in order to have an effective system. For all these reasons, I propose that the report be adopted without amendment. But it is not just the controls that need to be standardized. As a next step, we also need to harmonize national food books. This will avoid the intensification of populist voices based on the different nature of current regulations, which are now deliberately tuning the population against the European Union precisely because of differences in the content of perceived or real Western and Eastern European food.

name: Emil RADEV
text: - The scope of the texts we are discussing now is extremely wide, but I would like to pay special attention to two aspects. These are controls on animal welfare and health requirements. Both topics are extremely important, as they directly concern the health of millions of European citizens and have a direct impact on the European economy. Firstly, the control of animal welfare requirements is closely linked to the issue of poor conditions in recent years for the transport of farm animals, both within the Union itself and in transport from the European Union to Turkey and other third countries. countries. With my colleagues from the Intergroup on Animal Protection, we have repeatedly raised the issue with the European Commission, insisting on more control over the implementation of this type of transport and strict compliance with all existing European regulations. This is important not only to protect animal welfare, but also to protect the interests of European producers. Better control means greater security for the animals themselves, which in turn would lead to less financial loss due to deaths during their transport. You yourself understand that when transporting tens of thousands of livestock each year, the financial losses for producers can amount to millions of euros. Secondly, better control over compliance with the rules for the transport of farm animals will provide greater certainty about their health and safety, and hence the quality of the products from these animals and the whole food chain. This would be extremely beneficial in terms of preventing and reducing the risk of disease, both in animals and in humans. After all, human health is the highest priority. I therefore welcome the recommendations in the report and thank the committee and the rapporteur for job well done.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: - Mr President, the main issue is what ends up in the human body through the chain of animal nutrition and plant breeding, but also the behavior of animals itself demonstrates the level of our culture. Controls in the Member States must be stepped up, and with sudden interventions, and the method of repression must be attempted in addition to preventing any fraud. Appropriate penalties for offenders are also a necessary measure. Human civilization, dear colleagues, acquires real meaning if our attitude towards the other creatures of the earth is at the level we deserve. Until the day when man manages not to have to kill other creatures of the earth for his food let us at least try to behave like rational animals.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - So the food industry, in all its complexity, also poses certain risks, as confirmed by some scandals, some unfair trade practices, and some recent allegations that certain similar products are being sold in different countries from west to east.with a completely different quality.It is therefore right to regulate greater security controls, effective anti-fraud rules, effective sanctions and, of course, to introduce a high level of security, because, after all, this is also intended to protect consumers, operate more transparently and raise standards in the field ofdiet.I do not think it is a secret, of course, that some corporations in this sector also use certain controversial means in the name of profit, from phytosanitary, which are otherwise prohibited, and pharmaceutical, which are harmful to health, and I thinkput an end to this practice.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am grateful to Parliament for its important contribution, hard work and constructive approach throughout the development journey of this file. Today I heard broad support in our debates.  I can only agree that implementation is key. I am sure that Member States – especially now, when the economy is growing – will allocate sufficient resources for that. I would like to thank and congratulate the rapporteurs – Mr Pirillo, under the previous term, and Mrs Kadenbach, under the current term of Parliament – for reaching an agreement in the political negotiations. I would also like to thank the shadow rapporteurs and the teams involved in the negotiations for all their efforts and valuable input. I think they are on the right track and that we will see very good results.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: Rapporteur. -  Mister President! I would once again like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs, but also everyone who spoke up today, for this very constructive climate that we not only had in advance, but also today. And, Commissioner, I have a very big request: on the basis of this regulation, the Commission is empowered to adopt the proposed delegated and implementing acts. And, as you know, there were a number of provisions and regulations that Parliament would have liked to have included in the basic act. But negotiations mean that one cannot insist on some of these things, but has to make friends with other forms of legislation. Nonetheless, I would ask you to continue to convey the spirit and the atmosphere in which the negotiations were conducted and in which this discussion took place here today in the drafting and subsequent adoption of these delegated and implementing acts. It was a very constructive climate - a climate with the aim of having a regulation here that really fulfills these expectations of consumers and, on the other hand, of course, does justice to all honest producers by not burdening them excessively. I think this regulation does all of that. Help us to restore consumer confidence in food safety and in the quality of our food to the extent that we deserve it! You have our trust, Commissioner. We will be happy to contribute to the implementation and implementation of this regulation, as far as we can. Keep us up to date! We will take a very close look at how things continue here.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate based on the Declarations of the Council and the Commission on the follow-up of the recommendations of the TAXE Commission and updated information on the reform of the Group "Code of Conduct" on taxation of thecompanies (2017/2600 (RSP)).

name: Ian Borg
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, first of all I would like to thank you for giving me the opportunity to address you on the essential topic of the fight against tax evasion, fraud and avoidance. This is a shared EU goal that has constantly been highlighted by the European Parliament, the European Council, the Council and also the Commission. Similarly to previous Presidencies, the Maltese Presidency has placed the fight against tax evasion, fraud and avoidance among its top priorities on the Council’s agenda. The TAXE resolution of July 2016 called for a significant number of measures to be adopted in a large number of areas. I will give you an update on the achievements reached to date in the Council in reply to the general call for action. In a nutshell, the Council completed work on the Anti-Tax-Avoidance Directive 1 and 2, on the Administrative Cooperation Directive 4 and 5 and on defining criteria to establish a list of non-cooperative jurisdictions. More specifically, we have called on the Member States to adopt measures to counter aggressive tax planning, tax avoidance and the particular mismatching tax qualifications that lead to cases of double non-taxation. In a joint effort to speed up our common fight against tax avoidance, the Council reached two political agreements on an Anti-Tax-Avoidance Directive. The directive provides for a comprehensive framework of anti-abuse measures aimed at ensuring that taxation will happen where value is created. Measures such as the control of foreign companies and anti-hybrid-mismatch measures that you mention in your report are no longer a wish but a binding reality for all Member States. As a result, the European Union can claim that the measures to counter base erosion and profit shifting, which were given impulse by the G20 and the OECD, have now been translated into the EU binding instrument. In several respects we went even further than the basic OECD recommendations. As regards transparency and exchange of information, I am also in a position to report that progress has been achieved on the Administrative Cooperation Directive, as multinational companies will now be obliged to report key tax information on the amount of revenue, profit before income tax and income tax paid in each country where they do business. In order to reinforce transparency, tax authorities have also been given the competence to access anti-money-laundering information, in particular on the beneficial ownership of companies. Furthermore, Parliament also called for  progress to be made on a common consolidated tax base. Responding to that call, the Commission issued two legislative proposals that the Presidency has put on the table in the Council. The Council has identified a working method to deal with those proposals, starting with the common corporate tax base, and we are currently working on the new elements introduced by the Commission on research and development, allowance for growth and investments and cross-border loss relief. We will also strive to increase tax certainty by, we hope, making as much progress as possible in establishing a mechanism that will improve double-taxation dispute resolution. This could be achieved by making alternative dispute resolution mechanisms binding, faster and more efficient. Honourable Members, turning to the Code of Conduct Group on business taxation, developments aimed at improving its working methods and effectiveness have been undertaken. We have adopted two sets of conclusions which enhance the effectiveness of the Code of Conduct Group. One of the group’s main tasks in the near future will be to finalise the process of establishing the EU list of non-cooperative jurisdictions for tax purposes. I would also take this opportunity to recall that this is an inter-governmental exercise, to be carried out in the Code of Conduct Group in conformity with the competences as set out in the Treaties. To sum up, the Presidency is striving to move forward systematically on the basis of a clear road map for the Council’s work in the field of tax evasion, fraud and avoidance at EU level.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: membre de la Commission. – Monsieur le Président, Monsieur le Président du Conseil, Mesdames et Messieurs les députés européens, il y a une saison, c’est celle-ci, pour regarder les réussites et les insuffisances de ce que nous faisons comme Union, avec l’objectif de définir la voie à suivre dans l’année qui suit. Assessing where we are today, where we need to go and where the added value of the EU actually lies, this is a useful contribution to the wider debate. Therefore, I very much welcome your invitation to discuss the progress we have made and the work still to be done in delivering on one of the top priorities for EU citizens today, which is fair taxation. We know that taxation has a vital role to play in addressing some of the biggest challenges we face in Europe today. The need for more social justice, the need for equal treatment and opportunities for all, and the need for stronger economic growth with more jobs and more investment. And that is why the Commission has given the highest priority, as you know, to advancing an ambitious agenda for tax reform throughout our Union. Our agenda for fair taxation rests on the two twin pillars of transparency and effective taxation. With these pillars as our base, we have built a new, improved and crucially fairer corporate tax framework for the entire EU, and we have done so in a remarkably short space of time. D’abord, la révolution de la transparence, que j’ai appelée de mes vœux, prend forme. Elle pousse nos États membres vers un niveau sans précédent d’ouverture et de coopération sur les sujets fiscaux. L’échange automatique d’informations sur les rescrits fiscaux, les tax rulings, le country by country reporting, l’échange d’informations sur les données comptables et fiscales entre autorités fiscales, tout cela est maintenant incorporé dans la loi européenne. De nouvelles règles européennes vont autoriser les autorités fiscales à accéder à des informations cruciales pour lutter contre le blanchiment d’argent, pour mieux faire en sorte de fixer les audits et les enquêtes. La Commission a aussi répondu à l’appétit de nos concitoyens, aux exigences de nos concitoyens pour plus d’informations sur les pratiques fiscales des multinationales, avec cette proposition, le country by country reporting – dont je rappelle ici à quel point la Commission est attachée à la publicité et à la transparence – et, depuis le 1er janvier de cette année, les États membres échangent automatiquement les informations sur les comptes financiers, pour faire en sorte de mettre fin à la pratique du secret bancaire et pour que l’on voie qui cherche à cacher son argent hors des frontières. Sans aucun doute, nous avons poussé la transparence autour des systèmes fiscaux et des pratiques fiscales en Europe avec un véritable résultat, qui fait que nous avons franchi un premier pas pour rétablir la confiance publique dans nos systèmes fiscaux. En parallèle, nous avons travaillé sans relâche pour nous assurer que toutes les entreprises, grandes et petites, paient leurs impôts là où elles créent leurs profits. Nous avons maintenant des règles anti-abus qui sont contraignantes pour toutes les formes de transferts de profits, et c’est ce que dit notre directive anti-évasion fiscale. Cette directive a été acceptée et votée par le Conseil en un temps record. Elle a, récemment encore, été complétée par des mesures additionnelles pour traiter ce qu’on appelle les hybrides avec les pays tiers également. Nous avons utilisé – comme vous le savez – nos outils en matière d’aides d’État pour traiter de cas qui ont trait à la concurrence fiscale inéquitable, et nous avons poussé – comme l’a rappelé le Président – le code de conduite à s’assurer que les États membres jouent de manière équitable sur le régime préférentiel. Enfin j’ai relancé le projet fiscal le plus ambitieux de tous, qui est ce qu’on appelle le CCCTB, l’assiette commune consolidée pour l’impôt sur les sociétés, et nous voulons là un système fiscal qui soit capable d’anticiper, qui soit capable de se mettre à la hauteur des défis que nous rencontrons en matière de taxation d’entreprises aujourd’hui, et aussi à l’avenir. Our agenda for fair taxation over the past two years has also extended beyond the borders of our Union. With today’s globalised economy and interconnected markets, the external threats of base erosion and unfair competition cannot be ignored. Therefore, we have stepped up our work to export a higher level of tax good governance worldwide, especially in the framework of the G20, and we will have a G20 meeting of Finance Ministers at the end of this week at Baden-Baden, for the first time in the presence of the Secretary of the Treasury, Mr Mnuchin, with whom I had the occasion to exchange yesterday. Our preferred approach is a cooperative one, to work closely with international partners for fairer competition, higher standards and a level playing field. We have positive incentives to achieve this, such as development head, EU funding and bilateral agreements, and we continue to be active players in shaping the tax agenda in international fora such as the G20 and OECD. However, there are some countries that consistently refuse to play fair, despite our best efforts to collaborate with them. With these countries it is time to play tough. By the end of this year, the first EU list of non-cooperative jurisdictions will be published, together with appropriate common sanctions, and it will be something very important. Our Member States are honouring their international tax commitments, so other countries must do the same. Honourable Members, you have asked for an update on how the Commission responded to the recommendations of the TAXE 1 and TAXE 2 committees. The brief overview that I have just provided should reassure you that our agenda fully reflects and respects the expectations of this Parliament. As I always say, we are on the same side, respecting our diversity and our differences, but fighting for the same cause. Many of the actions called for by TAXE are now binding in EU law. Many of TAXE’s recommendations are now robust Commission proposals waiting for the agreement of the Member States. Let me give you just a few examples, which prove that our institutions have a shared vision on what is needed to secure fair taxation. The EU list: transparency on tax rulings; improved anti-money laundering provisions; public country-by-country reporting; tighter rules for patent boxes; the relaunched CCCTB. These were all recommended by Parliament and proposed by the Commission, some of them adopted by Member States. And there is more to come. For example, in line with TAXE’s report, we will propose greater scrutiny on revisers and intermediaries by the summer, to clamp down on those that promote aggressive tax planning schemes. We are also exploring how to better protect whistle-blowers and are examining ways to boost transparency on beneficial owners. For the Commission, the work of TAXE 1 and 2 has been a valuable asset, both as a source of inspiration and as a strong political backing for the many new initiatives we have brought forward. I have every confidence that we can rely on the same positive relations with the PANA Committee as it advances with its work, and I am fully ready to cooperate with this committee, as I did with the previous ones. You have also asked specifically about the reform of the Code of Conduct, which was among TAXE’s recommendations. On this particular point the results, I must say, are mixed. The Commission pushed very hard for an ambitious reform to make the Code more relevant, more transparent and more accountable. Some progress has been made; for example, the Code is now committed to more regular and transparent reporting of its activities, and the chair of the Code will appear before this Parliament, as well as ECOFIN, when needed. In terms of the content of the Code itself, technical work has started to review the criteria, so that they are more relevant to modern realities. But I have to admit that so far, the scope and pace of the reform in Council has not been as fast as I, and I know as many of you, would like. I do think that more could and must be done if Member States got fully beyond this project. A new Chair has recently been appointed to the Code Group, and this creates potential for a new momentum to be injected into the reform process. So I would suggest that you keep up the political pressure on your side for real and meaningful improvements to the Code of Conduct. On our side, the Commission will provide all the support that we can to this process. Looking ahead, I would stress that the many achievements so far in our fair taxation agenda should not be an excuse for any complacency. If anything, we need to be more vigilant than ever in ensuring that the momentum is maintained. Proposals must be agreed, commitments must be respected and legislation must be properly implemented. As already indicated, the Commission is working on more new initiatives to reinforce transparency and fairness in our tax systems, and we will continue to respond quickly and decisively to new challenges as they arise. However, we are not the only institution with obligations to fulfil: important proposals which need to be agreed quickly – I am conscious of that – are in your hands now, notably public country-by-country reporting and revision of the anti-money laundering directive. I would encourage you to use your combined forces of ambition and pragmatism in order to reach consensus with the Council as soon as possible. I would also urge you to keep the spotlight on crucial files such as the CCCTB, which rely entirely on the agreement of our Member States to become a reality. As we have seen before, political and public pressure has a powerful capacity to deliver results. It is the most powerful capacity. Chers membres du Parlement européen, j’espère que j’ai pu vous rassurer aujourd’hui et vous convaincre que lorsqu’arrivent les sujets de taxation et de fiscalité européenne, les positions, les suggestions, les demandes de ce Parlement, sont prises très au sérieux. Votre apport a un impact extraordinairement positif sur notre agenda. Votre attention, votre vigilance, votre exigence politique nous ont aidés, voire m’ont aidé, à obtenir des résultats inespérés dans le passé, à une vitesse absolument record et d’une manière qui aurait semblé absolument inimaginable il y a quelques années. Nous en avons des mérites. Il y a aussi bien sûr la crise, les crises, les scandales qui sont passés par là et qui ont mis une pression plus forte sur les États membres. Je voudrais conclure en vous remerciant pour notre partenariat, pour votre soutien dans ce travail que nous menons en commun pour une taxation juste pour toutes les entreprises et pour le bénéfice de tous nos concitoyens qui sont conscients qu’il y a là un champ encore inespéré il y a quelque temps, et vraiment très puissant, pour une vraie preuve de l’efficacité et la nécessité de la construction européenne.

name: Werner LANGEN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mister President! If I have heard what has been said here - once by the Minister from Malta - then everything is well on its way. Tax equity was not included as a Presidency priority and practice in Malta leaves much to be desired, despite all the progress. Mr Moscovici has now explained in fourteen minutes and thirty seconds what you are doing - it seems that he is now on the march. It is very kind of you, Commissioner, to leave now that Parliament is leading the debate! I don't think you should do that. You should stay here and listen! Because what you have announced here is an ambitious program. When half is achieved by the end of 2017, we will give you the greatest applause. Because so far the member states have blocked it, and on a large scale. And if transparency is seen as the most important point here, I can only say: transparency is not guaranteed. As the Panama Committee, we have seen documents from the Code of Conduct group: the most important passages in the Member States' negotiations have been blacked out. It is a provocation for Parliament to give us documents - it passed through your hands, but it is not your responsibility, Commissioner, for the crucial passages being blackened out there. And here the Commission and the Maltese presidential representative preach that more transparency is the most important issue. So there is still a lot to catch up on. I would like to express my thanks to TAXE 1 and 2, because it is indeed the case without TAXE 1 and 2 - and I look at Chairman Alain Lamassoure - this public pressure would not have been generated. TAXE was primarily about tax rulings and behavior, accounting systems that the member states tolerate - an unfair tax competition initiated by the Member States.Panama is about the individual behavior of market participants, banks, lawyers, tax advisors, and there is still a lot to be done there.I can only encourage you to actually implement the great track record that has been announced here by both sides.We won't let up!We know that the Commission is in good faith that you want to help - no question at all, Commissioner.But the common instruments that we have been denied, in terms of information and transparency and influence, the fact that, under the pretext of unanimous tax policy, the Member States have tolerated a system for decades here that is irresponsible to the citizens: that isour topic, and we will follow up on this, and if necessary we will also quote those responsible to the Panama Committee!

name: Peter SIMON
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. -  Mister President! I would like to expressly endorse what Mr Langen has said and express my thanks to the Commission for taking up what we asked for, for putting legislation in place where the TAXE Committee asked for it. However, I would like to expressly address the Maltese Council representative, who has highlighted various points that have been initiated, but from my point of view has only ever illuminated the side on which the sun is currently shining. We disregarded the pages in the shadows, and I would like to revisit them for a moment. You rightly pointed out that we are now launching a list of non-cooperative jurisdictions and that the Code of Conduct Group is to draw up this. However, they explicitly do not include as a criterion that a non-cooperative area, where one has zero percent taxation, is a tax haven. Sorry: what is a tax haven if not a country where there is no corporate taxation? Can you explain that to me? I don't think you can explain that to anyone outside. Then you rightly said that in future we will have a better overview of what taxes multinational companies pay, that we will have country-specific reporting. However, you have not indicated that this is limited to only those companies that have annual sales of more than 750 million. However, over 90% of the internationally active companies in Europe fall through the cracks. That is not enough! 40 million sales is the threshold we have for large companies in Europe. Be brave! Really go ahead, address all the companies that should actually be affected here and take legal action! I would also like that if we become the beneficial owners in the future published - you rightly pointed out that we have made substantial progress in this regard - and at the same time sanctions are introduced wherever this is not possible.We call for no more trading with such companies in the EU.Be brave!Go ahead and not only whenever parliament is forcing you through political pressure!

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. - (FI) Mr President, the European Community's work to avoid double taxation began with the Treaty of Rome in 1957. In this world of the 1950s, reducing the threat of double taxation was a big step forward in encouraging international trade. The finance executives of big industrial companies couldn’t even dream of the kind of tax planning arrangements we’ve seen in this millennium used by big business like Apple, Google, and Starbucks. The Code of Conduct for Business Taxation, conceived at the European Community Finance Ministers' meetings in 1996 and 1997, was an important milestone at the time. Interstate tax wars were becoming a problem, and the Code of Conduct Group managed to put a brake on the development of the worst models. However, in the world of LuxLeaks, aggressive patent boxes and increasingly complex tax products, the mandate of the Code of Conduct Group is outdated. This is also underlined by The Guardian's January revelations about Luxembourg's problematic role in the group. The role of the group needs to be strengthened and its remit and range of means expanded. Transparency and representativeness must also be increased. The final report of the first TAXE special committee provides a good basis for this. Key reforms would include the election of a permanent, politically accountable chair, the extension of the criteria for harmful tax practices, including the impact on non-EU countries, the strengthening of the implementation of decisions and regular visits by finance ministers and senior officials. The publicity of decisions must also be increased. I am in favor of taking these recommendations as a basis for reforming the Code of Conduct Group.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: for the ALDE Group. - Mr President! When you read the reports from TAXE 1 and TAXE 2 and compare Parliament's wishes with reality, you get a little desperate. One has to ask oneself the question whether we have the muscle at all to pursue the policy that everyone in this Chamber is now calling for. Many answer that question with a no for the simple reason that it is so easy for the Council's minority members to stop all development. However, there are at least some opportunities to move forward. Firstly, through Article 20 (1), we have the opportunity to allow those Member States that are genuinely concerned about tax evasion to go their own way, to create sustainable patterns for how Member States should behave. That way, we can leave behind those who do not want to follow current moral rules. Then, of course, we have another problem that is interesting and that in a specific way applies to Malta. We can understand that a small island in the sea, where there is not much crop and where there are not terribly many conditions for an extensive industry, needs something, but not the reverse transfer union that we have now created, ie. that one transfers money to oneself through a tax system that does not abide by the moral rules. We therefore need to review our means of cohesion and offer Malta an honest way out of this awfulness that the country has experienced. So there are opportunities. We are only calling for a little will, and we are also calling for a Commissioner to listen to us.

name: Fabio DE MASI
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. -  Mister President! Since LuxLeaks, the EU member states have vowed to fight corporate tax tricks. We lose hundreds of billions of dollars annually to Disney, McDonalds & amp; Co, while the EU threatens to collapse because of the policy of cuts and a lack of investment. But the truth is unfortunately not on the pitch, but in the dressing room behind closed doors, where it stinks like in football. The Code of Conduct group has been responsible for combating harmful tax competition for 20 years. And since then she has not managed to do it and plays like empty bottle. The Maltese government is also addressed here, which among other things is softening the criteria for the black list. Try to explain to one of the viewers here why you are not a tax haven if you do not charge taxes. Anyone who grants EU tax havens a right of veto turns the goat into a gardener. Mr. Juncker also permanently hindered progress, as documents that I evaluated with my colleague Sven Giegold show. Without a reform of the code group and the EU treaties, we will be slowed down again and again - whether with a black list of tax havens or a consolidated determination of corporate profits in the EU. However, this does not only affect Luxembourg, but also Germany, for example because it blocks public reporting by corporations. Keyword variable geometry: How about if a coalition of the willing - Germany and France - finally takes the lead on minimum taxes and penalty taxes for financial flows in tax havens, as long as the EU treaties are not reformed? The Left parliamentary group continues to complain that the code group's documents have been fully inspected. Mr Juncker, given his register of sins, has to make code group reform a top priority and we will be monitoring very closely what the Maltese Presidency is doing in the negotiations on the Money Laundering Directive given that some members of the cabinet were themselves involved in the Panama Papers.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mister President! First of all, it has to be said very clearly that some things have changed since the big scandals. Internationally, at the G20 level and also at the European level, we have decided on a whole series of things that a few years ago would have been considered completely utopian. We have seen progress in combating tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance. But unfortunately we are now seeing a relapse. And here I have to address you very directly in the Council: No matter which Commission proposal you take, you always delay! Always water down! You only know one direction when it comes to tax cooperation: backwards. Mr Moscovici has presented everything that he has promised us. Mr. Juncker has presented what he has promised us - here he has changed a little from Saul to Paul. Unfortunately, none of this helps, because the Member States are doing exactly what you have said here: they believe that this belongs in the field of intergovernmental cooperation. But that is not in the European treaties. In the European treaties there is an internal market that is fair and corresponds to the social market economy. And in the tax area that means unanimity in the Council, but unfortunately not intergovernmentalism. It is therefore correct that the Commission must now draw the right conclusions from the watering down of the last proposals. Submit the next steps in accordance with Article 116, in the framework of co-decision with the European Parliament. It says: If markets are distorted, decisions can also be made in the tax area according to a majority procedure in the Council and with the participation of the European Parliament. Then there is an end to negotiating behind closed doors and irresponsibility in the area of ​​taxes. Article 116 shows the way, Mr. Oettinger! I hope that the Commission will present its next proposals in this area Present the basis of strong European democracy so that the tax loopholes are finally closed.

name: David COBURN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, for two years, MEPs in the Special Committee on Tax Rulings (TAXE) have kept themselves busy inventing a concrete aeroplane. Of course, nobody is in favour of tax fraud. But the Committee was hijacked by left wingers and Euro-federalists. In the EU, the legal practice of tax avoidance has become a synonym for illegal tax evasion. The more complicated you make tax, the worse it is for small business. Instead of simplifying, the EU is harmonising tax and abolishing competition between various jurisdictions. The Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base is just another part of the EU’s corporatist agenda to maintain the tax cartel between Europe’s socialist economies. Tax competition forces governments to be efficient, and saves taxpayers’ money. Fortunately, we will soon be out of this place and will be able to exercise due diligence in these matters ourselves.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, I regret that Mr Moscovici spoke before hearing the truth about the European Commission. The "code of conduct (corporate taxation)" group was created in 1998, officially to identify legislation favoring excessive tax avoidance and optimization. The conclusions of the “Tax” commission in 2015 clearly showed that this “project management” group was a total failure and its work remained a dead letter. The result: nearly twenty years lost in the fight against tax fraud and optimization, and above all hundreds of billions lost by the coffers of European countries. For France alone, it is 17 billion euros per year in lost tax revenue, especially during the period when Mr Moscovici was himself Minister of the Economy and Finance. I understand better why he left. So it is he who is responsible for the breakdown of the European Union and not Marine Le Pen - she is simply defending France. The countries victims of these tax evasion pay for the duplicity of Jean-Claude Juncker in Luxembourg and the hypocrisy of national leaders. It is true that it is difficult to run two hares at the same time: globalism and the drifts of deregulation. Patriots are eager to hear about the Union's proposals, facing the risk of a new tax haven with the post-Brexit UK. We want the people to stop drinking in place of the multinationals and your European oligarchy.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mr President, Einstein once said that the hardest thing to understand in the world is taxation. When you look at this Special Committee on Tax Rulings (TAXE) and you look at the Commission, you can quite clearly see that this Chamber and its civil servants have taken that quotation to heart. They really do not understand taxation. If they understood that excessive taxation drives down business and puts people out of work, they would not be doing it. There is a man at the front of this Chamber who has just put his head in his hands, and he clearly needs to go back to school to understand. Mr Giegold sees devils and evil behind every corporate in the world. He thinks that every businessman who gets up in the morning is trying to evade taxation and steal from the pockets of himself and those around him. The socialists in this Chamber want harder taxation rather than dealing with those actually in this Chamber who try to avoid it. I will not grow old thinking about my time when I have left here wondering whether there are those people in this Chamber who have understood taxation, because I know they never will. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – Would you agree with me, Mr Woolfe, that this place does not understand capitalism, and that one of the reasons they are failing the citizens of Europe is that they will not try to understand that this system here does not work and that we must have reasonable taxation or people will simply not pay? Why should people hand over their hard—earned income, whether companies or individuals? Do you agree with me?

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Coburn, it seems to me that socialists today want to preserve their academic position by assuming that they understand everything. The fact is, they understand very little, and if only they trusted the hands of people themselves, governments should get out of the hands of public, get out of the hands of business and get out of the hands of ourselves. If that was the case, then you would see greater growth in the European Union.

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: - Mr President, at a time when subjects of satisfaction are rare, let us welcome the first results of the opening of a huge project: the application of equal competition and tax justice between companies. With the TAXE committees and now PANA, chaired by Werner Langen, Parliament has been able to amplify and relay the demand for transparency and justice expressed by citizens after scandals such as LuxLeaks. Without having any legal competence, our Parliament kept the finance ministers under pressure through its fact-finding missions on the spot, through its hearings, through the interparliamentary conferences organized in Brussels and in the national capitals, thus preparing the ground for the examination of the proposals of the European Commission. The first results are indisputable: the case has progressed more in two years than in two decades. The obligation of reciprocal information on rulings, the unanimous adoption of the recommendations of the OECD, the anti-tax avoidance directive, the anti-money laundering directive are important advances, to which must be added the end of banking secrecy. But as Werner Langen has said forcefully, this effort only makes sense if it is carried through to the end. In particular, three dossiers will be decisive for the success of this political initiative within the framework of the Union. First, the harmonization of the tax base of multinational companies is the CCCTB project. For us, Parliament, these two directives are the two legs that the device needs to walk upright. Parliament will be ready at the end of the summer. Second, a common list of non-cooperative countries, from which all the consequences must be drawn. Finally, third, the group's promotion of the code of conduct at a political level. It is time for our finance ministers - it is your responsibility, Mr President of the Council - to show that tax justice is for them a priority that goes beyond the horizon of their office managers.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: – Mr President, thank you for this very urgent and important debate on our recommendations and on the reform of the code of conduct group for business taxation. I think this is a very timely and urgent matter. I think when we built the single market in Europe, we failed fundamentally to ensure that we have a fair tax regime, and the code of conduct group of business taxation lacks transparency and its principles on unanimity are destroying fair competition. What we have seen in Europe over the years – as you will see if you study the documents of the code of conduct group – is that we allow schemes, harmful tax regimes that are stealing revenues from each other, from Member States, revenues that should go to welfare, revenues that will protect our welfare states. So we need urgently to reform the code of conduct group for business taxation; we need transparency; we need to get rid of this principle of unanimity and secrecy. So I hope the Council will do something about it, and I see the Parliament and Commission, we have to stand together in reforming the code of conduct group to bring tax justice to Europe. Then I also want to say, as the rapporteur of the TAXE 2 Committee, it is important that we look at the instruments of tax evasion and tax dodging in Europe. We see that intermediaries – banks, law firms, tax advisers, wealth managers and so on, lawyers of all kinds – they are helping rich people and companies to evade taxes. This is a scandal. We should be much more tough on them. We should revoke their business licences if they repeatedly engage in illegal tax evasion, helping tax evasion – this is really dangerous. And then finally, I think if we want to build real trust in Europe (and we should), we need once and for all to have a fair tax system. We need to see the Commission and Council acting on the many recommendations that this Parliament has put forward and adopted. We need to see action now; we have seen some action but we need much more, and we need also the Council to listen to us and act, not only sit back and relax.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Taking the floor in this debate, I would like to emphasize that my country, Poland, is interested in introducing solutions at the EU level aimed at determining the tax base in corporate income tax on the basis of uniform rules. We have been heavily experienced in previous years with operations conducted, among others, by Luxembourg, which allowed for tax optimization by various large companies operating also in Poland. The related losses were estimated by experts at EUR 11 billion a year, so they significantly exceeded the annual CIT revenues to the Polish budget. In this situation, we support the actions of the Commission aimed at introducing regulations at the EU level to determine the tax base in corporate income tax, so that the same rules for qualifying expenses that can be classified as tax deductible costs apply. Ultimately, the point is that corporate income taxes are paid in those countries where actual economic activity takes place and where economic added value is generated.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Mr President, we are now seeing a very disappointing pattern, whereby by some Member States, including our Presidency, play in fact a destructive role in Council by opposing reforms for fair and transparent corporate taxation. Indeed, my own Finance Minister in Ireland claims Ireland is committed to the highest international standards on tax transparency, but then, on the other hand, is also on the record as opposing public country-by-country reporting. Government and tax industry representatives claim this is about trust. They say the Irish people have trust in our Revenue Agency, therefore country-by-country reporting does not need to be made public. But a lot of people do not trust organisations like Revenue. They were, after all, the Agency that gave the infamous sweetheart deals to Apple. So making country—by—country reporting public is vital to ensure democratic public scrutiny of corporate taxation. Transparency and sovereignty can go hand—in—hand, but we need governments to stop using the limitations of the OECD’s proposals as an excuse to block action on tax transparency. Either we are in favour of transparency or we are not.

name: Eva JOLY
text: - Mr President, tomorrow the Luxembourg Court of Appeal will deliver its verdict in the Luxleaks case. Antoine Deltour, Raphaël Halet and Édouard Perrin shed light on the tax agreements between Luxembourg and large companies. These tax optimization practices deprive the European Union and the Member States of tens of billions of euros each year. Since these revelations, the three whistleblowers have had to endure a long legal journey. This lawsuit shows that European protection for whistleblowers is necessary. This is moreover one of the recommendations of the TAXE and ECON committees made almost two years ago. After numerous requests and initiatives, in particular from the Green group, the European Commission has finally launched a public consultation on a European statute for whistleblowers. This initiative is late, but it is welcome. This is a first step towards effective protection for whistleblowers. This must be horizontal and broad enough to leave in particular the possibility of launching the whistleblower both internally and externally, to the media, for example. In addition, we are still awaiting the publication of a European blacklist of tax havens. Member States, through the "code of conduct" group, are in the process of weakening the criteria to be taken into account for the establishment of this list. This is unacceptable, especially since it is all negotiated in a completely opaque manner. There are two urgencies: reform the group "code of conduct" by imposing the transparency of debates, and maintain strict criteria for the definition of tax havens, otherwise the black list will be an illusion when citizens expect concrete actions. .

name: Marco VALLI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it has now been more than a year since this Parliament, together with colleagues from TAXE, made recommendations for reviewing the objectives of the code of conduct group. It is hallucinating that in twenty years this group has not led to any results, indeed, that it has even rowed against, from what are the indiscretions that have come out with respect to this group. So, once again, after twenty years we are wondering what is the only way to pursue issues from a fiscal point of view, for international tax cooperation: it's all a matter of political will. I do not see too much political will today because, above all the representatives of the European Union and the Eurogroup, namely Mr Junker and Mr Dijsselbloem, represent two characters who, in the last twenty years, have pursued policies, which we consider immoral , towards other countries I would like to know if you do not think right at this point, given that we share the single market and above all a single currency, that these countries, in some way, directly compensate other countries, from which they have subtracted a lot of taxes in these years. This is the key thing: the issue of conflict of interest and political will.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I do not share the optimism and lack of concern of the representatives of the Council and the Commissioner, who unfortunately is not here. When he heard the president of the committee on the Panama papers speak, I asked myself "Wow! But if even one of the representatives of the majority in the European Parliament criticizes the tenuous proposals of the Commission and the Council so strongly, perhaps there really is something is wrong. And looking at what has been done in the last twenty years in terms of fiscal cooperation within the European Union, it shows how fragile the construction of this bureaucratic overhang is and proves useless in solving the problems of The group on the code of conduct started in 1998: it has been trying to solve this problem for twenty years but has not reached any conclusions. There is even no desire to make resolutions transparent and how much the Member States have exchanged in those meetings. Who was with me in the TAXE commissions knows how much difficulty we had in accessing these documents. timo report by Oxfam International, four states out of the top ten tax havens in this ranking belong to the European Union, we must ask ourselves one question: is the European Union really capable of solving this problem? Is it really capable of cooperating to make taxation transparent and fair for European citizens? Given the results, I am not convinced and I think we need to work only on one issue: banks! By making the banking system transparent, we will solve more than 90% of this problem.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Mr President, I am sorry that the Commissioner has left, because he could have heard something positive about his agenda, and that is not so usual. Why? Because I believe that, in the past two years, we made really substantial progress in the area of better, efficient and fair tax collection – more progress than for many, many years. The Union is always considered to be slow, inefficient and unable to find agreement and move forward, but this is not exactly the case. We can point to the adoption of the Anti-Tax-Avoidance Directive (ATAD) I and II and the Administrative Cooperation Directive (DAC3 and DAC4), and we have started to use state aid rules to enforce better and fairer tax collection. I hope that we will make similar progress quickly on the Anti-Money-Laundering Directive and, more importantly, the common consolidated corporate tax base (CCCTB). Obviously, there is reason to be at least a little proud, not just for doing something, because taking action is not always a good thing, but for doing right things in a basically reasonable way. However, there is no reason for complacency, and we must be aware that the fruit of our efforts will come later, because the macroeconomy is slow and we will not move forward unless countries implement the directives properly, tax authorities cooperate and work properly, and the Commission plays its role decisively. As I said, there is no room for complacency and many things have to be done. I am dissatisfied with the situation of the Code of Conduct Group. It has not exactly been the leading force in improving tax collection in the last decade and, in my opinion, it needs to regain people’s confidence. There is an agenda that it is definitely on the table of the Code of Conduct Group, including dealing with patent boxes. I guess Parliament will carefully follow the progress made, and I hope the results will be delivered soon.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: - Mr President, this meeting provides an opportunity to take stock of an issue to which, ultimately, our fellow citizens are quite attentive. Two messages to the Council: first - as you can see - to make progress in these areas, it is better to have the European Parliament at your side. So when in the hybrid dossier, the famous ATAD 2 dossier, the Council concludes by saying that it will adopt the directive once the European Parliament has delivered its opinion, and that in reality it does not do so, I believe that these are not good practices. Even if we are not always formally in codecision, the expectation of our fellow citizens is such that good governance within the Council should be to be able to rely on an enlightened opinion, with the contribution of the European Parliament which, in my opinion - he is often a good vector for progressing within the Council. Likewise, with regard to the code of conduct, many colleagues have spoken about it. I remember the days when this code of conduct was implemented. But, dear colleagues, let's be honest, it was another time. It was a time when the question of cooperation, harmonization, the fight against tax evasion was completely embryonic. But today we know how important it is for us to get results in this area. As the Commissioner has said, the room for maneuver to move forward from the Council's point of view is, it seems to me, great. I have the impression that the Maltese Presidency could be one of the presidencies during which we could make progress in this area, for more transparency with governments who really commit to being actors of this code of conduct, which would not be not just an alibi for the Council.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr President, competition should not only exist between economic operators, but also between Member States.Unfortunately, in this House, competition among members is predominantly considered an unfair practice, and most colleagues advocate tax harmonization that will cement the existing situation and leave less developed members permanently behind those more developed ones.Why do I say that?Because it is quite clear that members that do not have a developed infrastructure, a large internal market and a highly skilled workforce can hardly attract investment in any way other than incentive tax policies.If we deprive them of the opportunity to attract investors with lower taxes, we have condemned them to economic and demographic extinction.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: - Mr President, I also appreciate the efforts made by the Commission and the Council to prepare the legislation needed to combat tax evasion and money laundering. The urgency of this legislation is given by the fact that the Member States of the Union still lose, according to some estimates, 10% of the gross domestic product, revenues that should go to the budgets of these Member States. Today we have good news: Commissioner Moscovici told us that the criteria for identifying those tax jurisdictions that do not cooperate in combating tax evasion have been agreed, and he also told us that by the end of this year, publish the list of these non-cooperating tax jurisdictions. Of course, we would all like this commitment to be maintained this time, because he himself, some time ago, told us that he will do this in six months. Six months have passed for a long time and I did not have this list. So, I hope we have this list, as he promised. Let's not forget that the main role of these offshore centers is none other than to hide illicit revenues and we also hope that, by the end of this year, we will have proposals for sanctions for those who do not comply - no more transactions with these uncooperative tax jurisdictions.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: - Mister President! How are we supposed to achieve fair taxation, as Commissioner Moscovici has just mentioned, when we know so terribly little about the flow of money - where it comes from, where it goes - and that the national governments play a full part in this unfair competition, if it is about disguising these cash flows? Thanks to TAXE 1 and TAXE 2, we now of course know more about these rulings and have made a wealth of suggestions. One part is on the table - more light in the dark - very good. Some things have been put forward, but there is still an infinite amount of work to be done when it comes to transparency so that we can finally achieve our goal - more fair taxation. I am now addressing the Code of Conduct Group. I was one of the MEPs who took a closer look, and it is not only true what Mr Langen said that some things have been blacked out, but it is also rather embarrassing to see that the 2016 documents end in June. So when things get exciting, when we want to know how these tax haven talks are going, that's over. That is completely out of time. These are methods - an intergovernmental way of working - that are absolutely inappropriate today. Another point: more transparency in public, country-by-country reporting. I would like to address the point in the Commission proposal, which now concerns the bundled information for other EU countries - that is, those countries that should then be available more or less aggregated when we address the information. It is not enough if we learn that money flows via Liechtenstein to the Bahamas, to Singapore and then back to the European Union. That is absolutely not enough to meet our transparency goal.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the revelations of the Panama Papers and Luxleaks have shown that the Member States of the European Union urgently need to combat tax evasion, tax avoidance, tax dumping and aggressive tax planning. The Commission estimates that tax evasion and avoidance cost the Union € 1 trillion a year, with the OECD estimating a global revenue loss of 4 to 10% of total income tax revenue, equivalent to 75 to 180 billion euros a year. So it is time to create a fair tax system without gray areas and tax ruling practices at European level. All Member States must assume their responsibilities, take steps to ensure that multinational companies are taxed in the country where they make their profits, and stop turning to tax havens such as the Netherlands and Luxembourg. They should also stop using the practice of intra-group transactions, thus avoiding taxes and depriving state budgets of huge tax revenues.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: - Mr President, Commissioner. It has already been said: the revelations of the Panama Papers and Lux ​​Leaks highlighted the pressing need for the Union and its Member States to fight against tax evasion and avoidance and aggressive tax planning and to promote greater cooperation and transparency , making our tax systems fairer and ensuring that corporate taxes are paid where value is created. Some tax jurisdictions cannot be allowed to actively contribute to the design of aggressive policies for multinational companies, which may thereby seize the opportunity to avoid taxation. We need a joint effort, at European and international level, to prevent aggressive tax planning, increase transparency and create a fairer environment for companies in the European Union. At the beginning of last year, the Commission introduced new measures against corporate tax avoidance. These new rules are essential to harmonize tax legislation in the 28 countries of the European Union, in order to fight effectively against aggressive tax practices by large companies. Likewise, at the end of last year the agreement on the criteria and the process for the preparation and approval of a pan-European list of non-cooperative jurisdictions in tax matters was approved. The objective of creating this list is to promote the good standards that the European Union already applies in tax matters. The criteria for including jurisdictions on this list will be fiscal transparency, having a fair tax system and implementing the OECD recommendations against the erosion of tax bases. The list of non-cooperative jurisdictions and sanctions - according to the commissioner has added - must be presented before the end of this year, and I am sure that there will be some absence. With that said, I welcome the work carried out by the Group "Code of conduct", the European Commission and the European Council.But let's not forget that there is still a lot to do.

name: Anneliese DODDS
text: – Mr President, like the Commissioner I was pleased to see that we will have a new head of the Code of Conduct Group. The Group, as many colleagues have said, has been sorely lacking in dynamism since its initial leadership under Dawn Primarolo. Mr Borg referred to two revisions in the Code of Conduct Group but surely these cannot amount to the proper, full review of the Group that this Parliament was promised. Such a review is desperately needed. That is evident from the recently leaked cables, with one participant stating that it was impressive to see how some Member States presented themselves outwardly as proponents of tax reform and, at the same time to watch, in the Code of Conduct Group, how they actually behave in EU discussions protected by confidentiality. So, will the Council support the Code of Conduct Group becoming more transparent? And, on the point that Mr Kofod underlined, will there be a shift away from the stifling unanimity which has prevented progress in this area? I would also ask this: will the Group be taking forward the TAXE and ECON reports’ calls for action to ensure that Member States notify each other of new tax measures? Finally, I want to focus on the problem of tax havens. It is disappointing that Mr Woolfe and Mr Coburn have left the Chamber. I actually listen to my constituents and I know they are furious about tax dodging by both businesses and individuals. And they are disgusted in particular that public funds end up in tax havens. The TAXE and ECON reports called for no EU funds to go to tax havens in the future. How will the Commission and the Council ensure that this never happens again?

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: - We are now more than two years after Luxleaks. Meanwhile, there were already the Swiss Leaks, the Panama Papers, the Bahamas Leaks and who knows what else will come. The outrage after each new revelation gave us as politicians a clear mandate, yes even an obligation, to deal with these abuses. In the European Parliament, we have taken up the gauntlet with the two special committees on tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect and the Committee of Inquiry into money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. We have always come up with concrete proposals for solutions, but unfortunately our power is limited to holding the Member States and the Commission to account. Nevertheless, important legislative steps have also been taken, such as the automatic exchange of tax rulings and the anti-BEPS directive. But is this enough? Can we now look our citizens in the eye and promise that Luxleaks will never happen again? Certainly not. I want to mention three things. First, the list of tax havens is a missing link. I explicitly ask the Member States to throw taboos overboard and arrive at a single, comprehensive European list. Because as long as there are loopholes, they will be found. That is already certain. The associated sanctions will also be crucial. But in addition to formal sanctions, we must also respond to the reputation effects. That is why I am calling on the banks here and now to sign a European charter in which they commit themselves not to conduct transactions with tax havens. Third, the loopholes within Europe itself must also be closed. And let's be honest: this is only possible through the proposed CCCTB. Unfortunately, the signals from the Council on this are anything but encouraging, but it is now or never. In the meantime, several countries have also announced a reduction in their corporate tax rate, which will eventually make a debate about a possible European floor tariff inevitable.Finally, the catch 22 in which the Member States are holding each other today in tax matters is evidence of short-term thinking and, to my regret, not of the political courage we need to look our citizens back in the face and work towards a just Europe.

name: Paul TANG
text: – Mr President, the Code of Conduct Group is probably Europe at its worst. It operates in near-complete secrecy and has a dismal performance. Indeed, input and output legitimacy are minimal. In fact, work by the European institutions is essential to arrive at a fair corporate tax system. Progress has been made for the first time in history but much more progress is needed. A major step would be the actual introduction of the consolidated common corporate tax base. It would provide, among other things, a level playing field in the internal market for large companies and not-so-large companies: and people are right to expect that Amazon pays as much in taxes as a small book store. As rapporteur, I will do my utmost, together with Alain Lamassoure, to find support inside and outside this Parliament. We need political and public pressure on the Member States. But let me also point to one omission in the approach by the Commission. The tax avoidance industry is a rather exceptional instance of Jean-Baptise Say’s Law: yes, in this case, supply creates its own demand. Tax advisers will always find ways, new ways, to work around the corporate tax system. So regulating the industry of tax advice is a further crucial step in tackling tax avoidance.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Mr President, taxation issues are a perfect example of a case where the European Union gets the most blame when, in fact, the fault lies with the Member States and their inability to act. What is to blame is the fact that unanimity is demanded in the Council, that there are opaque structures and a lack of transparency in the Code of Conduct Group, and that the Member States are unwilling to transpose powers to the European Union and unwilling to serve their citizens. I am pretty fed up with this and I am convinced that none of the civil society players, the media or the European Parliament is going to drop the issue as long as it is open and unsolved. There are easy ways to solve the problem. What about the automatic exchange of information , which is halfway or more to finalisation? A truly automatic exchange of information would be where all benefit payers all over Europe had a tax index number for their beneficiaries, and the information would be transposed immediately and automatically with the technology that we have, for Member States’ tax officials to take into account. It is not very difficult. This is automatic exchange of information. In fact, the Commission has been promising a tax index number regulation for quite some time. I have no pats on the back for the Commission either. We do have regulatory actors which we could use if they had the fully competencies. What about audited annual reports? What if we were required to tick a box to say whether we had received preferential treatment in certain Member States or third countries and, if so, we had to specify what kind of preferential treatment we got? And the Transparency Directive could also be used much more effectively to reveal tax havens and unfit tax practices.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, trust in tax matters must be restored and the cooperation tasks assigned by the Member States cannot be reduced. The Ecofin code of conduct group has been acting as substitute for years, evaluating the tax measures relating to the code of conduct and supervising the provision of information. In the hierarchy of sources, however, the code is not a legally binding instrument but is entrusted in its adoption and effectiveness to the commitment of the Member States to abolish existing tax measures and refrain from introducing new ones in the future. However, there has been much resistance in the adoption of national tax policies, preparatory to compliance with the code, in particular on the preparation of reports on relations with local multinationals, on cross-border tax avoidance and on improving the sharing of tax information between States. . It is solar evidence that these shortcomings, which I have already pointed out here and through questions, justify the inadmissible maintenance of artificial tax saving techniques with distorting effects on competition.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: - Mr President, this long work on fraud and tax evasion is a very concrete reality, and that, were it not for the multiple tax scandals that brought this issue to public opinion, would still be in the shadow of the European Union's government offices. We know today that tax evasion and fraud are widespread across the European Union and that governments continue to enter into tax agreements with multinationals, while punishing their populations with austerity policies. In other words, tax fraud and evasion are not the result of spontaneous generation, nor do they represent any dysfunction in the system. Fraud and tax evasion are one of the increasingly visible faces of the capitalist system and the subordination of political power to economic power. Only a political break with this system, opening the way for public control of the financial system and the movement of capital, can pave the way for a lasting solution that can effectively combat this phenomenon and end the federal government-sponsored plunder of the multinationals European Union and its Member States.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, I want to join my colleagues in calling for greater transparency, greater legitimacy for the Code of Conduct Group, because in my opinion it shows - I do not want to hurt it very unnecessarily, but I feel - all the averted faces of the EU institutions..Trust is very difficult to build and very easy to lose.However, I would like to warn against using the current situation precisely to call for a fair tax system, which I think is an attempt to break into a certain defense of the Member States, which I want to fully protect, because in my opinion we cannotlevel to legitimately construct a fair tax system.Something else is unfair tax competition, and we have to be precise and targeted there, but building a fair tax system, I think, is a very dangerous endeavor.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: - Mr. president. I want to give you an alarming fact, ladies and gentlemen. Since the Directive on the exchange of information on tax rulings between tax administrations has already come into force, the rulings have increased. Attention: the information exchange system has come into force, but the States do more rulings with the companies. And this has an explanation, and that is that the Member States of the European Union consider that fiscal sovereignty is a nuclear element of their fiscal competence, of their economic competence. And this means that when one examines, for example, the minutes in the secret chamber of the Code of Conduct that we are examining, it is observed that the States reserve the power to make agreements with the companies. This looks great. And this is the problem: we have to roughly harmonize taxation, and the States do not want to. This is the problem. I think we have to tell the European Council that it has to help this to work better, because that is not how we are doing well.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! The vast majority of what you have spoken followed in the same direction - an analysis we share and an expectation we support. My colleague Moscovici had to go to another appointment. He sends his regards, but has asked me to take up your comments. We do this together with the experts from his cabinet and from the general management. I can say again at the beginning: We see the position of the MEPs largely congruent with the position of the European Commission. Anyone who wants to expect tax honesty must promote tax fairness. Both are closely related. We therefore believe that more progress has been made in the last two years than in the previous 20 years. The glass is half full or half empty. Transparency, cooperation, information requirements - a lot has been achieved, but not enough. The situation remains unsatisfactory. We believe that tax competition can be part of an acceptable European location competition. Regions, municipalities, member states inside and outside advertise with good education, good culture, good infrastructure, advertise with certainty and advertise with taxes on sales and earnings. I am a realist. I do not believe that this competition between municipalities, regions and member states can be leveled out in the next few years. But we should see that we are much further ahead in sales tax law than in income tax law. In sales tax law we have European framework rules for the determination and for minimum and maximum taxes and for the different tax levels, in income tax law we practically do not yet have this. It would be a step forward in corporate income tax law to get to where we are today in sales tax law in the European Union. And one thing is clear - me I believe that we should see the presidency as a partner here, asking you to convey your analysis, your criticism, to the Council, to convey it to the 27 colleagues: in the end we are all losers. If the one with tax advantages, with deals, with dumping has a short-term locational advantage, we will all lose in the medium term. That is why I believe that a common approach is necessary. The European single market is the most attractive market in the world. Everyone wants to act in it, everyone wants to export into it, everyone wants to use it. That is why we should avoid companies inside and outside Europe operating in this internal market and tax avoidance or even tax dumping or tax deals coordinated with member states continue to be possible in the long term. Mr Giegold mentioned the subject of the method. Indeed, tax law doesn't have to be intergovernmental. This can happen with the financial transaction tax, but as a rule tax law is also subject to the Community method, with the principle of unanimity. And we continue to work towards that. It is a tough process and Article 116, which you mentioned, Mr Giegold, may be a last resort. I deliberately do not rule this out for the Commission. We will use the last two years in our endeavors as a basis, to continue our work, but not as a neverending story. If competition rules in the internal market are violated by tax policy - other violations are also possible: subsidies, state aid, etc. - then it can lead to Article 116 being withdrawn from us here, not infinitely late, but at some point got to. One final point: you are all members of this Parliament, but not only. They are also delegates, elected officials, officials in your national parties who partly rule, partly want to rule, who form governments that are responsible for write national election programs that create coalitions.We all - I agree with you - should perhaps do more to increase the pressure not only in Strasbourg and Brussels, but also in Berlin, Paris, Vilnius, Madrid and Rome.As long as national governments feel free and this debate is not also strengthened in the national parties, we will have a hard time.I think the formation of public opinion, the pressure in the public sphere over the past two years has been essential.That must continue, that is what the debate is about tonight.But that must also serve the debate in national parties and parliaments, in which we have weight - you, others and myself.Thank you very much.The Commission remains on the ball on the subject.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Thank you, Commissioner Oettinger, also for the clarity of your speech.

name: Ian Borg
text: President fil-Kariga tal-Kunsill - Sur President u Members ta ’din il-kamra illi bħali u bħall-Kummissarju assistsjna għal dan id-debateitu u l-interventions.
