Ħafna minnhom kienu kostruttivi u ningħaqad mal-aħħar sentiment illi express l-Kummissarju għall-fatt illi waqt li l-kienu interventions addressed, ħafna minnhom, lejn il-Kunsalaill, kulħadd, l-institutionzzjonijietrokitta ga, u għaliex naħdmu sabiex l-oġġettivo fuq dan is-suġġett jintlaħqu. Ħadt ukoll note ta ’dak illi ntqal mill-ġdid, b’mod partikolari ovvjament fejn kien hemm kummenti kostruttivi. Tifhmu li jiena hawnhekk qed nirrappreżenta lill-Kunsill u mhux lill-Member States u allura għalkemm it-tentazzjoni tkun kbira sabiex inwieġeb għal kull min irrefera għal xi Membru Stat partikolari, jiena qiegx nagilljoni-hawn-sabi. Il-Kunsill illi wkoll ħadem fl-aħħar snin f'dan ir-rigward u kien hawn uħud minnkom li rrikonoxxew il-konklużjonijiet illi ġew adopted kemm f'Diċembru tal-2015, kemm f'Marzu tal-2016 fuq il-code of conduct group kif ukoll anke l-ħidma l-oħra illi qiegħda ssir f'dan ir-rigward. Iva, anke bħala Presidency aħna kommessi illi nkomplu naħdmu, inkluż fuq dan l-aħħar punt, il-code of conduct group illi l-Presidency ofġà rreferiet għalih fil-BEPS Roadmap illi ħarġet f’Jannar li għadda. Jiena mill-ġdid nirringrazzjakom ta ’din is-sessjoni li għamiltu u nħares’ il quddiem sabiex inkomplu naħdmu anke magħkom il-MPs fil-ġlieda komuni kontra l-evażjoni tat-taxxa.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The discussion is closed.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing. - In a fair tax system, multinational companies also pay their share and must do so where they add value and realize their profits. In July 2016, we voted for the recommendations made by the report of the Luxleaks Special Commission on tax avoidance and fraud by multinationals. 8 months later, where are we? The European Parliament has just adopted the establishment of a central public register of beneficial owners of offshore companies within the anti-money laundering directive and has reopened negotiations for a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base. I would like to conclude by emphasizing that we are on the right track. Indeed, in less than 3 years, we have taken a huge step forward in the fight against tax evasion. However, we must not stop there and it is essential that we can continue our efforts in the months to come.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: in writing. – I welcome the progress that has been made on the regulatory level to fight tax evasion avoidance, AML and fraud. Although the Council has achieved results in record time, the Commission should not become hasty and overstep its mandate. We are achieving good results in the field of anti-abuse measures and tax transparency. Tax authorities in the Member States now have automatic access to tax ruling and anti—money—laundering information in other EU jurisdictions, which allows them to provide for a level playing field, to combat money laundering more efficiently and better target investigations. I also fully support the leading role of the EU in setting up global good tax governance rule. Although I welcome a common European approach towards fairer taxation, I believe fiscal matters should remain exclusive competences of the Member States. Fiscal competition between Member States should not be curbed. Fiscal harmonisation should not be used to protect fiscal expansionist governments at the expense of countries with lower taxes and better public governance. The idea of a CCCTB deserves attention, but cannot be a precursor of EU fiscal powers. Lastly, the growing importance of the CCG Group must coincide with greater transparency and better communication with Parliament and European citizens.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the report by Siegfried Mureşan, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on general guidelines for the preparation of the 2018 budget, Section III - Commission (2016/2323 (BUD)) (A8-0060 / 2017)

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, colleagues, Commissioner Oettinger, I am bringing to your attention tonight the draft report on the guidelines for the budget of the European Union for 2018. It is the report in which we, as a Parliament, are putting forward our political priorities for the budget of the Union for next year. I would like to propose two political priorities: number one, growth and jobs; and number two, security. I would like to propose these as priorities because these are exactly the areas in which the citizens of the Union expect that the Union will deliver: number one, growth and jobs; number two, security. How will we achieve this? Number one: on growth and jobs, I propose that we invest more in infrastructure, innovation and research, that we support more SMEs, and that we invest more in entrepreneurs, especially highly innovative entrepreneurs. So programmes like the Connecting Europe Facility, Horizon 2020, COSME, Erasmus, the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) have to be enforced in the budget of the Union for next year, because it is only by strengthening the economy of the Union and making it more competitive and more credible in the eyes of investors that it will be able to grow and create jobs. The second priority which I am proposing is security. This has two aspects, two components: internal security and external security. For internal security, as we all know, the financial means under heading 3 are very limited. So the question is: how can we have an impact with the limited financial resources which we have available? I propose that we strengthen the agencies of the Union which have responsibilities in the area of justice and home affairs: Frontex, EASO, Europol and Eurojust. We need to strengthen them, and we need to make them cooperate better and use synergy effects between them. Also, to improve internal security, I support the defence pilot projects launched by the European Commission this year. They have to continue because, until now, we have spent money in 28 Member States of the union 28 times for defence industries and defence research for the same results. This needs to end where it can. We need to achieve economies of scale. Spend money once at European level and share the results, as is normal to do amongst partner countries. Security also has an external dimension, and I would like us to stand side-by-side with the eastern neighbourhood of the Union and with those countries which have embarked on a pro-European path the three countries that have signed Association Agreements with the European Union: Ukraine, Georgia and the Republic of Moldova. They face a more aggressive Russian Federation. We need to stand by their side to strengthen their institutions, their judiciary – the independence of the judiciary – the rule of law, to fight money laundering and to fight corruption. We also need to stand by the countries in our southern neighbourhood, Northern Africa and the Middle East. These are countries of origin or countries of transit for refugees, and it is for us much cheaper, it is politically easier and it is safer for the Union to support refugees in their countries of origin. It is also preferable for them. We can achieve much better results by supporting them there and preventing them from coming in high numbers to Europe. These are the main political priorities which I am putting forward for debate and for vote tomorrow. In addition to these, there are also small punctual projects which help different categories of people in Europe. We believe in the Erasmus programme. It has to be strengthened, but we believe that in addition to the Erasmus programme, the Interrail project – which was proposed over the course of the past month and which would enable every young citizen in Europe who turns 18 to receive from the budget of the Union a free 30-day Interrail pass – is something which would enable people to learn more about Europe, to practice the foreign languages which they have learned in school, and, in particular, to increase their chances of finding a good job. As we know, employers appreciate international experience. On this basis we would like to ask the Commission to put forward a legislative proposal to enable the Interrail project in a transparent, predictable and sustainable way without, of course, affecting any other existing projects. I thank you for your attention. I am looking forward to the debate tonight.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, With today's debate, you too will begin discussions on next year's budgetary procedure. I have carefully looked at Mr Muresan's report and the priorities it has set out. I can say that the Commission fully shares the priorities and expectations set out in this report for the financial year 2018, and I am also pleased that the Council's guidelines, which were adopted in the Council on 21 February, are largely communicated coincide with the priorities of Parliament. The starting position for a constructive and purposeful discussion of the 2018 budget proposals, which we as the Commission will work out and present, between the Council, Parliament and the Commission is therefore absolutely good. The 2018 budget will not differ significantly from that of 2017. We assume that the tasks, the challenges and the priorities in the coming year will be very similar to those of 2017. One area is growth and investment in Europe with the aim of creating more jobs - this is exactly the first priority that we share. And the second is: security with knowledge of migration and other tasks - external and internal security. We will anchor these two priorities in our budget proposal based on the experiences and realistic expenditure to be gained in recent months and this year. With your support, we have earmarked EUR 6 billion in the 2017 budget for migration and security. That is the amount of growth in the budget in general to help both Member States and third countries to cope financially with the consequences of migration flows. In 2018, we also want to propose the necessary budgetary resources to finance legislative measures that have already been adopted. Let's take that Proposal package on border management, heading 3; let's take the new partnership framework under heading 4 - Europe in the world. This means that in 2018 we will reflect in the budget what has become of a joint policy by Parliament, Council and Commission in recent months. We will take the necessary steps to adjust the budget for migration and security. But we know that our options in the current multiannual budget framework - in the FF - are finite. The multiannual budget framework adopted in 2013 did not, in principle, foresee these tasks; all the more we will do everything we can to make these tasks and their financing possible. In addition to new priorities, we should continue to anchor, with great sensitivity, the enabling of existing projects and programs in the budget: Horizon 2020, Connecting Europe Facility, COSME for small and medium-sized companies and Erasmus +. New focus areas must not displace established programs. We have to find a wise middle ground. 2018 will again only be possible with sufficient use of the instrument of flexibility. There are new expectations for us: the State of the Union Speech by President Juncker with WiFi for Europe, the extension of EFSI until at least the end of 2020, the consideration of a European youth solidarity corps, but also the European defense action plan . All of these projects and ideas are new, innovative, correct, but not free. That means that we are facing quite a challenge, especially with Heading 1 A, to at least partially or even fully finance all of this seriously in 2018. The idea of ​​an Interrail ticket coming from the middle of Parliament, which we want to give young Europeans for their 18th birthday, seems to us to be a very interesting idea. With our start in 2017 of Learn to Move, Move to Learn, we want Enable first attempts and gain first experiences with young people. We put this pilot project at the beginning so that we can see what we can finance together with you as a permanent funding project. Here, too, we depend on the Council of Parliament to see how we can achieve serious medium-term funding for 2018, knowing the foreseeable large number of young people who will take part. Mr Mureşan mentioned the issue of young people and the Youth Employment Initiative: the reinforcement, as agreed in the course of the 2017 conciliation procedure, will be taken up by the Commission. In a few weeks' time, we will be presenting a draft amending budget to you, Parliament and the Council. I mentioned the subject of flexibility. We will only be able to finance our diverse tasks in the next few years if we make extensive use of the flexibility and expand it. That is why we believe that the process of mid-term revision and mid-term review does not hit the wall. After many weeks of standstill, an agreement was possible in the Council a few days ago. The Council has now given the go-ahead for mid-term revision and review, with some expectations and conditions to be discussed now. We will be happy to advise you on the assessment over the next few days and weeks. We are grateful to the Technical Committee, the Budget Committee, for wanting to address this issue next Monday, because we have one concern: As soon as the Article 50 letter arrives from London and Brexit is on the agenda, that the time window for mid-term review and revision will close. And, in my opinion, it would be very disadvantageous if the mid-term review and revision, which had always been a concern of Parliament, were not to result in a pragmatic, factual result got.The time window is still open and, in particular, more flexibility would be the main advantage for financing numerous projects that are also very important to Parliament in the next three years.We will do everything we can to avoid a backlog in 2018 on the way to 2020.Your worries are our worries;we share them in full.We will have a first trialogue on March 27th - an initial exchange of ideas - and there we will also have to discuss the schedule until October / November of this year.On the same day we will also have a debate on agencies and on monitoring the payments situation.All in all, we have a clear agenda, and I do not see Parliament's priorities and your report in conflict, but an effective partnership for the Commission.We are happy to take up your expectations for our budget proposal for 2018 in a few months.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: on behalf of the Group. - Mr President, I would like to greet the Commissioner, greet colleagues and colleagues and congratulate the rapporteur on the excellence of the work, on the consensus he can bring and involve all groups, which means that we will have, once again, a Parliament united in this goal of wanting the best for the European Union and the best possible budget for citizens too. To speak of the European Union budget is to speak of a small budget - it corresponds to about 1% of the Gross Domestic Product. When we compare it with the federal budget of the United States, we see the difference well, since the federal budget has 20% of the Gross Domestic Product. But this budget, being small, has enormous added value and the proof is that, in many regions, it is the only investment available and, in many Member States, it also represents more than 50% of that investment. In fact, the European Union budget is an investment budget: 94% of the budget is for investment and only 6% is for administration. I congratulate the rapporteur once again on the fact that he has set clear priorities for employment, growth and security, and this obviously has to have consequences in terms of the programs that we have, such as COSME for SMEs, but also essential programs for youth, such as Erasmus +. But jobs, growth and competitiveness are also done with innovation and research and, therefore, it is important that we provide Horizon 2020 with the means necessary for this objective. 2018 is the fifth year of the Multiannual Financial Framework, Commissioner, and I hope that cohesion policy in 2018 will reach its maximum speed, since there has been a delay in the implementation of the programs and since, in 2016, there were even more than 13 billion euros that were not implemented. Therefore, it is essential, Commissioner, that cohesion policy and other funds enter a maximum speed in 2018, not least because it is the fifth year of the Multiannual Financial Framework, and that there are sufficient amounts for payments.A strong word for youth, which has always been our priority.A youth that has about double the unemployment of other generations and, therefore, it is crucial that the Youth Employment Initiative program has the necessary amounts and sufficient amounts for this objective.It is important that Erasmus +, which promotes mobility and professional training, also has the necessary minimum objectives and sufficient amounts.For this reason, I thank the rapporteur once again for this excellent proposal and I am sure that, in this process which is now beginning, on Parliament's part, we will always be up to the wishes, the will and the hope of the citizens.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the budgetary procedure for the year 2018 will not be business as usual. In the time of Brexit and of the sovereign parties fighting for the governments of their countries, we must find a new spirit and a new impetus to keep the very idea of ​​the European Union alive. The plot thickens and the hands travel fast: we are called to respond and do it for real. In this year's guidelines - and I thank the rapporteur, Mr Muraşan, for the excellent and fruitful cooperation - we have tried to identify the areas of action on which the Union must focus in order to respond to citizens, who are wondering what sense still have this Europe - from sustainable growth to research as the key to youth employment, from investment as a tool for innovation to migrant issues - fully supported by the European Parliament. There are signs of recovery but we are still living the long wave of the 2008 crisis to the point that many, especially young women and young men, no longer even remember what the world was like before. The budget must be a political tool at the service of our idea of ​​Europe and almost all those elected in this House are well aware that Europe represents the only possibility for growth, peace and happiness. Just remember how to do it. If we don't give answers, someone else will give them and we know what the answers will be. European citizens want clear answers: a welfare model that works, a strong push for investments, a great plan to fight inequalities and a Europe capable of welcoming migrants while protecting its own security. And yet, on the other hand, what must be said, and what everyone knows, is that our work will be completely useless if it is not directed above all to the younger generations. For decades, Europe has been synonymous with the future and we have a moral duty to align that our policy to this idea, the survival of the very idea that we are here called to represent is at stake.Out of tactics, I hope that this budgetary procedure represents a new chapter and a new history.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. -  Mister President! The draft presented contains many correct points of emphasis. I would particularly like to mention the security of citizens, competitiveness, which must be increased, but also investment in research and innovation, which ultimately means that we must continue to improve the standard of education throughout the EU. At the same time there is light and shadow in this draft, especially in the basic setting of the course. On the positive side, I would like to emphasize that this draft shows that jobs are mainly created in the private sector, and also that migration is finally recognized, that it must be combated by investing in the migrants' countries of origin - i.e. at the sources of the causes . That means that we have to invest there. It is also important that we integrate ad hoc financial instruments into the budget in the future, because that is an effective measure against shadow budgets. These are all significant improvements compared to previous years. However, I would also like to note that there are still some points with which we are not satisfied, because there is still no overall EU concept for the very great challenge of the migration crisis. But we should make it dependent on how much money we spend where. There are also minor theaters of war that we continue to deal with. I also include the Interrail ticket. That will cost us several hundred million euros, depending on how it is introduced. I don't think that's the right focus. In addition, it is very important that we should not give the EU budget the impression that it is a panacea for all crises. That can not be. More realism is called for here. In conclusion, I would like to expressly acknowledge the work of our colleague Siegfried Mureşan and therefore say: We as the ECR Group will adopt this draft for the first time now in many years.We will abstain from voting because we see it is a step in the right direction.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Europe is facing challenging years. That is why it is important to find the right priorities in the budget as well. The ALDE Group believes that they have been found well. It is important for the EU to invest in growth, youth, the future and security. In this sense, it is important that the focus of this budget is on investment in SMEs and research, as well as on Erasmus training for young people. Secondly, I would like to raise climate targets. My group welcomes the fact that the report takes into account the commitments made in the Paris Climate Agreement and that the EU is committing to 20% climate-relevant funding. Thirdly, I would like to raise the issue of security. This budget or these guidelines assume that the EU must invest in and develop a common defense policy and devote resources to common defense research. This is important and will certainly bear fruit in the years to come. A worrying challenge is that Brexit takes up a large part of the budget. This means that the use of money needs to be examined more closely. In the future, we also need to be able to prioritize even better what the money will be used for, because it is certain that the money will not come from the Member State in the coming years by more than 1%.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr. president. We are at the gates of the 60th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome and in the greatest crisis of this project of the European Union. Of course, with a White Paper under his arm. It would be a disaster to pursue any of Mr. Juncker's options. It would be a disaster, too, if the next budget of the European Union did not get out of the calculated ambiguity and the halfway options-solutions. The report talks about the need to reinforce the European identity. But who wants to feel part of something that leaves refugees freezing to death at the borders, privatizes public sectors or drowns countries in debt, while rescuing bankers? The European identity is built with material policies that do not leave people behind. And please stop referring to the PPE's brilliant idea of ​​giving young people trips to make them feel European. It is insulting. Do you really think that a young man can go on a trip when his family does not make ends meet? For this, budgets are a fundamental instrument: to collect more own resources, with progressive European taxes and national contributions balanced with the per capita income of each country and with a serious European public investment plan, with social and environmental criteria and not with austerity and military deployment, as we are seeing.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, it happens that today we are celebrating the birthday of the Estonian language, one of the smallest and oldest languages ​​in the European Union, and it would be against the Estonian Constitution if I did not use that language today, so please put on your headphones. Mr President, The rapporteur has rightly focused on growth, jobs and security, because these are the most important issues for citizens in the European Union. For me, however, the link between security and action on climate change, for example, is not sufficiently reflected in the report. This is also confirmed by the European Court of Auditors' audit, which states that 20% of the money in our budget should be spent on stabilizing the planet's climate. I am very pleased that the rapporteur's emphasis on the Interrail youth program is strengthening it. The same applies to the Erasmus program. There is little doubt as to whether we need to be as lenient with regard to the investment fund and the strategic development fund as the report states. For example, in the field of national defense, I am the only member of the Group of the Greens / European Free Alliance to support these initiatives. I warn you once again that the energy program in France near Aix-en-Provence, abbreviated ITER, will cost much more than we have planned. We have also tabled our own amendments, which, because of the precision and delicacy of the wording, I think could be supported by all the political groups.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, after a long and arduous process, after delays on one side and then another, the British Parliament has finally voted to give the green light to the Prime Minister to invoke Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty. Even if perhaps many of those here today may not join me in celebrating this momentous decision of the British people, I hope that all will recognise the exercise of democracy. There are two ways of doing a divorce. It can either be a mutual recognition that paths are leading in different directions; to still be friends and neighbours while recognising that both parties can thrive separately, but that that relationship is not working – or it can be negative and acrimonious. I certainly prefer the former. Today we are discussing the guidelines for the 2018 EU budget, and the report makes all the usual calls: more resources, more EU action, more taxpayers’ money to be spent. There has always been a disconnect between the structure of the European Union and the British people. This report typifies, in a lot of ways, that disconnect: strong support for common EU initiatives in defence and defence research, the Interrail tickets, the fact that the Court of Auditors’ reports are giving such a high error rate, and the adverse opinion on the legality of the payments underlying the accounts. Again, those things are put to one side. We see political groups in this Parliament not only exempt from the staff reduction target, but getting 76 more posts offset by the staff reduction target for the general administration. All of these things go fundamentally against the way that the British people would see these things, but ultimately the elephant in the room is how we proceed following Brexit. The UK must make sure that it is protected, and as Brexit approaches, the relevance of all of the items of spending to the UK will diminish month on month. But according to the multiannual financial framework regulation, by the end of this year the Commission has to put forward a proposal for the next multiannual financial framework. So in the spirit of this truth we must tell the Commission, first of all, that it should of course not include the UK in its proposal for the next multiannual financial framework period, and that is an important and necessary first step for accepting Brexit and moving on. There needs to be a credible long-term plan from the EU’s perspective on what happens post-Brexit. The amendments that we have tabled will help protect the UK from a never-ending EU bill. They also call for cuts in the EU budget, demand further reductions in EU staff and bureaucracy, and reject expansionist EU defence initiatives.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is now the fourth budgetary procedure that I am following and I see that, unfortunately, the same mistakes tend to be repeated every year. First point: it is useless to consider the European budget as the tool to solve all the problems of European citizens, which are called recession, poverty and unemployment. To foster the recovery, it would first of all need to get rid of the bosses imposed by Brussels and Frankfurt, which do not allow the States the necessary fiscal and monetary policy maneuvers that would serve to get out of the crisis. It is therefore necessary to leave the euro, dismantle economic governance and then start over on different bases in order to seek a new, healthy and clear one: cooperation between European countries. Going into the specifics of this report, I do not see how EFSI or the Youth Employment Initiative can be assessed as successful. The EFSI was a propaganda tool, which was supposed to restart investment. But the results are far from flattering, as the report of the European Court of Auditors also points out and demonstrates. The youth employment initiative starts from a concrete problem, which in many situations becomes a real drama. However, the measures undertaken through this program have been of little or no avail: in Italy this budget line has been affected by several cases of fraud and mismanagement. The European Union, then, cannot think of raising its image by giving an Interrail ticket to young people: this is a shameful useless failure to curry favor with the people. We must also be very careful when talking about projects and funds for the common defense, because we have already ceded a lot of sovereignty to Brussels and with this idea we risk taking a step of no-return, trampling again the desires and will of the peoples who do not they want more integration. Finally, I consider a passage on the Brexit, as I fear that in Brussels they will try to pay a hefty bill that smacks of revenge for the free choices of British citizens: this would be mean and shameful, as indeed the very idea of using the United Kingdom to leave the Unionto strengthen the EU's own resources system.Monti has already tried to destroy a country on behalf of Brussels and now we will certainly not let him impose new taxes even at the European level, because this would mean the end of the freedom of European peoples and citizens.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Mr President, the Union's budget offers, through its financial tools and mechanisms, solutions and catalyzes the challenges, problems and difficulties faced by the citizens and states of Europe. The management and allocation of funds demonstrates what more and more European citizens are embracing: The economic crisis is primarily political and is due to the lack of politicians capable of making the right decisions. Illegal immigration and the rise of terrorism are due, on the one hand, to the wrong financial allocation and, on the other, to the mismanagement of funds. The political elite tries to manipulate public opinion with guilt and phobia syndromes. But the blood tax of the terrorist attacks and the squandering party enjoyed by millions of friends and relatives of the regime are reflected in the minds and consciences of the people. The budget is about money. To make money you need talent, but to spend you need culture. The multicultural ethno-zero culture that is being promoted is wrong. The national, patriotic and popular culture will soon be adopted in its place.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, in recent years I have looked at the EU budget from the point of view of the LIBE Committee and I have always been satisfied with the budget, because the money for this area has increased significantly. It was no different last year. Today, however, I see that this area is still underfunded and we are forced to look for every euro to strengthen this area. In my opinion, therefore, a further increase in the budget for security and the migration crisis should be the main priority of the 2018 budget, as proposed by the rapporteur today. Above all, I want the new budget to have sufficient flexibility and to be able to obtain EU funding quickly and efficiently in times of crisis. However, this must go hand in hand with proper control of this funding and its effectiveness. We must therefore not only ensure a balance between flexibility and control, but we must also ensure that budgetary discipline is respected. Another aspect that I think is new and important for this proposal and for any other proposal is the spillover of money from area to area. Pouring from the area where money is left to the area where it is missing. One example for all is European agriculture. Billions of euros flow there every year for pointless and poorly controllable projects. On the other hand, there is still insufficient funding to address the migration crisis. We do not have the funds to strengthen some of the needs in the field of humanitarian care and in the area of ​​supporting young people. Commissioner, I would like to thank you for being willing to always discuss and listen to us, and I firmly believe that you will take the most out of Mr Mureşan's proposal for your next budget.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: - Mr President, Commissioner. On the eve of the celebration of the 60th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome, it is a good time to take stock of what the European Union has meant for the continent. And I believe that of course, there is no doubt that it has been a positive effect. The sixty years of the history of Europe have been positive. But this does not mean that there is not much to do, much to improve and, of course, much to change. Issues such as unemployment, especially youth unemployment, care for refugees, protection of the environment or the fight against tax evasion have to be at the top of the European agenda. We need a sustainable Europe in all areas. Sustainable economically, environmentally and also socially. And to meet these challenges, we must use all the tools and, of course, also the budget. Therefore, we believe that the budget must be used to the best of its capabilities. It has to be a tool of both internal and external solidarity, decisive to fight for the eradication of poverty, for sustainable development or for a knowledge society. Europe needs a change. Insurance. And it is up to us to provide answers to citizens' concerns. And if we talk about the future of Europe, I, of course, have no doubts. As an African proverb says, if you want to go fast, walk alone, but if you want to go far, better go together.

name: Stanisław OŻÓG
text: - Mr Chairman!I am pleased that the report on the guidelines for the preparation of the 2018 budget pays great attention to small and medium-sized enterprises as a key factor in promoting employment and growth.After all, SMEs are the main source of new jobs and therefore need access to finance.I would also like to draw attention to the need to improve access to know-how on how to obtain funding, especially under the European Fund for Strategic Investments with the European Structural and Investment Funds.The European Commission, knowing that we have little of this money, should analyze the projects that have so far received co-financing in order to be able to assess the justifications for the next potential beneficiaries applying for co-financing.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to support the excellent report by our colleague Siegfried Mureşan. My colleague Jäätteenmäki has said this - and I will not repeat it - in reality we find in her proposals almost all of our concerns and our priorities. For my part, I want to focus on a problem that I consider to be essential in the current state of the European project: the level of youth unemployment is too high in the Union and it is even dramatically unbearable in some countries. At a time when so many populists - and there are some here in this room - want to destroy the European project, we have an obligation to demonstrate that the Union is a real added value for the younger generations. The Youth Employment Initiative deserves to be resolutely supported and strengthened. The Council's greed in this matter is a shame. The Erasmus + program, whose success is undeniable, must be able to be extended to young apprentices and make room for young workers tomorrow. Our rapporteur also takes up in his report the proposal for a European Interrail pass, and the Commissioner seemed to find this idea sympathetic. I also find it sympathetic, but it still has to be both well calibrated and financially manageable so as not to turn into an electoral gadget serving the interests of a single political party. In our view, to merit support, this proposal must meet four characteristics. First, the pass must be accessible to young people from all walks of life and not just from wealthy backgrounds. Second, the benefit of the pass must be linked to a trip to another country as part of a training or discovery process. Third, it is not completely free: an adequate personal contribution must be the pledge of the beneficiary's commitment to the displacement project. Fourth, funding does not necessarily have to come from the EU budget alone, but can be extended to other sources of funding.Finally, the best investment we can make is investing in youth.Please let us not miss out on the future of Europe.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: -  Mister President!The EU's internal and external challenges are high and growing.Nonetheless, we must confront them with a budget that is less than 1% of the Union's gross domestic product - 50 times less than what national governments spend as a whole.Even if the EU budget were very efficient, it seems difficult to use these figures to produce results in key areas such as unemployment, climate change, research, competitiveness, migration or social cohesion.The debate on the next MFF, particularly in the context of Brexit, and also the debate on the EU's own resources - put back on the agenda through the Monti report - will be a good opportunity to see how strong the political isThe will is to turn wishes and goals into reality through a strengthened EU budget.

name: Marco VALLI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have seen fit to table some amendments to this text. Because of the only minute available to me, I will list the three main ones: first of all, we ask that infrastructure projects financed by the Union have real added value and are not controversial projects designed only, very often, to finance large companies or clientelist interests of politics. We then ask that, again on this issue, a serious discussion be opened on the EFSI and the Juncker plan, which so far has shown not to achieve the expected results, that is, a broad discussion on additionality and on all the criteria that had been promised; we would like to open a discussion precisely because it does not achieve the objectives that have been set. Finally, the point that is most close to my heart: we ask that the funds spent on the safety of buildings for seismic and geological instability measures are excluded from the deficit calculation used by the Stability and Growth Pact, as well as all the necessary public spending to boost investment, development and employment. If we do not get out of this dogma linked to austerity and the monetary constraint, it will be very difficult to relaunch demand in the eurozone and, above all, to justify the failed policies undertaken so far.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we are only at the first stage of the procedure for the 2018 budget, where Parliament sets out its vision, expresses its expectations and formulates its perspectives and proposals. After the financial and economic crises, I should say human, after Brexit it is no longer time for procrastination, but for action. Citizens can no longer take declarations that are not followed up. They can no longer tolerate this double-talk which consists in demanding that Europe act in new areas (migration, relaunching investment, combating youth unemployment, borders, security), even though the budget itself is remains the same. They expect responsibility from us: either we endow the European Union with the budget sufficient to exercise its powers, or the Member States stop the blah blah. Europe will not be able to act effectively if we do not give it the means to do so. All over Europe, nationalism and the far right thrive on this misery. Europe risks dying from this masquerade. In the 2018 budget guidelines, two examples: defense and the Interrail pass. We ask for additional resources for any new policy. In this report, after recalling the political priorities displayed by the Union, the European Parliament has the honesty to demand a guarantee that all payments are made on time, and that new own resources are supplied to this budget. . The Socialists and Democrats will be particularly vigilant in mobilizing all the means available in the service of the fight against youth unemployment, investments for the future for quality jobs and the security of our fellow citizens.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: - Mr President, Commissioner Oettinger! Tonight is about the EU budget for the coming year. You want more money, and you now want to be able to raise your own taxes because there is no longer enough money, for example because of the refugee crisis. Some countries have not protected their borders, they have allowed migrants to enter and not registered - a violation of the law. You then sent it on - another breach of the law. And then Ms. Merkel let them all enter their dream country, namely Germany - another breach of the law. The refugee crisis arose because all states do not comply with current EU law. We have a legal crisis. And instead of criticizing these violations of the law, ask for more money. How about if you simply demanded compliance with the law, compliance with applicable law such as the Dublin rules for example? I can already see the breaking news: the EU Parliament is demanding compliance with the Dublin rules. That would be a real sensation.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is time to give the European project the means to fulfill its ambitions. The persistence of the economic, social and migratory crises today weakens the European Union, whose budgetary capacities remain far too limited. The current challenges remain numerous: youth employment, socio-economic convergence, territorial balances, migration, security, defense. They must be dealt with in line with the aspirations of our fellow citizens who expect solidarity, efficiency and progress from us. But this strong commitment will not be possible without a budget capable of supporting public action. If synergies are to be established with the private sector, in particular with a view to supporting our SMEs, it would be dishonest to clear customs in favor of liberal thinking, which too often forgets that the creation of value must remain shared. Financial instruments, which too often replace budget lines, cannot be exempt from democratic control. We must, dear colleagues, avoid the socialization of losses and the privatization of profits.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, the sums of the European Union budget are insufficient and, if compared with the sums available from the United States budget, with which the European Union is in competition, the difference will be seen: 20% of the GDP of the European Union. The US is the federal budget, 1% of the European Union's GDP is the budget of Europe. And yet, the sums available for unemployment are crumbs. Youth unemployment cannot be tackled in this way, at a time when Mr Draghi has € 2.3 trillion in the famous quantitative easing. The same goes for development, the same goes for cohesion policies, for social Europe. At the same time, there is not enough money to support the refugee crisis, especially for aid in Greece, where, although the famous NGOs have received a lot of money, they are still having a party, and it needs control, Commissioner, which is why I have also requested OLAF to intervene in this matter.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: - Madam President, we are at a turning point for the future of Europe. Citizens want a European Union that is closer to their needs, more transparent and more democratic. The European budget can allow this rapprochement with citizens not only through financial allocations, but especially through better budget execution. Therefore, in addition to the general guidelines, what I am proposing is to see what the effects of each funded program or action really were and how European money was spent. Taxpayers need this. We need to rebuild confidence in European programs. That is why I strongly support additional funds for the programs with the greatest impact: Erasmus, cohesion policy, Horizon 2020, without ignoring the need for precision, innovation, investing in young people, but also to focus on results , including in terms of promoting the European project. It seems unnatural to me that the British do not know that they were among the most important beneficiaries of European funds for Horizon 2020 or EFSI. Any reform of the European funding system must take into account our common values, and I am referring here to solidarity and cohesion.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Madam President, the Union's budget must be sound, with clear targets and real added value at European level, in response to the unpredictable times we live in and all the conflicts that have been, are and may continue. take place. Let's not forget the fight against populism. It is also very necessary to combat extremism in relations with third countries amid recent escalating crises. Only an iron budgetary discipline can react and help us to react to crisis situations. Last but not least, I want to mention the security of Europe and the security of its citizens. For example, the current budget of the Internal Security Fund is around € 700 million for all EU countries and I think it is insufficient. It will have to be enlarged in 2017 precisely to ensure an efficient, modern infrastructure in all the states of the Union, to fight terrorism and protect people's lives.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Madam President, I want to join the goal set by the rapporteur here. I think it is important to really support budget growth for next year. And here we should focus on the invasion of technology, a lot has been said here. And I would like to point out one contradiction that we can actually use to illustrate how the EU is approaching this somewhat internally. Here in audiovisual legislation, we set out the obligations of what broadcast content should be, etc. However, we do not address the fact that in other Member States we cannot see the content of that broadcast because we are facing internal obstacles, just the settlement of those rights. So we should think about how to remove these obstacles. And the second aspect of security is absolutely clear. Not only the internal aspects of internal security, but also the external ones. Russia remains an aggressor, I think that is a threat and we should also set our budgetary priorities for that.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the time of Brexit and the emergence of nationalist pressures, Europe must find a new impetus to keep the idea of ​​the Union alive. The budget must be seen as a political tool at our disposal to concretely respond to the requests coming to us from European citizens. We must first find more effective ways to adapt public spending to the real conditions in which Member States find themselves: youth employment, digital infrastructure, immigration, internal security, up to climate change and the challenges of food sustainability, are the issues on which the future of the Union is at stake and these are issues that must be tackled with a global approach, not just a technical and financial one. Additionality and the geographical balance of investments need to be improved, overcoming austerity policies, focusing on growth and investing in the new generations. We take the opportunity of the budget to revitalize the relationship with citizens, regaining their trust.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! Firstly, I want to say: we are not asking for more money. The accusation of Ms. von Storch, who can no longer be there, is simply wrong. We have a budget, we have a cover for it, we keep it. We will do everything we can to accomplish the tasks within the budget set by the Council and Parliament for 2018. In general, I think you could all be a little more proud when you look at the efficiency of European budgets. Europe's government quota is on average 50%. For every 100 euros that a citizen earns in Europe - through manual work, mental work, investments - 50 euros go into public hands. In some countries up to 57%, in others only 45% - on average 50% percent. So for every 50 euros that we take from citizens for a gross 100 euros, one euro goes into the European coffers and 49 euros remain in Berlin or Madrid, in Düsseldorf or Barcelona or in municipalities or with state health systems. One euro out of 50 - we are responsible for that. With this one euro we do a lot of things right. I'm not saying we're doing everything right. That is why the discharge debate is necessary, and the Commission is also capable of self-criticism. The error rate has been reduced significantly year after year in recent years, and I look forward to the debate on discharge in a few days here in this House. We had an excellent factual debate in the Committee on Budgetary Control. We have achieved discharge in the Council and here too we want to use good arguments to promote discharge for 2015 in the European Parliament. The 2018 budget is not about Brexit, no matter how and when the negotiations start and when they end. Our member state Great Britain is a full member with all rights and all obligations for the entire 2018 financial year. That means it works around EU-28. We also know that in the next post-2020 budget, there is a probability bordering on certainty that the British will no longer be there. That is why the EU27 Commission's White Paper is mentioned. And that is why we will of course, within the framework of what we as the Commission have to work out, concentrate the next budgetary framework on 27 Member States in terms of revenue and expenditure. And yet there are subsequent obligations. It's like any normal relationship. Even after separation, there may be subsequent obligations. This is what the family calls children of divorce, and what is called commitments here. If we now make commitments that will continue after 2020 when the children are not adults, then we will be able to expect our British friends to fulfill the subsequent commitments, which are decreasing year by year. By the way, especially in the area of ​​research: those who will suffer most from Brexit are British research institutes and industrial companies that are currently participating in Joint Undertaking, Public Private Partnerships, the Important Project of Common European Interest and, to a large extent, funds from Horizon Want to access in 2020, also in the future. That is why we need a clever solution here, which we will discuss in the course of the divorce negotiations over the next few months. The idea that defense should become a European issue has been criticized. If you know how inefficiently 28 Member States are doing defense research individually, how many branches of arms we have, how little standardization we have, then you know that Europe is not well positioned here. The Americans - our partners in NATO - get for one dollar several times what we currently get from one euro or one pound. That is why it was the consent of the European Council to ask the Commission on the subject Defense research and joint projects to work out a proposal that we will also present to this House before the middle of the year. We will start defense research with first projects. It doesn't make sense to develop the use of drones for defense 28 times and research 28 times. The smallest child knows that the company size can run far better for such complex projects in partnership, in cooperation and in a harmonized way. It is correct - we will come back to this: Defense projects cannot be financed at the expense of social policy. This is exactly what we will pay attention to. We do not want to save on our important social spending and programs, the fight against youth unemployment, to finance defense projects. That would be unfair to the young population and to socially disadvantaged European citizens. But it still makes sense. And that is why the Member States may have to provide additional funds, because these tasks and expenses can be financed more efficiently and therefore more cost-effectively for the taxpayer in a European team, coordinated at European level. The subject of own resources was mentioned. This, too, has nothing to do with the 2018 budget; the report by the group around Mr Monti will have to be discussed with you in the course of the next budget framework in 2021. What are we thinking about? When the European Community was founded, customs revenue was a focus. With every enlargement of the European Union, the customs revenue decreases. Denmark to Holland, Poland to Germany and vice versa used to be customs-related processes, today they are no longer due to membership in the European internal market. With every trade agreement - CETA - customs revenues decrease. And that today we finance 70% and more of our income through contributions and tariffs have dropped to 10% and another 10% are sales tax shares basically an imbalance.We don't want more income, we want the income base to be broadened, we want diversification.And that is what the Monti Report serves, which we are discussing openly in the Commission and with you.There are some clever ideas in it, for example, how one can more meaningfully combine the subject of the ETS trading system, CO2 emission rights and payment for them or other European policy areas with the income sector of the European budget.The income should no longer be placed on a broader basis.Many thanks again to the rapporteur for trying to get a large majority here.Your report is an important - the important - basis for our budget, which we will then draw up in the spring and which we will discuss together during the course of the year.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, dear colleagues, firstly I would like to thank you all for your constructive remarks during the debate tonight, for the amendments which you have put forward and which in particular the rapporteurs of the political groups have put forward. I was able and happy to integrate most of your amendments into the compromises which we voted on at the level of the committee last week, and I am looking forward to continuing the work together with you over the course of this year in the same constructive spirit. I would also like to thank Commissioner Oettinger for sharing our priorities, for the positive evolution on the priorities which we have put forward, which are: number one, growth and jobs, and number two, security. We believe that the primary mission of the Union is to support the economy, which would then be able to create more, better, stable, better-paid jobs for the citizens of Europe, and this is of course only possible if people feel safe in Europe, if companies invest, if people start companies, if they unleash their entrepreneurial spirit, if they are ready to move throughout Europe to other Member States of the Union in search of a job. Commissioner, I also agree with you in what you have said on youth unemployment, and many colleagues have also voiced their views on this. The youth employment initiative should continue, should be strengthened and should be improved, if possible, in the next year. I also agree that we need to make available the financial resources which we need for payments next year, because the operational programmes in the Member States will be at full speed next year, and we need to make sure that we have the money to pay the bills of the Union immediately, because there is no worse signal than a Union which is not capable of paying its bills immediately. On this basis, Commissioner, colleagues from the Commission, we are looking forward to you putting forward a draft budget later this year which takes full account of the political priorities of the Parliament which we will adopt tomorrow.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: - The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, Wednesday 15 March 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: in writing. - The report on the European Parliament's budgetary guidelines is the starting document for the 2018 budgetary procedure, which sets out Parliament's political priorities. According to the report, the motto of the 2018 process is an EU budget for sustainable growth, job creation and security. Hungary has been at the forefront of sustainable economic growth, increasing employment, reducing unemployment and strengthening the security of its citizens for many years, so this is an important message for us. The report also states that the mid-term review of the current seven-year financial framework must be concluded as soon as possible, ie the European Parliament must give its assent as soon as possible to the compromise reached by the Council. This is crucial for Hungary for two reasons: the Council confirmed that a reduction in cohesion, agricultural and rural development funds, ie resources previously allocated to Member States, was ruled out during the review. This succeeded in ensuring that the EU funds fought by the Orbán government could not be reduced and that the support of Hungarian farmers was also ensured. However, the revision of the multiannual financial framework can also help to avoid a liquidity crisis under the previous seven-year framework, when the Commission was unable to pay the invoices submitted to the Member States for the projects implemented. The Council agreement can provide an adequate guarantee: there will be sufficient resources in the annual budgets for the catching-up programs already running and for the payment of agricultural subsidies.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: in writing. - In the context of the 2018 budget guidelines, I draw attention to the need to increase funding for research and innovation and for the Erasmus + program. In terms of research and innovation, the low success rate of projects applying for funding under Horizon 2020 means that many good-quality projects are rejected. Therefore, an increase in funding is essential to further develop the European innovation policy and to strengthen the EU's competitiveness and innovation. I am also sorry to note that the redirection of H2020 funds to support EFSI projects has resulted in marginal benefits for the cultural and educational sector and for public universities. The problem of the low success rate also applies to the Erasmus + program. Here, too, it would be necessary to increase the budget, as initially announced by the European Commission. Moreover, it is very worrying that the Commission plans to finance other projects, including the European Solidarity Corps, from the Erasmus + budget. This approach will lead to a further reduction in the funds allocated to Erasmus +. To ensure that limited financial resources do not discourage potential beneficiaries from participating in Erasmus +, I also encourage the Commission to highlight projects rejected for lack of funding in order to help them attract investment from other sources.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: signed up. - I consider that the part dedicated to internal challenges is being treated inappropriately. It is stated that, with regard to the issue of migration in the current context, a viable and budgetary solution is still awaited. So far, much has been done for this crisis at the expense of other budget chapters, such as the CAP. What should we understand, that Europe needs money to keep an unresolved issue? I therefore propose in this way a first concrete solution, namely the return of competences on migration and border issues to the Member States. In this way it will win in both directions, on the one hand the Union budget will save, and the Member States will have a harder time saying a word about border sovereignty. In conclusion, I consider it irrational to increase funding and introduce new taxes for European citizens as a direct result of a still uncertain situation of the migrant crisis. I disapprove of the fact that the Member States are obliged to implement and, above all, to finance those centralized decisions which are strongly contrary to the national interest.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: - The next item on the agenda is the statement by the Commission on 'Serious malnutrition and impending famine in Nigeria, Somalia, South Sudan and Yemen' (2017/2601 (RSP)).

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the world is facing the largest humanitarian crisis in the history of the United Nations. The European Commission is deeply concerned by the humanitarian crises in North-East Nigeria, Somalia, South Sudan and Yemen. Twenty million people in these countries are at risk of starvation and famine in the coming four months. The international community should step up its support now. Tomorrow will, unfortunately, be too late. Let me briefly refer to the situation in each of these four countries and then inform you as to how the European Union is helping the people in need in their countries. I would like to start with Yemen. The situation is dire. Almost 19 million people – yes, this is the figure – are in need of immediate humanitarian assistance. This is the largest food insecurity emergency in the world: 7.3 million people are at risk of famine over the next four months. The truth is this: the intensification of fighting is making the humanitarian situation even worse. What we are witnessing is an appalling disregard for protection of civilians and international humanitarian law. If fighting reaches Hodeidah Port, which is the main entry point for food imports into the country, there will be dramatic humanitarian consequences. Second, there is the Lake Chad crisis, which includes North-East Nigeria. The situation in North-East Nigeria is of great concern owing to Boko Haram’s activities. I witnessed this myself when I visited the country, especially the area of Yola town, at that time. But the worry is even bigger right now because of the combination of extremism and instability with climate change and population growth. Over five million people need emergency food assistance in North-East Nigeria alone. Thirdly, South Sudan. This is the very definition of a ‘man-made crisis’. It is a shame. Three years of conflict have had catastrophic consequences. The United Nations declared a localised famine in February. Hundreds of thousands of people are at risk of dying. These figures could further increase if they do not receive urgent assistance. This is unfortunately the situation on the ground. The European Union is a leading donor in South Sudan. However, the parties to the conflict, including government troops, are stopping the delivery of assistance even in areas hit by famine. Unfortunately, this is the tragic reality for millions of citizens. I saw it with my own eyes when I visited South Sudan, but also during my recent visit to Uganda, which is hosting thousands of South Sudanese refugees. There is no more time for empty promises. The international community has to take a stronger, more outspoken and principled stance on this. Fourthly, Somalia. The situation is desperate. Half the population – over six million people – are now facing acute food insecurity and hunger. Three million people need urgent life-saving assistance. This is three times more than it was six months ago, and even more than at the time of my visit to Mogadishu at the beginning of last year. The expected weather conditions can only make this worse. Dear colleagues, this is the situation in these four areas on the ground. As the European Union, we are fully committed to doing our best to help, as we did last year when we adopted a package of EUR 540 million to help address the El Niño effects in Africa. The European Union has already taken immediate steps to address the most urgent needs. We stepped up our humanitarian funding in all these countries last year, in 2016, with almost EUR 345 million. We have already allocated EUR 200 million in the first two months of this year. I was in Oslo two or three weeks ago and I pledged, on behalf of the European Union, EUR 105 million in humanitarian assistance for North-East Nigeria and the Lake Chad region. Also, last month we stepped up our assistance to South Sudan to EUR 82 million, and we provided a first package of EUR 10 million of emergency assistance to Somalia. This is an initial allocation. We are currently mobilising all our funding possibilities to step up our response. You will receive, probably today, the Commission proposals for a new emergency package, in particular for the Horn of Africa and Yemen. We count on your quick adoption. At the same time, the Commission is finalising a new significant package for North-East Nigeria, linking relief, rehabilitation and development. This, as you know, has to be matched by other donors, because the needs are huge. Every hour that passes is crucial. Thousands of lives are at stake. I am sorry for this very bad picture, but this is the situation on the ground.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President! Commissioner! After six years, we have once again such a dramatic situation in the Horn of Africa, but this time it could be the biggest humanitarian crisis in decades on this continent, and this time it is much more difficult because the crisis in hungry countries is man-made. 20 million people in Yemen, South Sudan, Somalia and Nigeria are facing starvation. Prolonged conflicts mean that there is a shortage of food, food prices are rising and people are forced to leave their homes, while humanitarian convoys have limited access to those in need. In the last famine in the Horn of Africa, 250,000 people died, half of them children under the age of five. A famine means that at least 30% of a country's children are severely and severely malnourished, and the death rate among the population is enormous. Already in February, the United Nations declared a famine in the northern part of South Sudan as humanitarian aid was cut off. It is now a national problem, and its sole cause is an internal political dispute that has turned into a violent conflict. You have already spoken about the data: 7.5 million Sudanese people require immediate help, and there is a cholera epidemic spreading in this country. In Yemen, two-thirds of the population suffer from food insecurity as fighting continues. There are displacements, and the lack of access to medical care results in higher morbidity and, of course, higher mortality rates. In Northeast Nigeria, where 80% of the population was dependent on agriculture and cattle breeding, Boko Haram militias forced many people to flee their homes and destroyed livelihoods in rural areas. As for Somalia, there is a period of drought from January to March, while previous rainy seasons were poor in rainfall and the crops were destroyed, and the water reserves are exhausted.Added to this is the terrorist action of the Ash-Shabbab group, which carries out attacks in the southern and central parts of Somalia it controls, effectively destabilizing the country.We are pleased that the European Commission decided in February to donate 82 million as part of the aid package for the South Sudan famine, and today's declarations by the Commissioner are also proof of the EU's swift response to the appeals of the international community.However, the UN Deputy Secretary General for Humanitarian Aid Stephen O'Brian said that about $ 4.5 billion should be allocated to the implementation of the plan of action prepared by the organization.This is a huge amount, but I hope we can make a collective and coordinated global effort to prevent the tragic consequences of one of the greatest crises in recent African history, which could claim 20 million lives.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group.- Madam President, about half a million children in Nigeria, about two hundred thousand in Somalia, about three hundred thousand in South Sudan, about five hundred thousand in Yemen;In total, a million and a half children, like this child who has been lucky enough to live and be born in the European Union, are at risk of severe acute malnutrition.It is a certain and immediate risk of death.Millions of people are hungry.And the cause of all this is an explosive mixture: war conflicts, poverty, climate change.As always, climate change affects the poorest;conflicts affect women and children first;poverty affects everyone.I support the fact that the package that the Commissioner has presented to us, which we will receive today, is quickly processed in Parliament, to serve millions of people who are at risk of death.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Madam President, the world community is facing the worst humanitarian crisis since 1945. More than 20 million people in Yemen, Somalia, South Sudan and Nigeria are starving. Yemen is facing the biggest crisis, as 2/3 of its population needs help and more than 7 million people are facing the spectrum of hunger. In South Sudan, which has been ravaged by civil war for three years, the situation is worse than ever. More than one million children are estimated to be severely malnourished, and 270,000 of them are at immediate risk of death. At the same time, in Somalia 185 thousand children are on the brink of starvation due to drought. Their number is expected to reach 270 thousand in a few months. The same situation prevails in Nigeria, where 2.6 million people have been displaced and more than 200,000 have been killed in the northeastern part of the country due to the activities of the Islamist organization Boko Haram. The international community must act immediately and decisively to prevent famine in these countries, and the European Union must take the lead in this.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, we have put on the agenda of our session the famine which threatens five countries because time is running out, not only today, but already since February, when the World Food Program, the Unicef ​​and the FAO have reported the first victims. Moreover, the current crisis differs from the past in that it is occurring in a large number of countries at the same time. It should be remembered that around 30 countries are dependent on external food aid and that five of them have entered the acute phase of the food disaster. We can go on about the current crisis for a long time to conclude, finally, that the five most affected countries are all marked by conflicts. This does not explain everything, but internal conflicts are often such that the distribution of food aid is almost impossible. The drought in East Africa should be added, but this only partially explains the phenomenon of the current famine. When it is not a conflict between Shiites and Sunnis, it is an ethnic war which endangers millions of lives and, among them, many children, who are only skin on their bones. It is up to us to act with our means of humanitarian intervention, while being aware that we will not be able to do everything, unfortunately. While human stupidity and malice are clearly among the causes of the current famine, this does not allow us to remain indifferent to the plight of threatened populations. I do not doubt for a single moment the will of the Commission - and of its valiant Commissioner, Mr Stylianides - to do everything possible to alleviate the suffering of those concerned. I fully share the analysis and diagnosis of Mr. Stylianides, as well as the proposals he has submitted to us.

name: João FERREIRA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, the speech of commiseration and compassion towards hunger in Somalia, Nigeria, Yemen and South Sudan cannot erase the need to look for the root causes of this humanitarian drama, nor the proper attribution of responsibilities. The reasons for hunger are political, in the first place. IMF and World Bank interventions and the prevailing neoliberal guidelines, the significant increase in the cost of production factors in agriculture, inseparable from the power and role of multinationals, the drastic reduction in the purchasing power of the urban population, the dismantling of programs social debt, debt and debt servicing, the replacement of state cereal reserves and the price fixing mechanisms of agricultural products in local markets by the Chicago Stock Exchange, for a world market dominated by agribusiness multinationals and speculators, the civil wars and the various conflicts instigated by external powers, such as the United States, Saudi Arabia and some European countries, external interference and the imperialist impulse to control natural resources, such as oil - all this led to what the United Nations already classified as the biggest drama, the biggest humanitarian crisis, since its creation in 45. A change is needed policy and emergency humanitarian aid is needed, with greater accountability from the European Union. At a time when scientific and technical development reaches levels that would easily allow the eradication of hunger, its persistence is one of the most vivid accusatory libels that weighs on the capitalist system, which is dominant worldwide.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 2017: 20 million people affected by hunger and famine. It was since 1945 that the world was not facing a humanitarian crisis of this kind and we cannot even hide behind hypocrisy, because malnutrition and the impending famine are mainly the cause of man and it is no coincidence, in fact, that four countries mentioned above are all war zones. I think first of all about Yemen and the proxy war taking place there between Sunnis and Shiites and the 462,000 children currently suffering from severe malnutrition. In South Sudan we have now reached 300,000 victims and two million refugees. But we must also not forget the climate changes, which can be observed, for example, at this time around Lake Chad and the drought that is now affecting particular areas of Africa. I could obviously continue citing Boko Haram and also Somalia and what happened in the various areas but what I want to underline is that this hunger is not an unforeseeable fatality, but an unacceptable consequence of the trade policies we implement and also of the actions of multinationals - ours as Europeans - but also of giants such as China and perhaps, in addition to the very important economic aid for which I thank the Commissioner, we should act more decisively from this point of view as well.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, Commissioner! Yemen, South Sudan, Somalia and Nigeria are currently in the midst of the biggest humanitarian crisis since World War II. People in these countries have access to less than four liters of water a day, and this means that, due to malnutrition, they have an average body mass index that is below the limit value. We are now experiencing war in Yemen for the third year in a row. The situation is worst here, as almost two thirds of the population - that's 19 million people - urgently need humanitarian aid. Seven million people are at risk of starvation. South Sudan is also a troubled country, where a devastating combination of famine, disease and armed conflict threatens millions of people. In parts of South Sudan, the United Nations even declared famine a few days ago. The situation in Nigeria, where Boko Haram, the African arm of the terrorist organization IS, has already killed 20,000 civilians, is also disturbing. 2.6 million people are on the run, 5 million need food aid. The situation is similar in Somalia, where the Islamic State and al-Shabaab militias are responsible for the deaths of almost 6,000 civilians. 1.4 million people are on the run, 6 million are suffering from acute food shortages and 3 million are in need of life-saving help. The emergency aid coordination of the UN speaks of 4.4 billion dollars that we urgently need in aid. The EU is very exemplary in this area. We have a great duty to help these people. We must not leave these people alone!

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! The former UN Commissioner for Refugees and current UN Secretary General recently warned that millions of people in the sub-Saharan zone are at risk of starvation. But who is his appeal aimed at? First and foremost, he should address the member states of the organization that he now heads. It has long been clear that drought and natural disasters are only a small part of the current plight of so many people. The threat to millions of people from hunger and death in Nigeria, Somalia, South Sudan and Yemen - as previous speakers have already said - has first and foremost political reasons. Corrupt rulers are waging senseless wars and civil wars, in which they also enrich themselves, and the world just watches on. Where the causes of hunger, hardship, flight and displacement are political, political solutions are also needed! Who does it benefit if we try to treat symptoms with 100 million euros? That is an imperative of charity and, Commissioner, I thank you for taking on this task. But if we do not get to the cause of the evil, we will only be able to drop the famous drop in the bucket there. The situation is exacerbated by the fact that, according to the aid organizations, many aid deliveries no longer reach those in need or are attacked and robbed beforehand. Two EU states are permanent members of the UN Security Council, three more are non-permanent members of this body this year. It is high time we did our best there to ensure that those who are responsible for causing these emergencies are also held accountable and finally sanctioned.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are facing the worst humanitarian crisis ever, yet another in a few years. Faced with a famine of this magnitude, time is life. At stake is the survival of one million and 400 children in Somalia, South Sudan, Yemen and north-eastern Nigeria: a total of 20 million people at risk. We work on the root causes that make these places highly vulnerable to climate change, the center of crises of enormous size, starting with the conflicts that take away any capacity for resilience from these doubly raped populations.
