Commissioner, let's hurry up! Drought cycles in many areas of the world are now increasingly long, while conflicts arise precisely from the hoarding of the few available water resources. It is not an emergency but a fact that we must take note of. We intervene through actions capable of making these populations resilient and development policies with short, medium and long term proposals.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: - Everyone has said it here: 20 million people are starving in South Sudan, Yemen, Nigeria and Somalia. Every day 21,000 people worldwide die of starvation. That is, one every four seconds. That means, if you can count quickly, a huge number of deaths while we are having this debate. Mr Commissioner, you said: “We have a very extensive aid program planned. We have allocated money and provided emergency aid ”. From your words I understood that you see the need and the urgency. All aid organizations ask that we act urgently. In Yemen alone, half a million children are at risk of starvation. I fear that the emergency aid that we are now providing is not enough. I would like to pledge our support from ALDE to do more: emergency aid, structural support, intervention in those conflict areas, attention for the children. I really fear that if we don't do more very soon, my children will later ask a commission of inquiry to say, "Europe, why haven't you done more?"

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 20 million people are at risk of starvation in Nigeria, Somalia, South Sudan and Yemen. One and a half million children are at imminent risk of death: it is an unprecedented crisis. These are the UN data on the situation in African countries; it is not a statistical or census exercise: it is a warning, an alarm, the prediction of an announced drama. However, the cause of these deaths is not only nature, drought or impending famine. The main responsibilities are of men, of the guerrilla between rebel groups, of terrorism, of those who, in that area, exploit the resources in a criminal way, impoverishing the territory and the population. We need 4 billion dollars: just 90 million has been raised, at a time when Trump's United States could also reduce aid. It is now that the European Union must become decisive and assume a leading role immediately, to save those lives and, strategically in the future, to give Africa an opportunity for development.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: - Madam President!The European Parliament's debate in February warned of an impending humanitarian crisis in South Sudan.Now we stand here and witness it happen.However, it is not only in South Sudan, but hunger is also threatening Yemen, Nigeria and Somalia in what is being called the biggest humanitarian catastrophe since World War II.It is not acceptable for people to starve today when we have all the information we have, when we know in time what is about to happen.Then it is not acceptable for the outside world to close its eyes.As a parent, I say what many parents have said before: Through my child, I see the children of the world.When I, as a European, put my child to bed tonight safely and calmly, I know that there are mothers in other parts of the world in countries where you can not guarantee that the child will fall asleep full.That is not acceptable.We in the EU must do much more in solidarity with the starving children.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, it is clear that we are in the middle of a tragic humanitarian crisis. We absolutely have to avoid a catastrophe in these countries, where 20 million people are facing hunger and drought, by all means. The number of undernourished children in urgent need of life-saving interventions has spiked against the backdrop of drought. People living in fragile, conflict-affected states, have to cope with national disasters and with the impact of violence and instability on health, basic service provision, social cohesion, mobility, opportunities and livelihoods. I believe we can still save many lives. The severe malnutrition and looming famine are largely man-made. We must not repeat the tragedy of the 2011 famine in the Horn of Africa. Our common humanity demands faster action, and I urge you, Commissioner, if you have not paid a visit in the region, you have to do it.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Madam President, I admit that I did not know about the extent of this humanitarian catastrophe, I only knew about its framework, but until I heard the words of the Commissioner, I did not really know this extent and it is huge for me.rival.I want to say to the Commissioner that whatever step he takes to save even a single life, I think, of course, that not only I but all my colleagues will support it.I would like to hear the words that we will look for the cause of this catastrophe and at the same time derive the personal responsibility of specifically responsible people.So that these people know that they are not hiding in any hole in the world, that they will not escape this responsibility and that it will be inferred according to the applicable rules of international criminal law.I think this is very important for such a message to be heard today against these people in Strasbourg.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, I thank all of my colleagues here, especially Soraya Post, for raising this issue. The scale of the catastrophe we see unfolding before us is staggering. UNICEF estimates that 1.4 million children are at imminent risk of death from starvation, today in the 21st century. Hundreds of thousands of children are in immediate risk in Nigeria and Yemen. This comes on top of the food insecurity in these regions that affects millions already, especially women and girls. Clearly, more must be done urgently to save these lives. Women and girls, particularly pregnant women and adolescent girls, are the most vulnerable to the effects of malnutrition. We must make sure that our policy on this is coherent and consistent. We cannot expect to solve the humanitarian crisis if we keep selling arms to Saudi Arabia or overlook the role of Iran in the war in Yemen and the region. I also want to reiterate the long-term role of education and intercultural dialogue in peace-building and development. Fighting against malnutrition requires we ensure access to education.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, you have our full support for a humanitarian aid program. But we must ask ourselves a series of questions. Why have we destroyed the local productive economies? Do our free trade agreements and our latest agreements not contribute even more, when we see in fifty years, dependence on the agrifood level? Have we not introduced systematic interference at the political level, the manipulation of powers, but also the policy of free trade, that of the "free fox in the free henhouse"? In particular, do we not have a responsibility in this split in Sudan that I was opposed to and which led us to war? Do we not also have a responsibility in this war in Yemen which has not been denounced, with our ally, a so-called ally - it is not my ally - that is Saudi Arabia and its exactions? against humanity, also in Nigeria?

name: Seán KELLY
text: - A Uacharáin, bhíomar ag gearán sa Pharlaimint seo faoi seo agus faoi siúd ach i gcomparáid leis na tíortha seo, níl móran le bheith ag gearán againn faoi. Sna tíortha seo a leanas: an Nigéir, an tSomáil, deisceart na Súdáine agus an Éimin, tá se scannalach sa la atá inniu ann go bhfuil an méid sin daoine i mbaol báis de bharr ocrais agus gorta agus níor cheart an ar milleán Aontas mar tá an tAontas seo ag déanamh children mó chun cabhrú leis na tíortha sin ná aon aonad nó tír eile ar domhan. Agus ní aontaím freisin mar a duirt daoine on eite chlé go gcuirfí an milleán ar chomhlachtaí móra domhanda, an Banc Domhanda, an IMF agus mar sin de. Níl siad gan locht ach tá se soiléir gurb iad na cúiseanna is mó daoine a bheith ag fail bhais ná cogaí inmheánacha sna tíortha sin, cogaí cathracha, drochrialtais agus athrú aeráide. Cabhróidh COP 21 leis na fadbhanna a bhaineann him hathrú aeráide a shocrú amach anseo agus caithfimid ar ndícheall a dhéanamh chun rialtas buanseasmhach féaráilte a chur ar bun sna tíortha sin.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: - Madam President, there is no more time. We are facing one of the greatest humanitarian crises since 1945, when more than 20 million people in Nigeria, Somalia, South Sudan and Yemen are threatened by famine. According to UNICEF, 1.4 million children could die by the end of the year. But to avoid a disaster, the UN estimates that more than $ 4.4 billion is needed by the end of July. Despite generous promises, the UN has received only 90 million this year. All four states have in common the conflict, but especially the lack of reaction of the great international actors, who again do not understand that we cannot hide, that we have a humanitarian responsibility. For those who do not see beyond the immediate aspects, I remind them what direct and immediate effects the situations in Syria and Libya have had on Europe. So there is no time. Commissioner, you have my full support. Let's get to work, but also act directly on the causes that generated these situations.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 20 million people are at risk of starvation in the coming months. According to Stephen O'Brien, UN humanitarian officer, the area between South Sudan, Somalia, Yemen and northeastern Nigeria is facing the worst humanitarian crisis since the creation of the United Nations. The first victims of this food catastrophe are largely the weakest sections of the population, such as children. The condition of South Sudan appears to be the most alarming: around 250,000 children risk their lives due to malnutrition. Similar figures have not been seen since 1998, one of the most violent years of the civil war. According to estimates, 4.4 billion dollars would be needed by July to stem the effects of the famine and avert a humanitarian catastrophe. A situation that Europe must take charge of, above all for humanitarian reasons. This time we cannot turn the other way: if these populations are not helped, the highest price will be paid by Europe, which could find itself at the center of a gigantic migratory flow.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Members very much for their comments and views. We definitely share the same concerns and worries, and of course our determination is common. There is no doubt that we have to do more. But make no mistake: as my dear friend has already mentioned, the European Union is doing its part and we will, of course, do more. But let me remind you of something critical. This is also a development crisis. As some of you have already mentioned, we need to address the root causes of fragility, conflict, poor governance, non-governance and the rule of law. Otherwise our response will never achieve sustainable results. The European Union Trust Fund for Africa and the External Investment Plan, as new instruments, are aimed precisely at covering this dimension. We do not, of course, have any illusions, but I think we are already moving in the right direction in order to address the root causes. In parallel, what matters in any humanitarian crisis is that humanitarian organisations have immediate and full access to do their job and deliver aid. Repeated violations of international humanitarian law are simply unacceptable. The governments of these countries have a primary responsibility to care for the basic needs of their populations and to allow aid organisations to support them in this obligation. To conclude, let me say that this human suffering is not inevitable. Almost all these crises are manmade. Above all – as some of you have already said – they need political solutions. The European Union has a responsibility to put its weight behind efforts to address the root causes of these crises, be they driven by conflict, climate change, population growth or other causes. Once again, thank you very much for your support in this very difficult situation. My personal promise is that we have to continue in this way in order to alleviate the suffering of the people and to save lives.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: - Thank you, Commissioner!I wish you and above all all the people who are affected by this terrible famine that we can actually help.The debate is closed.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - Nearly 1.4 million children are at immediate risk of death due to severe acute malnutrition, and more than 100 million people worldwide are critically malnourished. Hunger is particularly prevalent in Nigeria, Somalia, South Sudan and Yemen, where conflict and drought are hampering food production. The wars in Yemen, Nigeria and South Sudan devastated those areas, and droughts in East Africa and Somalia destroyed agriculture and left millions in poverty. Reports and information coming from those countries warn that the food crisis, which has already claimed the lives of hundreds of people, could be the most devastating in decades. In Nigeria, almost 250,000 children under the age of 5 will suffer from malnutrition this year. The situation in that country is also deteriorating due to the violence perpetrated by Boko Haram, the country has been left without agricultural production, the market has been disrupted and food prices are unattainable. The situation is similar in Yemen, where the civil war has been raging for two years, as well as in oil-rich South Sudan, where fighting has ethnically divided the country and has been torn apart by the 2013 war. It takes a quick reaction, because time is running out for millions of people.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Patrizia Toia, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of the 470-790 MHz frequency band in the Union (COM(2016) 0043 - C8-0020 / 2016 - 2016/0027 (COD)) (A8-0327 / 2016).

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: rapporteur. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, first of all I want to thank my fellow shadow rapporteurs and the other colleagues I have worked with because in just one year - the Commission proposal is from February 2016 - we have come to the approval and to agree in the trialogue a good job, I believe, which is a fundamental step for the full achievement of the digital union. Today it is clear to everyone that high-speed connection is essential for our society and our economy. It is expected that by 2021 the number of smartphones will double and that by 2020 Internet traffic will increase by eight times compared to the current one. I mention only these two data to give the measure of the increase and rapid growth of everything related to digital. We must be ready to answer this growing demand for connection. I think we need to do this because consumers, like businesses and public administrations, need it to offer better and more efficient services. I am thinking of all the innovative services - they are in front of all of us - that are emerging: from connected cars, to all remote healthcare management, to all public administration services and also to the whole huge issue of the digitalization of businesses. . Internet of things, cloud and mobile communication services are just some examples of connectivity that are experiencing this development globally. And therefore there is a demand for speed but also for communication networks capable of carrying a lot of data, a huge and growing mass of data, reaching densely populated areas as well as remote areas. The development of the most advanced technologies therefore requires the European legislator to guarantee the best possible access to the Internet for all citizens, even in remote areas, also contributing to the development of increasingly cross-border applications and transnational. Radio frequencies have no borders, which is why it is necessary to provide for better coordination of the spectrum at European level - I have long been a great supporter of this need for coordination at European level - and it is in this context that the proposal of this a decision we will vote on tomorrow, which contains specific measures for the coordinated release of the 694-790 MHz band, more quickly called the "700 MHz band". The aim of the proposal is to create uniform criteria at European level for the allocation of frequencies, to overcome barriers to entry, to overcome the current obstacles to competition and to offer this high-speed wireless connectivity with a universal character. The availability of a broad radio spectrum is one of the essential prerequisites for the deployment of broadband services. Its management takes place at national level - it is a national asset - and the sale of the related rights of use can ensure huge revenues (some states have already done so) for the coffers of the member states. But the management of the radio spectrum at national level determines very different conditions between the individual states, both in terms of license duration, coverage obligations, but above all the consequences of inefficient use of this precious resource. That is why, in the opinion of the Commission, but also of Parliament, we need to act in a timely manner, as we are doing, to ensure that spectrum is managed and regulated more efficiently. Basically, the proposal focuses on two elements: for the 700 band there is a common timetable for it to be effectively available for use by wireless services under harmonized conditions, with coordination measures to support the transition phase. For the sub-700 band a long-term priority is foreseen for the distribution of audiovisual media services to the general public, together with a flexible approach, the use of spectrum in response to the different degree of diffusion of digital terrestrial television in the various Member States.We have reached a good compromise in the ITRE committee, asking for the release of this band to take place by 2020 but also for the possibility of a small delay, motivated by some specific conditions, to be provided for some States.And we also asked for a coordination plan for transnational issues.I think it is a good, balanced job that responds to clear objectives and that will put us in a position to win this race for the spread of 5G and all the most advanced technologies.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members of Parliament, we welcome the political agreement in December 2016 and the swift preparation of the final text by both co-legislators. A coordinated and timely release of the 700 MHz band by mid-2020 is fundamental to establish a European world-leading 5G home market of innovative services like the connected car and high-speed rural broadband. The Commission has suggested ambitious connectivity targets in its digital single market strategy, and also a structured plan for European leadership in deploying 5G mobile services. One objective is that all European households, including in rural and remote regions, should have access to connectivity offering download speeds of at least 100 Mbps by 2025. In addition, uninterrupted 5G coverage should be ensured in urban areas and along major transport paths by 2025. For this to happen we need high-quality spectrum to provide wide area coverage at high speed and a reasonable cost for operators. The 700 MHz band is ideal for this purpose. With regard to the agreed sub-700 MHz band, its availability for broadcasting until 2030 ensures legal certainty for developing our European audiovisual model as well as flexibility for adapting to diverse national situations. Therefore we will work closely with the Member States on a timely and structured implementation of this instrument by the following steps: publishing national roadmaps for transition, a key tool to ensure predictability for our stakeholders and consistency of approaches in the single market; minimising delays for 700 MHz availability and resolving cases of cross-border interference in a timely manner; enhancing wireless coverage for high-quality connectivity for citizens and innovative services; fostering coordination of the evolving use of the sub-700 MHz band including a future review. I would like to congratulate Parliament for the timely work on this file initiative, and in particular to thank the rapporteur, Ms Toia, for her efforts.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Toia. It was a very good cooperation and we achieved a lot, securing that the 700 MHz band can be allocated in 2020, with some adjustments for some Member States if they have duly justified reasons until 2022. This means an important opportunity for Europe. I think you can say that the third generation of mobile telephony was a digitalisation of telephony, and Europe was in the lead with very important consequences of a positive kind for the European economy. 4G was the digitalisation of services, and Europe lost the lead because of fragmentation, and because we did not deploy the networks rapidly enough. And that also had economic consequences because Europe is lagging behind, not only regarding 4G but also regarding all the services that are coming from 4G. That creates problems for our competitiveness, innovation, unemployment and growth. 5G is the normalisation of the digital, and that makes the game much more important, because if we cannot be in the lead regarding 5G we will not be in the lead regarding innovative products, companies, services, and we will not be able to take the lead regarding growth, global champions and competitiveness. This has huge consequences and I think, seen from this perspective, the decision here tonight is one of the more important in Europe in order to make Europe strong, globally and economically.  5G is dependent on the 700 MHz band. Not only because of the rapid increase in mobile data traffic, which our rapporteur described, but also because it is essential as a base for 5G regarding connectivity, regarding rural areas but also regarding the opportunity to reach through buildings and make the services possible everywhere. And 5G will mean huge opportunities for us in healthcare, for the car industry, for traffic, for small cities, indeed for everything because it will be not only the internet of things but the internet of everything or anything. And we must be aware that other parts of the world want to be in the lead: China, the US and a lot of others. I want Europe to be in the lead. So let us do this as fast as possible and be as ambitious as possible regarding spectrum. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: question "blue card".- I apologize because it is still a bit late, but given the praise that my colleague has given to 5G and the desire that Europe indeed be a leader - which I can share with him- I just want to ask him a question: is it possible for Europe to be a leader when it does not currently master software and hardware?So today, can we be the leader of a technology when we do not master the industrial construction of this technology?

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: blue-card answer. – I think the answer is quite simple. If we do not have the best preconditions for 5G and the services, then we will not have the best opportunities. We have seen, as regards 3G and other parts of history, that we were able to take the lead, but we will never be able to take the lead if we are not looking globally, if we are protecting our borders and closing ourselves off to the world outside. Then we will not be in the lead because the thing is, if you are alone, you cannot lead. Being a leader means that you are global, and I want Europe to be a global leader.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, first of all I want to congratulate Patricia for the agreement that she has reached. Many times in this Chamber we have talked about the digital revolution, the internet of things, millions of devices connected to each other, the deployment of 5G. This decision that we know today is basic to make all this a reality, because, without sufficient spectrum, none of it is possible. This agreement is positive, and it is positive because it frees spectrum for mobile access, facilitating a new lane for a whole new generation of services. It is positive because it gives certainty in the sub-700 band to broadcasting services. And it is positive because, as this Parliament has repeatedly requested, compensation is provided, in particular for end users, for the costs of migration. In short, this is an agreement that puts Europe on the right track to achieve its connectivity objectives, which, as the rapporteur has said, is something very important, very important for our society, but very important for our economy.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam president. I appreciate the consensus reached in this Parliament to give flexibility to the transition from the 700 band until 2022 and guarantee, until 2030, the presence of terrestrial broadcasting in the sub-700, and to base any subsequent decision on this spectrum on social objectives , cultural and economic of general interest, with the participation of all interested parties. I believe that this way of proceeding should serve as a reference for the future of the digital market in Europe, including 5G and the new communications code. We must be able to regulate to ensure that the promotion of new digital uses does not deepen the digital divide between urban and rural areas or between generations. We must regulate so that strong public services are maintained in the field of broadcasting, as a guarantee of our own production and quality, and as a source of truthful information. We must regulate to fight against the concentration of the digital market in a few platforms that steal the works of creators and cultural workers and prevent them from a fair remuneration, substituting information and creation for sensationalism and advertising. And, for this, we must weave an alliance with workers and creators to jointly define the transition to the digital future. Beyond today's decision, we have a lot of work ahead of us. And I also take the opportunity to congratulate the speaker.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, Commissioner! The Internet of Things, the cloud and mobile communications services, the digitalization of industry - keyword Industry 4.0 -, e-government or G5 technology - they all have one thing in common: They need communication networks that are fast, that can transfer large amounts of data and that are dense populated as well as remote areas, i.e. rural areas. In addition to new technologies for data transmission and reception, the most important thing in the gigabit society is the extensive use of frequency ranges, in this case the frequency band 470–790 MHz. The aim of this report is to create an EU-wide uniform frequency allocation in this bandwidth, which enables companies and citizens alike to have a comprehensive wireless network connection at high speeds. We need fast internet, but it will be expensive. The German Federal Transport Minister recently calculated that the nationwide broadband expansion in Germany alone will cost around EUR 100 billion. Internet connections with a performance of 1000 megabits per second should be the digital measure of all things by 2025. At the EU level, people are less ambitious. All EU citizens should have access to broadband speeds of at least 30 megabits by 2020. What is important about this report: In order to achieve a harmonization of the frequency band, it is planned that the member states will adopt their own timetable for the reallocation of the 700 megahertz band by June 30 of next year. If one assumes that the mobile Internet will increase eightfold by 2020 compared to today, then the capacity expansion is a basic requirement for the gigabit society. The rapporteur is therefore to be thanked. I agree with Mr Hökmark's assessment that this report is particularly important with regard to the implementation of the 5G frequency because the 700 megahertz band is an essential requirement for this.

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: – Madam President, I would like to offer my congratulations to Madam Vice-President. Congratulations also to Patrizia and to all the shadow rapporteurs. It is a very good result, and also a very large majority in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE). It shows our strong support for the Commission proposal, even though we also introduced crucial amendments. We gave flexibility to Member States, up to two years, to postpone assignment of the relevant part of the spectrum, and we also made sure that broadcasting operators have investment certainty until the year 2030 using under-700 MHz frequency. To bridge the digital divide in Europe, to offer higher speed and higher quality broadband to consumers, and ultimately the 5G revolution – these are a huge step forward, but some issues before us are very important. We should not forget about that – the timing of auctions, licence duration, spectrum trading, greater EU coordination of spectrum assignments are all very important. They are all addressed in the telecom framework. I can assure you, dear colleagues, and also the representative of the European Commission, that in ITRE committee we will do everything to make sure that all our regulations will help our industry, our SMEs and, first of all, our citizens, so we are prepared for hard work. Mr Vice-President, dear colleagues, once again, thank you for the regulation.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Ms Toia, for reaching compromises so quickly in the interinstitutional negotiations on this 700 MHz band agreement. Spectrum policy is an area where better coordination and harmonisation of allocation schedules bring significant additional benefits for consumers, industries and societies in Europe. We have set the path towards 5G to regain leadership in digitalisation in Europe. Countries willing to deliver spectrum allocation quickly to meet the increased need for wireless broadband electronic communication are now able to do so, and we are also setting a deadline for when the last Member States should follow. I am happy that Parliament was even able to modernise this piece of legislation so that it does not limit spectrum allocation to downlink only. Both uplink and downlink are important for future two-way connectivity of the digital society in order to get from it everything that we need.  The next step on spectrum policy is being taken with the reform of our telecom framework. We have to deliver added value for our societies. We must boost digital economy innovations, well—being and jobs in Europe. To do that we need to ensure that spectrum policy facilitates competition in the markets. We need spectrum policy to push investment to the vital digital networks, and we need to allow innovative services to flexibly gain access to the spectrum and enter the market.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this text - which, moreover, I very much appreciate the rapporteur - has no real reason to exist, because the harmonization of the spectrum is already carried out by the International Telecommunication Union and bythe European Post and Telecommunications Conference, which do not depend on Brussels, but are intergovernmental organizations.The Commission therefore wants to once again renounce the powers of the States.The Commission's proposal is in fact a first step towards its European spectrum project, towards a single regulator and towards the allocation of frequencies at European level.However, the amendments tabled by my colleagues, the flexibility granted to States in the negotiated amendments, the deadlines for the implementation of applications, the reaffirmation of the rights of States, all this will lead us to abstain on the legislative resolution.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, even though it is now 10.30 p.m, I am enjoying this debate. First, and foremost, I would like to commend the rapporteur, Mrs Toia, and also my good friend and colleague who has just left, Gunnar Hökmark, who did an excellent job and reached what I believe to be a good and well-balanced agreement.  The key point here to remember is that a requirement for the fast roll-out of 5G is: do we want to be a leader, or a follower? Allocating this spectrum as soon as possible is vital if we want to ensure the steady roll-out of 5G. 5G is a development which brings significant benefits to European economies. We were too slow in deploying 4G and, as a result, we were left chasing our competitors. We need to secure enough spectrum for this roll-out  between faster download speeds, higher capacity, more broadband users and more reliable networks. This is crucial for businesses and citizens alike, and we need to ensure that they are at the forefront of the roll-out.  Coming from a rural constituency, I know only too well the problems with connectivity outside urban areas. Skibbereen is a town in county Cork, in my constituency. It is Ireland’s first rural digital hub, Ludgate, also known as Gigabit Town. As a result, Skibbereen is home to many innovative businesses and projects. It is an example of the possibilities when our rural areas are given access to strong connectivity, and I am extremely proud to see such great work happening in my constituency.  This frequency band is crucial for ensuring the provision of these broadband services in rural areas, to keep up with towns and cities and help to ensure that our rural population is not left behind in the digital age. From the perspective of Ireland, a country which prides itself on leadership in the digital start-up sphere, it is crucial that we set the infrastructural framework to attract companies to Europe, and this means rolling out 5G. We cannot be left behind in this regard, otherwise we are allowing jobs to go elsewhere at a time when we should be giving the signal that all of Europe is open for business.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: - Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate Toia on her success. The Internet and mobile communications services are developing at a very fast pace around the world, trends that must be followed, including at European level. In order to be able to build a digital single market, we also need new data transmission and reception technologies. That is why I support the European Commission's proposal to release the 700 MHz band. It is suitable for ensuring the provision of broadband services in rural areas, responding to the specific needs of the distribution of audiovisual media. Thus, we can guarantee the access of all citizens until 2020 to broadband internet at a speed of at least 30 Mb / s. Given that by 2020 mobile internet traffic will increase eight times compared to the current level, it is necessary to assess the possibility of having a uniform regulatory framework in the European Union. I therefore support the immediate preparation of a roadmap by each Member State. We must not have winners or losers from the technological revolution, so that, indeed, European citizens can benefit from the opportunities it offers.

name: Michał BONI
text: – Madam President, my congratulations to Ms Toia, the rapporteur, for the excellent work. This proposal needs to be put into the right context. It is not purely a matter of allocating spectrum. This is about ensuring that Europe has the potential to lead the expansion of 5G and to attract investments in this new economy. With the rapid expansion of 5G, which will need spectrum in the lower parts, such as the 700 MHz frequency band, Europe holds the potential for transforming into the world’s most dynamic market. 5G is crucial for the Internet of Things, virtual reality development – key for the new educational tools. It is basic for car-connected development and the paradigm shift in the healthcare area. The use of 700MHz frequencies has to be considered in the light of this rapid technological game-changer.  The broad implementation of 700 MHz is meant to be as coordinated and harmonised as possible, in order to pave the way for 5G. Timely and harmonised decisions are necessary. It is the obligation of all of us, and above all, of all Member States. Making available the 700 MHz band – starting with using Giga frequencies (from 1 to 26/28 in the first stage) – in a timely manner, is a cornerstone of delivering on European Digital Agenda targets, particularly to sparsely populated and remote areas in Europe. I am from Poland. There are some challenges related to cross-border interferences of radio signals from Ukraine, Belarus and Russia. Working on this portfolio, we wanted to have this scheme for justified reasons in view of potential delays in the implementation of the solution for 2022. We will do our best, but we can avoid these delays if we act together – the Polish authorities, with the support of the European institutions – during negotiations.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: Madam President, we are witnessing a digital revolution, induced by technological acceleration, in the capacity to capture, process and transmit data. This revolution is an opportunity to reconfigure the society in which we live, making it more focused on the realization of people, less unequal and more sustainable. That is why this revolution cannot be driven by technology - it is technology that has to be instrumental in relation to the European Society's vision of Gigabits that we choose to achieve. I welcome the draft legislative resolution under consideration and, in particular, the excellent work done by my colleague Patrícia Toia. Assuming the virtualities of the Commission's proposal, the agreement ensures improvements in the good allocation of spectrum resources in the European Union, allowing the development of a new generation of technologically leading and inclusive wireless broadband services. This is also the philosophy behind the WiFi4EU initiative, of which I am the rapporteur, and which aims precisely to provide European citizens with a good experience of accessing Gigabits to the European Society, regardless of their economic situation or geographical location. In summary, Madam President, the project under consideration is a very important step towards the realization of a digital union, which puts the European Union at the forefront of a revolution at the service of the people, the economy and the quality of life of Europeans .

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, congratulations to Patrizia Toia for her excellent work. Connectivity services are experiencing rapid development on a global level and require speed but also communication networks capable of carrying a lot of data and reaching the most remote areas. The availability of a broad radio spectrum, currently managed at national level with very different conditions between individual Member States, is one of the essential preconditions for the deployment of broadband services. With this proposal for a decision, the criteria for the allocation of frequencies will be standardized at European level, obliging Member States to make marketable rights to use spectrum for electronic communications services in the 700 MHz frequency band. the proposed measures, in addition to making the development of innovative devices and services cheaper, will allow Europe to accelerate towards the digital single market and towards the development of the 5G network and, therefore, to recover the gap with the leading countries in band large mobile.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, the 400 to 790 MHz band is now widely used for digital television broadcasts and wireless microphones. In Europe, there is a significant increase in demand for wireless broadband services, mainly due to the use of video content on mobile devices. Increasing mobile data traffic is putting pressure on the capacity of existing networks and the demand for additional radio spectrum. This proposal envisages the availability of more radio spectrum for broadband services in the 700 MHz band. At the same time, it aims to preserve the European audiovisual model, which offers free public service broadcasting and requires sustainable radio spectrum resources in the band below 700 MHz. However, the release of the 700 MHz band requires technological changes. Consumers will have to change home appliances, broadcasters will have to modify their infrastructure. There is therefore an additional cost and Member States have to bear the cost of travel expenses.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, we were recently able to abolish roaming surcharges. Everybody in the European Union will benefit from that, and everybody can understand the meaning of this decision. We were recently also able to allow portability of content to our citizens. Once again, everybody will benefit from that, and everybody can understand the meaning of this decision. Regarding the 700 MHz, the situation is a little more complicated. Not everyone is able to understand about 700 MHz. I would say that a majority of our citizens will switch off if somebody starts to talk about 700 MHz, but it is an extremely important issue. We can only dream about remote surgery or connected cars and 5G. Without clarity in 700 MHz it will never become reality in the European Union. But this is global competition. We know that South Korea has stated that it will start to use 5G at their Olympic Games in 2018. I took part in the G7 meeting in Japan, where the Japanese said very clearly that at their Olympic Games in 2020 they will start to use 5G. In Europe, Ericsson and Telia have stated that they will start to use major elements of 5G in 2018 in three cities: Stockholm, Tallinn and Helsinki. It is easy to think that it is possible to create new apps based on 5G or to build new cars based on 5G by just knowing theoretically how it will work. But we know the best solutions we will be able to get are if we are faced with real-life situations. So we are in a terrible hurry, and that is why we are setting ambitious aims, namely to cover all the urban areas and main transport paths with 5G networks by 2025. There is a secondary aim: in at least one major city in every EU Member State, they have to start to use 5G networks on a commercial basis by 2020. This is important for self-driving cars, absent and remote surgery, etc. This clarity in 700 MHz is a real pre-condition for being among the leaders of this global competition. I would like to cordially thank all Members of Parliament, but especially the rapporteur, Ms Toia, for this heavyweight decision. I am sure that, thanks to this decision, Europe will take a leading position in the meaning of 5G.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: rapporteur. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this has truly been a job in which each colleague has made his own contribution, has given his own ideas and is therefore the result of joint work. I want to say three very brief things: we all understood the importance of winning, as Europe, this challenge of 5G: therefore a rapid availability of these frequencies and a harmonized and effective assignment, because we know that this band with lower frequencies allows a capillarity of diffusion. However, we knew that, with the very slow release of the 800 MHz band, we had a lack of success with 4G, which slowed the diffusion of all networks that used 4G. The first goal was therefore to take a step forward. However, we could not forget the objective of satisfying the needs of broadcasters, which are also companies that give work, generate profits, so we needed to find a balance, a win-win strategy. We worked very well with the CULT commission, with my colleague Maullu who was its rapporteur, and we have found, I believe, a balanced solution that allows us to overcome this challenge but also to leave the whole issue on the field, which is of great interest to Europe. , creative and broadcasting companies. One last thing, which concerns my country a little: there was a lot of concern when we wanted to introduce the possibility of reasoned postponement to free frequencies until 2022. We said, however, that it is not due to the laziness of the States, that they fold their arms and do nothing! It is a question of understanding certain objective situations. It seems to me that it was a choice of trust but also a winning one: I speak for my country which seemed one of those that, due to historical and political conditions, had a certain delay. I know that many things have been set in motion: the coordination plans to address the issue of transnational interference, which are many and we, in Italy, are affected with France and Croatia.All this is going on and therefore maybe we will not use that delay and I hope that the other states do not either so that we will all be ready to do our job well, with realism and with seriousness.So I thank you, Mr. Vice President, also for all that we will still do together on the 5G level.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: - The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, Wednesday 15 March 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - Honorable Members! The report now on the agenda is not just a technical document, even if its title suggests. Ultra broadband internet and 5G internet connection, but the so-called "700 MHz band" can be a milestone for the development of the whole digital union. Currently, the 470-790 MHz frequency band is used for digital terrestrial television and various audio equipment such as wireless microphones. The so-called "800 MHz" frequency band (790-862 MHz) is used for broadband services, but this is no longer sufficient for the further development of these services. The basic condition for moving forward is the availability of sufficient radio spectrum. From 2020, the "700 MHz band" would also be available for broadband and 5G internet, thus contributing, inter alia, to improving the quality of digital and broadband services, full coverage of rural and less developed regions and ensuring social, social and digital cohesion. In the EU. Among the objectives, I would also like to highlight the conclusion of cross-border frequency coordination agreements, which would allow the future cross-border use of the frequency band without interference and, consequently, the phasing out of area-based restrictions on digital services. I believe that we must not stand in the way of digital development and, by adopting a report, we must create the right technical preconditions for it.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - The telecommunications market is undergoing enormous transformations. Technological advances have made available innovative solutions that have radically reshaped the world we know, creating a whole new competitive environment. We do not yet know exactly which technological innovations will have the greatest impact on our future, but if we do not act in time, we are guaranteed to lag behind in global competition. We need to look at this transformation not as a source of danger, but as an opportunity. If Europe is able to take the lead in the technological revolution, it can put its economy on a growth path that can put future generations in a competitive position to compete. Fifth-generation telecommunications technology can bring about fundamental changes in related services. Europe needs to become a market leader in the development and application of these technologies as competition in the telecommunications market intensifies. The release of the 700 MHz frequency band is the first major step in this direction. There may be differences of opinion on the restructuring schedule, but broadband wireless internet is in the interest of consumers. In this way, reducing the digital geographical gap, better coverage of areas and faster transmission speeds can become a reality.
